content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
I'd love to recommend this game I really would...It has all the hallmarks of a great game, but there's just one snag and unfortunately that one snag is the size of a continent:This game is far too glitchy to recommend (at this time).It honestly feels like I'm playing a beta test and not even a late beta at times.I don't think I've come across an area in the game that, at some point, doesn't glitch, be it the busted AI, the ships that change class when you upgrade them or the research that decides "Nah, y'alright" when you've finished an area of research but to name a few examples..EDIT - Best glitch yet: I invaded a planet with my troops, when it came to the land battle for the planet I was put in charge of the defensive force whilst the AI attacked for control of the planet with my troops...At some point I'll make a list for the developers and send it over, but it's going to be a long list and it's going to be a while before I send it..."Why am I moaning about things rather than helping fix them?" you may ask.Simple. I paid for the game, a whole game, not a beta test or a DLC, the whole game. Had I bought a beta then I wouldn't be writing this, heck, I'd be praising it. But I didn't, so I can't.There's been an absolute shedload of patches and updates since the game came out little over a month ago, so I'm kinda glad I didn't buy it at release as I would have been majorly angry / disappointed. I'm also quite surprised that some pretty major issues haven't been addressed at this time.Like I say, I'll get around to addressing my woes to the devs at some point, but as I'm a little busy with work and suchlike at the moment I don't see why I'll effectively be doing a job that should have been done properly and by someone else in the first place.I play games for enjoyment and to de-stress and unwind, not get angry and be turned into a unpaid beta-tester.This will probably be a great game at some point and when that happens I'll change my review accordingly, but for now I'd recommend waiting until a few more patches have come out.And by a few I mean a lot.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												I am writing this review to help guide others, like me, who are seeing the "Mixed" rating, and wondering whether to take the plunge.  I read the reviews, and saw that the developer was busy fixing the many bugs, and decided to take the chance that the game would still be buggy.  A little background first:I love space games like Master of Orion 2.  I bought this game when it was 66% off, and right after patch 1.2 went live.  With that said, here are my thoughts:Pros:-This game is basically Master of Orion 2.1.  To say that this game is inspired by MoO2 would be the understatement of the century.  The gameplay is copied, the tech tree is copied, and even the race customization options are copied directly from MoO2.  This is not a bad thing, but it was surprising.  I really love MoO2, but this game is only slightly different and expanded compared to MoO2. -The art is pretty good.  Better than MoO2.Cons:-Buggy as hell.  And not in the weird technical-glitch kind of way.  Simple stuff that should have been caught by the bug-checkers.  Your planets will be invaded, but you won't have any troops, so there is no way to start the battle.  You must exit and load an auto-save.  Enemy ships fly off the edge of the screen in space combat mode.  You must retreat (lose) the battle.  You conquer an enemy civilization but somehow the planet doesn't get captured.  It just sits there, uncolonizable and unconquerable.-Interface is really finicky.  When zoomed way out, there's like a 2x2 pixel range on which you have to click to select a planet.  Lots of other little stuff like that that makes the experience less than seamless.Conclusions: DO NOT BUY.  Wait for the bugs to be fixed.  This game is at Alpha level at best.  The good news is that the developer is actively fixing bugs.  The bad news is that they are also working on an expansion.  This is going to seriously detract from the bug-fixing, and will probably introduce a bunch of new bugs too.  Not a great sign.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												I've played Masters of Orion 2 (One as well, but 2 a LOT more) it's, in my humble opinion, the best 4X game ever. After that, I've played many, many more: Galactic Civ, Alpha Centauri (Rants about Civ ripoff) Sins of a Solar Empire, Endless Legend, etc, etc ,etc. None gave me such a new or enhanced experience as MOO2. Then: Stardrive. WOHAAAA! Great! it's like MOO2, but with everything better: Cooler ship design, better tech thingies, more exploration, tactical combat, flavorful events. Terriffic!The downside, and for me the number one reason to never play again (Please, make a patch, expansion, DLC, ANYTHING): there is only one way to win: total conquest. So after hours of playing I have to destroy my friends. No economic, diplomatic, cultural, 'who has the most bunnies' or anoher origional victory at all. So I own 60% of the planets, the biggest fleet and most technical advancements (Ok, I was playing 'normal', sue me) and have to spend hours conquering planets. No fun at all.One small thing when you're make a patch: Please give an end-of-turn warning when a planet is doing nothing or convert the excess labor in coins or anything. It's frustrating to discover after 5-6 turns you forgot to give one planet new construction orders.When the victory thingie is solved, it will be a A+ recommendation from me!With kind regards,Sebastiaan.

												This game shows a lot of promise but its certainly not finished, theres no way to ally with other races simply peace, its severly flawed with many bugs practically breaking your game.Once i had a planet switch races, one turn it was mine the next with no battle no war and no warning one of my worlds simply joined a different faction, I regulary in ground battles find myself controlling the other side, or unable to move troops with no reason why, i played the game on normal and got through to the end it was challenging but i won, i thought id play another game on easy quickly and found it harder to play than normal. Races defined as evil will simply ask for anything and if you decline at any point war will follow within a few turns, occassionally war will follow the next turn regardless of how much they like you.this game needs a lot of work to be playable and then a lot added to it to be enjoyable, true ship customization is good but finding out which tech to get to get the right things for your ship is difficult, Overall wait a long time and dont spend anywhere near £20 for it, i wish i could return it

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												SD2 is a decent game but it doesn't really add anything to the 4x genre and feels restrictive due to the small maps ( 100 system maximum ).  This means that you will meet other races pretty quickly and all of a sudden are rushing production as the AI appears to be able to pull fleets out of it's hat at will.  This turns what should be a strategic game into a "I can field more ships than you" slugfest.  The various ( we want to eat your granny ) type races ensure that diplomacy is no more than an afterthought and certainly not a means to an end as they will attack you anyway.I decided not to recommend this game as there are better 4x titles out there.  For those that want strategic depth without worrying too much about graphics there is distant worlds.  For those that want the 3D combat coupled with decent strategy there is Sots or Sots 2.  For those that want an RTS feel there is Sins of a Solar Empire or Star ruler 2 and for those that want a more traditional 4x then Galciv 3 is just around the corner.  SD2 tries hard but it doesn't excell at anything and in what is becoming an ever more packed marketplace it is doomed to fall by the wayside.  That is not to say that it can never rise to the top.  With more development, larger maps, much better diplomatic systems and better strategy overall it could be a winner.  At the moment though, close but no cigar.With Sector Zero DLC:I didn't think it possible that this game could be any less desirable than it is already but I was wrong.  Sector Zero takes what was already there ( and flawed ) and adds a liberal dose of absolute boredom while not repairing or addressing any of the previous ♥♥♥♥ed up systems.  Diplomacy is still♥♥♥♥♥♥ The Ai can still create fleets out of nothing etc. etc.  To the developer I can simply say:You obviously have talent.  You obviously have some good ideas and a fertile imagination but ffs bring a few more people in so that you can bounce some of those ideas off them and gain different perspectives.  Maybe then you will end up with a product worth playing instead of this pile od detritus.

Posted: August 25, 2016
												Personaly I loved this game before the DLC's came out for it. First reason I do not recommend this game is mainly due to the AI. People who have played this game will understand that the AI has practicaly no rules to even follow while the player really has his/her hands tied in alot of restraints, such as ship fuel applying to the player and not the AI as well as AI not seeming to need any economic structure to support massive fleets. Secondly I feel that the game is just a money raker. The developer only cares about getting money rather than worrying about if the game is even good or not, basically, I feel he doesn't care about his own game.When your a game developer I would imagine that you would try anything to make your game fun and enjoyable for players which this guy doesn't seem to care about at all. This game has potential to be insanly good, but the developer is putting more time into DLC's rather than trying to fix the base game.Its like he breaks the game on purpose just to try to get you to buy the DLC's which don't even fix all the problems.Now I'm no game developer, I don't even no the first thing about game developing, but people have been complaining about some the issues, such as the AI, for quite a while now. The way I process this is if people were complaining about the issues for so long, why weren't they fixed earlier when the game was still starting out?I do not recommend this game to anyone. I truly wish this game had a developer who would put time into the base game to make an amazing game rather than "fixing" SOME of the issues in a DLC. Waisted potential is what this game is.

												Nice Open Beta so far... wait what?First of all i like the Game, and i will love it when its finally finished.But the more time i spend with it, the more unfinished and/or buggy content im facing.Maybe im wrong, but i expect at least all the Key Features working properly if i Buy a Game that seems to be "Complete"For Example: Land Battles is nothing more than a PlaceholderAI agression on small Maps - everyone is declaring war on you. Sometimes without any reason they travel across the whole Galaxy instead of fighting thier neighbours first.AI agression on large Maps - what Agression?? Once reached late game there is no war anymore unless you dont declare or provokate it.Localisation is about 75% finished, many Texts are just Google translated (at least keep it english, if there was no time to finish it...)Even the Shipdesigner is not done 100%, i mean why the hell are there still Ships with unsymetrical design Errors.That Game has a huge potential, very nice Ideas in every part of the Game.Its just not finished, and as a player i feel that in every Round playing.Would that game be marked as Early Acsess... fine, i know what i have to expect then.But not that way.After screwing SD1, i really hoped the Devs took thier time for SD2 and learned from thier Mistakes.Now i bought the second unfinished Game from Zero and can only hope it will be done one Day.I cant recommend it in its actual Build, everyone whos interested in that Game should wait a couple of Months an Check the Progress, before spend Money on it.EDIT:So 6 Months passed, a few Updates are released, and a DLC is anounced.I thought its about time to check out the progress of the Game and maybe i can find some things fixed and/or finished.And believe it or not, its worse than before -.-There is still not a Single part of the Game 100% done.On Top of that there are new Bugs wich makes it impossible to win a Space fight, a Key feature of the game, just because the enemy ships fly out of the screen and are never seen again.Fun Fact: If you fly your own ships to the edge of the screen, they disapear aswell xDAll that Updates are just small things that really shouldnt be at top Priority, and its so fun to read when the Developer says he cant reproduce all those gamebreaking Bugs everyone has, on his Side...And now a DLC? Comon are you kidding me?Can you pls sell your Licence to someone who actually knows what hes doing? Or hire Someone who does, please!DONT BUY THAT GAMEIts off for 75% or 50% for reasons.

												The basic format for this game is superb.  I can see it becoming very adictive.  The management and expansion of colonies is interesting without being complicated, and the ship designing is enjoyable, if time-consuming.HOWEVER, this game is NOT ready for release, and definitely not at this price.  It has extremely frustrating bugs that need to be worked out.  For example (and this is only one of many), there are sections where you have no choice but to forfeit a battle, even if you are winning, because an immovable message panel obscures the part of the screen that you need to see.I am going to set it aside until I see a patch available to make it more functional.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Star Drive 2 takes allot of what made the original star drive fun. Improves on it, then changes the game into more of  a traditional 4X experience, with turn based game play.The Good: Ship design - This is very deep with a level of subtlety and customization which no other game seems to have, at least in terms of whats on your ships and how they behave in combat.Personallity - The races all have distinct ship models and very distinct personallities. There is a bit of cheesy humour in the game and allot of pop culture referencing which is worth a laugh. *spoiler* I got to weld guns to a t-rex's head and then use it to eat people!!!*AI - After about 8 hours I have come to appreciate the difficulty of the AI, they wait till your fleets are out of position and attack core worlds, will try and undermine you diplomatically and have varied personallities ranging from homicidal to just the nicest little plant people ever. They also seem to adapt to your ship building strategies and it seems very difficult to cheese the AI in this game.Empire Management - This is HARD and requires allot of thought. Managing some worlds to be food producing worlds and others to be ship producers or science worlds is an interesting balance and sometimes having more population on your homeworld is not the best choice. This means that a variety of adaptive stratagies are required, absed on your surroundings. This adds allot of replayabillity as games can vary wildly.Fleet Combat - very pretty, plenty of strategy and a bit of point and click. Not one of those games where i want to autoresolve every battle.The BadGround combat - Can still be fun but is not quite up to the standard or polish that the rest of the game seems to have. There is however a suprising degree of strategy in what looks at first to be a very simple minigame. Especially when you take the variability of some of the races into account. I freaked out when i realized the squid men could squirt ink into peoples eyes......Some balance on certain weapons - Overall ship modules are well balanced with few weapons ever truly becoming obsolete which is AWESOME. However there are some modules (Im looking at you plasma cannons) which could really use a buff.The Ugly:Haters - There are ALLOT of haters after some of the issues with SD1. Personally I can see where they are coming from but i easily got my 30 bucks worth outa the game. BUT i swear i am sick to death of the illiterate streams of untruthfull vitriol that get posted about this series. This is the onlly reason i wrote this review. I am a busy person, but i got so sick of all the polarized BS i felt i had to write something.To Sum-up: Stardrive 2 is a difficult game with a steep learining curve that has deep and rewarding systems. Its not for the feebleminded. Some of the production values in certain areas of the game are a little low but otherwise it feels like a AAA game. I would heartily reccomend this game to any lover of 4x or grand strategy games and to anyone as obsessive as i am about building the deadliest ship ever.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												I don't think I'm even going to bother to write a "helpful" review here.Instead, here's a little story.Once upon a time, there was a very nice EA game called Stardrive. It promised to be so many good things to so many people, and to be a spiritual successor to MoO2, one of the greatest 4x games of it's time. Our young hero read many reviews that said "THIS IS AWESOME, IT HAS SO MUCH POTENTIAL!" and, not realizing at the time that "potential" almost always translates into "don't buy this♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; in non-review english, he decided to buy it.Many hours passed, and because our hero likes starting 4x games more than finishing them, as well as designing ships, some great fun was indeed had. Soon though, cracks began to appear in the happy facade of his new game - memory overrun bugs would kill games part way through, unfinished tech trees robbed our young friend of satisfaction, and AI issues began to make things feel dull and drab."Why have I spent so much time playing this?" he lamented, "If only I'd realized earlier that there is literally no lategame here, instead of starting a thousand different games and only playing the first bit?"He had to suppress a sob. "And why did it take me so long to realize that there's only one tactic you really need to use in this game? I'm supposed to be good at games, how could I have been fooled by the shiney ship design, when all I had to do all along was jam my ships full of cheap, first level missiles in order to ruin all?"In the end, he was crushed. Where was this potential the other reviews had told him about? Where were  these promised features that never materialized?Distraught, he turned to the forums. "Hi guys, I just noticed a few things about this game, and had a few questions." He detailed his experience, and his input, and made a few simple queries such as "How do I make my fighters actually land back on my ships?"The response that await our hero was unexpected. No sooner had he posted than a wave of drama, anger, and malcontent rushed forward, flowing out of the screen of his ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop, and engulfing him. The force was so great that it nearly capsized his desk, and caused him to be lost in the swirling vortex of it's black waters. "SUCKER, THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME IS GARBAGE AND BROKEN AND THE DEV IS A MASSIVE ♥♥♥♥♥♥", and "ABANDONWARE, NOOB, DON'T BUY IT", and "STFU YOU GUYS THIS IS THE BEST THING EVER AND ZERO IS MY BUDDY AND YOU'RE ALL♥♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;, and "BUT THERE'S ONLY ONE DEV, SO IT'S OK THAT MOST OF THIS SUCKS", and finally, "Hello, I'm a moderator. The dev has essentially done all he can with this engine, and has dropped development in favour of StarDrive 2, which will be everything that was promised and more. Check it out, you'll get 33% off since you bought this game! Also, check out my mod which fixes some of the problems with the game you already own!"Somehow, he managed to swim free from the maelstrom, and hit the vitriol release valves built into his computer room. As the drama-fluids slowly drained away around him, he vowed to write a negative review, forget about the experience, and never be involved with sequels or games with "potential" in general ever again.Then, years later, he fatefully stumbled across StarDrive 2 in the Steam store. I must resist the urge. Resist the shiny. Resist the 33% off. Our hero fought the good fight for a time, but all the positive reviews speaking of "potential" (no, you fool! you say) and improvements over the last attempt by the dev began to haunt his every waking moment, invading his thoughts at work, while playing MoO2, and eventually, even began to snake into his dreams.One night, awakening in a cold sweat from dreams of turn based glory, galactic conquest, ship design, and fighters that could actually land rather than being doomed to spend eternity floating through the cold vacuum after launching, he fell to the dark whispering, and clicked BUY.The next morning, he realized what he had done, and was filled with sorrow. "My god! What have I done? Even with 33% off, this game is 66% overpriced for what it will likely contain." In shame, he did not play the game for quite some time, during which drama raged, DLCs were released, and countless empires could have risen and fallen. I must resist! the despaired internally, I cannot allow myself to be drawn to gaze into the abyss of abandoned "potential" yet again, for when you gaze into it, it gazes back into you.But one day, the urge was too strong. "What's the worst that could happen? Besides, I already bought it."Our hero, despite having grown wise with the years, foolishly decided to try the game."Gee, this isn't too bad. The new turn system is ok, and the ship design is slightly less ♥♥♥♥ed." While not "complete yet", the game was indeed a bit of improvement over the first iteration, and once the promised features of the first game and the new promised features of the second, combined with some of the new DLC, were all in place, it could truely be great. Several hours were spent playing, and our hero slept easy. For some time afterwards, the game was forgotten, buried deep in the far recesses of the Great Steam Library, under an opaque pile of other games that fit the tag "space" or started with "s". While on a grand re-organization, our hero stumbled on it yet again."Hm, I only have 9 or 10 hours on this, and there's lots of easy looking achievements to get. I don't remember it being all that bad, really." And so, he began to play again. "This seems to be loading slower than normal. And appears to have more bugs than I recall. And wait... this is all hex based. Did the developer do me a solid as a former customer, and give me the DLC for free?"Perplexed, he turned to the forums, and it was immediately evident that something terrible had happened to the denizens within. The place was nearly empty, the remnants of spam and flame wars splattered on the once stunning marble pillars being the only indicator of what may have happened. Through judicious exploration using his trusty torch and noble search feature, most of his questions were answered. There were indeed bugs, and some issues, and the DLC had indeed been given out for free, though apparently by accident. One question remained, and so he shouted out in the dark to anyone who may still have lingered to hear: "Hi everyone. Been playing this again, it's pretty ok. I noticed that I seem to have gotten the DLC for free, which in my understanding is a bug. I was wondering if I now just *have* this, or if it's going to be patched out. Is there much point in me starting a new game right now?"The question echoed around the empty halls of the Forum for some time, before a quiet answer was given. "Hello, I'm a moderator. The dev has essentially done all he can with this engine, and has dropped development in favour of...."The last thing our hero remembered before his vision turned to darkness and his torch sputtered out was a howl, full of fury and pain."ZEROOOOOO!!"------Ok, so I took a little artistic liscence on the last bit there. No one ever answered my question, presumably because the forums are just as abandoned as the game. Nor was there an agonized howl cursing the dev - I missed all the drama this time around.I've hit a word limit, so please see the comments for some more serious thoughts.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Brutal. Absolutely brutal under the default settings. I assume that the AI can meticulously manage all of the aspects for proper execution because they almost instantly out pace me in construction, colonization, and research on the order of 5 or 10 to one in every aspect all at once. Diplomacy inevitably fails as the AI resources are always valued at 10:1 for me as far as I've seen. I guess that's the take away; Ten-to-One and I'm truely terrible at this game after 15 hours invested that I won't get back.Revision: Even with a vast number of the setting stacked in my favor (no pirates, running cybernetic and setting the galaxy for low organics and high resources, advanced research and production, number of opponets down to two, etc.) the AI is still horribly overboard. I was able to make contact and with an equal number of systems found myself overwhelmed with ships both more advanced, more numerous... faster, stronger, better, and more of them (again on the 5:1 ratio). Pro: It's pretty.Con: The game.So if you enjoy a "challenge" and wrestling a 50 year old oak tree isn't frustrating enough, spend money here. I'm going to see if I can't get a refund.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												When I bought this game I was initially very impressed because of some superficial resemblances in the research tree to the classic Master of Orion 2 and thought the developer was inspired by and trying to make a worthy successor to that game.Now my view on the developer's intent is somewhat more cynical.After playing the game for a while it seemd to me that much of the research tree is not well thought out and balanced but just thrown together willy-nilly with a superficial resemblance to the original MOO2.Much of Stardrive2 strikes me this way: hastily thrown together design decisions, numbers arbitrarily plucked out of thin air and various pieces of code cobbled together with little thought of balance and overall design.Much about the game design is astonishingly poorly thought out, such as the massive imbalance of ship design layouts between races and the huge investment in time and preparation to perform even simple espionage missions(I could conquer the entire civilization militarily in less time) as well as the incredibly overpowered Mass Driver weapon.And let's not mention the horribly repetitive and childish ground combat.I have put a lot of hours into this game; aspects of it are quite fun for a while.I stuck with it as I was finding ship design interesting, even as I was hoping that the developer would address some of the game's many design flaws. However, it became apparent that the developer had little interest in doing any more than fixing some of the glaring bugs and has more or less abandoned the game's development.Much leaves me wondering if the author ever actually sat down and played the game.Uninstalled.

number of helpful: 155 of 212 people (73%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												I have played a lot of 4x games(Master of Orion, Master of Orion 2, Ascendency, Master of Magic, Fantasy Empires, The Civilization Games, Heroes of Might and Magic 1-5, Galactic Civilizations, Imperium Galactica II, and probably a bunch more that I don't remember right now), and the reviews for this one seem a bit more enthusiastic rather than accurate.It borrows heavily from other games but to the point where it feels derivative of them rather than being a synthesis of them.  Moreover it is so blatant about it that it feels like it is flirting with the breaking the fourth wall not something I am a huge fan of.The game has a lot of potential in the ship design and strategic aspect of space and ground combat and the level of depth that it allows you to manipulate your empire.I will say that it was better than MOO III in general fun and striking a balance between allowing depth and getting carried away with it.My big gripes about the game are as follows.Technological advance doesn't yield significant upgrades until you get very very far along in the trees.  I almost always had better luck researching a few basic (tier one or two technologies), the pumping everything into producion ships and troops and conquering the galaxy without ever doing more than cursory reasearch.The AI literally cheats on basic settings, I have tested rich homeworlds on small maps with optimized industrial output and the AI will invariably massively outcolonize me and outproduce me (in terms of fleet and fleet size) very quickly in the early game.  You can still win by being clever or cheesy in your builds, but the fact that it literally plays by a different set of rules on default settings really really bothers me.The technologies are poorly balanced to create a stable empire.  The game forces you specialize each of your planets because of prohibitive maintanence costs (making one planet that has all upgrades and buildings your empire is capable of will put a big dent in your wallet).  Basically I find myself skipping almost all of my unlocked buildings on most colonies just because of what it costs to maintain them.  The way various technolgies interact and overlap with each other just makes a lot of them feel useless or redundant or only of use on a very small proportion of your colonies.I do think the game has a whole lot of potential and with some patches or balance changes could be more fun.  Essentially my complaint it that it forces you to play in one of a few very specific ways if you want to avoid getting wiping out quickly on default difficulty.  It felt more like how well can I implement this strategy which I know will be the only viable one for this map/race selection rather than what type of empire would I like to build this time. It feels like the game has mechanics for amazing strategies and fun but makes it impossible for you to implement them before you have already taken control of the map. Bottom Line I just didn't have fun playing it.

												First StarDrive was abandoned with the Dev unable or unwilling to fulfill the original promises for said game.  Gave him the benefit of the doubt despite SD1 being a huge mess.  Bought SD2 to find it is still a mess and hoped the Dev would at least patch it. content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Edit: The game has improved considerably since the review that follows.  I still don't recommened it but not nearly so definitely.-----------------------------------------------------Pros: 1) Pretty RT space battles2) Very much a MOO2 feel for the nostalgic old farts like me3) Turn based empire management4) More relatable and presentable alien races than one usually sees5) The UI is solid, except for missing production6) Graphics are sleek7) Runs well, no glitches I could seeCons:1) Diplomacy is broken by the usual fickleness of 4X games. This exacerbates2) The pain when large and powerful fleet of enemy ships (who were all confetti and chocolates a few turns ago) that rock up once your economy is almost functional to smash you to bits, which is particularly onerous when you are playing on3) Easy mode.  Not.  Nope.  4) Ugly and moderately difficult ground battle in an ultra-simplified Xcom style5) Most of all though falling for this twice.  Twice.  It's one thing to make a bad choice.  We all do that from time to time. It's another to chew on the fishhook a second time.  I was that stupid fishy.6) I researched an issue with my planet in a tidal lock.  It killed the planet.7) The sounds are a bit sparse and the GNN (news that pops up) is a shock in comparison to regular gameplay8) The AI can reach me at the other side of the galaxy when I can't even reach the next cluster properly.The game is fun at first.  As those first few turns burn away while presumably the AI builds those battleships you have a sense this game might be a good one, or at least ok.  But no.I don't actually care if the AI cheats or not.  I don't care if my gameplay skills are sucky or brilliant.  I care that it simply isn't fun and that's the core of the not recommend for me.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
Updated to consolidate thoughts after all the time played so farIf you are interested in a military 4X game with a heavy focus on extermination then Stardrive 2 is recommended.  However, if you want to play a more peaceful or diplomatic game then I would not recommend it as it’s really not possible to play that way at the moment.  The GoodThere are various early game opponents and some events with nods to sci-fi fans.  The AI is strong early game and I had to reload during my first game a few times to improve my strategy before winning on Normal difficulty.  The technology tree really does feel like Master of Orion 2 and I enjoyed mulling over the options.  The Battle Arena has been good fun to test designs and weapons and the combat is generally a highlight.I've encountered no major bugs and while there were some minor bugs, there was nothing gamebreaking.  In some ways it is an improved game over Stardrive 1 but there is plenty of room for improvement.  The BadThe technologies and weapons need to be better balanced.  Once you've tested them in the Battle Arena it becomes apparent some are worthless.The late game is really tedious.  Colony governors are needed particularly for the mid to late game as it becomes micro intensive.  There are no defaults for troop loadouts so you have to do every one manually.  Late game AI ship designs are very weak so the battles become trivial and nowhere near as much fun as the early game.The ground combat is weak.  Automatic resolution comes at a high price as it leads to excessive losses compared to manual combat even when you have a massive advantage, so it essentially forces the lame ground combat or bombardment to avoid it.The AI’s are far too aggressive in responding to expansion.  The AI's are very similar and it's difficult to avoid anything other than Total War.  The tolerance mechanic used in diplomacy is good but needs to be increased as currently diplomacy is a bit of a side show.  Brutal difficulty is not hard enough once you get familiar.  In fact once you learn the mechanics this is the easiest 4X game I can remember.The LowdownI had a lot of fun with the early game and Battle Arena.  As a result of the time I've played the game, I'll stick with a recommend, but without more serious improvements I don't see myself wanting to load the game up again (and I tend to play genuinely good 4X games much longer than this).

number of helpful: 167 of 234 people (71%) found this review helpful65 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												I made a race of photosynthetic treehugging cybernetic (trans)humans, killed space eels, found an eerie asteroid, experimented on my own citizens to create a zombie plague from said asteroid, lost Earth to a space wolves sneak attack through a wormhole while my main fleet was capturing my robotic enemy's homeworld. Then I turned the space wolves core systems into a zombie infested plague quarantine zone and retook Earth with space eel-cannon-armed-battleships produced by my new robot servants. After that the samurai space bears started a border war with me and things got interesting.10/10 would terrorize the galaxy again with zombie plague fleet mounting space-eel-cannons.Seriously though, this is a good game. Great? No. Good? Yes. Bugs? Yes, but they are consistently being stomped and progress is happening quickly.A little bit about me, I have played probably every major space 4X game made. MoO1-3, Space Empires 2-5, Galactic Civilizations 1-2, Sword of the Stars 1-2, Sins of a Solar Empire, Imperium Galactica 2, Endless Space, Distant Worlds, and many many more. I also was a Beta Tester for a couple of the Distant Worlds expansions and you can see my name in the credits. So you could say that I have been around the space 4X block, and I really enjoy this game, warts and all. Let me break it down a little. Keep in mind the next few things throughout my review:A - this game is made by one developer (goes by the handle "Zero"), and he contracts out art, music, and other assets. So very indie. B - this game is only $20+ at time of review, and as an owner of StarDrive1 I got a discount (so no ♥♥♥♥♥ing about having to pay for a new game if you bought SD1, and yes this game is a huge leap forward and worth the price). What's my point? This game is arguably as interesting as Civ Beyond Earth, and a fraction of the price, so lots of value for the money.C - I am comparing this game to other space 4X games in each category, not other genres.D - I have read some reviews where players claim that the AI is cheating, I think they just didn't RTFM and don't realize that there are mechanics like TAXATION that can net players and AI lots of cash to supports massive fleets and cash negative planets with.Graphics 9/10 - This isn't Halo4, but man this game LOOKS GOOD for a space 4X! Great colors and effects, and the ships and artwork are clean and stylish. Explosions and weapon effects are slick. IMHO best looking space 4X in a while. The only weak point is the ground combat doesn't look very good. Would have preferred the ground combat from MoO2, even now the most epic looking space 4X ground combat.Sound 8/10 - This game has an epic sound track that I didn't tire of easily. Weapon effects like different thuds as mass drivers hit armor or shields brings the combat to life. Quite adequate.Diplomatic AI 7/10 - This game has a great feature where there is a threshold on how many deals you can make with another faction that keeps you from spamming tech trades or going from being complete strangers in to becoming instant besties like in the Master of Orion series and most 4X games. The main drawback here is that the other empires just don't feel as alive as they could, but to be honest this is a huge problem with most 4X games. The main one that does it better is GalCiv2, man that AI was dastardly! I will note that as of yesterday (4/24/15) Zero released a patch that works on my of the Diplo AI's issues so this is definitely something that will get better with time.Strategic Fleet AI 8/10 - Your opponents don't quite feel as alive as they could, but man are they AGGRESSIVE, and I am not just talking about declaring war. This is the first space 4X in a long time where the AI contantly pounces on my undefended systems (and INVADES the planets successfully) and aggressively engages my fleets. Enemy fleets could coordinate a little better, and upgrade their ships more often, but overall the Strategic Fleet AI is solid. Ship Customization 9/10 - Dude this game is seriously cool, like Gratuitous Space Battles mixed with Master of Orion. Love the ship customization, the only drawback here is that SOMETIMES the AI doesnt pick great ships to build. The other minor gripe is that not every race's ships are created equally, some races have more spaces on their ships for components, etc.Map 9/10 - Two of the four "X"s are Explore and Exploit, well this game has fun mechanics that really support this. Meaningful wormholes with interesting placement, space monsters, pirates (human themed space monsters), Orion... I mean Master raiders are there and there are rewards to be gained once they are defeated. Also, planets can have specials like having deep caves, dangerous fauna, strategic resources that give your empire a boost, etc. In addition there are minor races that you can trade with, hire mercs from, or attack and subjugate.Ground Combat 6/10 - This feature just isn't there yet. It has the potential to be very advance wars or XCOM, but instead it is just kinda underdeveloped and a bit of a slog. I would suggest Auto-Battling until this is fixed in a patch or in a Mod, which is sure to happen and would be pretty easy to flesh out.Tech Tree 9/10 - This is very closely based on the Master of Orion model, including the core concept that you can only research one of three techs at each level of research and can only trade or steal for the ones that you didn't research. This is assuming that someone researched a tech, and often one tech isn't researched and so you can have a game where some techs aren't available. There are a few nice features that earn this high score. One, you can often unlock secret research projects by doing things like killing a space monster and dragging it's corpse in for research. Two, each race has hidden techs specific to it.  Three, at the end of each tech tree are a choice of two advances that you can take over and over again that give you meaningful benefits like increased ship speed, weapon damage, diplomacy boosts, shield strength, etc. There are also references to one of my favorite scifi book series "Old Man's War", so kudos to the dev.End Game 8/10 - Currently there is no allied victory condition, but Zero posted as of the latest patch that he will be adding that in. No victory animation or movie (like the slick one in Master of Orion 2), or Civ style map replay (which would be really cool to relive the adventure), nor a power graph screen, but it does rank you versus fictional SciFi chracters (I was ranked Picard); funny I dont recall seeing Kirk or Blackjack Geary listed, what a shame.Modding Support 8/10 - As of right now the game has Steam Workshop but it isn't listed like normal, you have to navigate to the Workshop tab and search plug-ins to see them. Alternatively you can head over to the game's forums on the dev's website. StarDrive1 benefitted heavily from player made content and I suspect that this game will too. Unfortunately at time of review there is no integrated mod loading menu like in SD1, not sure of dev plans but I hope this is added sooner than later and that the Steam Workshop works correctly soon.Stability and Bugs 8/10 - Small bugs, but no crashes, and not too surprising considering that the game is so indie but looks and feels so high budget. Some people report framerate issues, but I have experienced none. I have an i7 processor, 16 gigs of RAM, Nvidia card. Make sure to keep your drivers up to date!There is more here than I have listed, like a really in-depth medal and experience system where your ships can level up and earn medals through various combat exploits, which give them relevant bonuses (ie: Purple Heart, if your ship survives after being reduced to 35% health, whenever that happens in the future it takes 10% less damage). There are fun missions, and funny alien empire dialogues, overall this game is really great for around $20 at time of release.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Up until today, I could deal with all the minor bugs I encountered. Some weird graphical glitches, screen lay-out that sticks around when you switch to a different screen, ship modules that seem to float around on their own in space ... all of that I can either ignore or "fix" ingame.No big deal. I love the basic game, having fun playing it.Today I surrendered to the never ending barrage of bugs and threw in the towel. I leave it up to you to decided if I'm overreacting or not:- This campaign is going better than everything before. I understand better what is needed to survive this galactic battlefield! Not waiting to be attacked, I went agressive ASAP and managed to defeat the main fleet of those damned psychic slavers. Blockaded their homeplanet and invaded their second planet. First invasion of their homeplanet failed. No worries. Second wave of two full barracks is on the way.- Bug 1 enters the batlefield. I can't invade the homeplanet ...- Everytime I try, the game freezes during loading the combatscreen. Can only get out by ending the game by using taskmaster. After trying a few different infantry set-ups (maybe just 1 item is bugged?) with no succes, I stop trying. Having to get out of the game with taskmaster, starting again and reloading the campaign gets annoying after 10 times or so.- I quickly build a fleet of Corvettes with Nuclear Bombs and kill all defending troops. No luck, still can't invide. I then kill all the population. Planet is now a nuclear wasteland instead of a very productive production facility. I colonize it anyway, no bug is going to stop me from domination!- Struggle with a few of the usual minor bugs. Also a new one: apparently my hired special characters don't like flying through purple clouds en route to their assigned systems. They're stuck ... they also refuse to fly back and take a detour. I decide to leave them, maybe they'll decide to get unstuck after a while.- Discovered what hides in the pink wormhole ... hint: it's big and it hurts.- Having a lot of new shiny tech, I decide to do a big fleetwide upgrade. Bug 2 arrives. My planets refuse to build anything. What??? I can select the build, I can even pay the price so it's done in 1 turn, but it will always stay just 1 turn away from completing ... no matter how much turns I wait.- Tried different combinations of ships and modules. Only thing my planets like is building the original explorer ships it seems. Try to scrap some fleets, still no luck.- Bug 3 moves in for the killing blow. During all this testing and trying, two of my fleets happened to pass eachother on the galaxy-map at exactly the same time. Now their fleet-avatars are stuck together and they can't leave. They also can't merge and become one fleet .... they're just stuck.I give up. Doesn't matter how good a game is if the bugs never let me enjoy a full game.You decide if you can (or want to) deal with it, good luck.

He's designing tons of content, good content, but when it comes to implementing it, he's just being lazy and disorderly. Probably he should start to employ professional programmers.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												One of the best 4x games to come out in a long time. SD2 has phenomenal game design philosophy...in Most parts.THE GOODShip design:- This is by far the best ship building feature off of any 4x game excluding the original which manages to outdo this one just ever so slightly. You manage everything within your ship in a FUN way. This is the problem with a lot of other 4x games with ship building, they add a ton of things you can do, but it doesn't feel fun. You're just moving numbers about. In SD", you get to see exactly where your components go, why they go there is completely up to your combat logic. You want to create massive artillery ships with weak armour and then create some up close and personal heavy shielded and armoured heavy hitters to protect the artillery? Easy. Then when you've built your ship with a specific class in mind, you get to see how it plays out in battle. Combat:- Superb combat. The action takes place as an RTS. You get to build your fleet in factories after you're done designing it, then put them together in a fleet. When that fleet meets an enemy fleet, you enter into an RTS strategy map where you can plan out your manoeuvres in real time or with a pause function. There is some UI issues which I'll go over in "THE BAD" section. My only other complaint besides the UI is that there really isn't anything to interact with in these battles. An asteroid battle or having to battle over your home planet, trying to make choices of attacking the ships that can kill your ships, or attacking the bombers that can kill your population would make an excellent addition to the ship combat. As it stands it's awesome, but with a few wasted oportunities.Events:- Another thing that SD2 outclasses everything else on. Events make you feel like you're really managing your empire. In most 4x games you see something on the map, get the reward and off you go to the next one. In SD2, you can find things that intertwine within other concepts of the game. For example, you can find a world where dinosaurs live in. So you now get a new research project to mount guns on the dinosaurs... There are quests you can find, the usual $50 from every other 4x game, and events that  happen because of your own doing. Create too much pollution on a farm world and your crops are dust for a few turns. Build a ship production line on a lava planet and you might just find a new way to make hulls more durable using that planet's natural resources. Events make the universe come alive and it follows choices and consequences in a logical and believable way for the player.Tech:- At first I was disappointed with the tech tree. I've been let down so many times in 4x games before, that when I saw videos of it pre-release, I just thought there wasn't enough there. Well I was wrong. The choices you make in tech are really meaningful. You have to pick one tech out of a couple of choices and you never get to pick the other tech again. You can trade for it with other empires, or steal it from them using spies, or taking over their planets with a specific trait or tech. This makes trading for tech pretty important. But even though you never research all the techs, there are so many that you will be researching for days. You also get new techs that come up due to events in the game. Found a strange asteroid? Tow it back to earth for a new research project. Colonized a planet with a specific negative attribute? New tech (My only complaint is that these don't exist for every planet with negative attributes). Found a wormhole next to a research planet? New tech. You get the point. I really hope that this feature gets expanded on in a future update though.THE BADUI:- There needs to be a more user friendly interface. It does a lot of stuff right, like showing information most of the time for example, but in combat, it fails miserably. Why can't you highlight all of your ships and have their powers show up at the bottom so you can click on all of them instead of each one individually? Same with troops. Why do I have to waste time loading combat with my scout, just to wait for him to retreat? Why can't you drag all of your ships and place them in a different location before the battle starts (or even save a formation for your fleet?!?!??) Why can't you click on an enemy troop with your troop selected for an automatic attack with your main weapon? Why can't your melee troops auto run and then attack when you click on an enemy soldier with your troop selected? Things like this are just not acceptable in this age of gaming. An almost catastrophic oversight in SD2.Ground Combat:- This is not fun. It's OK, but it's not fun. Most of the problems come from the UI. So once that's fixed, we can begin to enjoy the simplistic nature of this minigame. Maybe an expansion should really concentrate on adding more to this mechanic.AI:- the AI cheats. We all know this. The problem is that they don't play by your rules. I hate this sort of mechanic in games. I like the AI to play by my rules, not for them to get bonuses while we get gameplay mechanics. It's much harder to balance a game this way and I feel like this was a bad but maybe forced decision by the developer.Generation Options:- There just isn't enough options for generating your galaxy right now. No slowing down tech or production options, only 100 planets, not being able to add custom races to go over the 8 AI limit. A missed opportunity here.PERSONAL STATEMENT ON DIFFICULTYI don't really feel like the game is too hard right now. I play it on hard as the humans and I'm doing pretty well. I feel like deployable shields are OP in ground combat. It's got to a point that I just don't lose soldiers anymore. My under tech'd ships are doing their job just fine because they have shields and a good formation with strong artillery, and the enemy doesn't do that. They get some missile throwers but it's just not enough when I have big massive cannons that start attacking them before they're even in range. I really don't see why everyone is making a big deal about the difficulty. Start off with building as many small ships as your empire can handle for free, then defend with them (for medals) until you get shields. Build 2 artillery ships with little armour, and 3 frontline armoured ships. All 5 ships with shields. That's enough to defend against any attack through most of the early game (safe till at least 2 fifths of the way through). I know the humans get some pretty powerful ship traits, maybe this is why I'm not finding it difficult.FINAL VERDICTThis game is awesome. I've not been able to put it down since it came out. I know it was made mostly by just one man, but I'm not paying to appreciate the awesome talents of one man creating an awesome game, I'm paying to play an awesome game. And I can't say I'm displeased with that. I got a nice discount for owning the first game, but I would still recommend it even if it is full price. Just know that there are parts of the game that will feel unfinished. Specially the UI. As it stands, it never really prevents the fun parts from being fun. It's still a masterpiece, a slightly flawed one though. 8.5/10MESSAGE TO ZERO (Maker of SD1+2)Make DLC for this game. I waited a long time for SD1 DLC. Don't disapoint us, we all want to throw our money at you for DLC.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
 Overall not a good deal for almost 30€	The good:- UI and graphics are appealing.- Ship design and space combat are fun. But very easy and exploitable once you understand the insights.The not so good:- Far too oriented to war, but the mechanics of space warfare are not especially deep or rewarding.- Research and tech tree are counterintuitive, although it opens some diplomatic possibilities.The bad:- The ground combat is, to keep it short, completely and utterly terrible. And unskippable because the "auto" function is a slaughter for your troops.- AI is idiotic, treacherous and, at the same time, completely predictable.- Because the AI is how it is, and the space combat is easily exploitable, you can "game the system" to win against the odds.- Forget any playstyle besides warmongering. War up to extermination is the optimal response to everything in this game.- Very buggy and glitchy. Nothing game-breaking but it feels like an unfinished product (for now).- Big empires require to much micromanaging in my opinion.I think Star Drive 2 fails to deliver innovative concepts/ideas or a well balanced/polished "classic" 4x game. I had some hopes that the game would improve through the months, and I've seen some improvements, but overall is not specially fun or challenging. It's not worth the time nor the money in my opinion.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												At first I was like: damn this game is awesome. It's so close to MoO2 and there are some nice additions.Then I played "some" rounds. I didn't finish one map.TLDR: The basis is great. The execution and balancing is lacking. Has a rather rushed feeling after a whileMy main complains are:- The tech-progression is too fast or the tech-tree to short. It's too easy to reach "future-tech" without ever deploying researchers.- Ground combat is meh.- The AI (premade) ships are boring and the AI just spams. Most ships are low-tech only. There is only 1 pre-made Titan (high-end ship) for the Vulfar I could see. It's full of spinal lasers (low-end weapon).- The ship spamming of the AI leads to slideshows in combat, when fighting against "bigger" fleets full of rockets.- The ship-limit is really weird. The 2 smallest classes don't cost command until a certain margin. Which the AI uses to spam. Most of those ships are not worth the building affort, but again kill the framerate.- The AI sends more spies to you, then you could ever remove. Even with the Anti-Spy Leader. I got 2 messages for removes spies for every turn. Never got less.- The ship-design info about how long your energy weapons will last straight down lies.- There are not enough different special-encounters. The ones that are there a kinda nice, but doing them over and over is boring.Okay some good points:- The overall feeling of the game is nice.- Ship creation is quite fun.- Combat looks awesome, if the framrate doesn't die.- Some quite funny references to other universes in the game.Overall the game is nice for a while, but the issues are to big to acutally fun. I kinda got annoyed after 30-35 hours and tried for the last 15 if there's a way to make it more fun. Didn't find one.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												As I played this game, all I could think was that I would rather be playing SD1.I came to SD2 with a slight bias. I loved SD1 and so was convinced I would love SD2 as well, but I can honestly say, I'm disappointed. The game looks pretty, I can have an open mind when changing to a turn based campaign, but found that SD2 was lacking in alot of details ,and had something of an identity crisis. The UI is clunky, apparently something as simple as pointing and clicking is to damn easy, hope you learned all your hotkeys. The camera is stuck, you cant rotate or see any planets and even zooming is quite limited in choices; far away or in your face, cant have anything in between. Diplomacy is sadly 1 dimensional and boring, lots of options, but few applications. The AI is a mess. I tried about 10 attempts now as humans and got completely steamrolled by massive fleets or rampant monsters in more than 6 of those attempts, in under 100 turns. This is on easy..You wont have a nice relaxing "get to know you" experience here, prepare to get slammed shortly after contact. That wont take long, the galaxy is a sardine can. Despite being open minded to its transition from real time to turn based, I didnt adapt to the transission well, and I dont feel this game did either. SD1 just felt much more alive and fluid, the sense of the distance between stars was apparent when you watch your little colony ship slowly zip through the void to a distant beacon of light. You wont feel that here, the galaxy is a flat, small, tiny world full of crappy planets. Sadly, i didnt get a feel for being in space at all. The galaxy is emensely small (100 stars max), and so crammed for space, that you'll be pilling on top of your allies and enemies alike. Not that your likely to have many allies though, even they will turn on you in a hurry if you happen to occupy the only terran planet in whole tiny galaxy.There was no sense of space, its expanse, or progression of my species at all. In SD2, you should feel rushed right from turn #1, and dont you dare make a single mistake or you'll get slammed by indestructable fleet of monsters on turn 45. I didnt feel like I was leading or playing a star civilization at all. I didnt feel particularly connected to anything, and camera and poor controls left me frustrated by an already overly aggressive and simple minded AI. This game isnt SD1, its MOO with SD1 touches. And even with that identity in mind, its a let down.And Frankly, as much as I wanted to love it. I'm not feeling it. I would much rather play SD1. My 2 Cents.(edit:typos)

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I want to love this game but it won't let me.  Numerous bugs, bad UI, rare crashes, half baked ground combat.  This game is unfit to be called a finished product.  A good beta maybe.  Needs polish, lots of polish.  You can tell that love went into this but it did not come with an equal measure of design skill.  Fleets will frequently overshoot their targets without engaging/parking.  Ground battles will sometime bug out, switching control of you and the AI's forces.  Real time space battles are unforgivably disorganized and nearly impossible to command in any meaningful way without 10+ minutes of pre battle formation micro management that you have to do every-single-battle.  Save your formation?  Nope, F U.  Simply clicking on a ship and telling it to "fly here" is absurdly difficult when large fleets are present.  Planetary production Governors?  Nope.  All micro.  Insta scroll game text with a click?  Nope.  Get used to watching the letters crawl across the screen like a legless orphan eating crayons.  Enemy transports will bug out in/near wormholes, becoming permanent, untargetable fixtures until their race is annihilated.  The music is awful and may as well not exist.  In it's defense, smaller space battles are fun and pleasing to the eye.  The random events/missions scattered about the galaxy are fun and interesting.  Ship designing is lots of fun but probably poorly balanced.  A colorful cast of aliens, even the 1 world minor races, Art and writing fluff did their jobs at least.  Really, if everything worked properly and had a decent UI, I'd say StarDrive2 is slightly above average.  But in this state?  Unacceptable.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
OverviewIt's fun for a bit, but after awhile it gets repeatitive and it's errors come to surface. Not saying it's a terrible game, but it's not in the top 5 list.PROsDecent graphics on the galactic map and ship tactical combat.Ship design is fun to play with.Good enjoyment for the most part, for awhile...CONsAI is not balanced and isn't very intelligent. They basically get to cheat.Economy isn't tweaked one can say it's bugged. Example: You can have eight farmers, but if you remove five farmers the three remaining farmers will produce more then the eight.Ground combat isn't to entertaining. Limited weapons and useless upgrades that'll never be used. No strategy required. Late game you'll start hitting your head on your desk because of the ground combat. YES there's an AUTO option, but with all other aspects the AI is terrible and you'll find yourself loosing half your troops.Ground combat AGAIN. I don't know what causes this but theres been a few times where I'm defending a planet and the game switches my units with the attackers units (ie. I have control over the invasion force and the AI has control over MY defenders).Large fleet battles (70+ CP) becomes all but unplayable due to framerate drop. Even when I drop the graphics to the lowest setting this happends. I do have a decent rig (AMD 6-Core, 2GB GeForece GTX 760, 16GB Ram, running on SSD). This is simply bad and unoptimized coding plain and simple.My RatingAreaScoreGraphics5 Some areas are done well, others seem to have gotten the short stick.Gameplay6 It's fun at the start, but it soon becomes repitive.Immersion5 You really get into it at the start. Towards the middle and end it's errors and repitiveness shows.Value3 Numerous bugs, Bad AI and generally un-balanced and un-optimized.OVERALL4.75ClosingI would love to recommend this game, I really would. But with the numerous bugs, bad AI, un-balanced, bad/un-optimized coding, and what I would consider a product that's not fully completed... I just cannot recommend this game. Yes it's fun, but it soon becomes a chore and that's not what a game is supposed to be.Wait until it's patched up and completed further before buying this game, or when it's on sale.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												This game's problem is...it 'tries too hard to be MOO2 without understanding what made MOO2 fun and balanced'. Having played through and done some reading I will point out some glaring flaws.AI is hyper-aggressive stupid expansionist. It will gobble up as much as it can as fast as it can and use that to produce as many junk ships as it can to throw at you the instant it detects weakness. That's ALL it will do - the ships it uses are pre-designed and total junk. It makes no attempt at clever diplomacy or alliances. It doesn't use starbases. No hiding in the trees to do a devastating flank attack here - no sir it will conga line straight into your wall-o-doom in the puddle size combat arenas. Constant escalating attacks by 'NPC factions' - remnants and pirates and space crystals that don't attack the AI, so you have to dedicate a fleet to defending against them while the AI out-expands you then sends a fleet of doom at you.Diplomacy is a joke. Half the races Want To Eat Your Granny and will declare war right away if they have more ships. Every other species is going to demand/threaten right off the bat, sometimes your homeworld, and if you don't give it to them they'll declare war if they have more ships. If you do they'll declare war anyway a few turns later if they have more ships. More ships >>> diplomacy.Balance is...nonexistant. Tech 0 lasers and tech 2 mass drivers are all you ever need, maybe gauss later. They aren't the best weapons in the game because you can use them to flank or do ninja flips and death from above the command center, they are the best weapons in the game because their stats are better than anything else you can research. Some traits are grossly overpowered - subterranean + more money per pop. The optiris have ships that are TWICE as large for the same CP cost as the vulfar.Ground invasions are 3rd wheel. What is a stripped down Xcom doing in my 4x? Ugly, simple, beyond mindless, pointless, click-fests that can be avoided at no cost by having one ship filled with nukes. Seriously, you'll need a ship with nukes and one trooper per fleet and that third of the game can be safely ignored.The bugs! Oh God the bugs! And I don't mean the hivers. Ranging from game-breaking (autoresolve with many losses) to devastating (can not scroll systems in leader-assign screen) to merely annoying (deployment area does not auto-size for fleet).Do Not Buy. Will update in 6 months if they fix stuff, it's gonna need at least that long. Unless the dev abandons it like he did his first game.

number of helpful: 54 of 72 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Disclaimer: This review focuses mostly on a comparison between StarDrive 1 and 2. If you're new to the series you can safely skip this text. A 'Tl;DR' summary can be found at the end of the review.I almost feel bad about giving this game a thumbs down. But since there is no "it's just average" option and I certainly can't go with a thumbs up, it'll have to do.StarDrive 1 with its free-flowing combat, RTS feeling and huge fleets was a nice change of pace. StarDrive 2 being turn-based came as a bit of a shock to me and took me out of the game almost instantly. On the other hand, if you're into more traditional 4X games you're probably fine with this change.Also gone are the huge fleets you could build in StarDrive 1. The number of ships is now (soft)capped by command points, which results in much smaller battles. But since even small and medium scale battles can have quite a severe impact on frame rate, this might not be a bad thing, at least not from a performance point of view. (I'm running an OC'ed i7 with two OC'ed GTX780s, not exactly a "slow" setup, but during battles the frame rate can drop to almost 0).Speaking of ships, there is now less variety - the smaller classes are mostly gone. So most races are down to four different classes, and again the Titans have no preset layout, so unless you don't supply the AI with your own layouts they won't build Titans (which further reduces the hull variety to three).Meanwhile, the ship editor has been reworked and streamlined: Similar weapons and components are now grouped together and you get nice diagrams showing you the range and damage output of each weapon. You can also set a default behaviour for each ship layout. Unfortunately you can no longer manually edit the firing arc of your turrets. Granted this was very fiddly in StarDrive 1 and I like the fact that the turrets default to either a bow or port/starboard firing arc. On the other hand, it would be nice to have the option to overwrite these default firing arcs. But all in all I think the ship editor has seen the most improvements compared to StarDrive 1, although you have less hulls (per race) to play with and all the remaining hulls (except for the two new races) are more or less directly copied from StarDrive 1.Speaking of "copied from StarDrive 1". A *lot* of stuff has been either directly copied from its predecessor or only slightly modified. Now I won't go on about this for too much, since as far as I'm aware these game were pretty much a one or two man operation... but I was still surprised by the amount of images, ships and weapons that were reused. I guess if you're new to StarDrive 2 then it doesn't really matter, but if you've played the original then there really isn't that much new content. (if we discount the fact that StarDrive 2 is turn-based it could almost be an addon for StarDrive 1 instead of a new game)Although, to be fair, there is now turn based ground combat (think of XCOM) which is kinda neat. But it doesn't feel fleshed out. Personally I would have kept ground combat the way it was in StarDrive 1 and focused development on other areas of the game. If I wanted in-depth turn-based squad combat I would play, well, XCOM. Luckily there is an auto-resolve option that lets you skip this part of the game.Talking about combat: space combat is of course still a big part of StarDrive 2, but you have to micromanage a lot more than in StarDrive 1 since there does not seem to any sort of "attack-move". Without input your ships will just sit at their spawn location. You have to manually assign targets because your ships won't automatically pick their own target (you can defince a "typical behaviour" in the ship editor but that only seems to affect the way the enemy AI is utilizing the ships). TL;DR: StarDrive 2 goes from RTS to turn-based. Fleet sizes seem to be severly limited due to a command point limit. Space combat is still in real time but you have to micromanage and babysit your ships a lot (which some people probably find appealing). A lot of the ingame art, ships and weapons have been lifted from StarDrive 1, and while the introduction of turn-based, XCOM-esque ground combat might set the game apart from other 4X games, I found it very tedious.On the plus side, the ship editor has been improved greatly and the game seems to be more stable (at least for me) than StarDrive 1.Again, I would give the game an average score if I could (but for now Steam is lacking this option). Overall I was hoping for a continuation of StarDrive 1 (think different hulls & weapons, new tech tree), but what I got was basically "StarDrive 1 - the turn based edition".

												I regret buying this.  I loved the first game.  It was so close to being perfect, but it had some very game breaking problems that I feel could have and should have been fixed.  Instead Zero left it broken and made this.This is quite obviously unfinished.  Lack of balance, basic UI bugs, crazy strong AI that loves to kill you a little too much and seems like it's cheating. The turn-based systems lack the amount of control that the real-time systems did.  For example, you can't reinforce your ships during combat, or position your forces around an enemy before attacking, or make any kind of hit and run moves.  Just seems like it loses a lot and gains little, which I think sums everything up perfectly.  Can't say i recommend it, and I wish I hadn't supported them.

												I would like to start off saying I would have loved to love this game. I liked the original Stardrive, even though the developer left it unfinished and buggy,  only using the titles mangled corpse as a springboard for the sequel, Stardrive 2, leaving many of the games backers with nothing but an unfinished game and buyers remose. While the game is fun in it's current semingly incomplete state, it requires a beefy computer to even finish a campaign due to the massive fleet size. The game's AI is overly warlike and game itself is entirely riddled with bugs. All of this aside, what really pushes this review into the negative is the utter dissapointment I have for the developer after so many people gave them a second chance with Stardrive 2 after the failure and abandonment of Stardrive. Stardrive 2 is in a buggy and what feels like downright incomplete state. Instead of fixing the problems in the games, or adding better and more exciting content the developer has chosen to lock away these things behind a DLC paywall for the game, forcing any loyal fans to purchase the game a second time, or even third time if you wish to count the original Stardrive, to even continue receiving updates to it. This is very saddening as I had hoped the abandonment of the original Stardrive would be the last of the poor consumerism choises made by the developer of the Stardrive series, I am clearly mistaken.

												So many good points, but let down by the finer details which ruin the game.TLDR - wait for the Moo remake due later on, you will end up frustrated by this game. I don't expect the AI to be as good as me, but if I select auto resolve I expect the AI to do a reasonalble job, example: I had 6 cruisers, the best I had, auto resolve and I lost all ships and took down 0 of theirs, reloaded the turn before and took control myself and I utterly stomped them, I did not even lose sheilds on 1 ship never mind lose 6, before people think I employed advanced tactics, I had rail guns, I did nothing, I issued no commands, default deployment and watched only and won hands down, WTF did the AI do to lose that? I can only assume it turned off all the guns and sat there and died slowly as there is no other method.The AI is scewed against the player, all random events attack them and not the other AI, in Moo2 for example the anteries attacked the strongest player, in this one they just attack the player, regardless of how well they are doing.The AI in general for other empires is heavily flawed, it boils down to, regardless of how powerfull you are: give us tribute or we will declare war to the point of our own death, even if you have 20 planets and a huge fleet, they have 1 ship and 1 planet they will still give diplomacy options as if roles were reversed. Many basic options of that of a 4x are missing.ground combat is a joke, I would have avoided it totally but if you don't then the same as space combat, you can win it with 0 losses, let the AI 'auto resolve' and you lose all your troops, shocking really. terrible UI whereas selecting planets and fleets can be a total nightmare, trying to click a fleet and taken to the planet menu is something you will be used to after playing a short time. As said soo many good things, the ship design is epic and great to play with, but the small botched ideas ruins the whole thing. Stay away, save your cash for a sale and get it for alot cheaper.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												I spent a lot of time playing the original Stardrive and I loved it. Although a few hours in it's very obvious that it's not a finished game. I had oversight with that because of two facts, the game is simply great from a 4x point of view (though somewhat lacking in the diplomacy departmeant), and it was developed by one guy. Stardrive 1 captured my interest with a non-turn based system, it's wonderful shipdesigner where you can put modules pretty much anywhere in your ships making them, essentially, your design. The tech tree was wonderful and the empire managemeant was comprehensive. Stardrive 2 threw out the ship designer, the non-turn based system, the meat and potatoes of the game in my opinion. In place they put in a turn based system and a dumbed down version of the ship designer. The diplomacy has been improved but at a fatal cost, at least to me. The ground combat is somehow worse than the first game and the battles now take place in a seperate scenario where when you encounter enemy fleets load into a combat screen where you duke things out in real time. This eliminates the dynamic open world combat with on the spot micro, retreating somewhat easily, reinforcing with ships on the way or being built mid fight. It results in a game which boils down to biggest highest tech fleet wins the game. I bought StarDrive 2 hoping it would beat the odds again only to be met with a turnbased, dumbed down StarDrive 1.Now when I want to play a 4x space empire game, I play StarDrive 1, because to me, it's simply better.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I read the reviews and thought "okay, this looks good."  I plunked down my quarters and I got to say this is a very frustrating, boring game.   I understand that AI's have to cheat to compete, but good lord this is ridiculous.Issues as I've found them:a) The tutorial, though appreciated, feels like it's setting you up for an easy fail.   It's basically a dad who, giving you encouraging words as you learn how to pedal a bike, stops holding on just as you start down a grand canyon trail.   I got through it thinking I could handle...and then 10 turns later all my bases are starving, no functioning economy and two at-war races.  What the heck?b) The news feeds.  They type out so slow.  To further agravate hitting space, which one would hope brings up all of the comment being typed skips to the next comment.  While "cute" the poor design of the interface  does little more than irritate.c) The tech trees.  Illogical.  Unfunctional.  While I like the idea that when one choses a course to follow other avenues close off but why the heck can't I research both fusion engines AND fusion shields?  Explain how one would exclude the other and not actually make the other easier to pursue?  Once gone, the only way I can pick it up is through dubious trade with other species?  Grrreaaaat.     Also...the tech time to get each technologie increased after each successive advance...why would somethng that needed 8 turns to calculate need 12 turns later all things staying the same?   d) Resources.  At "Normal" I couldn't get more than 3 viable colonies.  At the same time trying to fend off sudden war declarations AND, after barely expanding to three systems discovering I"m surrounded by alien races each with 15% of the available star map.  That initself was the most discouraging revelation of this game.  Trying hard and getting a third colony going only to find that the AI has 10-12?   I reaaaaaally want to know how beyond AI boost.    I have no idea how to produce a military that could defend my meager colonies let alone strike back.   e) Random bugs.  I'd send a colony ship to a planet and it'd not colonize.  I'd have to send it to somewhere else and back again to a planet to do so.   Had same issue with warps.  Couldn't use a wormhole and would have to travel somewhere else and back again to do so.  Feel like I'm missing out.  Will try again...but I really ain't feeling the love here.Would not recommend.  Not even a small bit.
