content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Never written a Steam review before, or returned a game. And I'm fully in support of ANY lone developer, and the huge amount of effort it must take to get a game like this to market all on your own...But seriously - £29.99 (price of DLC bundle), for this?!I don't know or care if SD2 is a rich and involving 4X strategy (although on surface inspection, it looks like a forgettable and mediocre space-4X like many others). For me, the dumb and inherently buggy interface killed any enthusiasm. Considering the advances strategy games have made in this area in recent years, especially since the interface IS THE GAME in this genre, and not forgetting this is the Dev's 2nd attempt, I honestly don't know how they looked at ANY of this and thought "Yeah! Looks great!"Again, credit where credit is due - apparently both StarDrive games are the work of a lone Dev. A solitary code-monkey who has clearly never used an interface in their whole life. Half of SD2 looks like placeholder art, with utterly dreadful layouts and spacings, 3-4 different typefaces in any single screen (most important text is... ugh... Arial). No consistency between buttons or widgets. If something looks click-able, it's 50/50 just meaningless. Somebody spent a lot of time drawing pointless "sci-fi" lines, dials and squiggles around everything, just to make the terrible layouts even fussier without any actual purpose... Mr Lone Dev: look at those stupid sqiggles, and now ask yourself: Why?Tutorial windows that wouldn't close when I'd done as asked (restart); Windows obnoxiously overlaying windows, but still allowing clicks "through"; Yet more windows appearing UNDER other UI ellements; An "Are you sure?" message that didn't care I'd clicked Cancel (restart); Paragraphs of unedited flavour text that only labotomised chimps would laugh at; Tool-tips for EVERYTHING, as if having ANY useful information on screen is just a damning admission that Yes, we made a mistake with the Arial font...In short, it looks unfinished, feels unfinished, and in the face of Stellaris and GalCivIII, most probably IS unfinished. Most other Steam reviews seem to agree, and there are plenty of conspiracists accusing the Dev of shenanigans.I haven't played enough to honestly comment on the long game, or AI failings etc, and I do feel a little disingenuous returning a game this early... but sometimes you just KNOW you've wasted £30, and that is NOT a small amount of money. Nothing about the 1.4hrs I've seen was in any way enjoyable. I can't imagine suffering that interface for any longer - let alone the hours an average 4X takes.Considering SD1 is still going for £22.99 (?!), was there really not enough spare cash to pay for a dedicated artist with a singular vision for the UI, rather than this hodge-podge? Sorry Mr Lone Dev (and I do mean that), but maybe you should employ a friend - if only to remind you that your s*** stinks.

												After a few hours of play through I have to say that the game has a ton of potential. That potential, at least without the expansion (which I haven't purchased) is not realized. If you are a fan of Master's of Orion 2 you'll feel right at home. The graphics are obviously better and the combat has been reworked, but otherwise the races have been borrowed from heavily and the technology tree is nearly copied in its entirety. All of this wouldn't be an issue were it not for the staggering amount of bugs that are still present in the game. I've not managed to get even a single play through to last more than an hour or two without running into a bug that causes the game to lock up. These are issues that are being caused by normal game play and I, like other reviewers, am amazed that they never game up in beta testing. In fact, they make the whole game feel like it is an early release as opposed to a fully completed product. Hopefully they will continue to work on fixing the bugs, but until then I wouldn't pick the game up unless it's massively on sale.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
Unfinished, unpolished, unoptimized and unbalanced. After 40 hours or so of playing that is my conclusion. Now let me explain some of the reasons why I honestly cannot recommend StarDrive 2 at this moment (version 1.1).When building something with the construction ships (Listening posts, subspace projectors or fueling stations) they CANNOT be destroyed. I mean not even by you.You will notice how irritating this is when you accidentally click the construct icon when the ship is on top of your planet. If you try building "space highways" with the projectors you can goof it up so bad that your ships can get stuck in an eternal loop when it's trying to reach it's destination. Basically what happens the projector accelerates your fleet to high speed, it shoots past it's target (for example a planet), turns around and repeats. Yes I have had this happen, more than once. Also path finding IGNORES subspace projectors completely so basically they're completely useless and a broken concept.Ship modules and their descriptions (What they actually do and what other modules they affect) are vague to the point that I had to dig through the game files to find out what weapons were point defense weapons (prioritize incoming ordnance over enemy ships).No auto build option for colonies (After you reach a certain point of colonies this becomes TEDIOUS).Unique leaders where some can engage in space and/or ground combat. Sadly for space combat their ships become outdated really quick and no way to update/upgrade them. Not even the modules in them like armor.Ground combat is a joke. It's a huge chess board with absolutely NO tactics involved. There are some weapons, some protective items and some utility items. You can select 3 of them for your ground unit. Guess can you create a "default" item set for new ground troops? Nope. The whole ground combat part seems more like an afterthought to try and get more sales.AI is, in pretty much every aspect, an idiot. Yeah it keeps spamming my 12 battleship blockade fleet with around 15-25 ships consisting of corvettes, frigates and cruisers.Race customization options aren't really that diverse (Pales in comparison to Master of Orion 2).AI ships designs are a joke. My latest discovery was a design where the ships had 3 ECM jammers, heavy armor at the front but no weapons. What does the AI do with that ship. It retreats right after the start of a space battle. And when there can be over 10 of those ships in the enemy fleet... well just picture a facepalm and you I'm sure you get my meaning. This is yet another glaring show how little the developer actually puts effort in the game.Space battles eventually turn into lagfests. Picture the enemy might have 30-50 corvettes or frigates. Each of those ships can have several rockets/missile launchers firing a rocket/missile every few seconds. Now please answer the question below.Does the above mentioned rocket/missile spam lag the *BEEP* out of the battle no matter what hardware you're running?[ ] YES[ ] NOGood you answered correctly.It does not matter what your computer specs are. In the end battles will become slideshows and turns start to take more and more time. If you think Civilization V end game turns took long, compare them to this and re-evaluate. That is if you want to waste your money on this game.What I mentioned are just some of the things that came into my mind while writing this review. It's not a complete list and hardly even a partial list of what's wrong with StarDrive 2. I have played StarDrive 1 and I liked it. I really wanted to like StarDrive 2 but the more I play it the more annoyed I get with the multitude of irritating things in the game.There are a lot of problems in the game currently and I do not believe that the developer can, has enough time or interest to sort things out. In reality the only hope for this game is proper modding support. The community might be able to salvage what's salvageable in the game if the modding support is extensive enough to be able to change and tweak all aspects of the game. Currently it is a very limited amount of things that can be modded.If you can get this game for a real good price (5 euros or under) then grab it. For 5 euros or so it's enough entertainment. I really cannot recommend paying full asking price for this game in this state.

number of helpful: 164 of 273 people (60%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Full disclosure: I am a Stardrive 2 closed beta tester, but I have not received any compensation for my testing or for this review. I'm really just a 4x gaming fan at heart who was lucky enough to be given access to Stardrive 2 during its development :)I highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a galactic empire building game featuring that "just one more turn" itch that some of the great 4x games of the past have offered. This is definitely a game that can keep you up late at night, constantly clicking end turn just to see what lies ahead in the development and struggles of the star nation you've spent hours carefully building.Right from the start, you'll be faced with interesting events, encounters, and anomalies that will drive you to spread your chosen species farther out amongst the stars. You'll research interesting technologies, some of them unique to your species and others totally random in nature. You'll find valuable resources to claim through colonization and exploration. You'll design and build your own starships to conquer your enemies and protect all you've gained. You'll engage in diplomacy and espionage with/against a variety of interesting and unique alien species all with their own agendas. You'll meet minor species to either befriend, enslave, or exterminate.The combination of turn-based empire management with real-time space combat helps to break up the pace of the game into enjoyable yet distinct pieces. Being able to see a newly researched weapon help your ships blaze a path of destruction across an enemy fleet in real-time combat helps to tie the entire game together and makes it feel like every decision you've made matters. The ship designing and customization are definitely high points of Stardrive 2. The space combat is visually impressive and always fun to play. The ground combat is turn-based, with an X-Com Enemy Unknown feel to it, which I've come to really enjoy as an entirely separate mini-game within Stardrive 2.In short, if you're looking to escape from reality for hours at a time by putting on the hat of a space emperor and building your very own interstellar civilization this is the game for you!

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												     I see quite a few negative reviews on here talking about the difficulty of the game, so I'll share my point of view on that. So far I've played a number of games over 11 hours (normal) and have lost every single one. You know what though? I get a little bit better every time, and I know I'm getting close to winning. The first time I conquer the galaxy I will feel like I earned it. The AI doesn't cheat, it's not entirely ruthless towards you as long as you dont take the repulsive trait because you want the easy 4 points. People get upset because they lose. The fun is in the challenge of rising to the top. I think it's quite fitting that the first few times you try to conquer the galaxy you get slapped around.      It's a game that takes practice, turn it on to easy if you are struggling and make sure you understand the mechanics of the game.  There is a tutorial which lots of people ignore and several help sections in the game. Some mechanics are a little obscure, for example how your empire generates galactic credits beyond population is not explained very well.  However, there is an insane amount of tooltips explaining anything you mouse over which makes it really easy to find information. Combat is really fun, though the fact that the default ships are designed incredibly efficiently probably contributes to the difficulty new players are having.  However you can easily see the default layouts (which again are quite good) and can work on designing your ship from there. There are a few performance issues with large scale battles, but I hope to see them ironed out in the future. There are a large variety of weapons and options for those weapons, as well as support systems so you can design ships any way you like them. It also looks pretty damn good too. I hope to see more activatable abilities in the future, but right now space combat is a solid tactical experience.The economy is good. It's really irritating that people are complaining about the map size, because I can't imagine playing on something like a 150 system map. There would be too much to do. I think a few people loaded the game and said "what, 70 stars default?" without understanding the depth of the economy. You'll be really busy managing your empire with even a few systems. You can specialize your planets and they also develop over time, gaining unique traits depending on what you do with them. High research planets attract universities, big farming planets will eventually attract a farmers market, etc.There is more I could go on about but overall I'm happy with my purchase. I'm excited to see a few balance passes over the next few weaks, but other then that it is already a solid experience.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												I will not be playing this expansion as the core issues that make the game unplayable for me have not been adressed.Ships have ridiculous balance. A vulfar fleet of 6 ships gets easily outgunned by two pollop cruisers. Even two vulfar battlecruisers will lose to two pollop cruisers. You can imagine that when the NPCs are these races, the vulfar will ALWAYS LOSE. ALWAYS. The Ralyeh Titan ship is smaller and less utilizable than their battlecruiser. What. The Kulrathi are actually decently balanced, HUGE but not usable for proper artillery guns and they're slow, so if you can pick them off before they reach you that's a great strategy. Bring flak against their fighter spam, I like how that race plays out. The Humans have small ships, and early on do not have the money to keep them. Not really a ship issue, but they've got issues with them and are easily halted to a stop early on. The Draylok are another all-right race, their ships are decently sized beyond their frigates. The Codrazine dew the shortest straws together with the vulfar, their slots are insanely hard to utilize and their titan is tiny. The Chukk are basically a better vulfar. They scale decently in the game and their titan is quite big (even though it's not exactly very usable) and their early frigates in a player's hands can hold off early fleets. As an NPC however, they are incredibly aggressive with♥♥♥♥♥♥ships so they're usually a joke. The Opteris are also really insane. Everything is very square so lots of usable space, their frigates can fit like six large cannons or five fighter bays iirc, have tons of port side capability for close combat and are quite fast, same goes for all of their ships really.So basically, the Opteris and Pollop are insane, the Kulrathi are close, and the rest are always doing incredibly bad and in a player's hand (Besides the draylok, they're usable if you abuse mechanics) give you a really big disadvantage.Untill this is addressed, I will not recommend it to ANYONE. You'll love the game initially, until you realise that only three races are playable without severe disadvantage on any real difficulty without abusing mechanics.. Purely from a combat perspective. This makes every game you play exactly the same with three races doing alright, one being a diplomatic switzerland sitting quietly in their part of the universe and a few pirate races that are the laughing stock of the universe. Randomizing anything including traits only ♥♥♥♥s up the balance even more and regardless of what you do, a mid game pollop fleet will win any battle with a much larger vulfar fleet without any casualties.EDIT: the new DLC doesn't change anything to address this.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I just finished watching a live stream of the dev playing the game and learned a lot from it. I still have my reservations about the game, however Zero is patching the game to address some of the concerns I've had about difficulty. Truth is if you play the game 'smart', you can win. Having said that, I tend to turtle. I like games with a slow burn to them. I don't like getting into wars very early. Maybe that's where my frustration comes from. I would still like to be able to refine AI behaviors much more and tune them to my preferences and hopefully we'll see the implementation of that. Regardless, Zero seems to really care about the game and the community. I believe he'll do everything he can to make it fun for everyone. Those that want an easier game, will probably get it, and those that want the challenge, definitely already have it. Bottom line is, the game is worth it. I don't want to turn anyone away from this with an overly negative review. My original review had nothing good to say about the game and that's very very wrong, the game is worth the price tag and definitely worth your time. Previously published negative review:There are a great many things to like about StarDrive 2 but unfortunately the incredibly unfair and difficult AI outshine anything good this game currently has to offer. The main problem comes from the fact that the AI seem to be able to 'cheat'. They always have these impossibly massive fleets that more than out match yours regardless of how advanced your race is. Diplomacy is laughable. It's always completely one sided, the AI will make you an offer but will almost always reject your counter offer even though it's more than a fair trade. If you refuse to trade with them on account of you getting a terrible deal out of it, be prepared for them to invade you almost immediately. The problem is two-fold because the difficulty setting does NOTHING for the AI difficulty. The only thing it does is change how hard diplomacy is. Because of this the difficulty setting might as well not even be there. Even if you are able to get a race on your good side, and you give them everything they ask for and more, they will inevitably declare war on you for seemingly no reason and they will always win that war because they're somehow able to match your forces 3 - 1 or more.This is not even taking into account the amount of 'random' enemies that spawn very early into the game and destroy any progress you make. They never stop. You can't destroy their bases because you aren't given enough time inbetween each attack to amass a fleet large enough to destroy them. The worst is when your main fleet is blown to bits and they go after your freighters. You can't defend your freighters because an enemy engagement with them is an automatic combat failure. They're just destroyed. So your colonies starve and die out. If you create more, the AI that's camping your home world will just immediately destroy it. You can't send reinforcements because the game forces you into a combat screen with no way to send more ships to help.This is a huge problem because your fleet could be RIGHT NEXT to your home world but the attacking fleet manages to get in just right so the only thing fighting on your side is the orbital station around your world. So you just have to let them destroy it while you sit there unable to do anything about it. The combat 'fun factor' suffers for me because if they decide to attack my lone scout vessel two feet away from my main fleet, I have no choice but to waste a good 30 seconds entering combat and making it retreat when it would be so much better if I could just have my main fleet join the battle.In short, the current state of this game is frustrating. The negatives I mentioned here would be completely manageable if not for the freaking AI steamrolling you 10 minutes into the game.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												The game is fun, if you havent played original Star Drive, you can try and have fun with this - most customisable interior of ships ever. Battle system was simplified, - the power plants dont explode anymore taking out parts of your ship, making the whole experience a bit more casual, then again this removed the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like enemy t1 ships kamikaze into your dreadnaughts taking them out by their heroic sacrifice. There are now ground battles  which are not enjoyable one bit. Its a welcome addition but it will need a LOT of work if it is ever going to make it. The problems with ground battles start from randomising the troops instead of allowing for 1 standartised troop type you want to take into battle wiht you; ♥♥♥♥ing up your carefull planning of team at some point * i honestly dont know  when * by randomising what they carry in battle despite meticulous repicking of what they have. But that doesnt matter, the enemy AI is♥♥♥♥♥♥poor. All you have to do is sit at starting point and accumulate points, then ai rushes in with nothing and you get what is 2 turns of firepower unleashed on them before they have a chance to respond,... then just mop it up.Ive seen a lot of people complain about how the game is hard and ai might even be cheating. Truth is AI is horrible in macro map aswell and it does indeed cheat at least somewhat. For this was made an experiment ( you can confirm this yourself btw ) -> create TINY map with extremely limited resoures and max ai. Reload till you have good starting place, since rest of galaxy sucks♥♥♥♥♥AI will be attracted to what your system has to offer and might 'scout' it with colony ship. Thats right! Its 'very lucky' with guessing where good planets might be. Incredible feat. Same goes for assuming firepower. AI knows what you have at all stages without scouting anything. If it saw you on map and met you you ♥♥♥♥ing bet it knows what you have. Does it matter that it knows? No it does not. AI has no ♥♥♥♥ing clue what is going on macro wise and all it cares about is Command points and total ship count. Suppose you have 4 stationed tier 5 ships outfitted to the maximum of capability, just imagine 2500-3k worth of manufacturing. Thats about 8 CP if you play your cards right. And just 4 ships. In AI"s mind you have NOTHING AT ALL. ITS A FREE WIN TOWN BABY WOOOOOOOOOOOO! TIME TO PILLAGE. And then they get destroyed. It wont stop them. No sir! They will keep spamming the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little ships untill their last planet dies. It refuses to adapt it refuses to utilise the technology they have. Hell i GAVE them tech for tier 4 and 5, gave them schematics for weapons and armor for free to what my diplomacy allowed. Gave them 100 turns and went to war with them. 200 turns later they still dont have anything bigger then tier3 ships with swarmers. Ai ♥♥♥♥ing loves swarming.And its  the ultimate cancer, you see in late game you will be facing say 200 CP (command point) fleet. Are you excited for some epic showdown of 2 mighty fleets? You better not be because you will be autoresolving the battle. If not prepare for 1 fps for next 15 minutes because ai will be carrying as many corvettes it can, and the t3 ships will be filled up with viper fighters spamming up everything. Do you have NASA supercomputer? Well too bad for you the game doesnt give a♥♥♥♥♥♥you will still be lagging. AI never changes tactics in any form or shape. Ive also never seen pirates spawn and attack AI how it does happen against player. then again maybe my scouts and listening posts are not all seeing so i might have missed it. Lets focus on the positive -> the diplomacy window for reactions is great! Its charismatic, filled with love, changes accoarding to what is going on, its hilarious and enjoyable. You know whats not enjoyable? The limiting system. I want to sell 21k woth system to someone too bad best fdeal i can get is 9k for it as a single tech from my semi ally thanks to all the limitations. Ai having different traits at start is great and makes the game extra fun, but as a general rule of thumb i found that the only 2 races one can trust are Dreylocks and Bears. Everyone else will be all too happy to backstab you despite all agreements and previus actios. The Values of things need to be adjusted aswell. Once again  - i have  the power to destory/slaver everyone then sacrifice whomever i dont like, entire galaxy teaming up cant stop it *mostly because they refuse to build good ships no matter what*. Ship symmetry/design is ♥♥♥♥ed big time for ships tier 5 as of right now. Its not a design choice, its a design ♥♥♥♥ up, - there are tiles missing, extra tiles making no sense, entire rows missing even though the face of the vessels are symmetric. Upon pointing that out, our valiant developer replied "I have a feeling that you may have an obsessive co'. Charming.  No word on fixing either. I mean i can guess that there was just not much time to probably test t5 ships  and few problems were missed  but...really? How hard is it to measure. Sloppy, lazy, insulting.Might i remind you that original StarDrive was pretty much abandoned in favor of pursuing more cash from creating 2d one? No multiplayer yet. It would have been possibly the redeeming part of the game, but its unfortunately not here. At least as of right now. What else was great: the charming world, elephant wizards, great Ghost Pirate Tigre, Zapp Brannigan etc, fun dragons, - those are all welcome additions, but what the game is really good is - these tiny details, like good diplomacy gimmicks, charming lore, those kind of things. What is game bad at? Everything else. Mostly AI. Its been a while since ive seen one so bad. Watching t5 beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of everythign enemy has to offer is like watching a professional boxer beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of a handicapped old man. Its disgusting and not fun.  Its bad strategically and tactically, all it does is spamms small ships even if its doing nothing for it. Thats the AI's plan to win. Enemy can destroy everything you have and not bat an eye? Wont agree to peace and give 2 technologies instead of 1. Overall its a fun game. Its NOT GOOD. Not yet at least. A LOT of things need to be rebalanced and tweaked and fixed before this game is good. If developer doesnt start fixing this and instead moves on to moving StarDrive 3 i humbly ask you to not support him. If, however the developer starts getting work dont, then by all means buy the game and enjoy it.As it is right now i give it 5/10. No multiplayer and about one of the worst AI's ive seen as of late. In 2010 maybe that♥♥♥♥♥♥would have slided, not today. Has potential to be 7/10, not more. Do i recomend this game? Barely.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												As a long time fan of Master of Orion 2, this game at first seemed to scratch an itch.  So many 4x games try and fail, this one seems to be great at the beginning then totally falls apart.  A nice ship design system, an okay tech tree and interesting racial options.  Where it falls apart is in its AI, it knows where everything is, and doesn't even try to hide it.  That one planet at the back of your nation that has never been scouted, the one without a star base, yup every enemy you have will attack it again and again and again.  Combine that with the ability for the AI to build huge fleets in a handful of turns, and sneak them around, and the inability to intercept said fleets because they go right past yours without combat, it totally ruins the experence.  I like the front end changes of this game vs moo2, but the depth just isn't there.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												This is the kind of game that will keep you up at night contemplating: "Which technologies would I pick next time?" "What if I built my ships this way?" This game has a lot of replayability and is one of those games you can happily sink many hours into.Pros:  Love the tech tree. I was initially put off that I could not research all available technologies, but later, I realized why this choice is a good one. 1. It forces you to choose your tech to match your strategy. 2. Encourages diplomacy with other races to trade technologies. 3. Adds replayability.   Good AI. SD2 can be very challenging. If you're new to the game, I'd recommend the "easy" difficulty setting.  Beautiful space battles, planets, and galactic map.  Managing your galactic empire is a lot of fun. Making sure your making money, making sure happiness is high, exploring the galaxy for the next place to colonize, are all great.  Ship design and space battles. Your victory in space battles is far from guaranteed. In large part it depends on how you build out your ships. Even then, there are some enemies that you will encounter where retreat is definitely the correct choice.  There is some light hearted humor in the game, which I appreciate.  Has a good tutorial system. The tutorial covers what is needed without overloading you with detail and stopping you from playing the game. Getting started with StarDrive 2 has been a much better experience than I've had with other games of this genre.Cons:  Loading screen takes a while.  Ground combat was not as refined as I would like it to be. I realize a game can not be all things perfectly. Look at Spore for example. Comparing SD2 turn based combat to a game like XCOM would not be fair either. I've had fun with the ground combat, but at times, it can feel a bit tedious. The thing to remember is that ground combat is a relatively minor component of this game, and is not the primary emphasis.The biggest feature that I appreciate about SD2 is that it runs on Windows, Mac, and Linux. I didn't play enough SD1, since I don't play on Windows as much as I used to, to adequately compare SD2 to SD1. That said, StarDrive 2 is a good game. I had a chance to play the closed beta and was not paid. Naturally there were bugs during the beta, but Zero quickly addressed all the bugs I found. If you're a fan of 4x games, as I am, you'll not want to miss StarDrive 2.

number of helpful: 119 of 204 people (58%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												StarDrive 2 is a complete rip off of Master of Orion 2 without any of the good and all the bad.A lot of people on here are writing reviews either praising the game or telling you it is too difficult. I doubt anyone praising it has actually beaten it or plays many 4X titles. I could write a long list about why you should avoid this game, but I will keep it short. Here is the breakdown:1. There is no ending. A silent video is all you have to indicate you have won the match. The game will continue even once finished. You have to exit to the main menu, quit to desktop, or keep playing.2. Conquest is your only victory condition. You cannot have allies, so there is no diplomatic option.2. The UI is a direct copy from MoO2 in every way. Managing colonies at the late game is tedious, and will take up almost all of your time unless you ignore them.3. The AI is terrible. If you need proof, go read any of the other 500+ reviews telling you it is terrible.4. Diplomacy is pointless. The AI will only use diplomacy to threaten you. Once again, you cannot have allies.5. The ground combat is terrible. It is similar to XCOM in style, but is devoid of any strategy. There is no cover, and only a few weapons / items in the entire game. You take over entire planets with small squads of marines.6. The game is too quiet. The only sound is the music (which is very lackluster especially in combat), and basic UI / combat sound Fx. There are no voice overs except for the tutorial. It truly feels desolate and without character.There are a multitude of other issues, but I will not burden you with them. The end all be all is that the game is not what it should be. Your play experience will not be good, and when you finally beat a match you will be extremely disappointed by the ending assuming you survived the boredom of the late game.

content:
Posted: March 28
												I loved the ambitions of SD1. Its main shortcoming was the ram limit issue, as most of its weaknesses were adressed by modders.Hence, I had great hopes for SD2. I've played it for hours upon hours, and wanted to love it, however it feels lackluster in every aspect. Shortcuts have been taken to address the issues of SD1 (Hexmap to adress map complexity, Separating combat to a "combat phase" to avoid overloading the cpu and ram with massive battles...).And even then, such shortcuts were not exploited to their full potential. Whereas most titles with "battle phases" allow for strategic troop placement, troop group controls (ctrl-1 2 3 etc), formations and such, SD2's battle phase is more similar to "totally accurate battle simulator" (google it), with the added bonus of selecting and moving individual or groups of units. That's it. You place your units and watch them fight. No quick groups, no formations, no path points, no tactics.Diplomacy is equally lacking. AI's will continually attempt to rip you off, and show discontent when you refuse to comply to absurd demands. If what you're looking for is a proper modern 4X, with a high degree of freedom, do yourself a favor and grab Stellaris.And Zero, if you ever happen to read this : man, please, listen to your users. By trying too hard to "make something that works", you parted ways with all the aspects that made us love your first game. You used to be a dreamer, and this is why we used to love you. If you ever plan on releasing another game, by all means please either take your time or gather up with a proper team and come up with a masterpiece. More generic attempts like SD2 will never cut it when it comes to restoring the image you once had.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Now that is how i would have imagined a reskinned and reinvented moo2 with not too much weird♥♥♥♥♥♥but some nice innovations. What have we got:Turn based Grand strategy: checkBasically same techtree logic and technologies: checkHeroes: checkFleets and Command Points: checkNo freakin star lanes: checkMonsters and other threats: checkWeird GNN stuff: checkTons of buildings: checkEmpire Wide food Share: checkFreighters to transport troops, food or citizen: checkCustomizable Ships: checkHighly tactical battles: checkLots of fun and some nice background story: checkEspionage: checkTrade and Diplomacy: checkOn the other hand:Turn based battles: nope! (But their solution is cool too)Well i can´t really tell why so many people dislike the game. Really can´t. I dont have bugs, it doesnt crash, it is smooth and fast and fun. The Background story is weird in a very good fun way. Had myself chuckle quiet often at the subtle humor of the game.Im looking forward to more, i can see myself wasting tons and tons of time with this.TLDR;You like Moo2? Get it!You like 4x Space Games... hell yeah get it!4X Space Games need to have Turn based battles: dont get it! or watch some Lets play first...All i can say, so far i love it.After 30 hrs Playtime edit:So now i have been playing for 30 hrs instead of 3 with the initial Review. I stand by my recommondation. The Game is fun. It is a nice Master of Orion 2 Clone with nice graphics, subtle humour, some balance issues and many bugs to be fixed. BUT: Zero, the developer is fixing like no tomorrow. There have been at least 5 hotfixes while i was playing during the last two days. Many bugs i found got fixed at the same day. Very impressed with the developer so far. Here is a lil enhanced list of pro and con:Pro: Nice Gameplay, well done UI Good Sounds and Music Closer to Moo2 than any other 4X space Game out thereTactical Battles are freakin fun, seriously, the one thing many would cry out since its not turn based...it is really good.Interessting "Story" (GNN Style, Quests, Heros with their own quests etc.)Nice Groundbattles during Quests XCom light style.Leaders take part in Ground and Spacebattles and die :)Technology makes your ships stronger, lighter, better in all the right ways, you always want more more more :) Just another turn feeling...gosh i wasted so much time with this already the last two days...my girlfriend is gonna murder me soon i bet :-DConsMy Girl is sonn gonna murder me because of this ;-)AI is not really aggressive, not a Game for masochists like me. You want it hard? Try a mod or maybe go play something else.I still have hopes for AI improvement patches though.Balancing is a bit off and hard to tell how effective a combo actually isUI is sometimes not really helpful, most cases its nice but in some its just...not yet done it seemsMany smaller and bigger issues, i feel i have to tell that but many of them are already on Zeros list of fixes or are already fixed. Needs a bit more time to ripe...to be perfectTLDR;Game is enjoyable in its current state. You love Moo2? Get it! The first 1-2 Games are tremendously enjoyable. If you are up for a challenge, look somewhere else ;-)

Posted: April 25, 2015
												Gotta start with this: This game is amazing.  If you like RTS/4x/Space you will like this.  Battles are RTS, rest of game is turn based.  Customization of your spaceships is the best part.  Well worth the price.But read on cause it's not all good.  This game has bugs.  Lots of them, way too many for a release.  Save often cause it crashes.  Occasionally you may control your opponent's army in a fight.  Sometimes units will start a battle with 0HP.  Beating the game doesn't always trigger the victory screen (In fact I only got it to happen once).  The events in the game are few and get old fast, but they aren't required to play.The UI needs work, the races need balence, the bugs need fixing and the only victory condition is poorly thought out.  But the core is great and the game is fun and addicting.  I'm done playing for now as it's getting old but if Zero ever fixes these things I'll be back building spaceships the next day.DLC Edit:Many of my inital complaints have been fixed.  Lots of good rebalencing.  Got me to spend another 20-30 hours on it.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												Stardrive 2 is a game trying to be a modern Master Of Orion 2. It was successful in some areas, but failed in others.To be fair, I did get some enjoyment out of this game. The space battles are fun as well as ship building. Most of the time in the first 100 turns you can find some enjoyment.However, the game falls apart in many other areas. Though it has been improved a bunch since release, diplomacy is still lacking. Espionage is flawed and annoying. The late game drag is horrible. More so than most 4X games.I had hopped the developer of this game would fix this "almost ok" game into a "great" game. At first it seemed like he was, however, after a bunch of disappearances, and some hostile and to be honest strange behavior, it seems we will be lucky to get even a simple bug fix from this point on from him.To summarize, if you are really into space 4X games and have a bunch of extra cash to burn you may want to give this one a look. If not there are other similar games that do this better with others coming out.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												Love 4X and games like Civilization, Warlock, etc. but don't care for this game.  Tutorial is lacking- manual is lacking often have no idea why I'm doing poorly or how to fix it.  Maybe if I played the first version would be more intuitive - <shrug>. Combat get super repetitive real fast.  Built three of the large starting ships and the AI starts attacking me right off sending their ships at my fleet. My ships just stay in the same place and launch missles at approaching ships until all other ships are dead and mine are all but undamaged.  Next fight same thing - by 7th or 8th battle I am super bored so I click auto resolve for the battle and two of my three ships die... whaaa...so much fun.   Meanwhile I am losing money with no apparent means for generating more.   So the game keeps selling off my buildings  which don't seem to do anything anyway since none of my colonies are growing even though i have surplus food and freighters.Tech seems mostly leaning towards upgrading ships which are already winning every battle.  Nothing seems to help me generate larger colonies or more money - tech descriptions are super vague as well.Overall seems like a lot of tedious work with poor documentation and in-game info and i am not enjoying myself enough to even put the time in to figure it out.

number of helpful: 47 of 76 people (62%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												UPDATE: Don't buy this game because you won't be able to play it, everytime a patch comes out you have to perform a hotfix by editing files yourself.So yeah, definately don't buy this unless you wan't to be spending time browsing the forums for fixes to crashes instead of playing.I'm only going to mention the original StarDrive once because it would be unfair to base this game solely on its predecessor. I loved StarDrive and had a ton of fun with it, I practically threw my wallet at my monitor when I found out StarDrive 2 existed and had already been released. The graphical and sound options aren’t abundant but the consistent and unchangeable graphics are part of what’s unique about this game. It has a cool look to it which is appealing. The best planets in your empire come to life as they grow, space stations can be seen orbiting them and large cities lights can be seen from space.Real time battles look nice and it is exciting to watch your ship designs stomp the enemy. On the contrary it’s also fun to watch your ships get smashed because you never took that class on the importance of point defense. The trial and error required to design a potent military add an exciting element to the game. I have never been engaged in a large battle however, every battle I have fought has consisted of mostly between 10-30 ships. Diplomacy doesn’t seem to do much at the moment. Each faction will contact you (probably once every 10 turns so get ready for the spam depending on how many AI you have encountered) and offer trade agreements or technology swaps (or to demand tribute if they're a more aggressive AI). The AI honor their treaties as far as I am aware (haven’t had any issues myself but others might have). By treaties I mean trade agreements or non-aggression pacts and nothing else. The game has a weird way of negotiating using some sort of tolerance system which I haven’t figured out yet. Spies allow you to perform multiple functions. Defensively they protect you from enemy spies. Offensively they can steal technology (in the form of moles which are currently unstoppable to my knowledge), reveal enemy fleets and movements and two other functions I cannot recall. Essentially you can just spam build spies because they can be produced quickly and have no cost or maintenance. Once you have an armada of spies you can plant an infinite number of moles to steal all the technology you need (the AI will do it to you so I hope you don’t enjoy your privacy).Technology works in (nine?) different tech trees. When you research anything in one of the tech trees that tech tree advances. You have to choose what is important for now and trade or steal (probably steal) the rest. The tech you unlock includes everything from ship parts, new space stations, upgrades or buildings for your empire. Gameplay wise imagine that someone told you civilization five was similar to a real time strategy game. All you have to do is hold down the end turn button. The problem is that it doesn’t work. It isn’t entertaining and StarDrive 2 ends up feeling painfully slow at times. The larger your empire gets the more it needs to be micromanaged (which is to be expected but ends up being oddly complicated). As the game slows down you’ll find yourself dealing with countless nuisances. Neutral AI entities will spawn at a constant rate to attack your undefended systems. Wormholes will open up faster than a hookers legs. I have not had a single game where a wormholes have not opened up in the heart of my empire to allow free reign to anyone who wanted to ravage my sweet virgin body. Countering the pirate/neutral AI threat would be fairly easy except that there are unreasonable soft population caps which punish you for having a fleet capable of defending yourself. I have not figured out a way around this aside from raising taxes to obscene levels during incursions or just having a huge surplus of space cash. Couple this with the fact that finding habitable worlds is like trying to find a straight guy in a gay bar. Your empire will end up being large and spread out but still only containing 4-5 good planets (meaning your limited size fleets had better be well managed)In conclusion StarDrive 2 is not a bad a game but at this time there are too many small annoyances that keep me from enjoying what might be a great game. It feels like I spend most of my time fighting everything but other empires. Its problems leave it average and unenjoyable. In time this game will probably become great through its mod support and continued developer input (the dev has been working non-stop to fix issues). <3 you Zero. 5/10. Please pardon any grammatical errors, I am but a simple plebian.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												To tell you the full scope of what this game can bring you, let me tell you a story. A story of conquest, Pollop treachary, and human insubordinationThe United Federation of Planets, my fledling creation, had reached it's third star system of colonization. We made first contact with the Draylock council. War soon broke out but was ended with the successful defense of Earth. They were forced into peace and eventually became lucrative trading partners. Galactic tensions were high between the many newly discovered aggressive empires, such as the Chukk and Rayleh. I soon discovered a small spacefaring civilisation of the Pollop race. They were peaceful and docile so I let my guard down on them.... a huge mistake.      They sent a colony ship to my homeworld system and claimed a colony on a small world with the "beautiful" trait, which I had overlooked due to it's ironic toxic nature. Enraged they had the audacity to pull such a move, I sent a task force to bombard the planet out of existence... My second mistake. Thinking I was safe I continued to focus on the other larger, aggressive empire.     Suddenly alerts begin blaring as an enormous Polop fleet enters my outer space and begins making a beeline straight for Earth. I rallied the fleets but only about 2/3 of my forces made it to the homeworld in time. They has at least 8 cruisers with an absolute swarm of fighters. They tore through the orbital defences in a matter of minutes and outnumbered our ground forces 2:1. Earth was lost. And soon the Federation was left with but one colony.     Our last colony of Epsilon was kicked into overdrive mode and started pumping out a fleet, with a new flak cruiser to combat the plant swarm. The Pollop invasion fleet finally made to to Epsilon, as the fate of the Federation and Humanity as a whole rested on this battle. After a long and drawn out battle the human fleet remains victorious, and prepares immedately to reclaim the homeworld.     The fleet jumps out of warp and engages the Pollop fleet. Lasers and missiles are flying all over, Pollop swarms and human fighters battle it out zipping around the cruiser slug fest, with flak rounds detonation all over. With the destruction of the new enemy starbase, human forces plant their boots on the ground to reclaim what is theirs. After a lengthy ground battle the Pollop forces cannot withstand the human combat prowess and determination. The victory fleet went around to reclaim all our colonies and is preparing to take the fight back to Pollop space...All in 8 hours of non-stop gameplay. This is the kind of story you can create for your empire. The challenges you will face and how you can overcome them using strategy and wit. Fleet variation and devised roles are crucial, as opposed to two walls of ships slugging it out as seen in games like Sins.The AI's are good and difficult, but not impossible to take on. The game is so much like MOO2 it's rediculous, but in no way is this a bad thing. Spectacular visuals, awesome gameplay and the games create their own narrative. All complemented with the amazing and very suiting soundtrack.The only things are that ground combat could use a little more polish and depth. Persistent debris would also be cool in the tactical battles.Overall an epic edition to the 4X sub-genre, and truely the spiritual succesor to Master of Orion.

content:
Posted: March 20
												I bought the game and the DLC when they first came out. I also played the original Stardrive which, by the way, was abandoned by the developer because the technology behind that game was supposedly hindering the game's development. Alright, fair enough. I've been waiting for over a year now before giving my recommendation and here it is: don't buy this game. Let me elaborate a bit.I was eagerly anticipating Stardrive 2 when the developer first announced it. The game looked and felt fresh and seemed to be the game that will scratch that space 4X itch. The battles looked good with sufficient-enough depth and scope, there are interesting events happening throughout the galaxy, and the way the turns worked was also fresh. The user interface looked neat and the different AI races seemed interesting enough to warrant unlimited playthroughs.Playing Stardrive 2 for the first time is like a dream. Designing your ships is fun, managing your colonies is fun, meeting the alien races is fun, going to battle is fun etc. I won't deny that for the first dozen hours or so, I've enjoyed my time with the game. Even the humor is well-placed.Alas, after this honeymoon phase ends, you'll quickly get over the infatuation once you encounter all the bugs and the overall lack of polish, content and depth. Most noticeable is the game's lack of depth in terms of diplomacy and victory conditions. Sadly, after a while even the battles (which is the game's main strength) become boring and laggy. It has most of the basic trappings of a 4x game... but many of these features feel tacked-on and underdeveloped. Take for instance the ability to customize your race  (ie. you can be sacrificers, slavers and others).  There are interesting choices there, but they are very limited. Another is the ability to customize your troops for special missions. This can be interesting and fun sometimes, however this part of the game is underdeveloped and limited. There are occasional special units and minor races, but these too are underdeveloped. By the 5th playthrough you've seen all the content the game has to offer. The foundations for a great game are here. The IDEAs are there, sadly they weren't fleshed out. The game needed more time to develop and grow, but it was rushed out and, just like Stardrive 1, ultimately abandoned.  Avoid this game. In fact, avoid Zerosum games altogether.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Gameplay in StarDrive 2 is too forced into a style that the developer wants instead of a style that I would like to play the game. If after a certian number of turns you have not made contact with any other players then a wormhole spawns between your homeworld and another players homworld. This often results in an AI fleet invading my homeworld is short order. The developer has responded saying that this is a feature designed to prevent turtling. My take is that if I want to turtle I should be able to do so!I would still like to turtle so I make contact with another player, but maintain peacefull/minimal releations with them. After a while I get a notice that my citizens are wanting to go to war with the AI player. Since Im just starting to build a navy I decide against it. A few turns later a large fleet of 'rebels' bent on going to war show up at my homworld to change the government. My fleet of now 2 ships gets steamrolled by the rebel fleet 3 times larger than my fleet.Let me play the game how I want. If I want to turtle and play 'simspace empire' for a while I should be able to without being forced to play aggressive.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												It is a Master of Orion remake. Its graphics are polished up, the combat is real time, but it all boils down to the simple fact that this is Master of Orion.If not for the hefty price tag, I would definitely recommend this game.Other points of concern:CombatThe space combat is entertaining in the beginning, but becomes a chore in the late game.With large numbers of ships, the battlefield is crowded from second one, it does not scale well over time.The load times before and after battles make the automatic battle resolution even more tempting. But Ships do not seem to get XP from automated combat...(Also, combat pre-load and after-load times are horribly long, even with newest Hardware)DiplomacyThe diplomacy is really broken: It is easy to keep other empires entertained or urge them to trade stuff with you no sensible human player would ever think of trading.The diplomacy mechanic seems superfluous to the eventual military conquest, there is no "diplomatic victory" of any sort, nor deeper mechanics known from other 4X games.

												I really wanted to like this game. Unfortunately, the downsides eventually got me too frustrated to be able to continue play. * Really odd game balancing : economy is almost always doing badly, even with the barest of minimum planet maintenance facilities. Random space pirates show up with ships more advanced than your interstellar government's and knock out your flagships. Really?* Performance issues: The indie part of this game shows through painfully during ground forces combat. The graphics are far from anything special, but everything seems to lag anyway. There are similar issues throughout the game, like an annoying, delayed transition between space combat and the strategy map. Speech text is very slow. And there are no options for adjusting these things... Dah. I might give it another go and try to take on a capitalist personality in an effort to have a workable economy, but gads. So far it's just worn my patience thin.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												I feel I have played enough of this game to write a proper review.This game is a great deal of fun. Ship customization is awesome, Space combat is great fun and if you have the tactical mind about you, you can destroy whole fleets with just a handful of ships if you do it just right. The game is extreamly difficult passed easy mode, making it high risk high reward game. Random events will happen, like a random ship will apper with bugs on it, or your planet will have sharknados. This increases replay value and keeps me wanting to come back and find all of these. The Ui is simple and nicely laid out, making moving troops and building ships a breeze.However this game does have its issues.Ground combat is not as in depth as Most people would like. Its just a simple move-here xenonauts like combat, except not nearly as in depth, as previously mentioned.There seems to be only one way to win. Build a huge fleet, and steam roll the galaxy. Trading and negotiating simply puts war off. I wish there were other ways to get other peoples colonys with out bombing it from orbit. For example, Maybe spreading your culture across the galaxy will cause certian colonys to turn to "earth culture" and that colony joins your faction. This way developing relations with other factions isnt pointlessOverall, stardrive 2 is a wonderful game, and if you are new to the 4x stratagy genre, i recommand picking it up.8?10 would spam mass drivers agian

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Set the game to it's hardest possible difficulty. Won first try. I didn't just win, it was like beating a blind child with a spiked mace.Why?Probably because the AI... Well I should say the entire game, is so poorly made it is atrocious. Lets go over my experience:I have never played StarDrive 1, but I was a pretty big fan back in the old days when it was a Warcraft III map. I researched this one and thought it would be pretty similar, I mean, the WC3 map was a relatively simple but fun game, it would not be hard to add to it. The character/race customization for this game is decent, pretty good range of selection, and lots of races to choose from. My only issue was not being able to change the protrait, which in the end doesn't matter cause you never see it anyways.I started a campaign and was pretty excited, and if you played galactic civ, you will find it really easy to pick up the mechanics of this game, well maybe too much, it is almost the same game. When the announcer came up, it seemed like "alright, this guy will give some interesting narrative to the game!". Nope. In fact, everything he said, I already read on the character discriptions when looking through all the races to start the game. So this quickly became an annoyance, that I shut off.I did start this game on the hardest possible difficulty so I thought I should rush my economy, and build it up along with my capacity to build ships. I had races constantly asking to trade and demanding bribes. I quickly learned the following about diplomacy in this game:The diplomacy is complete nonsense.You can not allyThere are no "friendly" racesthere is 3 real options - Trade, Give, or DieAll wars are to the death, you may accept or ask for a peace, but because the hostility system in this game is so poorly balanced, the bot will soon declare war again on you.So.. besides a few side "quests", who's rewards are incredibly unbalanced to difficulty/reward, that they give you a massive advantage in the game.. There really is no more depth or story added to this game past the startup screen.My other big issue, and the reason I could beat this game, hard mode, so fast, was this game crippling fact: In battles, the AI is completely garbage. they recently boasted a patch that gave the AI 1500 new space ship designs to choose from, but I never saw them build a ship larger then a frigate (medium sized), so once you get the larger size to that, you are good, pretty much till the end of the game. So.. I built a few titans 3 to start out with, and just bounced planet to planet, fleet to fleet, and just utterly obliterated the AI with fleets of 50+ ships. Game over.So absolutely no replay value for me, unless I go for achievements, which I commonly do, but the fun is all gone. I really wish steam had a rating system instead of the yes or no, cause although I would not recommend this game to people who want an in depth and long lasting game, it is good for 1 play through, but a slightly unsatisifying play through at that.

number of helpful: 48 of 80 people (60%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I love the concept, but the game is not very forgiving to new players.  The tutorial seems very helpful, but that's somewhat deceptive.  It doesn't tell you how to make money, for instance, and it merely touches on most of the game's concepts.  Sensing that the game had multiple layers of complexity, I started on easy to familiarize myself with the game's mechanics.  My starting position was horrible.  I was placed on a nice, resource rich planet, but was producing negative food.  Before I could stabilize that situation, I had lost two citizens to starvation.  Perhaps even worse, the tutorial forced me to colonize the nearest planet before I was even able to stabilize my home world.  The tutorial actually said, "You have no choice" and made me colonize.  The trouble is, the nearest planet was incapable of growing any food whatsoever, which meant simply that it starved out in four or five turns, wasting a colony ship.  The tutorial did say, however, "here's how to fix the lack of food - import food from  your other planet."  Very helpful advice, and I'm sure I could have managed it if, perhaps, my home world was even capable of sustaining itself at that point.  In terms of finances, I was constantly running a negative of at least -2 BC (billions of credits), usually -5.  At one point I went from -30 BC in the bank to a surplus of over 300, with no explanation at all.  Then my surplus slowly dwindled.  Or quickly, because in the first part of the game, you're really just hitting "end turn" as fast as you can because there's nothing really to do.  There's no concept of time, or how long things should take to build and some of the items seem prohibitively lengthy to construct.  Even with my citizens focused on production, the most basic of star ships took 15-20 turns to produce.  Of course that's to say you have an idea of the relative power of the ships to begin with.  You don't, at least not initially.  You don't know what ships are good, and certainly not compared to the AI's ships.  You don't know how big you should create your fleet.  With the construction times, it turns out that if I were to produce a fleet that was big enough to defend against the armada the AI brought to the final battle, I woulnd't have produced anything else in my home world, and I even then it would have been big enough.  If you don't have a big enough fleet, well, by the time you realize it it's too late.  It's hard to add two ships to your fleet in hopes of staving off the enemy that just appeared in your system when the smallest ship takes a half dozen turns.  Undoubtedly this can all be chalked up to my unfamiliarity with the game.  I was unable to colonize any planets effectively (I finally retook that first colony, only to have it destroyed from orbit a few turns later), whereas my neighbors had six, seven, or eight planets all, ostensibly, churning out ships.  I hope that I'll get better at it, though at this point it feels like several hours of my life were wasted.  Coupled with the utter hopelessness of seeing a big fleet appear when you thought you were content with four or five small ships...  Hard to want to keep playing.  Plus the AI is quite deceptive; the first engagements were very easy to win.  You're lulled into a false sense of security with a modest fleet, focus on building up your population and home world, and then the AI hits you hard.  Game. Over.  Speaking of the AI: It's pretty aggressive.  My first encounters with it were positive.  Let's trade?  Okay?  Good.  You want to trade tech?  Sure.  Then it demanded tech, for nothing.  Then, all the sudden, it tells me, "I told you I claimed that world, now I'm going to take it!" and declares war.  He never mentioned that at all, first of all, and second of all, it was my home world...  Technology is a bit awkward.  As I understand it, you can only research one tech in a given part of the tree.  After you get the one, that's it for that part (unless you trade tech) and the tree moves on to a different part.  Sort of interesting, I suppose, but you feel pretty locked in, and if you make a mistake and research something that doesn't fit with your eventual style, tough.  And I think that even the first techs took at least seven turns to research.  The third or fourth tier jumps to over 60.  Shipbuilding and fleet management is also a bit awkward.  I can't see any way of retrofitting new tech like armor to existing ships.  You can change the ship's template, I think.  But even that's klunky.  I didn't see any way to strip a template to start from scratch, so you have to manually remove everything.  There's probably a way, but I didn't see one.  I don't see any way to remove designs from the list of designs either.  The concept of this is fantastic, and it looks great.  But there could be some refinements.  For example, there's a button that allows you to replace all the steel armor in a design with a newer form (plasteel).  However, when you click that button it only replaced half the armor and removed the rest, leaving huge blank spaces.  I'm sure there was a reason, but the game offered none.  So by clicking that button you made your ship invalid (because every design must have 75% of its space filled with components).  It isn't as simple as replacing armor, now you have to add other stuff.  The second time I tried it, a few turns later, it replaced all the armor properly.  Again, no explaination for what went wrong or anything.  All in all, I think the game has a lot of potential.   I love the idea of being able to customize your ships.  But the game is not very forgiving.  The tutorial is somewhat lacking.  And you don't know if you're doing anything right at all.  Would I recommend it?  Yes, probably.  Just be aware that the learning curve might be a bit steeper than you anticipate.

number of helpful: 30 of 47 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												I would definitely recommend this game. Forget the trollish reviews--a lot of people are reviewing the game not its own merits but by posts by the developer or experiences with a prior game (SD1, which is a different beast, but related). Yes, the game is HEAVILY indebted to a classic 4x space game, Master of Orion 2. It's not quite as good as that game (but what it is, eh?), but with some polish and an expansion pack, I think this game might surpass it.What you should ask yourself is this -- do you want a space 4x game with a turn-base strategy and a RTS tactical map? If so, SD2 is for you. Really, there are not many hybrid 4X games out there. There's the Total War games, Sword of the Stars series, and . . . ? Most game companies don't do these type of games--they either go turn-based all the way, or RTS all the way. Why? It's really hard to program two-games in one and figure out the proper way the two should mix.SD2 manages to pull off this hybrid approach really well. On the strategy side, you colonize planets and build buildings that help improve the economy. There are many buildings that can help improve industry or science or food. you can then use trade to boost these variables.On the tech side, the tree is deep enough but not too much to allow individual techs to feel unique and useful. There's still some balancing to do, but the nice thing is, lower tier techs, mostly the weapons, still have their place. You're also limited by your race and your choices, so nearly impossible to get the entire tech advances in one game. This offers some interesting strategic choices up front--do I choose better weapons or better buildings or research options?Combat involves an RTS game where ships duke it out. Lots pew-pew here with cool weapon and shield effects. Some battle can get pretty crazy, especially when there are lot of ships. Sometimes, the RTS mode can be buggy, and when you ahve a lot of ships on screen, the game lags. The developer is working on this problem and has posted some potential fixes.There's a lot more to this -- included is a scenario and campaign editor. You can also experiment with a "battle-only" mode, where you can design ships and see them duke it out. No reviewers mention this! It's such a great idea, and i can't think of any modern game that includes this option.Give this game a chance --it's a one man developer, and you can surely get a good 50-60 hours of this game, if not more if you mess around with each race and the scenario editor. There's a ton of content to play around with--don't get sucked into the negative hype. The game is well worth your money.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Stardrive 2 is a fun 4X with a focus on combat, ship design and exploration. Think Total War in space: turn based strategy map with real time space battles.Lots of good humour and references to SciFi in the game, as well as colourful characters / races / art. Lots of random events and anomalies to explore - the galaxy is a big place.Ship designer is quite deep and uses a module based system where you drop and drag engines, weapons etc onto your ship. Everything is directional, so shields placed on the left side will only shield the left side, and weapons have firing arcs depending on where they are placed etc. For those who don't like making ships, the game comes with default designs.This game is heavily inspired by MoO2. If you are looking for a massive complex game like Distant Worlds or Europa Universalis, you won't find it here. Ground combat is turn based tactical similar to Xcom or Advance Wars. I would say the ground combat is alright but not great.Some of the menus need polish which I expect will come as the dev tweaks the game post-release. I have not encountered any game-breaking bugs, but the game did freeze once and the one time the UI disappeared while I was in the ship designer. There are also some game balance issues which are of course being worked on by the dev.Even still, it's worth picking up.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Very similar to MOO2 but the tech tree is too severely limited and new types of weapons are called for so they can be scaled down and fitted into your cruisers and battleships. Diplomacy is also limited and trade for new tech is nearly impossible due to the restrictions placed on you by your population\'s  approval ratings for each transaction. The races are almost identical in their attributes so it\'s better to modify one to your liking ( if you can). You can\'t construct any ship past Titan size and outpost ships are very badly needed so you can stake out some good systems while you build your military and logistical infrastructure up. The battle with the \"Master of Orion\" (actually the Guardian) is intense but the reward is paltry, only one tech advance and no rich planetary system to exploit. Troop battles during invasions look like a bad rendition of \"Pong\" and they should more in-depth and intense. The pirates sprinkled through the game are pretty sad and are unable to withstand a concerted attack,they should at least be equipped with better weapons and bases. Speaking of bases, the orbital facilities around your planets are good for command points only because no matter what thier size is they are quickly overwhelmed and planetary defenses such as beam weapons or missiles are sorely needed. It\'s not a really bad game but it failed trying to step into MOO\'s shoes and I\'m glad I bought it on sale.

Posted: March 12, 2016
												First of all let me make it clear that even though I don't recommend this game I do sort of love it.This game would be the best thing in 4x genre I have seen since Moo2 if it was not so riddled with technical problems.Constant loading problems and stuff not working as they are supposed to make it a really unenjoyable experience.To give an example at one point I had a situation where pirate raiders would destroy multiple freighters and thats ok.The problem is there was like five of those fights which were just a press of a button and then my freighter would die.And at some point during this it would bug out and not allow me to continue resulting in me having to crash the game and load and hope it would go through the next time.It eventually did after repeating this nearly ten times.At other points weirdly usually after losing a fight it would get stuck in the loading screen resulting in the same thing.And these bugs are numerous let me tell you.In no other game that I have played i've had to crash the game so much as in this.Other issues I have had with it is that I think the research options are too narrow and simplistic.There should also be more options to how you want to play the game, as in victory conditions.The game events are very linear, random events are not really random as they pretty much happen always at the same time.I would also like to see more variety on ship hull types for all the races it is quite boring to only have one hull of each size class.Overall the game needs more content in it and get rid of the technical problems.Now having said that I do love what the game is trying to do.It is more like Moo2 than anything I have seen since Moo2 and that is very much a good thing so if you liked Moo2 then hope that this game gets it's technical problems in order and you will have a good time.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												As someone who enjoyed playing StarDrive, I'd like to share my experience of playing Stardrive 2. So far (14.6h) I've been playing as Humans (with my own custom civ traits of course - they make a MAJOR difference in your gameplay experience) on Normal difficulty, huge system with 9 other civs, and I'm currently faced with enemies on both my northern and southern space borders. I'm also becoming quite chummy with some samurai space bears. Now I've seen some complaints about Stardrive 2, and I have to admit my first few hours had a couple of complaints - mainly research and... well, I'll tell you what else when I get to it. Further into the game I found out how they downgraded the spy system, but let's get back to research. I was annoyed at how you could not research all the tech on the same tier, and then I encountered my first race. (I'd like to mention that I don't go exploring the entire galaxy, so I don't encounter multiple races before I'm ready to deal with them. That'd just be STUPID... Hmm was that too rude of me?) When I entered diplomacy with them, I was happily surprised to find out that you could trade the tech they had researched for whatever you feel like giving them. After encountering a few more civs, and by the time I met up with my favorite bear shogunate, I realized that unless you take diplomatic action towards these aliens, they're gonna wonder why they should keep the stupid foriegners around rather than kill and conquer them.I should probably mention that being able to customize your ships relatively freely is a big plus for me. They made it a touch simpler than the original StarDrive, but while it was disappointing at first - I realized it cut down the time I spent designing my failures and designing new ships to replace the failures (since they sucked in combat) or redesigning my redundant ships (due to new tech). For example, in SD1 you could face all your weapon firing arcs forward. In SD2, the location of your weapon decides where it aims (except cannons/mass drivers - they always aim forward) The way around this though is to select the *arc extend* feature on the turrets you mount so they cover a 180* angle - aka they can fire forward. I'll be updating this review in a few days once I'm back home and play a bit more, so I'll leave you with this: if you like customization and you find that you can understand a game's mechanics fairly quickly, then you'll enjoy this game.

												I have to admit that i wasn't sure if i should get the game at release.SD 1 was ok but... well... kind of a mess (i give a wet crap about MP)... but then again,i liked the atmosphere and the vague MOO2 feeling of it.So the fact that SD 2 is turn-based + the discount for owners of SD 1 made me get it.After all this years... this is as close to MOO 2 Feeling  as one can expect, i guess.*wipes a tear out of his fur* ... all those yea... nvm, where was i? A, right.(Don't forget, that if you are REALLY an old fan who sank a few hundret hours into MMO2, you WILL have a huge nostalgica-bonus in mind, after all we was young when we played that... almost 20 years ago...   ♥♥♥♥, i am old...)  )I wasn't stroke by any of the release-day bugs so i could have a look in a lot of stuff (didn't tried the ground battle so far, but for it is automatable who cares. Seems to be a nice little game-in-the-game from the cb-reviews i saw).It looks really good, better than i had expected to be honest.Graphical as well as UI- and Gameplaywise. It feels rounded, polished and ready for a full release.It is not overcomplex, personally i would like to have rather 1000 instead of 100 systems and 90 instead of 9 races at soem point, but well, you can't have all. ("All" would be a mix between this one and Armada 2526 ... )It is however   FINALLY  an enhanced MMO2, that is the best and most fitting way to describe it.I could write more, but there is a certain space-slug that just ate my discovery ship.And i really liked that ship, you know?There are a few really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Vulfar now and that space-slug will... nvm...Even without the discount, if you are a member in the Old-farts-wants-a-modern-MMO2-game-club,here you go.I wasn't really happy with SD 1, but if it was the price for SD 2 i don't regret a cent or an hour.
