content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I think I can sum up the game in one word: tedious. StarDrive 2 is a modern remake of Masters of Orion 2. It adds some neat features, like placing modules in specific quadrants of the ship but takes away on some of the others. I'll try to break down some of the main areas.Colony Management - It's very tedious, much like MoO2. There are some auto-builder scripts you can select from to focus on food, research, or production. But, when I pick one like production, the manager often moves some of the people off of production and over to research. If I try to correct this, the colony goes back to manual mode. Also, you may inadvertently get technology for colony buildings you don't want (some have drawbacks), and these will get rolled into the build queue by the colony "AI".Ship Combat - Actually the best part of the game. It plays similar to Homeworld, but without the bells and whistles that make Homeworld cool. You can't pause combat, which makes any kind of tactics pretty much impossible so you end up charging in with everything you got. Fighters are essentially unselectable as they flit about the main ships of your fleet. Still, it's satisfying to watch your enemy ships explode into debris.Ship Design - The design is another aspect of the game that is fairly good, but still lacks something. I found that at the end of the game, lasers were still on par with the best tech in the game. Either my math was way off, or there's really no reason to try new guns. In MoO2, it was fun to try out different weapon types, especially boarding enemy ships. But, I just didn't feel the same enthusiasm here.Ground Combat - Very very tedious. Similar to ship design, a lot of the tech you get for ground combat is useless. The skeletal upgrade gives +20 max HP but leaves your soldier wounded by 20 HP. Since they don't naturally heal out of combat (until late game), the upgrade is pointless. Guns like the fusion carbine will do 20% more damage against unarmored foes, but 86% less against anyone with armor, which is pretty much everybody. The AI is really stupid too. You can stand still and let the enemies exhaust themselves walking into your firing line of fresh troops. However, if you press Auto before combat, you're likely to lose a ton of troops than you wouldn't lose by playing out the combat. Also, Mech Units are very disappointing. They are very slow which makes me just want to use regular troops more. (The dinosaurs with lasers are pretty awesome though I must admit). Also, you must equip every single troop. If the enemy invades a far off planet and you didn't equip those troops with the latest tech, they are likely to be holding stupid worthless knives and get rolled. All the clicking involved here is very tedious, it would be nice to set a master template automatically used for all new troops.Research - Sad. I don't recall ever looking at a research screen in a 4x game and thinking "wow, I don't want to research any of this". Not until StarDrive 2 anyway. Many of the "upgrades" come with drawbacks. Like, you can grow food on radiated planets but it makes your people mad. Or the aforementioned carbine rifle, or pretty much any ship weapon. Some of the colony upgrades are very useful, but incur heavy upkeep fees which force you to raise taxes so much that you lose any additional productivity from the buildings. If the upgrades didn't have so many drawbacks, it would be so much better.Spying - I didn't try this much because it seemed too slow to be useful. You send spies in and they gather intelligence points which you use to plant a mole... which then gathers research points... which finally delivers enemy tech to you. But the enemy's spy network can destroy your mole fairly fast meaning you probably never steal any tech. It's far easier to just assimilate it or trade for it.Diplomacy - It's not great. You can trade for tech, but it raises this intolerance meter which requires time to cooldown. The other races are quick to declare war, on Normal difficulty, even when you have great rapport with them. This is something I expect at higher difficulty levels, but not Normal. I do like how the items offered in trade have point values so you can quickly tell how likely they are to accept.GUI - Sometimes my fleets would split up, especially after an invasion. One time I saw a fleet that said it would arrive in NaN turns (not a number!) and just froze in space. If you click on a planet from too far of a zoom, you won't be taken to the colony even though it highlights. The GUI just feels like it needs too many clicks to get what I want done.Overall - The game just feels tedious. I got to where I owned half the galaxy versus three small remaining alien races. I could tell it would be another four to five hours of clicking to finish the game when I decided to just uninstall it. It seems like it has a lot of potential though, and there aren't a ton of bugs. Fix the colony AI, add troop auto-equip, make the tech more enticing, UN-balance the ship weapons and I think you'd be on to something.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I'm a huge 4X strategy gamer and think that, for the most part, this is what Master of Orion 3 should have been.  This game begs for comparisons against MOO2 because many of its features are straight from the game and other predecessors, which is perfectly fine by me.  I actually prefer strategy games that build on the best aspects from prior games rather than trying to reinvent the wheel.The Major Gripes:- No multiplayer.  Unfortunately, the AI is just not smart enough to maintain my interest, so after 50+ hours, I'm probably done with this game, which is kinda sad because its very solid- The AI is dumb.  I play on the hardest setting and there's just never a point where I don't have the upper hand.  I'm absolutely baffled by all of the reviews on here that say the game is too hard.  If you build two of the largest size ships you can build (with the original starting tech), no enemy player can touch you for quite a while.  Now, I don't mean to say that the AI is particularly dumb in this game.  Its not.  The stupidity of the AI, unfortunately, is a problem that spans most 4x space strategy games like this (I'm looking at you SOTS 2, MOO3, Gal Civ 3, Civ 5, etc).  However, without multiplayer, that sorta ends the game.Random Musings:-  Designing ships is fun and just complicated enough without being too complicated and there's a lot of viable approaches to take.  Make ships super fast and give them devastating close combat weapons or slow your ships down with lots of long range artillery and kill the enemy before they get to you.  - I've never found any use for building smaller than the largest ships.  The AI hasn't seemed to figure that out though, so my fleets always completely annihilate them (even on the games hardest setting).- Unfortunately, without multiplayer or a brilliant AI, your enemies will never adapt to any of your strategies, so you'll never need to vary them up.- Turn based strategy map with real time combat space combat is my favorite combination in strategy games, but this is probably a personal preference.- You can specialize worlds.  Have a very fertile planet?  Make it your bread basket.  - Its pretty.  Its not going to win any awards, but its crisp and attractive and not a throwback to the 90s like Distant Worlds.- Ground combat is xcom style, but unfortunately its very limited to not being worth playing at this point.  The AI is particularly easy in ground combat once you figure out how to use shields properly.- Its got solid game mechanics.  The economy is complicated enough to be fun, and simple enough to not be tedious.

Posted: June 6, 2016
												This game, Star Drive 2, looked promising until I played it. Among the problems are the fact that most of the game settings won't apply when you play the game. A good example is the setting to keep minor races from attacking you. It simply doesn't work. And, to add insult to injury, they are usually far superior to your capabilities if encountered at the beginning of the game. Out of several games I attempted to play, I encountered the same problem every time. In many of the games, I had it set up with a single opponenet, that I never got to encounter. In the others, the enemy ended up being right next door. There was never a chance to get off the ground.The one game I did make considerable progress with included several possible enemies but ended prematurely, and abitrarilly, because the game simply stops. It counts x number of turns and then notifies you that the game is over. What kind of idiot designed this into a game like this? Again, one of the settings is for game length and has an "Epic" setting. I doubt, like the other settings, that it actually works. The game should at least have an open ended option and finish only when a victor has satisfied the victory conditions or conquered the galaxy.This is sad because this game looks like it has a lot of potential. That's why I bought it. The economics, tech advancement and colinization all work very well. It was everything I wanted in those respects, but the other aspects, as described above, make this one a real loser. It's too bad.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												Star Drive 2 attempts to improve upon the original by stream lining many of the tediuos aspects of the first and bring the juiciest parts to the fore, such as automating planetary invasions and trade, something that became obnoxiously boring in SD1's late game; and for the most part it has achieved this. Trading is practically automatic as long as you have the freighters available, but you cannot command said freighters, so they frequently wander into hostile threats (environmental encounters such as pirate or crystal fleets, but also faction blockades) with no way of preventing them from doing so (as you could manually in SD1). So your entire freighter fleet will smash itself into these threats until entirely exhuasted or the threat is removed. At least these fleets no longer require maintanence or their own custom builds.The AI's difficulty appears reliant on its handicaps rather than actual complex decision making. As a player you have a set of rules you need to abide by, which the AI apparently does not. Which effectively makes the campaigns cheap and unsatisfying:The AI frequently ignores your borders and settles within them even though if you were to do the same it'd require a declaration of war. Additionally the AI frequently ignores starbases even though again, for you to pass through AI controlled space would require a declaration of war. Which removes practically half the tactical decision making you could apply on the tactical map, such as controlling choke points between nebula's or specific hex's with wormholes in them via use of starbases. Additionally, this lack of respect for territory affords the AI to pre-emptively strike from within your own territory.The AI's overzealous efficiency even on easy mode causes it to pull ahead technologically, economically and militarily, making the game incredibly difficult to learn what mistakes are actually being made by the player and how to correct them as these issues often snowball and often before you even notice a problem has arised.It is generally accepted by the community that cheese is not a viable tactic (as it once was in SD1) as any conflict is too expensive for the player. Not only will you unlikely have the tech to send a fleet into deep space, but fluctuations in military strength has immediate repercussians from all enemy factions who will either begin to bully, if not outright just invade you, resulting in immediate game over; and the accepted status quo of the AI always being ahead in tech leads to the (ironically) incredibly tedious gameplay of "just surviving" until the late game when you can catch up to the technological cap and finally fight on equal footing with the other factions.It must be said though that the community is generally very supportive and has excellent advice to give out so you can learn the elusive curve the game has.Balance in general is also quite bad. Whilst i'm willing to give a certain amount of leeway to developers producing assymetrical strategy games, which are inherently difficult to balance, some elements just don't really bare thinking about and its any wonder how some of these got past paper planning, let alone pre and post testing. Some racial traits are just ridiculously powerful for their points cost, Subterranian is an obvious one and aquatic to a lesser extent are very strong, relatively cheap traits that can essentially double your economic output over other races for little to no penalty. This results in the same races dominating every game.Lastly, due to the introduction of the CP (command point) system that affectively applies a population cap to your fleet, it inhibits half the influence you ever had over the other factions diplomatically as you can never effectively intimidate with your fleet as it is essentially always the same size (if not smaller).The game has some glaringly obvious issues that seem to be fairly simple to fix. Make the AI less obnoxiously relentless, make the AI conform to the same rules as the player, address basic balance issues such as OP racial traits, address "all" the races being obnoxiously hostile despite the hints that they have "personalities". None of which seem particularly dramatic in terms of work load to achieve.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22
												Too much Civilization; not enough Ascendancy.I've been looking for a successor to Ascendancy since it doesn't appear that Logic Factory cares to do much with the IP, and copies of the game are online-order only at this point (from places like Amazon).  After seeing the ship construction menu, I was hopeful that this game could fit the bill.  Unfortunately, it does not.The early game can be quite fun, as are most exploration-style games.  Finding habitable planets and pushing through the tech tree to get bigger and better ship models and construction options is always great.  However, I find that the gameplay and mechanics beyond that (and even including those facets) is basically just a reskin of Civilization titles, and the aforementioned are really all the pros this game has.As for cons, there are quite a few that make the game unenjoyable as a title.  This is a space game, but the map and battles are all 2-D.  The PC knows all the algorithyms, and plays at a high level, even on easier modes.  They expand faster, research tech more  efficiently, and have an endless number of spies, which the player can never hope to match.  They seem unrestrained by that which confines you.  And in a diplomacy game where races will declare war on you with little warning and even less provocation, the fact that there is no "alliance" option is really inexcusable.Overall, it's a nice title if, and only if, you are a huge fan of Civilization and have some way of either running the game using the AI's algorithyms, or overcoming them in some fashion.  Otherwise, just buy Ascendancy off Amazon, as I intend to do.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												After watching a couple of gameplay videos that came out after the Sector Zero DLC was released I finally decided to give this game a try when both items were on sale (pretty much the same as when I go watch a movie I already know I won't enjoy so much, but don't mind the price of the ticket thinking I'd rather be busy for the duration than the alternative). Just like Stardrive 1, I saw the potential of some of the features of this 2nd game, although in the same fashion I was almost always disappointed by their implementation, feeling like the developper sometimes did not even realize how good his own ideas could have been if just a bit more passion had been put into polishing those specific features.There is - or there was? - a potentially very good game again in SD2 (as it could have been in SD1) but once more the fact the game is crippled by a sheer amount of bugs, a clunky UI lacking ergonomy, and that overall many of the features lack "that little something" that would have made them awesome. Also, while there are difficulty levels and several options to activate or not it is pretty clear there is a balancing issue (try playing brutal x4 without deactivating the attack events and you'll most likely get crushed by a master remnant fleet around turn 100 or something (6 shielded mid size ships using disabling EMP attacks and having very decent firepower), and if you miraculously manage to beat that fleet, good luck with catching up with the AI empires after focusing on building your military till that point in game).While tons of references to "geek culture" in sci-fi/fantasy fields can be found in the flavor text, they sadly get old pretty quick (provided they were "fun" in the first place) and sadly don't add enough to the enjoyment for the player to forget or in some cases forgive the effort put in those instead of making the core game much more solid in every critical aspect.But at the end, this 4X can deliver its share of fun and has a bit of replayability especially when you try to optimize custom races for some specific playstyles.I would never ever recommend it on full price though (its simply too expensive for a half-baked product to fully back it), I could say it's a ok game game that could provide you with several hours of fun and is somehow challenging, at least if you don't encounter game breaking bugs (I did encounter mostly UI display bugs and UI functionality bugs on my side). But if you are tight on budget and want a polished game that will last in your shiny library, it would be wise to avoid this one which has big chances to end up in your bin (of shame?) at some point.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Stardrive 2 is one of the best 4X games I've played recently, certainly the best game based in space. It has some minor issues, but none that can't be easily resolved with some time post-release. Pros:Great empire managementGreat ship design (One of my favorite parts of the game)Tech tree that forces strategic decisions (Unlike Civ tech tree where you always end up with everything)Difficult to win (I really am sick of strategy games where victory is assured on all difficulties except the very highest)Enjoyable ship combatGood graphicsCons:Various bugs, though not terribly commonHuge battles very CPU heavy (Playing on a Phenom II x4 840t, so not a great processor)Some weapon balance problemsNo multiplayer (This isn't a huge problem for me personally, but I know people who won't play games if it doesn't have multiplayer)Overall, the game has a great set of mechanics that will only get better as the dev polishes up the remaining content. 9/11, would certainly recommend it to anyone who likes strategy, or sci-fi epics.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												What a festering piece of garbage.I can't even believe that zero took a (slightly flawed) masterpiece that was SD1 and turned it into this turd. Dumbed down in every sense - with a terrible, boring and half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ground combat game bolted onto the side (why?? - why would you cheapen your game by tacking on a high school comp sci project level element?). Space combat is uninspiring at best - yes you get to watch your ships sit there for 5+ minutes because they can't kill a lone fighter (watch angry joe fast forward through it here: https://youtu.be/pHwEI7PKorE?t=13m10s)The cheating AI and remnants are completely over-powered. Played my first (and probably ony) game on normal. First remnant invasion destroyed my entire fleet, and a starbase without even losing their shields - and I was at my max command point size with the best tech I had available. And somehow a neighboring race (with the same empire size) declared war *without me even noticing* (is there not a diplomatic declaration of war??? if so it's effing bugged!) and had an invasion fleet 4x larger than my now destroyed fleet at my capital (which of course fell immediately). To add insult to injury - the fail screen (which I auto-turned to see) is a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ condescending "joke" with ZERO analysis of your "score" - apparently I performed at the level of a large rock - which is "still better than Janeway".All other bad reviews are right too - tiny galaxy, bland combat, weakened ship design system.Disapointing. Do not buy. Get Star Ruler 2 instead.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Just like with the first Stardrive, it took me a while to get the hang of this game. The way the AI worked, the combat system, the whole game really. I hated it. Just like I hated the first Stardrive. You know what I did though? I kept at it, until finally, I got the hang of it. I loved Stardrive after that and I was expecting something different from the sequel. I was a little disappointed, but you can't always get exactly the things you want. No, this game isnt exactly Stardrive. It's Stardrive 2. It's great in it's own way, JUST like Stardrive was.Just because it isn't exactly what some people were expecting doesn't mean it's a bad game. It took me almost two whole days to actually start enjoying this game. Now that I figured it out, I love it. If you liked Stardrive, then try this one out. It's a different experience but it's great all the same. If it's not for you, then it just isn't. No need to leave a bad review on OPENING DAY because it has problems or doesn't meet your expectations. This guy, Zero, put out two patches almost right on top of each other after listening to peoples complaints and bug reports. Where else do you get  service like that for your games? You don't, or at least not anywhere else in my experience. Be happy about that at least.Anyway, in conclusion I suppose, this game isn't exactly Stardrive, if you want that play Stardrive by all means it's a great game. So is this game, it just takes some time to adjust. The "customer service" from these developers is insanely good. Don't like something or think its broken? Bring it up, they'll probably fix it. Buy this game if you like Stardrive, or space games, or 4Xs. You'll enjoy it if you do.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												StarDrive 2 review: comparison to Master of Orion 2.The short of it:This feels like an overhaul to Master of Orion 2. Slightly buggy, but I found it more fun than MOO2 (!!!).The long of it:Compared to the initial StarDrive, this game removes a lot of mechanics (real-time play, space battles integrated in the strategic/galaxy view, ability to research the whole tech-tree), making it less of a successor to SD1 and more of a spiritual successor to Master of Orion 2.It plays almost the same way, with some added complexity (real-time space battles, ground battles, empire resupply range), while updating the UI to make the game play faster (sortable planet list, fewer clicks required to do most actions etc.).I played MOO2 and SD2 side-by-side, and I had more fun with SD2, especially due to MOO2's ponderous interface. Also, SD2 has a bit more *oomph* during battles, better spy mechanics and more race options. So, I'll say that SD2 does almost everything the same as MOO2, some things better, and I'll just list the (potential) drawbacks:- [edit: mostly fixed:] still slightly buggy, still slightly unbalanced, but stable and patched often.- tactical space battles replaced with real-time batles. Faster games, more ships, but less control.- ground combat is quite simple. Tactics, research, quests and individual equipment decisions make a huge difference, and this reactivity makes it fun.- [edit: Fixed! Game is much less micro-intensive now:] no auto-build/governor. The game slows down in the later stages because of this big issue.- no ship capture / scrap to get techs mechanic.- some racial traits, technologies, ship modifications and mechanics "missing", like converting Gas Giants/Asteroid Belts into planets, Core Dumps to get rid of pollution, and many end-game MOO2 niceties. Some new mechanics do compensate (ability to colonise Asteroid Belts, racial trait to generate less polution).Overall, I had a lot of fun with this game, and I give it a 19/20.Belter Pride.---Edit:After playing more of the game, I did encounter more bugs, including the switch sides one (where I get to control only the ships of my enemy in combat). Still, game support and update has been good, and so is stability. I also love the developer's hesitance to nerf, and desire to seek alternate solutions for balance (i.e. counter).I would lower my score to 17/20, but still remains very much recommended.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Fair disclosure, I'm a alpha/beta tester of this game. Sunk a good 200 hours of time into this game throughout it's development cycle.This game styles itself as a kind of spiritual successor to MoO2. It's a mix of turn based strategy with real time tactical combat. Because the game instances the fights, similar to Total War (But in space), the game is able to support hundreds of fleets, and thousands of ships in the same galaxy.The main feature of this game is that, like in SD1, you design the ships you take into combat. There's a few pictures on the store page that depict it. You can design your ships to do whatever you want them to do in combat. You can load them down with fighter bays and kill your enemies with bug bites, artillery ships that stay far back and lob Gauss cannon rounds and torpedoes, short range anti-fighter ships with beam and flak weaponry, or ships that combine multiple features. By far, this is one of my favorite features of the game. There's nothing like designing your own fleets to send against your enemies.The replayability is also great because of the customization options for your species, and because each species gets their own unique technologies. Both ground combat and space combat can be autoresolved based upon the relative strength of your forces VS the enemy's forces. This is helpful in the late game, when there are a lot of small skirmishes (Which I usually autoresolve) and a few huge battles (Which I command myself).All in all, I think this is a wonderful 4x game. I'd suggest it to anyone who enjoys strategy/4x games, and for sure anyone who played and enjoyed MoO2.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												The long and short of it is that this is the Space 4x we've been waiting for for 20 years. Were you disappointed in games like Endless Space, Horizon or Galactic Civilizations, games that ALMOST delivered what they promised but fell short in key areas? This game is for you. Taking cues from Master of Orion, and building on the first installment, this game feels like it hit a nearly perfect storm.The planet management is deep, but not overly complex, the tech trees are interesting, exploration system is finely tuned, and the combat is a blast. Space combat is visceral and fun. Ground combat is a little bare bones, but deeper than it appears on the surface, and very difficult and satisfying.There are many approaches to situations, and the dynamics between you and the rest of the galaxy is interesting and fun.It isn't the perfect Space 4X, but that game hasn't been made yet. This is the best one made in modern times. Pick it up if you are a fan of the genre or have been sitting around since Master of Orion 2 wondering why someone couldn't do better in 20 damned years. Is it better than MOO2? I don't know, but it's a damned fine game.Highly recommended, this game is a blast and a half.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												The game is very Masters of Orion-esc.  I have played stardrive and many many other 4x games.  Probably my favorite Genre.  Honestly i was on the fence about this one.  I didn't know if i wanted to spend the money and jump in, but after watching some lets plays, I had to try it.  The Good: Stardrive ship customization. Probably the biggest thing here.  You can literally make any ship you want and make it work, Its based on these little squars blocks outlining your ships interior and its 4 quadrents.  Each quadrent having a different gun facing and its own hps.The 4x-ness- spying, diplomacy, trading, combat. Multiply paths to victory.  Side missions and quest.  Which i might add can be harder than some of the AI players. The fact that there is ground combat. So, This is also a negative but still the fact they they at least have something representing ground combat is good from the point of future development.They game iteslf is Turnbased, but the combat is real time in an instanced battlefield.  I really like this!  One thing I didnt like about Stardrive 1 was that a battle would be really messy and meander all over the place. Some might like that, but for me having an actually formal engagement really made this fun for me. It also opens up battle arena that is also in the game.  So less persistant RTS and more Gratuitous space battles.The look and asthetic is well done. Hard to believe they have such a small team working on it.  The bad:Some things are half done or not fully fleshed out.  Ground combat needs a lot more love, but it is still enjoyable for me. There are some bugs here and there that need fixingMany racial weapons/tech/ship layouts are unbalanced or non existant.  I.e Kulrathi have their own melee weapon and defensive skill for ground combat, and they have tech that furthers this in the ???? tree for research. Pollops and Squids have it also, but races like human Vulfar chukk are kind of out in the cold.  Not to mention an optri cruiser has almost 2x the space to put modules on it than the vulfar.  I know that this is being looked at but for now its in the negative column as it directly effects the game in a big way. The game to me seems more like a beta, but I am a purist that believe games are not launched until they are ready and polished. Conclusion: ok so I would not have recommended this game when it launched, but in just a few days the developer released so many big changes in under a week that I had to take the plunge.  Sure, is it not finished and buggy. Yes, but I would rather have a game where the developer is constantly updating it to make it better than a ok game that gets and update every 6 months to a year.

number of helpful: 28 of 47 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												StarDrive 2 is a refreshing game to the old 4X genre and I really would like to recommend and here are the reasons why.The main reason, for not recommending it, is that I feel it is incomplete. Both in features and bugs. It is a shame though because the game is surprisingly well done. The UI is fluid and pleasant to look at (contrary to Galactic Civilizations 3). It has both tactical space and ground combat. It has beautifully rendered planets and the map is organised and does not become cluttered when you zoom out (again unlike Galactic Civilizations 3). But where it fails is in two areas.The game is incomplete. The ground combat is woefully underdeveloped, diplomacy is not very well done, building starbases is almost useless (except getting command points) and it takes way too quick to max out research techs which makes the game almost feel like a rush-type 4X game. The tactical combat, although refreshingly good for a 4X game, is not balanced and the different weapons and defence system can range from really good to practically useless.Then you have the lack of variety of ships where every race has only one ship model per tier.And then ofcourse you have the bugs. The worse is probably when you invade a planet and sometimes you are in control of your enemies(!) units instead of yours. It is nothing that can't be fixed but still reduce the gameplay quite a lot.That being said there are a lot of good things with the game. I already mentioned the good UI and tactical combat and how you fit your ships is really nice with a lot of cool weapons and utility modules. Sadly though that the rest of the game has so many problems because this is truly amazing game if you take into account the fact that it was developed by only one person.That being said, I found it well worth the money because you can replay it quite a lot. So despite the lack of bugs and incomplete areas, it will still give you some fun for your money.

												I was a beta tester and so i have had the game for a long long while. but... most of that play was just pointing out issues and commenting on things.And working on blackbox for sd1. A lot of time working on blackbox....I didnt really play the game as a game until it was released because i wanted to wait to play the real thing.I was not thrilled about the game being TBS. I know people like that but I really dig 4x RTS. being tbs was a big turn off to me.But... It works here. i can take my time. put it down to do something else. I still am much more attracted to RTS 4x but something about this game i find very engaging. I think its the ship design and how it fits in with the game.I find there is a connection between ship design and strategic use of the ships. research labs on a ship provide research points and provide ship combat function.sensors are useful.i find myself making my own command ships. ships with larger bridges and long range weapons and sensors and what not designed to give the rest of the more combat ships a better strategic use.I find myself making diverse fleets of ships with specific roles and not just mobs of super combat ships.I like that a lot. Thats not a feeling i get in a lot of these games where the ship design feels part of overall game.There are also all these mini quests and adventures. like what sd1 what trying to do with the revoran and such but did not make it and some of these quests are just killer in concept.but... There are launch bugs. Ill update this review in week or so and see where its at. There are not a lot of game breaking bugs. the one i hit was in the ground combat with deployable shields where i put the shields down in such a way that blocked my progress and it stuck me. no way forward no way out.those kinds of things will make me put a game down pretty quick but that is the only one i found like that and its avoidable.there are other bugs that muck up the gameplay too but i havent hit them.Final word... I enjoy this game. i dont say that lightly. I find it engaging and entertaining. Making my ship designs and feeling like they are mine and they make a difference and have a unique kind of role makes me feel part of the game.People say the AI is hard. i have not found that but i say thats good. I want a good AI. I dont want it to cheat. I want it to smartly kick my♥♥♥♥♥ edit. the AI is not really all that good. it has an initial good economic model that will cause people looking to take it easy a hard time but once the player learns the game they will stomp the ai currently.dev is still working on that. game is still pretty fun though.

												First off I never played Stardrive 1. But I would rate this an above average 4x game.Like Endless space planetary management with realtime space battles. Only con is the ground battles, which are noticable neglected. Planet layout, and tech tree are simmilar to endless space. Space view has high detail, easy to manage. You can manage the individual buildings on a colony simmilar to Masters of Orion. You can only reasearch one tech in three. This forces you to trade via diplomacy or steal with spies. A good game mechanic. Diplomacy is transparent and fair. Tooltips tell you all the bonuses, makes it easy to navigate alian diplomacy. Real time space battles are very good. You send in your custom designed starships, and let em duke it out. Not much in the way of stratigy. Just who has bigger guns and more armor. Wide variety of webs makes it interesting. I'm alwase testing new ship designs. Only con I have is that ground battles suck. The graphics are very poor in this section. Your troops are put on a chess board, and attack a few times per turn. Really boring. If it wasn't so crusial to defending my planets.  I would never use it. Overall 8/10. Probbably the best 4x game out right now. But that isn't saying much. The genere has been neglected for a long time. And with no major titles we are left with this. Good could be bettere. (Improve ground battles or remove them.!!)

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Do I recommend this game? Yes, and no. There are nine awesome races that all have an unique feel. But all these nine are not very well balanced. A race of robot bugs are the most op with a cruiser class ship with as much room as a battleship from other races while the wulfar has very limited space to work with. I would prefer that you could choose a layout you wanted and a look you wanted. You can choose to play the wolves with the same traits as the Robot-bugs, but not the same ship. A bit weird. The map generation is good, you can choose how many opponents, who these opponents will be and if you want random pirates attack. The size of the map can range all the way up to 100 stars, and each star can have up to four planets soo get ready for some exploration.The early game runs really well and with a tech-tree where you only get to choose one of two or three really good upgrades you will feel that your decisions do matter. You'll get a few colonies up and running (more likely than not on barren ultra-poor high G planets but still) and you'll tech up some new fancy moduel like mass drivers for you ships. Now comes the fun part. Building the ships!This is the reason i feel like you should buy this game, The shipbuilding is awesome. You need to carefully think if you really NEED that last cannon or if you should add an other layer of armour. You'll need to think how long this ship will be in battle, is 226 sec enough for a whole battle? Will you need more ammo?I could spend hours in this part of the game.The mid game starts when you have found the other races, some of them will want to trade with you, others will just want to take your hard earned stuff. Here the game falls flat. There is no point of being friendly to the others. There is no such thing as allies in StarDrive 2. Even if the flower-plant-alien loves you to 100% you still have you still have to kill them to win.  If you are combat oriented however you'll do just fine. Late game is weird. If you get here it's too late. One of the other races have half the galaxy and the number of ships in each battle are above 30 capital ships on each side. All with their own massive effects. The number of small ships can be over 60 + fighters(4/module and a ship could have 3-10 of these). It just gets too laggy to play and you'll find that you just want to peace out. How ever, I do recommend this game. There are rumors on the forums that there soon will be a fix to diplomacy. And even just as it is now I cant help but too love it. Seeing your ships destroy 5 times as many as you have is rewarding. Ground combat is fun even if it's a little bare bones. Tending colonies are not the most fun but not the worst either. As for difficulty, the game is kinda easy when you get the hang of it.  Shipbuilding doe! There is no other game that does this as awesome as StarDrive. just oh my god. If you into customization give this game a try! (My english is not the best, thanks for the read anyway! )

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												This game has good ideas and in some parts it is really strong, but it loses its charm because of it's many flaws.I really liked the first part. It felt buggy and weird sometimes but it also felt somehow right and had a lot of good ideas. I never got to finish a match though, because in the end there were always some flaws which made it impossible to continue (always attacking remnant fleets for example which felt immensly like a bug but I couldn't say it was).The second part is similar but loses its real-time focus. In some parts this felt worse: for example my favourite moment from the first game was when ships warped out of a sector and this is gone. But when you play a little bit you get to like the turn-based, more "strategic" command of your fleets. Battles are not taking place in the "real" map, but in special battle areas, similar to the game Gratuitous Space Battles. This is fine I think.But how these fights get started feels often very strange, for example when an enemy fleet is attacking one of your planets and you put your whole fleet there. On the way, however, the enemy is passing another of your planets. The AI clearly didn't intend to attack this other planet, but since it's in the proximity of this planet it starts a battle and you lose a planet. It's strange and there are a lot of those moments in this game.One other example is a remnant fleet attacking your planet, but since it doesn't have ground troops it just blocks it. Now, I don't know if I'm maybe just to stupid to find it, but you can't stop freighters from transporting food. So this planet was constantly spawning my empty freighters and the remnant ships destroyed them instantly. All in all I feel like there is a lot of options from the first part missing (for example the dialoge with alien races) and replaced with strange other things (like the AI television show). All of this feel like it was put in with a lot of vision but it lacks in execution.I couldn't finish a game there either. I played on easy but the AI constantly spammed me with ships which was just so annoying that I stopped playing. Every round in the end-game was micromanaging for me. And not the fun kind. Sorry StarDrive, I really liked your premise and I really hope you improve. I will stay tuned, but in this state I can't recommend you.

number of helpful: 19 of 31 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												It's good. It's very good. In my opinion it doesn't (yet) surpass the incredible MOO2 but it might be the best space 4X to come out since then. That said it is still something of a rough diamond and there is definitely room for improvement, fortunately the developer is generally responding to constructive criticism and I am hopeful that he will continue to refine the game. The good - The whole game oozes personality, ships look amazing, races are well designed and battles are really impressive.There are some really nice innovations. Designing ships is great fun. Interactions with events and minor races are on the whole well implemented and the way these elements play out is both interesting and rewarding.The diplomacy system - it's innovative and I really like it in principle. Although this is countered somewhat by the limited number of diplomatic interactions.The basic game mechanics are a lot like MOO2 and that, for me at least, is a very good thing.The space battles are a great spectacle and a lot of work has clearly gone into them. There are some weapon balance issues but these are already being looked at and patched.It's generally stable, I have experienced no crashes so far and have encountered only one bug, which has already been fixed. As far as I can tell it's in a much better state than SD1 was on release.The bad -There's only one victory condition and it's via the total elimination of all opponents. I have some concerns that the need for complete eliminations will make the late game a boring grind, this is one of the biggest issues with 4X games in general and I am disappointed that SD2 has not addressed it, at least not yet.There's no benchmarking mechanism to see how you compare to your opponents, there's not even a basic score counter. I realise this is personal taste, to an extent, but for me it is a significant issue and I hope to see it addressed soon.The lack of fleet formations, you fleets turn up for battles in any old shape. This means you can either manually arrange every single ship before any battle or just don't bother, I found my approach quickly became the latter option, and that is irritating and immersion breaking.On the whole the bad bits haven't (so far) detracted from my overall enjoyment of what is a fun game with huge potential. I would unquestionably recommend Stardrive 2 even as it is at present and if improvements continue to be made it could just be the true MOO2 successor that many people have been waiting nearly 20 years for.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Yes the game is buggy, those negative reports calling it out are not lying, some might be exagerating but from what I can see a developer is making progress fixing those up... wish it would be happening faster...Having said that, the game is heavily inspired by the all time best 4x classic Master of Orion 2 and borrows a good amount of great ideas from the game while adding some reasonable improvements to the mix (not so much as to spoil and oversaturate a good design with garbage gameplay elements I should say).My absolute favorite is free form fleet movement and removal of space lanes... always hated those and I am glad that I can send my fleet to any position in space, move around my fleet and approach a star system from another side of the star while avoiding that pesky npc fleet that does not let me get to it from the front.As I said before everything else including the tech tree would be imediately familiar to anyone who played MoO2, and I like that. I want a decent remake of MoO2, and so far even the official reboot of the game did not make me feel so close to that old days one then this ameturish, low budget, tiny dev team project.If you are not easily put of by the fact that the game needs alot more bug fixing and polish you might find this game a good throw back to MoO days.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												So here's my review (from someone that has put at least 100 hours into this game).This is a good game... a very good game however be under no illusion of what you are getting. This is a game made on a shoe string budget by what seems to be a single guy. He releases regular patches to fix the things he has broken in previous patches. The graphics are not going to win any awards and the gameplay at the end gets a bit repetitive. With all those negatives, this is actually a really really good game. I would put this in a similar league to tetris when it first came out. It's one of those games that will eat away at your life as you play again and again. The sight of your intergalactic empire sending out fleets of ships to defend against an attacking race is exciting. Will my fleet make it to the planet before I lose it to an invasion, will my state of the art research win the technological arms race and allow me to turn the tide of battle? This game feels how i imagine it must feel to actually control an intergalactic empire.Buy this game but be aware it is not without its faults.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Finally a successor to MOO2! Plays very much like MOO2, same planet management etc and fixes the flaws of SD1 (i.e it's turn-based now). The combat is actually better than the turn-based combat of MOO2, though I was skeptical at first. It's fast enough to be enjoyable, but slow enough that you can give orders to your ships, or just watch how your new designs perform.Research screen is a bit boring but the advances are nice. Some are identical to MOO advances.I like the alien races, though the music doesn't match the MOO diplomacy music. But what does?Ship design screen is simple enough to be intuitive, but complex enough that you can design ships to your requirements.10/10.

Posted: April 10, 2015
												Steam absolutely needs a middle ground between yes and no reccomendations. Everything is here to make a great game, but it just isn't implemented correctly.  Rather than say what I do like, I'm going to tell you what will turn you off from playing once the new game smell has dissappated. The AI just rolls in and mucks about creating all sorts of annoyances.  These aren't annoying because they are challenging, it is because it feels cheap.I absolutely do not enjoy the systems in place for taking over planets.More systems need to be put in place to respect the players time.  My biggest annoyances with any 4x are always late game empire management.  The game does not notify you when a planet isn't working on anything.  There are many very simple yet highly needed UI elements that just sap the enjoyment from the game.So I would say that if you are interested in this game, wait for updates.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												I propose to not buying this game, because there are so many annoying bugs. It never crashes, but very often (at least after *each* fight) you have to wait 1-2 Minutes until you can continue playing. At the moment, I own about 10% of the Universe, but after an usual fight I have to wait 68 seconds until the (mandatory) fight statistics are displayed. After confirming those annoying statistics (they are interesting only the 1st 5 times), the game requires again about 30 seconds to load. Its really annoying that after 1/10 of the game play time it's almost imposible to play the game if you do not just want to ... wait. wait. wait. ... wait.It's really annoying: there is a cool, big tech tree - but no precise descriptions, so that one has to start reverse engineering and try to find the differences.Additionally, one can not research items on the same level. This way I'm playing long time and suddendly I see that I made a wrong researching decision and so I have to hope I can get the missing item on another way. Or once more to realod an old game.It's really annoying that the tech tree does not list numbers and factsand that my engineers forget how to research another item on ab already researched level .

content:
Posted: March 2
												Plusses:HumorMinusses:- No windowed mode.- Poor UI. Ex 1: Only 1 UI window open at a time (would be nice to have fx Roster open a small extra window in Ship Yard, instead of closing Ship Yard). Ex 2: No feedback on stats when designing ships (does this 200% module work on this gun? UI doesn't tell you anything, a decent UI would increase the stats on the gun by 200%. This become double annoying as the game doesn't have windowed mode for when you need to tab out and read the internet for information that should be in the game). Ex 3: No queuing of orders (you have "worker" ships you can send off, but you can't tell them to start work when they arrive). Ex 4: No waypoints, you need to wait until each fleet arrive at each waypoint, then issue them a new order - or accept the (terrible planned) route the game plans for you. Ex 5: No "next worker" or "next idle fleet" button to help locate those workers / fleets you send one step of the way to where they need to be. Ex 6: No way to see what inventions you already have.- Endless number of bugs - the following are only a few:Ex 1: Warnings of planet starving when there is plenty of food on the planet.Ex 2: UI showing 4 free fleets to transfer 24 excess food, but you have a starving planet (actually starving, not just bug), but you need to make 23 excess food then 1 fleet will take 1 of the food and feed the planet.- Specific planet example: Moving 1 person from factory to farmer, should create 2.5 food, but UI says he makes 4 - and that you now have 1 less income from excess food (1 food gives 1 money normally). Not one part matches another.Ex 3: Sensor Range, hidden stats, different parts of UI doesn't agree with each other how much you have - and the stat seems to have been completely removed mechanic wise and you just have 0 or 1 systems view range.Ex 4: Some ships suddenly stop shooting in middle of fight - lots of ammo left, no damage taken, shields on full to prevent neutralizing weapons (and too early in game for them), you can order it to attack - but then it moves like an idiot and ruins your set up (it will at least always turn and ruin your shooting the guns on both sides + front at same time on different enemies + ruin your carefully planned protecting vulnerable ships by blocking shots from the sides) . So choice between bug to 0 damage, or poor command interface it to 0-50% damage (you might turn so slow you never hit again, or at least you will turn some weapons to point at areas with no enemies).There are many more bugs, and it feels more like a battle to get past the bugs, then a game to survive and rule the galaxy.This is written about 8 months after the last release of fixes for the game (fixes released June 2016 - now March 2017), so doesn't seem likely even the worst bugs will ever get fixed.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												(edit) After more play, I have changed my review to thumbs down. We are to version 1.0h, and none of the bugs mentioned below have been addressed. Meanwhile the developer has plans to release a named patch with new features while balance issues still exist. This misplaced sense of priorities makes me think the game will never be balanced, or patched, correctly.The good: It's an addictive 4X game that steals a lot from MOO 2. Many of the tech are taken directly from MOO 2 and choosing one topic locks you out of other choices, just like MOO 2, forcing you to use diplomacy to acquire them. It's a pretty game overall. The switch to turn based play for the galaxy map is a good one. The real time ship battles look great. It has that one more turn feeling. This is Moo 2 brought up to date. That should be good, right?The bad: Here are just some examples to give you an idea of what I'm complaining about. Ship design: it's a fiddly process. The game doesn't remember your previous choices in terms of size and quality of your components, forcing extra clicks as you fine tune your design. Also I have had the game simply refuse to save designs I've spent 10 minutes making, losing my work. Speaking of losing my work, the game will erase your work if you click a new hull. There is no 'mirror mode' that would allow you to quickly apply armor to 2 sides of a ship.The game's soundscape is poor. Some sounds are simply not mixed correctly. The game released with serious balance issues in terms of the different difficulty levels. This has been addressed somewhat in a patch, but still needs work. When being attacked, you can't see the components the enemy ships have. Listening posts and refueling stations have the same icon on the galaxy map, making it impossible to tell which is which at a glance. At the moment, listening posts are bugged and acting like refueling stations. When one of your planets lacks something to build, the on screen notification of that is ridiculously tiny and tucked in the bottom right, making it easy to miss.I hope this gives you an idea of the general state of the game. There are bugs, and there are things that are either just plain wrong, or clunky, when managing your empire. As I said above, the deveoper seems to be more interested in 'building buzz' by releasing a 'superpatch' than polishing his game.

Posted: May 11, 2016
												I love the game. I have no idea why it gets so low reviews, and for me it is the core title for this type for whole generation. Better by large margin than Stellaris or GC3, not to mention other titles trying to be anywhere close. What is bonus for me:- ship customization is vast and makes difference, its not just small adjustments, it all matters- battle tactics, allows you to change result of the battle if you play smart and know what your units advantages and disadvantages are- Technology tree is interesting and very hard to obtain complete there is awlways pick 1 of 3 techs in each branch and each tech level so technology trade makes difference- other races does trade with you (which is sometimes strangely not common in 4x games where AI see you only as thread and they do their best to do not give you anything of value, which was most annoying in Civ series diplomacy)- nice interesting perks for race customization allowing you to make race which is fairly normal or very different from what you could encounter in other places. One of the perks allows you to build Titan size spaceships from the start... but at any stage you cannot build smaller sapceships making it interestingly different experience.- Heroes are very nice and interestingNegatives- tactical unit battle is crude, it can be mostly avoided if you have DLC- no multiplayer

Posted: April 12, 2015
												I'm old... almost 40 ;) and I have seen the birth of Master of Orion I and all succeeding 4X games. Many of them were playable, some were even good, but in 1996, Master of Orion II came out and set the standard for a very long time ... until now! In my opinion, Zero made an update and enhancemend to Master of Orion II! Many tried to, no one succeeded. But Stardrive II will be the historical landmark after 18 years to be the No. 1 in 4X strategies! Yes, the game is not easy. I've never played such a challenging 4X game in 25 years, which was in a playable condition at the same time. They've brought out a finished product at release. That is unfortunately not common since developers can easily patch via Internet. The game needs some tweaks and a bit further development to reflect the issues raised in the feedbacks, like more victory conditions. But the new patch looks very promision and I am convinced, it will soon have reached the polished status, which makes Stardrives the all time No.1 in the 4X genre. They've already reached 95% of the way! In my opinion, they've already written 4X game history!

number of helpful: 13 of 21 people (62%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I currently have logged over 24 hours in game time and felt the need to express my opinion about Stardrive 2. My time with Stardrive 2 has been very up and very down. Let's start with the up's. First the price of the game is competitive with other indi games. Second the races are fairly balanced. Third the tech tree that forces you to skip a particular tech but later aquire it through trade is a fantastic idea, forcing you to expand your playstyle into areas you might not have chosen with diplomacy mattering. Fourth is designing ships. Seeing a ship that you custom built wreck the universe is one of the best parts of the game. Last is having the ship battles being free moving and not on a grid. Gridded ship battles would have been so much easier to create but free moving ships that can dodge with a proper timed burst of speed or be swarmed with smaller ships is the best.Now the worst. Bad starting systems can spell doom on turn one. Having a hero buff three even four planets can be such a huge boost to playability that getting stuck with only one hurts bad. Next is wormholes. Wormholes often give a direct perment route to your home solar system which spells doom for the player as the AI seems to cheat with ship building production. Also on the topic of wormholes a mysterious race will nonstop attack you with much more advanced ships when you least can afford to be attacked from special random wormholes. Most of my playtime was spent turtling due to wormholes. Kind of kills the explore part of 4X. Special research is avaliable but has to be turned on and off with a slider by the user and isn't explained very well. Hell sliders don't work well at all due to zero percise control of the numaric imput. Ships need a testing ground because important battles have been lost because a ship did not function as I believed it would. DO NOT USE MISSLES. Take my word for it. Last is the stability/loading issues. I did have a few nothing a autosave load didn't fix but after patch 1 I cannot load a campaign more than 33% rendering that mode useless. Deleted the game and redownloaded but same issue. I guess I will wait for patch 2. At the moment I feel very torn about the game. It is very much a 4x game but with amazing RTS portions that make it very fun to play but the speed you make contact with hostile AI combined with often lack luster starts can force rerolls untill a viable start can be had. That paired with the INABILITY TO PLAY THE GAME makes it where I cannot recommend the game to anyone who is reading this. Maybe in a month when it has been properly patched but that is another review.

content:
Posted: January 1
												I had figured the developers might have gotten over their over-ambition and would be able to put out a game that's playable.  Instead, we get a game like the last one; too buggy and poorly documented to consider playing.There's this disease going on with developers where they produce this involved game and don't tell you the rules, or they don't think they need to document them, so you have to spend hours and hours finding out how to play the game by exploring it in order to even have a shot at winning.  This is effectively a dumbed-down version of the pay 2 win business model for multiplayer games; the older and more experienced players know all these subtle tricks with the "product" they have bought.  When new players are brought into the game, it's advertised to them they are on-par, that all the shiney things the other players have bought are "just cosmetic" or some such hogwash.  The new players eventually find out that the next level is 100hrs of play, but it's 10 with the xp upgrade for $5.99, and they are continuously strung along one line of over-complicated crap to the next, filling their minds with rules nobody else knows all along.  I'm sure some actuary or analyst is literally sitting there figuring out how to profit-maxiimize players time, it's disgusting.  For multiplayer games, there's always a learning curve, you expect it, especially for good multiplayer FPS games that are not designed to be theatrical garbage.  For single player games, if you do this, your game is a bug-ridden mess.The final straw was forfeiting a battle so I could re-do it as there's no pause button or speed reduce button as far as I can see, in order to do this I use the pre-battle auto-save feature.  Lo and behold, I found out the AI can do multiple combat actions per turn, and so after forfeiting my main fleet so I could restore the save, it immediatly attacks the tankers, which I retreated the same move, creating a new auto-save.  So I can't reatreat ships out of battle but the AI Can?  It's an AI, it plays at an advantage; I've got other AI's building literally a half dozen starbases at the border of my emprire before I've even discovered them.  I'm sure there's some involved explination as to why what the AI did was a valid move that will take 200 hrs of playing\bugtesting this game to find out.  The last version is the same thing.  I've got better things to do with my time than waste it on this crap.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												tl;dr:Very disappointed sequel.(Edit: I left the game running in background when I was elsewhere, that's why I got about 14 hours playing time so I couldn't refund it)If you love SD1, there are some... downgrade... in SD2:First you can't set the weapon's fire angle. The turrets, the point defence systems... everything is preset. You can only extend the coverage angle when in shipyard.Then there's this 'new' engagement screen. In SD1, you fight on the strategy screen, you can choose where, when and how to approach your enemy, insert reinforcement whenever you can, let unimportant battles continue when you focus on other big things, basically you can do everything. In SD2, it's just downgraded to a engagement screen, you must fight the fight(or auto resolve), in an always similar screen(edit: very narrow and fixed battle space), you can't fight more than one battle at the same time, you fight with what you have when battle started, no reinforcement, no real maneuver(edit: you can't even synchronizing speeds of different ships), no positioning except head on assault, no reinforcement(well, I did say this twice lol), you can only finish this battle before you can do anything else. It's just like the Plants vs Zombies with starships.And this 'new' command point/CP system is quite tricky. Your fleet can drain your money dry in just seconds when you exceeded the CP limit. But I didn't have no more interesting to learn how it works.If you like SD1, just skip this one, even it goes in some huge sale off(like how I got it). The only thing you can get, is frustration.

												Played a few months ago and did not keep up with changelogs, so some impressions may be outdated.At first i was excited to find a game similar to Master of Orion that makes use of more recent technology and delivers real time ship battle. Until midgame, StarDrive 2 is allright. In later stages, ship battle turns to fleet battle and performed terribly for me on i5 @3.6GHz which i really didnt expect.Generally the idea is really great, and i do acknowledge that this game is written by a singular dev iirc. After having played for a few hours and having explored the tech and AI behaviour,  unfortunately i would say this title lacks the brilliance and entertainment i expected, as opponents feel hollow and monotoneous.- Ground Combat control feels unrefined and gets boring rather fast.- Interface is faulty and sometimes not clickable- FPS drops to slideshow in real time fleet battle and skipping to result with diverging outcomes ruined the motivation to keep a positive attitude towards a great idea of this game.Alltogether i appreciate this attempt at rebooting great titles like moo2 and galciv, but i can not shake a strong feeling of scepticism about the intentions behind the design and quality of product and thus would advice to wait for further completion or developement before buying it.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												The initial impressions of SD2 are positive. It is exceptionally similar to MOO2. I know it is common to say that when discussing any space 4X game but it is really true in this instance. The pace of the game, the way research is conducted, the complexity and scope of the game is almost exactly like Masters of Orion 2. There were a couple of good ideas from Stardrive 1 that carried over including the factions and the ship builder. I love the graphical style too. If that impression held throughout I would give StarDrive 2 a firm "good" rating. I've never played any 4x that evoked so much from MOO2 which is generally a good thing. The feel of the game is very similar to that classic game, down to the research options. The art style is wonderful, the ship builder is exceptional and the AI is more than competent (in fact, it's brutal). There's a lot to like in the game.But it falls down in a few areas and could use quite a bit of work.The middle to end game is not very good. Every game will devolve into the same pattern - at some point you'll expand too much, your neighbors will get upset and it's just all-out war at that stage. There are no really cool random events to upset the balance of power and no distractions to occupy the player's attention elsewhere. It's a drudgery of cycling through building on planets, pushing units around, auto-resolving battles and repeat. This is a common problem in 4x games but it's magnified here because there is only one victory condition - extermination. Thus the entire endgame falls apart and the whole game breaks down.Which brings me to the next problem......the Victory Conditions. The player has no choice and it becomes very tedious. Instead of building a consensus or achieving enlightenment or fighting some external foe, I'm forced into a policy of being a ruthless warmonger. That's not a lot of fun IMO. The random events are exceptionally limited. Usually it's me getting .5 fewer food per farmer. Big deal. Where are meteor showers or a comet to explore? Where's a powerful earthquake that changes the orbit of a planet, a new resource to be discovered, a really cool derelict ship to add to my fleet, an uprising by an alien species or things like that? The "?" in space tiles seem to be exceptionally limited and not very interesting. The diplomacy system needs work. That's putting it nicely. Diplomacy is a train wreck. I like the fact that we can't spam requests to rob the AI blind, but often I'm so hamstrung I have an option of either a non-aggression pact or a trade agreement because there aren't enough points to get both. Considering I have to do this every 30 or so turns, this part of the game feels woefully underdeveloped. There aren't any options for long-term peace, coalitions or friendships which then leads to the train-wreck ending of extermination because nothing else is possible. I also think the spy system needs work too. I don't feel like the AI is playing the game game when it comes to esponiage. It seems that they have far greater opportunities to take techs from me whereas I have to wait far longer. My spies seem to get caught almost immediately. So this part of the "game" it just shunted aside - I build a half dozen spies, put them on defensive and ignore this aspect. Why? Because building enough spies to accumulate 500 points and THEN using land troops to steal a tech is a heck of a lot of work. Nice idea, but the reward just isn't worth it. Finally, I'd suggest making the actual building portion of the game a bit more interesting. One good thing from Gal Civ 2 were the special tiles that were on planets - some gave more food, others more production, others more science, etc. It made building more strategic in nature and helped foster better planet specialization. I'd love to see something similar in SD2.SD2 has a good foundation. It's just that Zero never expanded upon it - and when he finally did, it was to charge for DLC to fix fundamental, core problems with the base game. SD2 is one of the biggest disappointments in my library because it is so close to being so good but never fulfilled that promise. Thus the base game can not earn a recommendation. Your money is better spent elsewhere.

content:
Posted: February 24
												Game-Version: v1.4 as of 24.02.2017As I have seen no serious review so far, well, here it goes. It is my first, so I'd be glad for productive criticism!I don't really get why, but this game is severly underrated due to people who seemingly aren't capable of handling the not-always-obvious complexity of the game.First of all, I would like to adress a few things mentioned in other reviews:- I have read reviews about massive, "unbeatable" AI star fleets needing the "impossible" amount of 200 Command points. I have 4 Fleets needing 40 CP each, and calculating the combat CP of one of them, I am at 252 due to frigates and corvettes. That is as much as I have to say to this manner.- There are bugs, especially considering random fodder appearing near fleets, fleets which disappear (the fodder will still be there), and so on. I even managed to get into a "resolve ground combat" loop which forced me to alt-F4 out of the game. However, there is no real game breaker so far, as the game saves each turn and before each combat. Most of them are of cosmetic nature. A few (like reappearing dialogue options which unlock the very same science projects) are quite hilarious, but everyone with some kind of memory should be able to handle it.- And here goes my personal favorite:"Spam colony ships.Take over 2/3s of the galaxy.Get your 3 super-powerful fleets wiped from the face of said galaxy by blatantly broken "balance" mechanics for the AI.Uninstall."Nothing to add. Dude, you are at the wrong kind of game. Simply take a look at the huge penelaties over-sized empires ;) (Expanding to fast? You lack all the rest.)So here comes my pro/con, despite the ones already handled:PRO- You can design your own ships, allowing you to create own tactics - do you want specialised ships working together? Do you want an all-rounder? Choose yourself!- Intense depth of gameplay and unbelievable complexity. You play your first 3 campaigns and you are pretty much assured to get the hell blown out of you. Trieing the 4th time, you hopefully know about the fleet mechanics, the economic difficulties and tweaks and the leaders fitting your playstyle. And you will still be beaten, until you mastered the balance between all 4X aspects and rule the galaxy. This is something many 4X games lack in my opinion. And sth that should not be missing at all!- Punishment for unbalanced approaches, if kept over long time. Not like having a massive fleet improves your planetary infrastructure, you know?^^CON- Missing move command for simply rotating a ship in tactical combat? I have tried it for a full of 1min before winning the battle anyway. So far, an attack order is needed, with the target in engagement range, to let the ship rotate onto the target without gaining directional speed. MEH.- Missing rotation in fleet deployment- Missing multiplayer entirely. Although it is turn-based (except space-combat and events).- Bugs. Even if most of them are cosmetical, and no real game-breaker is present, some of them require you to load the latest autosave (which doesn't loose you much, as in any progress at all) or force you to kill the process, may it be with alt-F4 or via the task manager.- Neutral, hostile fleets are simply overpowered in early game. My first playthrough got eXterminated - by the Masters. My second? By the masters. Howling wolves stormed my apartment at the third, so that one is not due to neutrals. Oh wait, my military forces vanquished against them just 2 turns to eXtermination. Who cares. I managed to handle them quite well on later playthroughs, though.- Spy-o-mania. That is completely up to everyone himself to decide, but I simply dislike the massive spam of spies getting in my empire. And later in the game, the whole events-bar gets spammed with killed, "enemy" spies.- Missing possibility to form alliances. This is a major con as it's simply stripping a major part of gameplay and strategic planning.- Enemy factions limited to a number of eight, as remaining peoples to choose from. Why a con? Because tree.All in all I can recommend this title to all hardcore 4X-fans who can oversee cosmetical bugs and got nothing against reloading a savegame every once in a while (as in "every 2-3 hours of gameplay" (I may have been lucky)). But I do mean "hardcore 4X-fans" who got nothing against loosing quite a few times before being able to do anything real, and who intend to get into the complexity of the game before expecting accomplishments. If you are more of the casual player who just wants to game on - well, move on. You will be terribly punished by this game as well as any 4X title worth of his genre.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Excellent addition to any 4 x library.This game came out of the gates deciding not to reinvent the wheel but instead enhance a lot of typical 4 x gameplay options. It feels like the developer has taken many of the best attributes of many 4 x games, added them all together and  then streamlined the process. There are so many interesting aspects of this game. Galactic empire building. Space combat. Diplomacy. And an xcom style ground combat. The custom ship builder is the best in any 4 x space game I've played and the AI offers a true challenge without being given an unfair bonus. This is a challenging game so expect to lose and have to adapt your strategy. That being said, SD2 isn't a perfect game. Having only one victory condition (military  victory) means that you will be going to war early and often. Being beside an aggressive neighbor can be difficult and require you to figure out ways to avoid an early war.Random events in the game are a lot of fun and interesting. But if your unlucky, can cripple a great starting in this game. A wormhole next to your home system that leads to an aggressive race , when your not ready, can make for a quick defeat. Small frustrations aside , this is a great game. Don't let any negative reviews or outspoken forum members sway you from taking a serious look at SD2. One plus SD2 has over any other space 4 x game is it's sly humour. There are many fun and interesting references to nearly every sci fi movie, show and book riddled in the game. It doesn't take itself to seriously and just pokes fun at every stereotype the genre has to offer. This isn't a selling point for some people but it's a great addition that breaks up the raw , tense gameplay from time to time. Watch some lets plays, read some reviews and base your decision on that. It's an excellent addition to any 4 x fans library.

Posted: August 16, 2015
												I would love to recommend this game. It has a lot of promise, but it is simply too unpolished to be considered great or even good. Every game basically starts the same, Same unoriginal encounters, same spawn problems. Even choosing the largest possible map (100 systems) the game always seems to spawn all the races right on top of each other. Meaning that normal 4x expansion and exploration is severely limited as you are effectively boxed in from the start. Ground combat is a joke. It is nearly impossible to defeat the bear race on the ground, they will walk over any garrison you build no matter what tech you have. Other races will often make unreasonable demands, even if you are friendly or allied with them. The Opteris, for example, demanded several of my worlds in order to not declare war on me, even though we were allies at the time. I've also had races declare war on me only a few turns after meeting me. It doesn't seem that the faction relations (good, bad, hostile, whatever) have any bearing on how that race reacts to you. The game does have a decent shipyard though, allowing you to customize any ship with upgrades and new tech to your hearts desire. With time and work put in, the game could be great, but at this time, even after patches, it is still lacking.
