number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I picked this game up when it was on sale when the overall reviews were positive rather than mixed, and I have to say that I am really glad that I did, because it is actually a rather good game with a unique character and sense of humour running through.Most of the negative reviews concentrate on the bugs and difficulty of the game.  I don't really understand this.  I get the occasional bug and have to re-load a save now and then, but it certainly is not bug-ridden as many reviews imply.It is a hard game because your enemies will send massive fleets against you and if you don't manage to defeat them in the first battle and lose your entire fleet, chances are you will not be able to recover.  It is very satisfying when the tide of war turns in your favour.Once you have learnt to design your ships effectively and understand the balance of research, construction, expansion and conquest, you will find progressing through the game very enjoyable because unlike most 4x4 games, it remains a challenge right up to the end.  The AI is clever enough not to engage you in battle unless it thinks it can win.There are little sub-quests and unusual things to be discovered in the galaxy, which keeps you interested when you first start playing.  The ship design aspect is excellent and it's fun to see how the different weapon systems work out.  The aliens are varied and interesting.  Dipolmacy can be very effective and I find I use it a lot more than in most 4x4 games. As it is such a hard game, I'll end my review with some tips.  Keep your ships fast and manoeuvre the fleet manually to avoid the initial barrage of rockets from the enemy.  If your ships are fast and manoeuvrable they can avoid a lot of the slow heavy rockets the AI often likes to use and you can run rings around their ships, attacking them from the rear with laser or beam weapon turrets.  If you have shields and your enemy doesn't, use hit and run tactics to give your shields time to recharge as their armour will be permanently damaged.  If the enemy has shields as well, then keep manoeuvring until they have used all their rockets then close for the kill.Use diplomacy to get the technologies you need if you can't research them.  Shields and good engines will beat a slow and well armoured ship, unless that ship also has shields and equal beam weapons.The Pollops are probably the easiest race to play as, because their ships have so much space for weapon hardpoints.  They are weak in ground combat, but you can blockade the enemy planets to stop them building fleets while you build up your troops.The game is very much inspired by the old MOO2 game and it feels like an improved and modern version of that game.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												i bought this game yesterday and have spent over 10 hours on it since my purchase so i feel like iv had enough time to test my skills. I love the create your own ship aspect, and it being turn based on the star chart it gives a great mix of everything i love. I am an old school red alert fan from back in the 90s, and i love xcom enemy within so this sounded like the complete package!Unfortunately, like many other people all over the net i feel that it is wayyyy to unbalanced. Even on "easy" i rarely get a couple of hours into a campaign before im crushed. The AI seems to either know everything already in terms of research or they have unlimited funds or food in order to focus everything on science. It would have been nice to have an AI that, like some of us, are completely new to the fanchise and will experiment with different research to give a change of pace to battles. Alas, no, new game after new game, its the same get up. same concepts, different factions. Its really no fun getting 2 or 3 hours into any game, only to realise you have absolutely no chance. Its a shame as im rarely taken in to purchase any game at full price.*UPDATE*After 31 hours, i have figured it out. its not  a case that the AI is to difficult, i think beating this game is more about the way you HAVE to play. I tried over and over for the first 10 hours trying different settings and methods of gameplay. Eventually i found one that worked, rendering the AI powerless to my fleets. The key is to hide for as long as possible. I found the easiest way of doing this is to use the "clusters" option. The AI is SUPER fast at playing at the start of the game, but it slows down a lot in the later game. I must have spent about 2-3 hours in game before i met my first enemy, who almost immidately declared war, but was crushed as i had unlocked the titans and he had not. After all the frustrations for the first 10 hours the game actually began to get a lot more fun. If there were any thing in the middle of yes or no i would have chosen that, as i really dont think you should HAVE to play in this manner. You should be able to play whatever strategy you choose. I do love the game, but there are still plenty of things that need fixing. I am sure my "no" to recommendtion will likely change over the next few patches.

number of helpful: 26 of 47 people (55%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
NOT your traditional 4x game4x =  "eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate"This game is heavily combat focused. The only way to win is to eXterminate. From the very beginning, you are met with hyper aggressive ai pirates and crystals entities who invade your space.  The design philosophy here is that you MUST be combat-centric in order to survive and succeed. You MUST focus on military and defenses. This is not a matter of subjective, personal opinion, even the dev has stated this is necessary. And that is why it deviates from the traditional, popular, successful 4x genre that most 4x fans enjoy.  This game is a 0x, 0x, 0x, 1x game. The real problem with the design: No Freedom...this is not an empire building game. It's not an exploration game. It's not a "focus on advancement game". It's not a diplomacy game. It's purely a "do specific actions so you are as efficient as possible." Why? Because the AI is incredibly efficient and does not play as a human being would (flawed) or simulated race would, it plays as a computer trying to be as efficient as possible and does so with no setbacks.I yearn for the days of MOO and MOO2, even Gal Civ series. These were 4x games that did it right. They allowed freedom in how the player would mold their empire and interact with the universe. You have no such freedom here. A 4x game (whether it is set in space or otherwise, typically gives the player the opportunity to focus on non-military philosophies. You can't do that with SD2, it's all about military power and having it as early as possible, and having as much of it as possible.A 4x game typically allows you the freedom to focus on being the most advanced race. You can't with SD2, it's all about military power and having it as early as possible, and having as much of it as possible.I, like many playhers, enjoy turtle races, taking the higher road, the more benevolent path. Focus on maximizing colonies to their fullest potential, maximizing diplomacy, maximizing technology, and having a big stick (advanced military) that is capable or sufficient, but isn't needed for rapid expansion or constant defenses due to hyper-aggressive ai. You can't do that with SD2, it's all about military power and having it as early as possible, and having as much of it as possible.Cool mechanics, good graphics...all goofed up because of silly design choices that require the player to focus on military might or else.SD2 does do some things right, but when it comes to allowing the player to play a variety of strategies and roles...it fails miserably IMO. Easy Mode?A recent patch was implemented to make it "easier" for those who felt the ai was too aggressive. What this did was made it so you had a slightly better chance at combat in the beginning. You still have to focus on establishing a strong military however.In other words, the patch address the concerns of those who wish to focus on combat and aggressive play by making it easier for them to do so...but it does absolutely nothing for the fans of the 4x genre who actually enjoy different strategies other than combat.  You are still requierd to quickly build up a solid defense and military so you can succeed.ConclusionFor those who are wanting a traditional 4x space game like the classic such as Masters of Orion or Galactic Civilization, you will not find it here. You will be heavily disappointed.For those who prefer to play with a very aggressive military, focus on combat and a large or advanced military (as it is required), you will probably enjoy the game.As others have said in the forums, the inspiration for this game does not appear to be the traditional 4x space game, but rather rts games (SC2 for example). The game probably would have been better received if it were an RTS actually as that is the crowd that seems to enjoy it the most. "Combat! Combat! Combat!"  If that isn't your "rallying cry" for what you want in a game...then Star Drive 2 probably isn't going to appeal to you as that is all it is, a space combat sim...and one that you really need to be efficient in as the AI does not make mistakes or cut corners when it comes to building fleets or engaging yours.

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I really wanted to hate this game. I'm a die-hard fan of StarDrive 1, even though it had its quirks and flaws.. I dumped more time than I care to admit into that game. I waited a day or two after release to see how the game fared, because I was a bit apprehensive of all the new changes. Mostly, I thought the transition to turn-based and instanced combat was neat and a cool way to go, but I felt the ship design was severely lacking in comparison to the first game.It is certainly a little less complex than in StarDrive 1, but I couldn't bring myself to dislike it. The ship combat just works out to be so much more fun. The small simplification in ship design has actually served to enhance the whole experience, and makes designing ships take a little more nuanced approach. Ship combat now feels a lot more massive ("slow motion" is awesome and feels more like "cinematic speed", and gives you lots of time to issue commands. I can't even play it in normal speed anymore). On top of this, due to the command point system you tend to value each individual ship far more, especially because they gain experience and can be given names. It certainly makes for a far more immersive experience, when you have a battlefleet of eight or ten heavy cruisers, and each one means something to you, which means battle losses actually make you feel kind of sad. I might have won a great victory over one of the enemy core worlds, but the valiant crews of the UFF Retribution and UFF Valiant, who were with the fleet and served with distinction since the start of the war, did not live to see it. Such is war!There's a little bit for everyone in the game and in ship design/combat -- for the Honor Harrington nerds, ships at long/medium engagement distance loose enormous waves of missiles, which slowly get plinked away by point-defence, flares and jammers as they approach (and it's incredibly entertaining to watch).. for the Star Trek geeks, there's ships which can swing around at breakneck speeds and blast eachother with photon torpedos and phasers. For the Star Wars junkies, there's waves of fighters and big ships with batteries of laser cannons.Ground combat right now is a little bare, but the designer will likely improve this as time goes on. The system itself is certainly a good foundation.As much as I wanted/figured I would dislike this game, I can't help but really enjoy it. For a mostly one-man team, this is still likely the best 4x currently on the market -- or at least will be once some minor issues are fixed and things like ground combat are padded out a bit more.

												I was charmed at first but after a few hours the flaws become really annoying.1. Diplomacy means nothing. Its more of a hunger-games type of AI, it will leave you alone if theres somebody else to kill but as soon as one war is finished it will declare war on you even if you just had multiple good trades and a solid history of friendship with a race.2. AI is ridiculously overpowered. I need to play on easy with a galaxy rich in everything to make up for it, otherwise at some point you get zerged by the AI with its infinite fleet.3. Your population feels more like chess pawns more than anything. Whatever your approval rating is, i have yet to see a revolt. They dont really seem to have expectations, aspirations, your victories or defeat dont seem to affect them at all.4. Ground battles needs work. They arent really fun.5. The only way to know who owns what seems to be with colors. Can we have a little text saying the planet is owned by x race?6. You can have a large empire but only 4 leaders. When you play on large galaxy its not a alot. A system where each star system automatically have a governor with bonus/malus would be a nice addidtion, and replacing the governor could have some kind of impact.Overall its not a bad game, but it needs work to win my recommendation.

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												A perfect example of why some game mechanics, no matter how old, shouldn't be changed.  The real-time "pause every 3 seconds to stop your fleet's ai from being dumb" is just clumsy and aggravating in my opinion; and I think alot of old school 4x fans (and those new to 4x who love the MOO2 gameplay) feel the same way.  It just gives a better foundation for all aspects of the game.From the reviews that I've passed by, almost all had a critique similar to "Diplomacy underwhelming... too much focus on combat".  ...Of the game's major aspects, diplomacy does pale to the rest when it comes to the matter of depth and detail.  However, I'm one of those that prefers to blast my way through and spend hours mastering my own path down the tech-tree.  (Not to mention the new and more fun to use ship editor). And I'd much rather see the devs focus on more tech-tree additions, new random events, and stuff like RTS'able special skills I can unlock and use during combat!Making the ships fun and exciting to watch as they destroy each other seems to be a lost artform. I've been dissapointed countless times with poor or flat out missing combat graphics.  If my end game death-ray has the same graphic as every single beam type weapon in the game, then I'm going to have a bad time.  It's a perfect example of why some gameplay fundamentals just shouldn't be messed with... only added to and refined... and as long as Zero Sum doesn't read to far into today's under-experienced, generic, newgen gamer mentality and pull a "Diablo III", then they will be the first among a painful amount of failed attempts to finally revive and modernize that epic 4x I fell in love with nearly 20 years ago.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I see a lot of negitive reviews on here because the game is hard.This is not a hard game. The AI also DOES NOT CHEAT. It will unsettle most of your 4x game habits. You will not get 50-100 turns of peace to quietly build resources & infastructure and expand to your hearts content. You have to prepare for an attack immediately. It may not come, but it most likely will.It is different than most 4x in that your in danger from turn one. I start every turn with the question, can i fend off an enemy fleet this turn if a wormhole opens up on my homeworld. If i answer no, then build ships. This game heavily rewards players garrisoning units (half command points and no maintanance).The AI is AMAZING! Any game you have ever played where the AI decision making could be exploited and you thought to yourself, I shouldn't be able to do this. The AI is actually very cunning. It will wait for you to launch attacks outside of your teritory, so your ships are low on fuel and have trouble returning to defend. It will steal from you, it will backstab you.There is no science victory, there is no diplomatic victory. You have one goal, domination. You can turtle, but only to counter attack. Yeah, expect the AI to have garrisons.I highly recommend this game. You will have to practice at it to get better. The in game tutorial is excellent. The tooltips are excellent. Do not give up on the game if you start losing. Start another game and instead of building that nice to have thing that gives +1 to whatever, build a ship. =)

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												If there was a mixed review I'd rate it that but right now I'm rating this a NO since its getting mutiple patches a day and seriously needs a lot more work on (AI cheats like hell) . I'm still mostly on the fence on this second game.  If your new to Stardrive and enjoy turn base games like Civ V then you should like this one. On the other hand if you played the first stardrive and enjoyed the free flowing real time feel of being able to build fleets and move them around easily to patrol your empire, set up governors to manage the bulk of a large empire then your in for very very slow and fusterating game. (the first stardrive had its memory bug issues as soon as 700 ships were deployed in game you were on borrowed time any moment the game was going to freeze and crash)   I do like the side quests but the staging needs work especially when you can't zoom out and control your units and they are hidden behind a pop up and you wind up basically stuck since the enemy units refuse to advance. Oneside mission I completely gave up on after I couldn't manuver my units because I couldn't select them because the info boxes were in the way. That seriously needs to be addressed. AI is extremely onesided reminds me very much of the early days of CIV where all empires are super aggressive and would declare war at a drop of a hat especially if you colonize a world after they are introduced to you. Bug they need to fix is the AI spams a huge fleet more than I'd feel is possible with a hand full of worlds.  Or they are so far up the tech tree its ridiclious cheap, one thing I don't like is the AI having the abvility to use my own ship designs. Personally that breaks the game for me why spend an hour building a kickass titian ship that can wipe the floor with every emipre out there and ten minutes late the AI has it and spams 10 of them in five turns while you might be luckly to get 2. For now I'm going to give this one a rest least till most of the bugs are fixed.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Was hoping that developer will do better this time, but he failed. Again. The game is out for 9 month already, and what do we have? Stardrive decided to become more MOO-like, with a few interesting ideas, but it failed at implementation.Space battles: realtime "wall vs wall" style with no tactics involved, you just stand and shoot with arty while your fighters keep enemies occupied. There are abilities, 2 of them, both useless cause you have to activate them for each ship separately. No formation moves. No random stuff like asteroids or junk. Selection often bugs out and selects the wrong ship. There is a slow-mode, but no fast-mode, so in the lategame i just alt-tabed from battle and went for a tea/surf net/whatever. And with lots of stuff in battle it drops to a few FPS, so why didn't he either optimise it or make a turn-based one - i have no idea.Ground battles: oh god. Why did you  even put it in here? It is the most basic turn-based tactical combat I have ever seen. With a separate loading screen. With a really strange battle system, when you have to wait till enemy comes closer so you can shoot a salvo (if you go forward, you will shoot only once). And it lags even more, so you get lags with only a bunch of people fighting.AI: that one is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Declares a war when he has no fleet, demands tribute and uses his fleets REALLY bad. In the first game AI could just raid you everywhere, now he just cheats. Every his planet has a negative income, every his fleet is over his limit (2-5 fleets of that size would eat really A LOT), but he somehow manages to get even more of that stuff.Empire screen: if you copy something from another game that was good, why not to copy ALL the features? That screen lacks half of the functions you would want and expect.Visuals: the only thing that is good and not bugged in that game, but really, how can you make a buggy graphics?Diplomacy: well, already mentioned it in battles and AI section, it is simply ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Races: MOO set of traits, that was, imho, done worse. Why do metal-made creatures eat food and not production? No idea.Planets: a beautiful screen from GalCiv without GalCiv functions. Why would you even bother to do that hex-based map if it is just a simple list of buildings and provides no bonuses for special tiles or connections? And yeah, automatic management of colony is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ too, it places people on farming when planet DOESNT EVEN HAVE IT!Ship design: well, it may be called somewhat good. Except that it is worse than original. And weapons dont show you their DPS.Oh, and I forgot: game is so bugged that even after killing every other race (there are no other win conditions anyway), you dont win. Why? I dont know.The game tries to be a "jack of all trades", but it did not only become "master of none", but it actually failed to be average in every field. If it doesn't get a good patch or update - it is unplayable. Some people ask about DLC, but really, how can you sell us TWICE one product? Cause current version is nothing more but alpha.------------------------update with the first DLCSo now dev actually released it. With propper implementation of what he promised to do in the based game. One detail: it costs the half of the original game. So you will have to buy it or you will not that content in a form it was supposed to be on release. Worst dev's attitute to buyers I have ever seen so far.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I happen to think, now that the Sector Zero DLC is out, that StarDrive 2 is the best space 4X since Master of Orion 2... and it takes A LOT of design cues from that all-time classic.  The tile-based ship design is particularly interesting and I actually like the research system that many people seem to be complaining about.  Rather than being able to research everything in the game you have to choose between one tech for each level of a particular scentific discipline.  It helps differentiate individual empires during a game and gives the player some decisions that can radically alter each playthrough by picking a different technology in the early game.  Perhaps you would rather have each farmer produce an extra 2 food on farmable planets rather than being able to place an airponics(air-grown plants) facility on any planet, including those planets who can't normally be farmed which produces a flat 5 food per turn.  The improved farming technique would add up quite fast, but airponics would make colonizing more hostile planet-types easier...  without airponics they cannot produce food at all which means any potential colonists must import food via freighters.What can I say, I am an absolute sucker for games that force you to make substantial decisions rather than just providing the illusion of making serious decisions.  If you can unlock everything via research then every game will look almost the same, and there is a reason I never could get into games like StarCraft 2 where there seem to be single optimal strategies and deviation or slow fingers means certain doom.:SidMeiersAcePatrolMissionLeader:

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												StarDrive 2 is not by any means, a bad game. That being said, it is incredibly small for a 4x game. After one short play through you will have experienced all the random events and found all the strange anomalys. It's ship designers is a direct downgrade from StarDrive 1, which is a real shame considering that was one of it's best features. The AI isn't horrible, but it also does not act naturally or organically by any means. It will provide a challenge, never researching the wrong tech or mishandling it's economy. The ground combat is a direct improvement over the first game's, with chess-like turn-based battles that are satisfying but easy to win once you know what gear to use and have one of the few heroes who mop the floor with ground based units. The game doesn't take itself seriously enough, with the dialogue of your enemies simply being silly and somewhat childish, which is a unique twist when it comes to the genre but in my opinion not a good choice. Rather than introducing a universe and advanced species with a lot of lore and depth, we get plant like creatures who act cute and cuddly, space bears who act like japanese samurai, and space lycans who act like dumb evil dogs who miracuously managed to get into space. The space battles, although in theory would be fun, are unplayable without a CPU with the minimum power of 3.5 GHz quad-core (even then you will lag with the largest battles) once the AI creates fleets which numbers are in the hundreds, all firing 20 projectiles a second. Late game, this issue renders the game unplayable for a lot of those who have purchased the game, including myself. This is the game breaking issue for me, because although the base game is somewhat underwheling in comparison to other 4x games, if I were able to play into the late game without lagging to death I could add some pretty great mods to turn this into a game I put a bunch of hours into, as well as continue my support for the developer. So overall, the game isn't terrible, but I would not recommend paying more than $15 for it, and that is only if you are really itching for a new 4x game.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												This game is exactly what I was looking for, it hits all the right elements for a deep strategy turn based 4X game.  I am extremely pleased with it's depth (the tech tree is HUGE!), the various races and flavor text are engaging and often a bit humourous, and I have no doubt it will have a ton of replayability as a result.  It's possible this game was once a bit buggy based on older reviews, but I can happily report that as of yet I have encountered no bugs at all, zero!  This is the game that Endless Space should have been (but was too buggy to ever work right).  The only thing lacking at the moment is more modding in the workshop.  This game could potentially have a very long life with additional DLCs and more modding options, but even in it's current state it offers incridible depth and is extremely satisfying to play once you understand it's nuances.  If you are at all fruustrated starting out, just go watch a Let's Play video or two on YouTube and it will quickly allow you to understand the game dynamics so you can dive in and have a blast.  This game is worth it at full price and an absolute must purchase if you can ever see it on sale!

												Lovely game! True descendant of Master of Orion 2  BUT much much better!! I thought i would never see that but it's true. This one is much much better than the new "re-imagined" "master of orion" that has actually no core mechanics of original master of orion 2 and just simplified boring another 4x for younger candy crush generations that can't concentrate on things for more than 10 seconds. This is complicated game but in a very fun and logical way and not in a tedious and unlogical way like Distant Worlds (thought it's almost ok for me game). Those who hesitate which game buy, try this one on evening with lights down and you not gonna regret, the music, graphics, events are so space magic. Another thing, i see that many people are not happy about this game but i got this game only with sector zero expansion. So i never played it without expansion. So may be vanila game without expansion sucks, i don't know BUT i do know that the game with expansion is very fun and very enjoyable! Those of you who didn't try expansion, should try it and you wil change your opinion cause game is really fun.Update:Game has mixed reviews. I found that unfair after i played it. I never played without expansion, so may be vanila game sucks, i don't know. But i do know that game with sector zero is very good, especially compared to other 4x out there. So the fact that game has mixed reviews is totaly unfair at this point. And it's a factor that don't allow new players to buy this game when they see that game has mixed reviews. I did't wanted to buy this game either. I played stardrive long time ago and i hated it. So it was abandonded by dev who wanted to focuse on next one "to make a great game from the start" I remember i was p_issed off and decided never to buy game again cause i thought it would same result. NOW after i played this wonderfull game, Stardrive 2, i understand that it was the only right desicion from developer's side, cause he couldn't focuse on this one (stardrive 2) if he had to use his time and resourses on that sh_itty game stardrive 1. So i am thankfull to developer that he abandonded old stardrive 1 to make this great game Stardrive 2, so that he gave us a lot of fun with this game (ofc i understand it has some minor bugs and so on but he works on them). So as i said above i wasn't gonna buy stardrive 2 cause of stardrive 1 and another fact that stardrive 2 had only mixed reviews. We all know that mixed reviews make players to ignore games. The only fact that made me to buy this game was the "new" master of orion from wargaming. After i read reviews on new "re-imagined" master of orion, i found out that developers decided to dumbify/simplify it for younger candy crush style generation players. They even tok away core game mechanics that made original Master of Orion 2 so great game for many years. So in their forum i read one commentar that Stardrive is true descendant to MoO2. And i decided to give a chance to Stardrive 2 though i had doubts. After i have started to play stardrive 2 the only thing/person i was really pi_ssed of on was me cause i was angry that i haven't bought this game earlier)) This game is indeed true descendant to MoO2 but much much better at all aspects that i can see at least (the only thing that i am not totaly sure is ship combat, i like turnbased but must admit i like combat mechanics in this one a little bit more cause it makes it more alive for me to see and maneuver in real time, move defence ships forward, faster ships around etc - makes more fun than turnbased - i thought i would never say that;) But don't start eternal turnbase combat vs rt discussion - it's not what i am talking about here;)So those of you who didn't play with sector zero expansion try it and you not gonna regret. So those of us who are happy about game are too lazy to write review and that's why this great game has mixed reviews though it's a great game and fans of space 4x like MoO2 deserves to discover this game and have fun with it. So we need to give them such chance. To do that we need to write reviews on this. Good people, do not be indifferent or evil wil take over ;) Go write review on this lovely game!

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												At first this game seems like a realy good 4x game; Diplomacy is ok, Fleet Combat looks nice, General UI seems to be ok but:Ground Warfare is bad realy bad, if you want to gather a Reasonable Ground Army you have a realy Boring gaming session coming right to you: You have to Equip every single Unit manually and you need a lot of them, You have to play through Ground Combat manually cause automatic Attack gives realy bad results. This wouldn`t be as bad if the Ground Combat itself would be fun. the Ground Combat is Round based and you have 2-5 Actions per Unit (or a long move) per Turn and you have to issue every action manually... This takes Ages and is a huge backstep to the Real time Fleet Battles. There are other options though: You can Nuke a planet back to Stoneage or not Waging ground wars. number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Stardrive 2 is clearly another attempt at a modern port of the old classic Master of Orion 2.  I've been waiting for years for someone to do this right... and unfortunately I'm going to have to keep waiting.What's befuddling and frustrating is that after almost 20 years and umpteen attempts, no one has been able to improve on the original's turn-based combat resolution engine.  Every game that tries -- and there have been MANY -- insists on implementing a real-time combat resolution engine -- because, ya know, real-time is better than turn-based, right? -- but all they ever end up giving us is a muddled mess.  In this case, every battle unfolds exactly the same way: every ship charges across the battlefield to point-blank range, and then flies in tight loops back and forth across its target (no collisions in this universe) until one side or the other is completely annihilated.  High-tech weapons and defensees with varied effects seem to make no dfference whatsoever on the AI's tactics.Oh, how I wish some developer would use their brain some day and realize that a turn-based combat engine would be better in this case.  After all, the whole rest of the game is turn-based, so you think they'd recognize the virtue in it.  It's a shame, too, because otherwise Stardrive 2 is pretty good -- mainly because it sticks to the script and slavishly copies MOO2's gameplay.  But the combat resolution engine is the heart of the game, and like every other clone, it just drags Stardrive 2 down from "good", past "mediocre", and straight into "disappointing".

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												I brought the DLC and it's an vast improvement for StarDrive 2. I'm very happy with the way he has set it up. I actually like the hexagon style gameplay and the game has been more streamlined. For example: 1. Ship Design - it is a ton easier to design a warship and not have to worry about the secondary systems or having to line up everything perfectly. Hours could be spent in here but thanks to the streamlined process, I can design the parts I want to mess around with and let the "behind-the-scene" nerdy people figure out how to power it and etc. Excellent improvement. 2. Freighter - this entire process has been automated and I'm vastly relieved as this was too much micro-managing. The AI now does it for you, provided you build enough feighter ships to transport the necessary items to the colonies. 3. AI - the AI has been vastly imporved and I LOVE LOVE LOVE having to deal with pirates, space monsters, and etc. This keeps me on my toe and I can't just send all of my fleets of warships to the border but actually have to watch within the terroritory and intercept any troublesome pirates/space monsters and so fourth. Just a fantastic addition to my gameplay4. Colony Management - this has been streamlined by a huge margin. I do not have to try to micromanage each colony but I can still set a theme of what I woud like the "AI Governor" to follow in building up the colony, such as focus on Science, Food, and etc. Furthermore, I do not have to bother with managing the tile management but only mindful of the total number of buildings there are and plan accordingly. Huge burden been taken off and managed by the AI. However, you still have a lot of control over the colony management but can automate it, if needed. 5. Space Battles - I do think this is an improvement over the StarDrive where we had fighting occuring on the strategy map and that was tough to juggle. Now, it's more streamlined and allows me to focus one thing at a time. I do think there's room for improvement but it's an improvement nonetheless. I do think there's some issues but the developer has been intent on hearing about it and working on fixing it. However, it is far less buggy than it was with the original game. The developer have made it clear that this is just the first release and will continue to improve it. If this is a sign of what's to come then I feel very good about the game improving even more with more content.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												A MUST HAVE! This game is phenomenal! Absolutely, mind-blowingly outstanding! I have done so much in just one night... Conquered planets, went to war twice, enjoyed the awesome diplomacy and unique races, love the leaders that come along too... I ended up have an Elephant man with a futuristic staff governing my people on a desert planet where they happened to harvest spice... Hell YES!           What can I say: 1) Stellar, action packed beautiful Space Combat 2) Awesome turn based ground combat with troops (very functional, fun and unique) 3) In depth and easy ship, weapon and troop customization. 4) Huge (nearly endless) talent trees with special projects that come your way time to time 5) Seriously among the best diplomacy systems of any game 6) Unique races, planets, ship designs, buildings, backgrounds and all sorts of beautiful illustrations accompanying the awesome texts. 7) Outstanding music with a wide variety and appropriate mood changes with events.             If you want a game that would be something like total war in space, then this is your ticket. In fact I would say this is even better than if total war made a space game. There is nothing that I dislike in this game, I honestly feel that it is perfect. I know that I will be back for hundreds of more hours to come! Thank you for making this extraordinary game! It has blown my mind, I truly love it! If you are questioning whether or not you should buy this game, THINK NO MORE! It is aboslutely worth every cent and more. BUY IT! It is one of the BEST GAMES that I have ever played. Can't wait to wake up tomorrow and hop back on!

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Good version of MOO II.  Good tech trees.  Interesting species. Similar character traits.  Thats where my pros end.Boring, slow, space combat. "Tolerance" keeps politics from reaching its full potential.  Poor AI makes for horrible automated fights especially for planet invasions. Fight all your battles yourself.  That said the land battles are painful to be part of.  They are unintuitive, difficult to work through and unrewarding.  I feel like they are punishment for invading.  If you choose "auto" resolve be prepared for ridiculous consequences.  In land combat, Its very common to grossly outnumber your opponent by 50:1 and lose all your troops, and then have the game crash.  I assume its because there is only so much space to place your troops the computer automatically kills them before battle begins.As for space combat, mass driver cannons are overpowered and take out any thought or development from ship creation.   You will need to micromanage your own ships as the AI really is not bright at all and you will find your overpowered ships pulled apart by an unintuitive computer admiral.Overall, not very polished and needs to be updated with some of its bugs adressed. With all of these bugs and oversights I think the worst has to do with pathing.  The pathing problem keeps ships from entering refit queues as they "hop" and "skip" over the planets they should be docking at, this same pathng problem occurs when trying to attack planets or passing fleets.  Of course this is only a problem if you can actually select the ships themselves which is an ordeal, the only thing harder than that is trying to mouse over several ships at once.  A process that works 50% of th etime.Another issue that annoyed me to no end was the "overlays".  When a new menu, map or option was overlaid upon another you could still access the GUI under it, so while trying to build something on a planet economy screen I would actually click the queue on the main map listing all of the items created on the turn before.  Annoying.  All of these problems make it nearly unplayable as these bugs often cause game crashes, forcing me to reload an "autosave", only to lose the last 4-10 turns and the hundreds of actions that likely went with them.  I play it not because I love it, but because for the price point it sucks less than the alternatives out there.  In the end I think I should have saved my money until the problems were adressed rather than having it forced through like so many other "indie"games only to have updates added later. There's a reason it has dropped to half its price and put on sale so many times in two months.Edit ** The first two patches have actually made the game more unplayable.  You can no longer choose to NOT send in your leaders in planet auto combat, so now they die.  THIS MEANS THAT YOU CAN NO LONGER "AUTO COMPLETE" GROUND COMBAT!!-Fleets will now randomly disappear and become unuseable. THIS MAKES GAME COMPLETELY UNPLAYABLE-Added "governnor control" is poorly implemented and far from potential.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												After playing StarDrive 1, I looked forward to getting this sequel as soon as it was announced. SD2 is turn-based on the strategic level while combat is controlled in real-time. SD2 retained much of the character and customizability that enthralled me in the first game. I purchased GalCiv 3 and stopped playing it soon after buying it - not because it was a terrible game but because SD2 was better in all the ways that mattered me. This game contains a good number of quests, special galactic and world events, randomly forming wormholes (short-cuts into unexplored and enemy territories) and more that work to keep the game interesting. After putting over 100 hours into it, I can say I don't regret my decision. My biggest gripe: ground combat. I auto-fight those battles. Apart from that, I recommend this game for anyone who is interested in 4x games.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												If you have not played StarDrive 1 this is a good 4x to pick up. It's fairly easy to start as the creator has a fully voiced tutorial and the game is a little less complex than it's predecessor (be warned if you jump around menu to menu while in a tutorial the tutorial will end and leave you helpless). If you have played the last StarDrive and really wanted this to be a good game, I have bad news and good news. Good news the game isn't broken like the last one and playing for several hours (as I normally do) caused no framedrop or resources hoging. Bad news the game is now a turn based strategy instead of one big realtime. This may not be a bad thing for all of you but it's something to consider, because it is a turn based strategy fleet battles now occur on a different screen. This once again is not really bad but the strategies you can use are limited since you always start on opposing sides and pretty much just clash in the middle every time. The ground combat is dull and managing your foot soldiers is a pain. This combat pops up often and it is rather dull with very little strategy besides shoot the things and not get shot by the things. Certain ground enemies are also really hard to kill for arbitrary reasons and will often cost you a well equiped group of soldiers. Talking about equiping soldiers it's impossible. Soldiers spawn with random gear and more likely than not the worst gear you have. There doesn't seem to be a way to say how many of each soldier you want or to even to limit their selection of items to make sure they spawn with more than a combat knife.All this said I have had a lot of fun with the game. Ship building is what I spend most of my time on but I just wish a few more QOL things were in the ship builder like the health and shields of the ship. Managing your empire is simplified with one screen that shows you ever planet you have, what they are building, worker allocation, and so on and so forth. Tech is kept interesting with multiple routes that you can take. If you take one tech you lose the others and are sort of herded toward using diplomacy to gain the ones you missed or the spying system. Subterfuge is rather simple but does the job with multiple missions that your agents can be sent on.I give this game a thumbs up and I think anyone who enjoys the one more turn mindset of Civ 5 will have a blast wtih this game.

												Awesome game for the most part.  Galaxies could be a bit bigger, then again Im a fan of HUGE galaxies and prolonged games.  The only thing lacking is the multiplayer aspect of the game. content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												I've put over 100 hours into this game, and will continue to do so. In a nutshell - this is a delightful, modern take on the classic Master of Orion series (1 and 2). If you enjoyed MoO, then you will enjoy this.The Good:-Fun, silly nerd humor with excellent art-An involved, intuitive, and complex ship building process as complicated as you want (use the defaults or plan every square)-Defined tech trees and economy-Customization of everything, from races to game modes-Fast and fluid gameplayThe Bad: -Some bugs here and there. The Developer (one guy named Zero) will fix the issues if you clearly identify what the problem is.-Diplomacy and Spying could use a reworkThe Ugly:-For some reason, Zero (and Stardrive) has attracted some "less than positive" community members. I don't really understand it...SD 1 and 2 are very fun, very modestly priced games. ...Conclusion - I highly recommend this game for all 4X fans.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												When evaluating this game, one must bear in mind that it has been made by one person. With this in mind, I have found this game to be very, very impressive. It feels like any 4X made by larger studios, and in some ways surpasses them. It only launched recently so there are still some bugfixing and balancing to do, but it's perfectly playable and the hours will fly by while you play this gameYou will like this game if you prefer 4X games with more of a focus on combat and ship-design. It's ship designing feature will have you endlessly tinkering with your designs, and the combat is very satisfying with explosion sounds and gfx providing you a suitable reward for your aforementioned tinkering. If you mainly want a diplomacy/empire-building 4X, this game still is perfectly fine but you might get more satisfaction from other games.Finally, beware that the game can be a bit challenging. Balancing of things is still on-going and I'm sure countless mods will spawn to help out with that, but the game will have you sweat a good bit and the AI can be quite aggressive if it notices vulnerability. The space combat AI seems, in comparison what other games of the genre have done so far, actually fairly good. The Diplomacy AI needs a bit of fine-tuning still, but it's already decent in it's 1.0 state.I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												StarDrive 2 is a true successor to Master of Orion 2, my all-time favorite space strategy game. They are similar, especially the tech tree, which is brilliant and, as I hoped, never ending throughout the game, however long. But SD2 has much more to offer, peppered with more than 100 potential random events. And it’s much improved over SD1.I see negative reviews that have only played for 3-8 hours. I’m on my first Normal setting game (probably should have gone Easy setting first) and I’ve played for 2 days against 5 AI, 161 turns, without the end in sight on a 70 star game (out of 100 at the moment). Granted, I’m carefully reading every well-written description of tech upgrades to plan strategy and learn the game. Nearly every item has a mouse-over tooltip to help. Love that. Developer has already stated on forums that he’ll make the Easy setting a bit easier for those who found it too hard and he says the AI doesn’t cheat or spawn ships as needed, it just plays more efficiently.Tutorial is nicely done, getting you off to a good start. The artwork is beautiful, from splash screens to the solar systems, ships, icons and elegant UI. One reviewer thought the UI was clunky but perhaps he didn’t know that you can back out of windows with a mouse right-click, so boink, boink, you’re back to the strategic or planet view in a second. You can zoom in to the battle scenes and see the hits and scorch marks on ships. Sound effects are very cool for each variety of weapon. One reviewer claimed he could only zoom completely in or out on the strategy map. Must be a scroll wheel problem. I had no problem smoothly zooming to any size view on the strategy map or battle view. One click on a planet and the planet view opens to plan your next building or ship. Right or left arrow can take you to each of your planets from that window. You can also build from the Empire Management screen or pick out your next planet to colonize from a list of explored planets with several filters. Planets may have a special resource or condition that can be beneficial or harmful in some way. If beneficial, it may affect your entire empire. If harmful, there is an opportunity to reverse that affect through special research. I’m just getting into the spy system and it strikes me as very cool.You can start a tiny colony on rich asteroids that fuel production with no pollution or build a refueling station on a gas giant, so eventually every planet in game has a use. Better explore early game to find those few Terran planets. Swamp, ocean and tundra planets can help produce food until you develop Aeroponic Farms, Subterranean Farms, etc. Build some freighters that will automatically deliver extra food to colonies that need it. Freighters are also used to move colonists between planets and for ground troop transport. You can also research an Experimental (read mystery) tech and get something unexpected. Last one I got was Unsavory Cantina, boosting morale, that wasn’t on any tech tree. Later in the game, you can research a Colony Ship that deploys a free Rover Bay (+production) and Aeroponic Farm (+food) to speed colonizing late game. Brilliant. The Terraformer, deep in the Bio-Chemistry tech tree improves the class of a planet every 25 turns until reaching Gaia. Looking forward to that! Stop at an unprotected enemy planet and pick up a few slaves for your Slave Pits, if you have that tech and mind set.SD2 has a lot to offer the space strategy gamer and I highly recommend it. I’ll be playing it for years as the developer refines the game and adds DLC. Just loaded my saved game for today (2nd day after release) and it’s already version 1.0c. I’m guessing the Easy setting has been changed already.

												Great fun from 1st step. First I encountered a little bug, but Zero has corrected it asap. This is customer service as we want it. Game shows up like a very detailed 4X title with a mix of usual turn-base play and real-time battles. Additional you get some X-com like ground fights. You have full authority over your ship builds and could even more decide detailed parts, which you could micro-switch probably larger distance for less hitpoints or else to your conveniance. Even your ground troops could be equipped from a pool of very different weapons, armors, health bars or whatever you may research. The game is mixed with a lot of surprising events...like stumbling over a wrecked ship with your scout...but you need some ground troops for further investigation. Once you start the mission you'll find yourself surrounded by a load of 'bugs' which pretty much like your taste. ^^  Played now for 4 hours on release day and can't wait to go on the other day...***Ok, found a minute to give another response after nearly 100 hours of play. This game is great, it gives you total into depth ship design, research planings or just colonization road to think about. Anyhow it is released and we currently are on version 1.01 there are still some rough edges. But Zero with his one-man-dev-show is working hard behind the scenes to bring new features every patch and recognizing every single bug response to make this game fun for every customer. Only thing I do miss is multiplayer, but currently I'm more into playing a StarTrek inspirated conversation mod with plenty of new ships and other stuff to get into the story.Anyhow it is same genre, I do not like to compare SD2 with GC3 as both games do aim completely different and have only turnbased and sci-fi in common. But besides that, SD2 is much more dynamic and brings more fun to me at the moment.Cheers!

												ok lets start of saying all the mishaps in sd1 are pretty much gone from sd2. better engine i'm able to run this with a 512 rad card and still look good.yet there's no multiplayer i could only see that happing in the games battle arena if it does happen with ships you have already made in advance.because in the normal game still takes me a good 10-15min to build a ship that wont fail hard. so here are pros and cons-Pros-better system turn base for the empire building-real time for ship battles turn for ground comabt-bombing planets far better than last sd1 you get to click the planet :)-random monster in space where you can get research off them or money.-Cons-Diplomacy is a pain at time there tolerance lvls go down while your people still♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥of at them making getting a none  aggression pact going pain the butt. even with shoving free tech down there mouth and trade pacts ect. they always want money from ya in tribute yet even if your empire could crush them. but still good system so you can't cheat the ai out of lots of tech for one good tech your giving them.-volume for the news robot and faction lead can be nerve racking when your not ready for it at 2am with head phones on so you don't wake the kid.i woke her wife almost killed me.-the remnant or master fleet can feel kinda trolly at time when at war with another faction i just let them wipe out planet some times re colonize and fire over some citizens to get it going again.  -it crashed now and then but prob my comp even so the dev fix it pretty fast with the crash report logs when given access to on the main website for the game.review may be a little biased but cause won the game 6 days before the masses could play it.all stuff beaning said if you like sci fi or just like 4x games or building space ships this game is a must for your steam library the modders will just make this great game better.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												This game directly appeals to Master of Orion and other space 4X games fans.  There are a lot of interesting aspects of this game, but unfortunately there are also too many fatal flaws.  The infantry combat is so bad that many players avoid it altogether.  It's basically a crappy isometric turn-based combat minigame that would have been sold on a Wal-Mart multipack floppy disk ten years ago (I'm serious, it makes the original final fantasy tactics look amazing).  The other fatal flaw is the sheer amount of interface glitches.  I can ignore and work around a lot, but they are everywhere.  The third fatal flaw is that you cannot give verbose commands to your ships in combat.  The ship combat is very interesting, but it's incredibly limited.  There is no formation move.  You cannot queue commands.  The battlefields are always the same boring grid, etc.The dev has patched it many times, but it's still a broken game, and he is already moving onto his next project.  He hard coded many parts of the game so it is very hard to fix/mod, so this game will NEVER be fixed.Do not buy this game, and be careful about supporting pre-releases!With great sadness I remove this once promising game from my library list.

It is broken and extremely hard to beat, yes, even on normal difficulty.All in all, I give this game 7/10

Posted: February 7, 2016
												Man am i dumb.  I didn't like stardrive 1, but because i really wanted this franchise to be good so i gave it a rather naive second chance and that was quite a mistake.  There is a fine line between homage and ripping off other games and this game is a blatant rip off of Master of Orion II, but it lacks the soul MoOII had.  Besides the ship building there is nothing unique about this game, and to top it off the ship building is massively unbalanced, some factions have ship layouts that are way smaller than the other races, others have such weird shapes that you can't possible do anything useful with them.  And then tiny little things like not putting things in alphabetical order in sorts, or not being able to filter menus really make this game just plain mediocre. Also bad ai, but hey no game developer in the history of 4x games has ever made a good ai...

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												If you enjoyed Stardrive 1, do not purchase this game.  While I will say honestly that I clearly do not have a long play time in the game and so can be accused of not giving it a chance, I will say that being a big fan of Stardrive 1 I was immediatly turned off by this title.All of the unique features of the first game have been lost.  We are back to a turn button in this game instead of the passage of time being constant like the first.  The shipyard and ship design from the first game was intricate, and although time consuming, very fullfilling and rewarding when you put the effort into it.  It has been simplified not enhanced.  The tech tree is set up as choices in each catagory that restrict you to one tech at a time and exludes the tech you didn't choose and you can only do one at a time.  the ability to order scouts to auto-explore, or setting up how you want the ship crew to engage in combat.... gone.  The options to automate or micromanage your shipping....  gone.  I loved that in the first game i could set up dedicated fleets of freighters to deliver specific materials among a few systems...  allowing for efficient exchange of food and production without having the AI sending shipping freighters to the other side of the galaxy to pick up food...It's become a MOO clone.  And while Masters of Orion was my first true love in the 4x genre, as it was for many of us...  I'm sick of MOO clones.  Stardrive 1 had so many new takes on the space 4x games...  it felt new, while Stardrive 2 looks pretty but feels old and tired.

The DLC includes various patches for the general gameplay which u won't get through the base game (bad decision of the developer for the fans, a good one for profit)This game is the spiritual new Master of Orion for me... even the MoO remake from Wargaming doesnt feel as much as the original ones like Stardrive 2. 												This game is a simple pleasure, the game style captures the best aspects of 4x games.  combined with the sly pop culture references with the heroes.  Custom races, custom ships, tactical battles.  This one has it all.  Strategy has depth and flexibility, no brain dead star lanes.  The only aspect of this game that I would warn people not to expect a multiplayer experience.  I Hope this is a future feature?  but even if it isn't this title will deliver one the 'just one more turn' hankering that 4x fans crave on a daily basis.Cons: The depth of the game is deceptive, it could be discouraging to players if they are too accustomed to the railroad space lanes concept.

If you love spending more time figuring out the mechanics of a game, how things work, what real impact they have than actually playing through a game, then this game is for you. Overall I'd say its like they took a good long look at MOO II and said 'hey guys lets make a game not quite as good as this, only cheesy'.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												The game is a good buy and enjoyable, overall worth the money. However, it is not yet a great game and will require patches and expansion packs to make it so. Detailed comments below.+ Throughout the game there is the feeling of an arms race, constantly needing new technology and designs to stay ahead.+ The diplomacy is quite good, albeit lacking alliances and a diplomatic victory. You also do get a few funny requests (such as one of my opponents declaring war on me for not giving them my homeworld).+ Graphics are good (from my experience for the 4X genre).+ AI and the game seems balanced but it does take c. 10 hours of trial and error as it is quite tough.+ Race customisation options are good.- The game does have a number of bugs e.g. for c. 25% of my first full game I would end up playing ground combat as the enemy. This is not game breaking as I could guarantee myself a win by therefore intentionally losing as the enemy but it is odd for such an obvious bug to be present at release.- The UI is at times awkward, e.g. for some races Titan ships (the largest vessels) are too large on the strategic map and prevent the ability to select any other planets or fleets in the system. This again is not game breaking but is quite frustrating.- As far as I can tell, elimination of all races is the only victory condition. This makes it very sad to have to turn on your closest friends to win the game.- Ground combat is relatively poorly designed; a system such as MOO2 would have been fine or a later expansion pack.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												If you enjoyed playing StarDrive, then continue playing it. StarDrive 2 is a gutted version of the first game with a few improvements. What I mean by a gutted version is that if you enjoyed the control over the fleets and dynamics of the space battles you will not get that with this game. StarDrive 2 is more of a point your fleet in the direct of the enemy and the computer will work out the rest. The game does have a better planetary battle concept; but, that is what it is a concept. Sometimes you take control of the enemy, sometimes the enemy doesn't do anything at all. I really loved the first game. When I watched the videos on the second game, I thought that is would be an extension of the first with better graphics, ship construction, and planetary battles. Changing the controls for the ship battles lost my support for this game.

												I wanted to like this game, and I almost did, but ultimately the tone-deaf developer and the balance of this game put me off it entirely.  I like to play 4x games with a minimal focus on combat, and its just not possible to do that in StarDrive 2.  No matter what you try to do in terms of economics, research, diplomacy, the AI is just a giant war machine that will attack you and force you to play your entire game around pumping out an endless supply of ships to survive.  I understand that the developer wants this to be a more confrontational game, but when you limit the player's options so severly, they may as well have none.Done with this game done with this developer.  Good riddance.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Well here it is, the sequel to the game everyone wanted right? Right?I'm gonna' start with the positives;   - The game has a nice UI when you're playing on the strategy map, it's relatively easy to use and tells you every thing     you need to know at this perspective.   - The games empire management screen is useful, it allows you to manage a large empire quite effectively from one screen.I find that I quickly run out of positives, the reason I've played it for as long as I have is because there are star wars and star trek model mods for it, most people don't know because the games steam workshop is broken.The negatives, unfortunately this may take a while;     - The game severely lacks originality, it doesn't innovate the genre at all and uses most of its aspects from the master of Orion game series. All of the races apart from the Chukk affiliation are ripoffs from MoO, and all of those races assets are reused from the old game, infact most of the assets of the game are reused from the first game, the buildings and the ship designs, the game has even less ship designs then the original which doesn't help.   - The game has six options if that, including the ability to disable the gnn broadcasts, which can get annoying, you can turn v sync on/off and fullscreen on/off, change the quality with 4 different options from fastest to best, you can change your anti-aliasing settings and change the resolutions. It's extremely lacking in option customability.   - The planetary production is boring, you can change the workers from science to production to food, again like MoO.   - The ship design has changed to become much less customizable, the firing acrs aren't customizable and it's less balanced.   -  There is only one win condition total dominance of the galaxy or you can just quit when you kill the masters.   - The AI doesn't favour diplomacy and they will all declare war because they can't do anything else, they don't really value allies or friends, performing diplomatic acts just pospones the envitable. They can't design new ships just the default ones which are terrible so if you have a decent few ships you can completely destroy their fleer, which brings me to the envitablility of ground combat. Unless you have nukes on your ships to exterminate the enemy soldiers and sweep in with some soldiers to capture the planet, you will have the unfortunate displeasure of meeting the ground combat. Its performance is terrible, it's ridiculasly unbalanced, dull and auto resolve is unreliable so you are force to do this monotonous task if you want to win.It's an unoriginal easy sequel that is buggy with a bad developer. Don't buy the game, if you want a game that's like this but more polished and by a reliable company, I'd either buy stellaris, GalCiv or the new master of orion.

												Having played Star drive 1 and loved it, I enjoyed the RTS style of that game but this one goes into turn based 4X strategy which is alot slower paced but more enjoyable i feel because i can sit back and think, and chill. number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13
												Thumbs up with the understanding this game comes with bugs but otherwise is a fantastic endeavor at a moo2 recreation.  (discounted purchase recommended)This game does a better job over any other game of its type at reminding me of Masters of Orion 2... in many ways its a more beautiful version of MOO2.  Very apt as another reviewer wrote Moo2.1.  But I am ok with that, as a matter of fact more than ok.  This game was as the professional reviewers put it, "compulsively intricate" and "the best thing since moo2" and if thats the case would have to say it deserves a Thumbs up despite its flaws because so many games nowadays release riddled with bugs and get great reviews.  Honestly, there should be a grade between 1-10 not just a thumbs up or down on these reviews, but I whole heartedly believe this game despite everything falls on the good side not the bad side, and deserving enough of a thumbs up.I'd give it an 8/10, if it weren't for the few game breaking bugs. But it's just so much fun when it's working right that I think it's still worth a 6+ but would recommend you buy it at a discount.  Some areas lacking polish like some additional informational text on a tech or two would have been nice.  But overall I am very happy with the product bugs notwithstanding and am sad to say that there may not even be another attempt at Stardrive 3 considering all the negative publicity it has recently gotten.My opinion is that most of the people that had gripes about the gameply or function of this or that just didn't understand the gameply mechanics fully.  I read the reviews before I played the game and tried to keep an eye out for everything they said and just couldn't find many faults with it.  One might say they attempt to steal your tech too often, almost every turn actually, but thats why you build and maintain defenseive spies... and honestly its one of the best ways to get ahead and would not put it past a player to try to steal tech every round if it were possible for themselves.  It usually comes down to enemy tries this, but you counter with this, if you don't counter, you suffer.  I don't think the game should be rediculed on many of the points it lists when there is a perfectly viable and available way to counter the issue built into the game. I also didn't run into any issue where I couldn't overpower the computer if i chose to invest in military might or any other catagory. As for command points, the maximum per colony is not 4, its 6 for the largest battle station, 1 for a command antenna and there are some other bonuses and techs to add more and you can even put bridges and cockpits to your ships to reduce the command point cost of them, in addition to this you can add 7+ points per colony, more colonies more points.  So if you have 50 cp you can use 50 cp worth of ships reduced by the bridge and cockpit modules if you choose to install them.  And all of that is on TOP of the multitude of free ships it lets you have.  For instance if you hvae 50 CP you might be able to have something like 30 corvettes and 15 frigates without even using one of those CP, then you can make a cruiser with a bridge reducing its cost by 1 and that would mean you could still make 25 cruisers before you ran outta command points. And that doesn't stop you, you can make more, it doesn't mean you have to stop, it just costs you money for maintenance after you pass your CP thresshold.  I feel like CP depicts the amount of ships you can control within your logistics capacity -  its simply a way to give you free ships... it by no means stops you from pumping out as many ships as your empire can support with money.  And this of course is not a new concept, many games use this in the strategy genre.  The game could use a few extra diplomacy options, and they do fall straight away to hatred if you expand too much, especially the races that have the trait expansionist, like hurt little kids if you take their candy... but I feel that just falls within their race trait and act accordingly.  I otherwise never had any issues with diplomacy and used it often with no issues.The ship construction and design isn't found in any other game of this type to the degree that has been implemented and I thouroughly enjoyed that aspect of the game.There are a few intereface changes I would make, but there are changes I always think should have been added in every game.  For instance, I would have loved to have 2 arrow buttons to slide between colonies onteh build menu, not just he planet menu, it would have saved a click or two.Bottom line, I thoroughly enjoyed the game for the first 40 hours and intend to put at least 100 hours into this game.  I feel that its worth the 30 dollars but if your not sure youo can handle the extra bugs that are in fact within this game and you are very interested in what you see, well then take the dive when its on sale.  If your open minded and understand that nothing on this earth is perfect and you liked moo2 and its faults then you should really like this game too.Thank you for reading.EDIT:  So, after a whole lot more hours into the game I have noticed a few bugs pop up that could potentially ruin the game.  Strangely the first round I didn't use the DLC ships and didn't have any of these problems.  But after using them I noticed the following problems in my second playthrough... one of them potentially catastrophic in that it can destroy your game progress.1) a graphical glitch on the strategy map fleet icon that wont go away with your fleet containing the DLC ships2) planet could get stuck in invasion mode and you cannot recover your soldiers (or hereos) leaving you with no chioce but to bomb it into a glass ball... however, i believe your still paying for the upkeep of these soldiers.3) after a battle the fleet upkeep will go from -800 to -8900000 for no aparent reason and the CP cap will be higher immediately after the battle, when it corrects itself your so far in the hole with  your currency that you cannot support your empire which could cause all your assets to be sold off.4) selecting fleets with HUGE number of ships can cause frame rate to drop to very low numbers until you deselect it.On a side note, your likely to enjoy the game in a small or tiny galaxy as it prevents the battles from getting onboxiously huge and making your graphics card **** itself inside out in battle simulation (no issue with auto battle) ... in addition to making the choices you make with ship building more impactful.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Stardrive 2 is the game for you if:1.You like a 'fast' turn based feel, don't expect to wait for minutes while ai's take their turns!2.A true Master of Orion 2 successor, which you notice very well as you play the game. Lots of ideas taken from there, so you can adapt very quickly to the game. So if you like MOO2 you will like this game.3. A nice ship combat system, really nice to watch, and you can actually apply tactics--especially if you design your fleets well. You won't just sit there and watch the battle happen. Unless you have a titan packed with mass drivers, defense guns,and a tough armor or shield.4. Focus on planets has improved drastically, especially how population and building special buildings has a huge impact. Colonists can either be taking care of the food business, the production business, or be Einstein-tier researchers.5. Customize ships. Shipyard is back, and while it isn't as free as Stardrive 1 the limitations are there because it makes the ship combat more realistic. Far more choice too with every component, want it to be armored-its going to be heavier,cost more, and take longer to build. Lots of different weapon options as well.  6. Lore, lots and lots of it. Also add to that the funny jokes and items you come across taken from many different sci-fi series7. Enjoy mods, because this game is build to support plenty and plenty of mods. Star Trek mods are already on their way. Also, with the current game engine choice it's bound to look  good.-----------------------------------Stardrive 2 has innovated upon1. Concept of freighter fleets is high in this game, don't remember if MOO2 has it though. So protecting freighter fleets is very important unless you want your empire to stagnate and crumble.2. Simultaneous turns system,it's turn based with a realtime feel.I might be the only one that really likes this system though. Turns happen instantly,not many(or any) 4x games have such a quick turn system.Also, every empire makes the turn at the 'same' time more or less.3. 3D ground combat, you rarely if never see that in a 4x game, while it is at the moment simple it has great potential.----------------------------------------Then again, the game could use quite a few improvements, but these are 1. More detailed ship battles, they are amazing as they are now, but nothing is ever perfect!2. Better ground combat. Perhaps in a future expansion?3. Better user interface in certain sections, speed timers in the battle interface?4. Larger galaxies, 100 systems is huge but the universe is the limit! ---Overall, great game-shines over its predecessor. A great single player 4x game, quite refreshing to see.Added bonus, it's the first turn based 4x game to come out on gnu/linux!(as far as I know).

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												I genuinely think this game is worth the asking price. It is a solid experience and has nice variety for those who look for it. That said though it is a little lacking in some areas. A few complaints are in areas like diplomacy. The lack of a Federation system as was present in the first game is noticable to me and combined with the demanding AIs always pressing your tolerance limits is an annoyance. The ground combat is weak in my opinion though permissable as it isn't the focus of the game but allows some break up in space battles. Most interestingly is that this game feels designed with multiplayer in mind. The tolerance limits would play well into players not over coorperating, the leader system means that no empire can have all the cards and players would have to consider sharing techs to get what they want. This would also help explain the lack of Federation since it merges two empires into one. This leads into my final point where, other than seemingly bottomless ability to throw ships and troops at you AI is a little lightweight. They don't use great unit cohesion in ground combat and I found them to use numbers rather than design to win space fights. A player would pose a much more interesting threat and I might actually have to bust out the Hazmat suits. Again a good game but it has a way to go to become great.Addendum: Thought of it as I was writing the above. I know that they simplified space to ease the burden on computers and such but I miss: being able to build battlestations in deep space, being able to jump ships in and out of danger, or the possibility of ships getting stranded in space after their engines are shot out, FTL and combat thrusters, ability to redesign transport ships (could be converted to combat use), designing stations, exporting production and assigning governers to build and manage things on planets. Regardless though I think this game is an improvement on small scale galaxies but needs some upgrades to help managment on large maps. Happy space battles and remember: It may not be much to look at... but Its RAINING DIAMONDS!

Posted: April 19, 2015
												I regret spending opening price to purchase this game. It has so many bugs that I wonder of the devlopers acually played the game before releasing it. I have fleets disappering, invisible enemies, freezing and crshing on minimal settnigs, and that's just the tip.The game itself introduces nothing new. it is essentially a reskin of its predecessor, but actally feels more limiting rather than less. Planetary governors have been removed, forcing you to micromanage every planet. Heroes were added, but barely rate a footnote. Espionage no longer has individual agents with their own names and rankings, Ground combat is clunky and frustrating, fleets will hover around, miss, or otherwise loose targets which you had ordered them to find, board, or engage, Diplomacy is socompletely unbalanced that it would require a separate review. And then there are simple things, like persistant scenario memory, that further frustrate me. You spend time setting up the ideal scenario for your game and then for whatever reason choose to restart and have to do it all over again. There is no apparatus to save  races or campaign settings.All and all, I was too frustrated to have fun.
