number of helpful: 18 of 34 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												While I enjoyed StarDrive 1, it was never finished. This game looked, at first glance, to be an attempt to create the game SD 1 was supposed to be. A lot of the changes are good (turn based but still quick gameplay), tech tree in which every choice feels like it makes a difference (but also extremely remniscient of MoO2) and hints of a story you might learn if you spend enough time with the game.Ship building is basically similar to the first game, but streamlined, which I highly approve of.The bad (and/or not yet done features) are too many to give this game a pass. If anything, this most certainly belongs in early access. If the designer disagrees, he ought to stop making games.A few specifics:-The tech tree is basically a mash-up of SD 1 and MoO2. But with sparsely any game effects visible (except for buildings, which are all well detailed, which makes the difference all the more obvious). The description certainly doesn't convey how utterly useless researching Plasma cannons was (in every way a worse choice than the weapons you start with, since they just almost never seem to hit) nor that researching and equipping rail guns to my troops would be a worse choice than sticking to the laser rifles you start with.-Ground combat. Wow. Are you serious? You release a game with this "feature"?Graphics are acceptable, if barely, but there's neither good advancement nor is there ever a point to this. The enemy advances in a direct line at you and will select it's targets and use it's abilities in the same exact manner every time.There is no way to define a standard equipment for your troops, you have to adjust every planet on it's own (not like there's really a point, your starting equipment is what you'll switch back to, once you realize how superior it is to later research, unless you go really far in the tech tree).-Diplomacy: The basic system is alright, but it sadly needs work.-The space combat is nice, but very one-sided, with some weapons being utterly superior to others. But there is great potential here. But there really needs to be a way to speed up combat. There's nothing more annoying than waiting forever for a fight that's been decided minutes ago to end and it taking forever because there's one last annoying small ship or fighter still alive and dodging like an ace.-The game's seriousness or lack thereof. It's not that there's humor in here. It's that the game seems like it's trying too hard, while also insecure about how funny or serious it should be. I wouldn't mind either way. Even a slight shift in either direction might be enough, but as is, it's in a weird place. Whenever I start taking the events in the game seriously, something reminds me I ought not to.I could go on, but while I don't want people to waste their money on this, I also don't want to make the wrong impression: There is real potential here. I had fun with this game, but I can't see myself playing it in this state.Currently, it feels less finished than most early access games I have.The bad, sadly, vastly outweigh the good. At this moment, I strongly suggest watching this game from a safe distance and waiting for it to either evolve into what it might be or to stagnate as the first one did.

												My Original Review had this tagged as a game to avoid, however i am pleased to be able to re-write this review and recommend this game. The only reason for the change would be due to the authors rapid response to complaints and required work with the game.To help out people planing to buy this game i have my Rig posted below : Amd Phenom x 6 16Gb DDR @ 1600 RamSSD Boot drive Win7 64 The above results in good clean gameplay 90% of the time however very large fights can result in slow downs , or if you use " carrier spam - More on that later " The Good : - Fun - Large scale combat based 4x type game- Ship design is hella fun- Random events add spice to the game- The AI is challanging for experianced players- No 2 games will be exactally the same- All races are almost fully fleshed out- Ships look fantastic, get the paint job pack if you want additional eye candy- Runs relitively well - You can make some very interesting ship designs , and the AI using the same side later will start using them ( helps you make a better mouse trap ) - If you ever played Masters Of Orion 2 the first 2/3'rds of the game are very similarThe Bad: - AI can be psycotic , " I the ai has 10 planets, you have 3 if you expand any more ill declare war  , I the AI finds your breathing offensive war time , I the ai find i don't like your face hole , guess wot? , war! - The slowdowns at end of combat can be frustrating, and can be up to 5 minutes, however you can Alt + tab out to do otherthings or talk to your family, get a coffee etc maybe its a feature ? - The Tech tree is not finished and it constantly feels like things are missing ( currently only 2 engine types ) - Ground Combat is painful slow and boring , some of the ground based weapons don't even do any damage and is still awaiting a fix from past 2 patches - Tracking / using ground forces is cumbersome, lift a platoon into orbit to fight on LV426 and the colony wont " make more " troops until its dead ? , if you put the platoon on another planet its still " assigned " to the last colony??? , but there is no " ground forces " overlay type interaction.- Due to the above its usally easyer to simply pound a planet into the stone age , land 1 troop take over and ignore ground combat entierly - Lack of Ship hull types, there are only 5 per side and you can't add more hull types, which is a shame given the level of customization you can go to on each ship. - There is currently a bug with assigning escorts to civillian transports that breaks the game - No Incrimental save system, which would be good given the bugs - The above should help you decide to get the game now or later , the DLC's are good but a bit expensive for what you get, however as this guy is basicly a 1 man team why not give him some extra $$$ towards completing this game? Having said that this game is worth the buy, but a little expensive currently for its current state if you have patience may be worth holding off 6 months and buying it then.

												Did not like this game when I first got it. Most of the reasons was because it was in somewhat of an alpha state at that time. Taken a second look at the game. It is much more playable now. Still hate one aspect of it, you cannot turn off the darned wormholes from appearing in you home system. Do not know if there is technology which which I have not yet researched which will allow me to plant a battlesation in front of it to stop enemy fleets from showing up in my home system. I think I will have more gripes about the game. Unfortunately or fortunately I think this is one of the games I will gripe about but continue to play.  C'mon you have to give a game a chance for a "Sharknado" planetary hazard! Not only that, but Molo farms! This game is made by a real SF buff even if the developers watch that crud SyFy puts out as movies.Edit: This game is a zerg rush. you either start fast and contact other races or you die by getting a wormhole pop up connecting your home system with that of another empire.  No choice built into the game. I am switching to a no vote on this game. The expansion won't do anything either to changing the war footing you are forced on.Edit: Ok, the patched game is much more playable. You can edit the config file and change the 100 system max to what ever number your PC can handle. I have played 300 stars without issue on mine. Also if you click disable attacks in the galaxy creation screen it removes the forced zerg rush. There will be no wormhole poping up to link your empire with that of another.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												I have changed my mind on Stardrive 2.  I am sticking to the prior posting that I don't really care about the Stardrive 1 complaints.  That said I am getting rather upset with the game balance.  After a number of hours I keep hitting a brick wall against the game's AI.  I am not a master of RTS or TBS games but I can usually hold my own against AI.  That said even on easy I am getting my butt stomped regardles of what I do.  I have read up what I can but it seems like I am not the only person running into what almost appears to be a cheating AI.  At first I thought I was expanding too quick eating up resources because of that and the AI was able to build a huge fleet to come at me, regardless of me owning 90% of the map.  So then I started playing it slow, building up a pretty good fleet or two with just a couple star systems under my control.  Nope still get stomped.   I have went back and trying countless different tactics and regardless of what I do I can't get anywhere near the fleets that the AI is putting out.    The game isn't bad but the AI is either cheating or there is something else going on.  Like I said I don't claim to be a strategy expert but even at easy I am getting stopped.  I don't mind hard games, but I don't like games that AI has balance problems.   Zero put out a patch that was supposed to make things better on that front, but if anything they have gotten worse.    Stay away for the moment if you want a game that has an AI that plays fair and isn't going to trash you over and over again even on the easy setting.  I can't imagine what the harder settings must be like.   I know I am going to get some L2P comments.   Maybe I am missing something major but after hours of play I continue to get slaughtered by the AI regardless of what my tactics are.Review at the 90 minute mark - outdatedI had the first Stardrive. I didn't have a big bone against it like some people.  I didn't play for Multiplayer anyway so it not getting included in didn't bother me.  I can see how some people were upset though.  I am not going to say that Zero didn't hurt himself when he dropped support of the first and started working on the sequel, however I understand why he did.  Personally with the 90 or so minutes I have spent in the game I can say that the sequel is worth the money.  I would have liked to see a bit of a better discount for prior users but still for $20 it wasn't that bad and if you don't already own the first I feel like the game is stable and more than fun enough to say that it is worth $30.  Do I understand why some Stardrive players feel slighted, yes.  Do I think it is unforgiveable?  No I don't.  As long as Zero continues to support 2 and doesn't run off starting 3 before everyone feels any major bugs have been addressed I personally think everything is fine.  I have a ton of space 4x games and 4x games in general, and I can say that SD2 does a lot of unique things, and well enough that it sets itself out from the crowd.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Simple: if you liked Masters of Orion II, you will like StarDrive II. This game is a direct forward iteration of the timeless classic. I cannot stress enough how wonderfully refreshing it is to play a game in that same vein that grows upon it organically without overdoing it or trying to change too much. Stardrive also has a very refreshingly light attitude and a healthy sense of irreverent and sometimes self-depricating humor, which helps a lot during a long slog through a highly technical strategy game on high difficulty.If you have not played Masters of Orion II, but you enjoy space turn-based 4X games, I highly recommend this one. The ship designer can be a bit overwhelming to do well at, and understanding the consequences of technological research takes a bit of getting used to, but as a spit-shine using modern engines and a fresh setting and story on what many consider to be the greatest space 4X game of all time, this one is well worth it.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												My issues with this are due to settings issues more than anything else. First issue, getting it to work properly when adjusting resolution is frustrating, at first I thought the game was broken but later realized due to changing the resolution certain parts like weapon stats and variations weren't showing up due to appearing off screen until i reset the game. In addition setting it to windowed mode gave me some trouble and took several resets before the game acknowledged the change.Beyond that setting things like abundant resources and planets really doesn't change the game as much as one would hope for setting it to max. Neither does turning off aggressive encounters which still leaves you fending against pirates as well as the masters and other annoying non-player entities. The choice based research seems interesting at first, but quickly just narrows your tech tree focus to the best choices over few games. While the base game is interesting and ship building and customization is amazing the rest of gameplay is let down. Given how even on the highest settings for resources and nice planets only yields you good planets about 1 out of every 20-30 having a max of 200 systems is a little on the low side.All in all, I'm very glad i got this game on sale. Never buy this game at full price, it's not worth it. It's hardly woth the 7.50 I paid and honestly this experiance is worth about 5 bucks.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												TL;DR Below adverage game, DLC makes it slightly better.Let me start off by saying this. At the time of writing I have 176 hours played and I have won once. Please bear in mind most of my hours were spent without the section zero DLC. Now im no master of stratagy games but that feels a bit off to me.Now with that being said I did have fun with the game. But this fun dident entierly come from playing the game. I like to dig around in game files and change things I dont like. Lucky for me one or two of the games issues can be fixed this way but the game isent very friendly to modding at all besides changing the stats of ship parts. That is only the first of many issues sadly.for instance your ships require fule to move outside your borders, your enemys do not. Yes saying THE ENEMY CHEATS isnet very dignified but this isent the only time the enemy does so. The very few times I've managed to take a planet from a gigantic enemy empire (before losing in the next 2 turns because my fleet wasent in my empires space) the planet was making -31BC per turn which leads me to think the enemys dont need currency to build or maintain anything. BC is the games currency used to build ships and structures by the by. For context my entire empire at this point was making about 6 BC a turn. Now on to the DLC, section zero. This DLC generally improves the game. A few things like the subspace projector are actually worth using and the ground combat is... better. Rather then playing a very very barebones knock off of xcom the ground combat is turn based and your planets citizens count towards fighting the enemy. In the base game the planet would simply give up without a fight if you had no infantry there. The map the game is played on gets one of the few improvements aswell. Your empires border in the main game is a bubble that extends around your planets and grows larger as the planet prospers. The largest issue I had with this is if I spent all my time and effort building up a planet so it could produce massive ammounts of food or build ships quickly when it gets taken by the enemy they get the bubble around the planet. So if my fleet of ships was at or near the planet and it was taken I would run out of fule and be destroyed if I retreat or I could fight the horde of ships that had taken my planet and lose my ships that way. This is much less of an issue in section zero because the map is now a grid of hexs and as long as your ships are in the same hex as a planet they can defend it.In conclusion I cant recomend this game. If you do own the base game however I would say get the DlC because it does help.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												This game is fantastic. I was shocked to see it had mixed reviews and realized I didn't post one.I keep coming back to it over and over again because it's easy to fire up and play and there are so many races and types of ships to build it makes each game a new experience. Originally I thought of it as a modernized clone of MOO2 (till I learned it a little better) but... I hate to say it.. I mean I really do because I'm a big long time fan of MOO2 but I'm starting to think this game is actually superior to Master of Orion 2. It's just got more of everything that is great about MOO2 in a slicker and friendlier UI. I can't believe it was made by one guy. I guess sometimes one persons vision is better than an entire team of developers with conflicting ideas. I was looking to get the the new Moo early access remake and... ya know I think I'll just keep playing Stardrive 2. Expensive voice actors don't really make a great game, it's gameplay that make them great. Great gameplay is what makes us play various games for over 10 years like MOO2. It's not the fluff of cut scenes or voice acting. It seems Zero understands that.I think this game gets some negative reviews or is called "incomplete" by some people is that they expect the game to have some kind of splashy story and a easy "story mode" setting.. and that is not really what this is. This game is about terrific 4x gameplay in the vein of old style gaming (like moo itself). You will not win every game and that is a good thing because it puts the pressure on an makes you take risks. As far as bugs go, I haven't really noticed any serious ones but I play it on Linux so maybe it's more stable. In all the games I've played maybe it's crashed a couple of times.. big deal. (I've seen major titles that are waaay worse,)Pros:* Great ship design.* Tactical ship combat is really good.* The UI is friendly and well thought out.* Planet management is fairly easy. (compared to Moo2)* It has a lot of cool races each with their own unique ships that is more than how they look they actually affect what weapons you can research and equip so various things work better on various races.* Customizable galaxy with random things to discover in it.* Sidequests that open various new technology and can impact your builds.* It's very challenging. (I play on hard or brutal mode usually)* Plays great on Linux.* High replay value.Some things it could improve on:* No DLC! - Seriously zero take my money.* Occasionally (on my hardware) the game slows down on 100-200 ships shooting it out. (w/ thousands of missiles or fighters especially)* Ground combats pretty basic. (tho better than MOO2)* Spying could be abit improved.* No Stat system or charts to see how your doing. Sometimes you feel a little blind.* No peaceful solution. You have to kill everyone. (tho diplomatic win is kinda meh..)* No real ending. You just win. (I wasn't expecting much but nice victory screen or stats would be nice)* Some of the larger ships are not symmetrical and have more space on one side or the other. It's an oddity..Haters be dammed.. this game rocks. If you like 4X, it's a must buy.

												I play for the battle arena...Really...The graphics are great, i love the ship customization (i do miss the arch changing ability from SD 1 though...) and from what I've played the tech tree is... interesting! I like the amount of thinking that the tech tree layout adds to research.I have not encountered any glitches in the game so far, and im not that annoyed that SD 1 wasn't "fully" completed. No star lanes! I mean, in Endless space the "star lanes" aren't bad but its nice to have completely free roam accross the galaxy...Okok, ill do a pros and cons list!+great graphics, always good for a space stategy game+planet managemnt is fun and interesting (though pollution sucks!)+Ship customization :) ++++Cool races and race customization options, GNN is cool too+Battle arena/ missions!!! AWESOME+Runs smoothly, although in crazy arena battles, the game does lag a bit...+I havent ecountered any glitches.+a fun experience, i havent gotten bored yetMeh stuff:=Ok ai diplomacy=Ok AI (but really, do any games have good AI?)=Arena is rather small, and i do like the open combat feel of SD 1The Bad-counter intuitive tech tree (other than that its great though!)Overall 9/10, would reccomend to all who like space 4x/turn based stategy games!

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Usual review caveats - The "Yes/No" recommend system on Steam is extremely simplistic. I'll try to cover both good and bad elements of the game and readers can make their own decision.Edit: Decided to cut down the review to something a little more succinct. Bugs and some dodgy design aside, let's cut to the chase. If you want a Master of Orion 2 clone, with a fair amount of bugs (although Zero has been working on resolving them), then great! Buy it, you'll probably like the game a lot.If you're looking for Stardrive, which was a flawed, but an extremely fun and novel mixture of RTS and 4X with some Master of Orion character with some especially amazing ship design mechanics and that gave you the feeling of running a living and breathing real time empire, with some additions and improvements, then don't buy it, because like me, you'll hate it. This isn't really Stardrive 2, it's a MoO2/Stardrive inspired typical 4X. Don't get me wrong, I love 4X games, but why buy one that is basically a reskin of a 20 year old game with mechanics that have long been improved on and, quite frankly, surpassed in every way? Be nostalgic all you like, but after a few rounds on any of Amplitude's 4X's, this is going to feel bland as grey buttons.I feel for Zero, I really do. SD1 got pilloried for never really becoming a final product. A lot of it was unjustified - typical Reddit gamer entitlement that makes you ask - 'When you got 150 hours out of a game, how can you justify being so upset?' really buried it. SD1 was ambitious, new, and with a little TLC and maybe a larger design team, could have got closer to it's full potential. SD2 felt like that was that opportunity, but instead ditched everything that was innovative and played it safe.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												I've been playing StarDrive2 for a long while now and I've neglected to add a review until now after seeing its Mixed rating which I feel is undeserved. I would like to list off the games major stengths and weaknesses.Strengths:- Extremely customizable galaxy (How many stars, liklihood of life in each system, several different patterns to place them in that have significant gameplay consequences for each one)- Excellent execution of the 4X concept (Explore fast to get a few treasure systems with plenty of buffer systems between them for protection )- 9 species with customizable racial traits (Personally I was happy with their presets and never changed them)- Beautiful digital graphics and fine character art- Stradegy in unexpected places (Most battles are decided by how well you built your ships and each race has a favored stadegy that requires a tweak to your fleet to come out on top)- Great replayability (I'd swear I would be sick to death with this game and after a two-week break I play as a new species and conquer the galaxy all over again!)- Crazy ideas (I've made talking elephant citizens, T-Rex shocktroops, and dropped zombie virus nukes on planets!)- The developer is good about fixing bugs or performance issues that get brought up (Crashes have been rare for me)Weaknesses:- Not much story in the campaign ( I've never played a 4X game brimming with plot )- The space battles dont require a lot of stradegy (Its mainly decided by the quality and size of your fleet)- The game really slows down in the epic 100+ ship battles (Patches have since made it tolerable)- The ground battles are stiff and slow in contrast to the fast and fluid space battles ( The troop limits on special missions keep it challenging though )-  The only way to win is wiping everyone else out ( Develepor claims there will be more victory conditions later )My personal score - 9/10

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I strongly caution anyone from buying this game. I really wanted to like this game, and was pleased to see a Linux port on a space 4x-er. After 111 hours in I am going to be deleting this game from my library. I spent those hours trying to find the promise that drew me to the game, but was delivered in frustrating little bursts of mediocrity: diplomacy, ship design, UI, land combat, and ship combat are all poorly executed. If the developer had put in the consistent work and updated the game maybe this game would have reached its initial promise. Instead, the game feels like an orphan, and a developer with a past who seems to spend more time defending himself in forums then making a good game. Again.For a contrast, check out Hearthlands (a totally different game) for a game that popped at the same general time as Star Drive 2. Look at how many updates and changes this game has gone through, and how much better a game it was then a year ago. And all those updates have been free. I am just pointing out the work by the developer, not the quality or genre of the game.Too bad for Star Drive 2.  And when Stellaris is released this game will be a memory. I will probably never buy a game developed by Daniel DiCicco again. Burn me once, burn me twice...

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												9/10 would recommend.I only say 9/10 rather than 10/10 because as of right now the numbers arent balanced very well. Higher tier weapons are actually a detriment and higher tier ships are a little too cheap to bring to the table. Both are purely numbers, though, and can be fixed very easily/quickly so that is the only reason i say its not perfect.The new turn-base system allows much more relaxed play even in the late game. SD1 had a bad reputation for becoming a micromanaging nightmare late game due to the RTS nature it had. The people that say otherwise should go play Starcraft if they want a fast-paced RTS, not StarDrive.Personally i love the new shipyard mechanics. Many complain about it because it removed a lot of customization with firing arcs and the ships are smaller, but i welcome it. I could spend upwards of an hour in SD1 designing a Titan ship because of all the firing arcs and power management it required. In SD2, probably 10min max. Much prefer the vastly faster customization vs the amount of customization.Difficulty meters cater to a wide array of players. The "Normal" can be rather unforgiving until you learn a few tricks of the trade, but theres a lot of ways to make it easier while you learn the game.

Posted: April 17, 2015
												Some of the best shipbuilding in any 4x space strategy game ever. Ground combat is meh, and it currently has a few issues with oversized fleets and auto resolve, but I really like shipbuilding. It also has one of the best start game customization I ahve ever seen. The options menu is lackluster though. It also really innovates with the diplomacy screen, even though the diplomacy itself is a bit lacking, by letting you see the exact value of different trades and why the other race hates or loves you. The research is also really interesting because you must choose between different techs, only getting rhe other ones through diplomacy or espionage, spying being pretty lame. Buy it on sale.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												StarDrive 2 impresses me in a lot of ways.  Firstly, the music and graphics are outstanding.  Secondly, the ship editor is both in-depth and intuitive...though I'm still trying to figure out optimal designs as the default ones don't seem to last very long in combat.  The races themselves have unique personalities and I appreciate their quirks and dialogue.  The tech tree is different in the sense that you have to pick between 2-3 techs every tier, meaning you'll pass on the others and may never get them.  This made me really think about what kind of empire I wanted.  Combat was also very fun and satisfying...I liked watching my creations attempt to work with what I gave them (shields and beam weapons, mostly).As far as what I don't like: the game doesn't tell you when a planet is not producing anything (it does tell you when new research is available) and the AI is still too difficult, even on "Easy".  I am not ashamed to say that I could be playing better and designing my ships more efficiently, but I'd also like to see "Easy" made even easier...that is, I'd like to build up my empire in relative peace and then attack when I'm ready. It would be great if there was a way to turn off the AI's ability to attack altogether and instead have it play a defensive game. Either that, or limit their CP in some way.  Of course, there are those that think "Brutal" is too easy and don't want the developer to change anything. That's why there are multiple difficulty levels...I'm sure it's possible to change one difficulty setting without touching the others, making the "don't nerf the AI for the casuals" complaints irrelevant. Some of us don't want a challenge, just a way to unwind after working 10 hour shifts. I'm just the type that prefers a "light" challenge...*shrug*, everyone's mileage will differ.  If some feel that "Easy" is just right, then perhaps an "Easier" difficulty setting could be added.Long story short, casual 4X players may get frustrated (like I have) at times when the AI decides to come at you with a vengence despite your attempts to be passive.  Difficulty aside I'm really enjoying this one and I can easily recommend it to 4X fans.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Star Drive 2 is a worthy successor to Master or Orion 2! So let me compare it to the classic: + Better economic/expansion AI than (vanilla, not modded) MoO2+ Better graphics than MoO2+ Better ship design (via module placement that matters)+ Special Resources for empire wide boni+ Special Research Projects + More diverse planets (types are about the same #, but SD2 has more modifiers)+ Mini-quests/events (some location/discovery based, some from heroes)+ Real time with pause space ship combat (-> you can keep formations, useful for specialized ships like canopy shield carriers or PD-Platforms)+/- Aggressive/opportunistic AI: If you are really weak, they will attack (even if they trade with you and like you, so no real "friendship")+/- strong focus on military/conquest aspect of the game+/- not (yet) as many mods as MoO2 (but is does have strong modding support) +/- planetary invasion mini-game (some like it, some don't, but you can still bombard from orbit)- less modules in ship design- lesser focus on diplomacy- slowdowns with very large battles (more than 100 ships for me)- missing some useful features MoO2 had (in-game encyclopedia, statistics)I can wholeheartedly recommend this game!If you get it, some things you need to know (or the AI will kill you, treaty or no):* Build Corvettes:You can build your CP in Corvettes free of charge (in CPs), so your fleet should be normal ships and in addition #CP in Corvettes. And get to your CP limit - otherwise the AI WILL attack, treaty or no. And look at the tutroials* You need your fleet(s)Unlike MoO2, your alone Starbase won't protect you from early raids, a devent fleet can destroy it even very early in game. However, your own fleet (max CP) in addition to the Starbase will work, even against fast expanding races* Expansion makes your neighbors nervous. If everyone (not just some) is talking about how you grow too fast, make a colonization pause (to get fleets & defenses up), and consider the possibility of several parralel wars if you continue on.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												This is one of those games that needs your attention. You cannot really play it while idly waiting for the AI to do something threatening. Honestly it feels a bit more realistic in the way it portrays aggresive expansionism.A strong focus on one sole aspect of the game can yield some good results (economy, research or military), but learning to balance the three of them while sending out scouts and forming a good set of core worlds is key to building up the strength to be able to stand toe to toe with an AI that makes calculated decisions every single turn.Is it an easy game? No.Is it a thinking man's game? Yes.If you're looking for a quick game you can beat in a relaxing afternoon, maybe look outside the 4X genre.All that said, I truly enjoy the challenge, and it makes the victories feel real and well earned. Combat is more meaningful and making otherwise "boring" decisions about your economy, research and politics is a tense and exciting process within the context of the larger game. With a few more options for better difficulty scaling and some great steam workshop support, this will definitely be a mass hit. But until then, enjoy the challenge!

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												After logging around 5 hours, i have found that the game is quite enjoyable. There are instances where you just want to turn it off because some space monster starts rushing you and blockades your planets or your fleet is harrased by them, but the whole idea is to get yourself into a stable position to be able to defend that.The game is nice in looks and nice in gameplay. The new landing battlefield is amazing and lots of fun, i find myself getting lost within the boarding fights or the attempts to wipe out an aggressive alien spieces that has control over an anomaly. I like the fact you have to decide which research you choose and then diplomacy is one of the other ways to attain the ones you havent researched, it means you actually need to interact with other races and build some kind of relationship with them in order to get what you need, and the fact that citizens have some kind of influence on which races you can trade with makes the game that little bit more challenging.There are some negatives like the fact that you will get rushed even if you dont have a fleet, by the hostile forces that reside in the galaxy, you will find other races rather quickly and in some cases have to go to war before you intended. There is also  the fact that it can be relatively fast paced due to small sized maps, and continual turn passing.. i think that every turn should matter and there should be things to do every turn rather then turn passing while waiting for research or so on... then again this could be me playing the game wrong :SAll in all i think that this game is worth it considering is low price tag, It's not for everyone but if you enjoy turn based stratergy and enjoy space colonization simulations, I suggest you buy this game.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												As of 1.0g I can safely say that this needed a longer period of beta testing. The balance is off, by quite a bit, in some places. This is most obvious in terms of the weapon systems where early-game tech is typically the best option throughout the game. Some of the available options don't work, like special research projects to remove some planet maluses. Sometimes these fancier systems work poorly like subspace projectors which are difficult to place, impossible to deconstruct, and do not provide a consistent bonus in their area of effect. The AI would sooner spite the player than actually attempt to survive in the game. I reduced a 10+ planet AI empire to 1 planet, and it consistently refused to surrender anything but one early game technology for peace. This wasn't a tolerance limit, but rather that it simply didn't see enough 'profit' in the deal.The worst of it though is the FPS drop on the tactical map. Depending on the weapons you and the AI have this can occur even on moderately sized battles (about 20 ships a side, most of which are corvettes). I have a beast of a machine, (i7-5820k, GTX 980, 16gigs of ram and SD2 is running on a SDD), and the FPS can drop to nothing. What's irritating about this is that SD1 had bigger battles, with bigger ships, and worked much better at these numbers than SD2 is doing with an only moderate difference in graphics.You couldn't justify it at $29.99. If you owned SD1 and can pick it up for a third off then it's a solid purchase. Otherwise though, you're better waiting for either a reduction or a fix to some of the above.That said, it is worth picking up eventually. This is probably the closest we've come in modern times to a 4X classic like MOO2.Manual ship and ground battles is a huge selling point. This is one of the very few 4X titles that has these mechanics, and it does both pretty well. The AI is a bit weak but that's hardly unusual. There are plenty of customization options for your ship, and while the balance is a bit off at the moment and you'll get to the point where you're mass-producing things very quickly so customization can be more tedious than enjoyable (like naming ships), they are very nice things to have.Something else that struck me is that the galaxy is very much alive. You will be bombarded with things happening in your empire - ski resorts being set up, restarting the gravitational spin of a planet, wormhole studies, pirate attacks, and just this great collection of events. There's not a 4X title out there that offers the same level of activity. There's also quite a bit of passive universe-building like ion storms and the 'grimdark traverse' with more than a few, not really terribly well concealed, easter eggs about other sci-fi titles. The AI, while not terribly smart or understandable, has great character. As a veteran of SD1 I had hoped to see a few more races but the existing ones are still very enjoyable.Empire management is also quite cool. You can have different races within your empire, and each provides their racial bonuses (so an Opteris citizen will get its smart bonus even if you don't have that trait). I spent quite some time setting up a few foreign exchanges and giving each race its own planet. I would have liked the ground combat units to reflect the racial make-up of the planet, but that's a small thing.If you own SD1 then picking up SD2 for 20 bucks before the discount disappears is a smart move. If you don't then waiting a bit to see how much patching Zero will do and how effective it is more prudent at $30. When it drops though, even if Zero hasn't managed to iron everything out, it's still a very good purchase. It's not flawless, but aside from the optimiziation issue in battles there's nothing in it that can't be relatively easily fixed.Ultimately the flaws with the game are mostly down to balance. That's something that would not have been an issue had it had a longer, or more exposed (but probably not on Steam Early Access), beta period.Edit: I forgot to mention the tolerance addition to diplomacy! In some ways it's a purely contrived mechanic, but how it ends up working is a really nice in-game restriction to prevent you from gaming the AI. Unfortunately diplomacy has some trouble at the moment (see above), but it's one of the innovations in SD2 that actually forces a different approach to the genre norm when it comes to interacting with the AI.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												I'm really not sure why this game has 'Mixed' reviews. This is truely one of the better 4X games out there and definitely one of the best produced in recent history. I can only assume that at least part of that is due to the fact that StarDrive II is totally different than StarDrive I. I didn't like StarDrive I personally so I would say thats a goood thing. If you liked SD I then you may feel differently. StarDrive II is a true classic 4X space opera title.Ship customization is a real standout with this title. You can pick all the systems from weapons, shields, hanger bays to powerplants, C&C systems, and medbays and place them on a wide variety of ship sizes and shapes. Which adds another minigame type aspect that is well done and adds to the enjoyment and variety of the game. Each playthrough you can tweak and scheme to build ships that are a little better.The real-time space battles are great with a well done variety of weapon effects (lasers, projectiles, missles, point-defense, etc), the ability to launch fighters for defense or offense, give standing orders, manually direct ships if desired, deploy mines, engage planetary stations, zoom in or out, whats not to love here?The atmosphere is engaging and quite complete with a solid and well thought out lore. The races have real 'personality' and quirkiness that actually makes them standout and be remembered long after you play the game. This for me anyway pushes this game towards 'classic' quality. The custom race generator is quite excellent and balanced and allows you to make well balanced custom races that cater to your own playstyle. The AI is above average for the genre. Clearly if you, like many of us that enjoy the 4X genre, have been playing these games for 20+ years the AI will rarely 'beat' you but it will give you a reasonable challenge. I have not seen the AI doing truely stupid thing like sending fleets to attack fleets twice their size or leaving planets undefended as I have with other 'bigger name' titles.The diplomacy system is well done with many options to trade; money, treaties, trade, technology, planets, etc. The diplomacy screen gives you immediate feedback of the 'value' of both sides trades so you can clearly and easily see the likelyhood of making a successful offer. The races traits even affects what types of goods/technology they value more than others. Well done.The graphics are quite varied and interesting. Not ground breaking but well above average. Different races ships look quite different. The universe scale map is quite nice with attractive atmospherics. The UI is well done and presents all the information needed to make decisions in an attractive and functional way without menu surfing. Planet development is standard faire for the genre with a wide variety of planet sizes, types, and environments. The varied environments interact with various racial abilities. Planets can be mono or multi-racial with associated ups and downs depending on your technologies. A wide variety of buildings can be placed to upgrade your basic production values of industry, food, reseach. Your tech tree selections provide more than enough options for specializing your planets and giving them different roles within your empire.The tech tree is perhaps not as deep as some would like but it is more than amply long for all but the longest of games in huge universes. The mechanic to pick one of three techs at each technology upgrade is innovative and ensures that on each playthrough the tech is varied and plays out differently from game to game. The tech tree can be easily modded if you really desire more.  Some people complain about the ground combat but I actually find it quite a fun 'mini-game'; sure it's not C&C ground combat quality but its a great way to break up the monotony of moving fleets and setting build orders. It's 'fun' not 'deep and complex'. Many of the ground combat scenarios are interactive story missions giving the game at times an RPGesque aspect which is nice and fairly innovative for this genre.The game is fairly moddable so I love being able to easily tweak and mod minor annoyances in ways I prefer. Compared to the many other recent 4X games this is the one I would recommend over many of them.In my 80+ hours I have seen few (if any) bugs and the game runs extremely stable which seems to be a rarity in todays world of 'early access' drivel.Overall, I strongly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the classic 4X space opera genre.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												The second I heard he was switching to a turn based system I started getting weary, but my love of the first one made me hope for the best, sadly my hopes where in vein.  This game is just plain boring.  Everything that made the last game cool and unique has been stripped away.  I loved the real time battles and micro turns of the first one, they made the game challenging and fun, but now it's a space bar holding simulator.  Not enough happens in one turn to justify making this game turn based.  This how it works, you pick a research and then you hold down the space bar for 2 mins, and then the research bar is done and you pick a new one.   The research UI is horrific.  I still haven’t figured out the tree.  In fact there doesn’t' seem to be one.  Or maybe the UI is just so terrible I can't tell.Making the battles a separate screen takes you out of the action a great deal, it's not fun at all.  Even designing ships isn't even fun anymore, because you start with like half the modules unlocked.  What’s up with that?This game is just boring as it is, and to fix it, it would require a complete overhaul of the game, so I doubt it's going to be better.  I don't recommend this game if you liked the first one.

												Solid 4x offering - probably reminds me closest of Masters of Orion: 2. Pros: turn based map which resolves very quickly (no waiting around), great graphics and performance, no crashes yet, price isn't unreasonable. Cons: only frustration I have had so far is an over aggressive, hard AI (may not be a con to all) and the develper has already posted about adjusting game hardness for different game levels and applied a day two patch that lets you disable some features.Bought plenty of games I regret, but this is not one of them - very pleased.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I'm enjoying Stardrive 2 like no other 4X space game since the original Masters of Orion.    It's brilliant.DifficultyI'm playing it in "easy" to learn the ropes and have disabled the random space creatures and pirates from attacking. This option helps avoid early fledgling empires from being crippled by an early attack by the random spawns in the galaxy.I reckon the difficulty for 'easy' is about right now - since a few minor patches to adjust the easy difficulty level. Great support from the development team hear. I wouldn't be put off by it being to hard.Why i like it so much   The complexity is about right. There appears to be loads of depth across the different aspects (economy, tech, fighting, expansion, diplomacy, espionage etc.) but no single aspect is hard to understand or control.  The ship battles are brilliant. They give you enough control but don’t require excessive micro-management, they are pretty and you get a good feel for what weapons and ships work, and what don’t.  The ship designing is excellent and not too time consuming. I usually get put off with designing ships because it's often too tricky to make the link between what you design and seeing the effect of those designs. Not here: as stated above, you easily get a feel for what works.Furthermore, you get plenty of information about how much power, ammunition, engines (etc.) you should be adding so you can ensure you don’t deploy something that just won’t work. Diplomacy seems to work.  I can easily understand what something is 'worth' and can make effective decisions around what to trade and what not to... Again, the game provides you with the information you need. Sense of humour. The game doesn't take itself to seriously. Ground combat. I think there should be an 'auto' option (i don’t think there is one), as long term I’d want to auto fight ground combat IF it occurs frequently.  Hmm.  That sounds negative. I like the ground combat mini game, it does it's job, but it's not what I *personally* want to spend my time on.  Overall though, it's a positive inclusion. Exploration is fun! There's plenty of variety and strategic resources etc. that no game will be a like.  The strategic resources are all worth having and give noticeable bonuses. It's stable. I’ve not had any stability issues. It's not 100% perfect yet. There are a couple of minor annoyances such as not being able to see the plant population cap when viewing your planets list - its a rare case where you don't quite have all the information you need. Also, sometimes your planet will say 'starving' because it thinks it's short of 0.5 food, but actually it's not having a negative effect. I hope this review helps!

number of helpful: 13 of 25 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I have played a lot of 4x games(Master of Orion, Master of Orion 2, Ascendency, Master of Magic, Fantasy Empires, The Civilization Games, Heroes of Might and Magic 1-5, Galactic Civilizations, Imperium Galactica II, and probably a bunch more that I don't remember right now), and the reviews for this one seem a bit more enthusiastic rather than accurate.It borrows heavily from other games but to the point where it feels derivative of them rather than being a synthesis of them. Moreover it is so blatant about it that it feels like it is flirting with the breaking the fourth wall not something I am a huge fan of.The game has a lot of potential in the ship design and strategic aspect of space and ground combat and the level of depth that it allows you to manipulate your empire.I will say that it was better than MOO III in general fun and striking a balance between allowing depth and getting carried away with it.My big gripes about the game are as follows.Technological advance doesn't yield significant upgrades until you get very very far along in the trees. I almost always had better luck researching a few basic (tier one or two technologies), the pumping everything into producion ships and troops and conquering the galaxy without ever doing more than cursory reasearch.The AI literally cheats on basic settings, I have tested rich homeworlds on small maps with optimized industrial output and the AI will invariably massively outcolonize me and outproduce me (in terms of fleet and fleet size) very quickly in the early game. You can still win by being clever or cheesy in your builds, but the fact that it literally plays by a different set of rules on default settings really really bothers me.The technologies are poorly balanced to create a stable empire. The game forces you specialize each of your planets because of prohibitive maintanence costs (making one planet that has all upgrades and buildings your empire is capable of will put a big dent in your wallet). Basically I find myself skipping almost all of my unlocked buildings on most colonies just because of what it costs to maintain them. The way various technolgies interact and overlap with each other just makes a lot of them feel useless or redundant or only of use on a very small proportion of your colonies.I do think the game has a whole lot of potential and with some patches or balance changes could be more fun. Essentially my complaint it that it forces you to play in one of a few very specific ways if you want to avoid getting wiping out quickly on default difficulty. It felt more like how well can I implement this strategy which I know will be the only viable one for this map/race selection rather than what type of empire would I like to build this time. It feels like the game has mechanics for amazing strategies and fun but makes it impossible for you to implement them before you have already taken control of the map. Bottom Line I just didn't have fun playing it.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I bought Stardrive 2 with a 33% discount since I own Stardrive 1. I don't mind dropping 20 bucks on a game I'll play for 20+ hours. Stardrive 2 is a game I'm enjoying more than some of the other stuff out there. Even the "tacked on" ground combat isn't as bad as everybody is saying it is. Overall, I like the game.If you can't afford or want to pay for this kind of game because you hate the dev or whatever, then don't, or wait for a Steam sale. Or, if you're like me and don't really care to light the torches and grab a pitchfork because a dev moved on from his former project, buy it for what it is: a decent single player 4X space game with tactical ground combat elements.Pros+ Ship customization is awesome+ Ship combat is interactive RTS unlike other games where you just watch the results (Gal Civ II) + You can't research everything, so you need to make strategic choices in the best research options+ You can acquire tech that you can't research through trade, racial traits, or assimilating planets.+ Cool events and side quests+ Races are varied and interesting+ Other subtle nuances in game that show care and thought went into it+ The price is definitely worth it. I could easily see myself putting well over 100 hours into this game over time.+ Replayability+ Steam workshop (future mods!)+ Music (I just like it)+ Tutorial is well doneCons- Some useful shortcuts are lacking, such as the ability to set fleet engagement ranges, instead, you have to set the optimal engagement range for each and every ship.- Damage to specific systems and the effects of such are not shown, rather it shows colored damage to ship sections instead, leaving you guessing as to what is or is not working in that section of the ship.- Ground combat feels incomplete, but I'm glad its there rather than not. Hopefully, future patches will improve it.- Cannot customize fighters beyond simply researching tech and having them auto upgraded- The community (Many people are griping about Stardrive 1 being abandoned too early.)Overall, I give Stardrive 2 a 7.5 out of 10, and I expect it will likely improve over time with modding and content patches or DLC.

number of helpful: 15 of 29 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Pretty good game overall. Somewhere in the middle between GalCiv (strategic, planet management), Sword of the Stars (combat depth with some physics) and MoO (ship design and management on MoO2 level). All in all, I'd say - It is very fun. Has a lot of small, nice events that add up to the general gameplay too. Tactical combat is interesting enough with ship design being amazingly fun.That said, it has a little bit more bugs than you'd expect, and of a sort you'd not expect. Most notably:- Fast fleets tend to overshoot their destinations - and then try to get back and overshoot again. This circus can for last a few turns if you're unlucky.- You can't enter the purple wormhole right after researching it. Need to wait for a new one to spawn. And then to not overshoot it ;-)- Very rarely, but sometimes you control the wrong ground force during ground combat.- Very rarely, (happened to me only in corvette-only fights) forces refuse to engage and you do not seem to have control over any of the ships.- Leaders appear so rarely that it's entirely possible to have a complete playthrough without ever encountering one- A lot of the weapons are not really much of an improvement over their predecessors - effective dps seems similar. - Auto resolving battles kills ships that would have not a single chance in hell of dying had the battle actually taken place.I would also be happy with a bit more documentation on weapons while placing them in the shipyard. It's not trivial to remember at first which weapon is 'beam', which a 'particle beam' etc, and if installing, say, a particle capacitor makes sense for one.The game's also a bit too easy. I have not lost a single game ever - even the new brutal modes seem to only give the AI more resources, but don't really make it any scarier. I think you can safely ignore any difficulty below 'hard' even on your first playthrough. All that aside - I would recommend to friends. Which I am hereby doing. Cheers!

number of helpful: 20 of 39 people (51%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Pretty awesome to hear this starship and empire building game was created solely or mainly by one person. The quality is AAA all the way from the excellent animated cut scenes and incredible still art to the intensely helpful professionally voiced tutorial to the gameplay mechanics everything radiates superb polish.Ship building is very exciting as one tries to see what is the best design for the job you intend to do. It is a major high creating a ship and seeing its purpose fulfilled exceptionally whether its for combat or colonizing or to transport workers and troops to another planet. There are also supply lines one has to keep open by avoiding enemy blockades as you will need supply lines to keep your ships fueled for the long trek into enemy territory to destroy their main empire planet.Combat is tense and alot of fun as i was maneuvering my ships to avoid enemy fire while getting in the best position to do the most damage while being able to pause at any time to revaluate the situation. Winning commendations after a battle also gave a added sense of satisfaction after a victory over raiders or another empire.Races are varied and interesting from the honorable shogun like bear race to the violent pyschotic wolf race. There are also space pirates to contend with which will harass your territories until you deal with them. There is a vast research tree which allows for the discovery of many new advances from ships to making life easier for your planetary populations such as increased population breeding and stronger lighter metals for ships along with better handling power plants to keep energy weapons going along with many other discoveries just waiting to be researched. Music and sound effects  have a excellent science fiction vibe creating moments of peaceful stellar harmony as you view the vastness of the space map or watch the humorous galactic news feeds. Many a focused moment i have found myself suddenly in a relaxed mental state taking in all the audio goodness with hypnotic futuristic music by the legendary likes of Isao Tomita. This combined with the soothing visuals made me feel i was back playing MASTER OF ORION 2 but with modern enhancement making for a smooth user interface experiance with excellent tool tips popping up revealing information on every single big and little thing happening on the screen. I definitely appreciate this and it has made my enjoyment of StarDrive 2 a much more richer experiance.StarDrive 2 a spectacular over the top intricate yet easy to get into masterpiece thanks to its incredible interface of star ship combat and empire conquest where galactic catastrophies will leave you smiling in awe as empires rise and fall.

												Have only played for a few hours thus far.  Really like the design and concept, but the UI is clunky, there's no key mapping, and cant save Ship Designs, which is a BIG part of this game.  Shipyard itself is generally buggy, the UI keeps shifting and sections keep overlapping other sections, plus it's really slow to respond.  Will continue playing to see if issues resolve for now, but disappointed in interactive execution.Edit - reload did solve the Shipyard problem (for now).  However, when running into alien races framerate drops dramatically.  The animation seems to really slow down the game.  Ground battles can experience the same issues - when selecting units the game freezes for a few seconds.Oh yeah, and what's with the 0 Food production on just about EVERY planet.  Out of over a dozen habitable planets, I've found a whole whopping TWO that allow any kind of food production (and both of those were minimal at only .5/farmer).  This wouldn't be so bad if your colony ships allowed more than 1 population on them, but NO customization for Frieghters and Colony ships means they aren't capable of increased capacity or armament.  Hell, you can't even control Freighters, so if you have a distant planet you want to settle, you can't accompany your Colony ship with a Foof Freighter so your people dont starve before you get some food there in the only way possible allowed by the poorly designed game mechanics.Based on this HIGH dependancy on food transport between colonies, there are some obvious racial benefit choices when starting a new game.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Review is current per ver 1.1aWith the latest patch fixing many gameplay and bug issues this is NOW a awesome game with a ton of potential down the line with easy moddability.  SD2 Combines the best parts of Moo, Moo2, Gal Civ and other 4x games. The crown jewel of Stardrive has always been the real time space combat and SD2 does not disappoint. The combat is now faster, yet with more control, more streamlined and less frustrating YET more complex with more tactical choices in battle.  Choosing the most optimal Strategic counter response to threatening enemy fleets can win or lose the game. In a recent game I designed a slow, heavily armored and shielded fleet to demolish a Vulfar massed frigate/CRV  swam only to have a another race tear my primary fleet to shreds from all the way across the battle map with long range stand off missile fleet.  SD2 has  By FAR the most engaging and fun tactical space combat in any 4x game.  -1 point for some lingering bugs/ AI issue/ things need to be fleshed out (occasional Crashes)  but with future mods an patches this game will deliver me (and any 4X fan)  years of fun.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												Still searching for the perfect 4X in space? Ya me too. There's lots to like about this game but the game still has a few warts. Pro's: 1. Ship design and ship combat. Personally from a Realtime perspective I don't think there is a current game that does this better. If you like TBS combat look elsewhere but I think this game makes a valid case for the transition to realtime combat in space 4x.2. Race diversity. I think the species that are in this game add a fair bit of flavour. I know the moo races will always have a special place in my heart but these are pretty good. 3. UI in general is clean and bugfree.4. Planet management is decent and not overly tedious.Cons:1. Ground combat.....ugh.....its hex based ground combat. Why or why after making the wise decision to go realtime for space would the developer go with hex based combat? It's so tedious and not fun. Fortunately its not a major part of the game.2. Diplomacy is rather weak in general. This is a flaw in many 4x games except for a few. This game is strictly centered around winning through attrition. One path to success. The game feels a bit linear in the approach in this sense.Overall. I'd recommend the game but it leaves me wanting. Combat is great but Diplomacy/victory conditions are just as important and the ground combat is the bitter pill to swallow in between.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Pros:- MOO2 Rip-off: This is better MOO2 than the original MOO2 ever was. Basically all of the orig game mechanics are there, but all of them are slightly enhanced (in the way that you think this is what is should have been in the original). Some of the mechanics seem to be new (ground/troop combat), but overall, very good design and approach for those players, who strive for a new and deep MOO-type-of-4X-game.- Very good overall graphics/sound design: Light, but effective, pleasing one's eyes. Some menus are very well organized so e.g. the empire management is thus very effective, even with lots of colonies.- Very good ship designing: Create multi-purpose or very specialized ship designs; mix fleets in a way that fits your gaming style. In general, there is a great variance of ship's weapon and module types.- Good ship2ship combat/battles: Ship design plays a big role in combat, but certain tactics are necessary and are a definitive advantage. Still, tactics are not the core of battles, it is mainly techlogies and ship design. Ships get various medals/bonuses for certain combat achievements and retain these for life; these are also upgradeable. Battles are also very well graphically designed to please one's eyes. Thus, some battles can be quite epic.- Well designed diplomacy: You know exactly what they think about you and why and what you did good to help the relations, what you did bad to harm them. You know exactly where your current diplomatic limits with each of the races are. Spying is yet another game concept which reminds of good old MOO2, but is nicely extended, so that a player has a better control of offensive actions.- Additional in-game candy: You can build Space/refueling stations whereever you need them on the map. Exploration of space anomalies - some trigger combat, some additional research; all provide various in-game bonuses and content. Various planetary enhancements, generated randomly ad-hoc as a result of certain long-term situations (sport resorts, merchant guilds, private shipyards, ...). Space-creatures. And a dark story, affecting the whole galaxy...Cons:- Diplomacy: Despite diplomacy being very well designed and informative, it seems its purpose is not to seak diplomatic victory in this game (e.g. a concept of permanent alliances is missing). Diplomacy does not need an ovehaul, but an extension to have even more possibilities.- No SpaceStation designing: This is a "minor" issue; but not possible to create customized space station designs. Neverteheless, space stations use the best tech the player has available.- Groud/troop combat: Although developer put quite an effort into modelling of this concept, it is a bit dull. It has a great potential, but it feels like it does not work as originally intended. This is overhauled in DLC.- MOO2 Rip-off: This might not be ideal for players ho seek new, unorthodox approaches to 4X gaming.- Some bugs: From time to time, there are small bugs/glitches in the game, usually not gamebreaking, but sometimes quite annoying. The number of bugs went down quite a lot just before the DLC release, on the other hand, DLC release might have introduced new ones. Anyway, the (only) developer is working to fix those too.Verdict: 8/10Very good content, sometimes spoiled a bit by occasional bug. This is an excellent 4X MOO2-like space strategy game, probably the best one out there.===========Get the DLC!- More exploration / remote mining of more resources.- Nebulae- Bigger universe, more stars, epic games- Extended research tree

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												As a fan of StarDrive 1 and someone who's played a fair share of 4X games I can't recommend this game to most people.  I think there are a select few 4X players who won't be turned off by the overbearing management required to win in a campaign.  I am not one.StarDrive 2 is very tedious.  There is a lot of variety in what you can do, what strategies you use or ships you build.  This game does a lot of good things, but nothing extremely well.  The RPG aspect, planet management, tech trees, diplomacy, and ship building are a positive.  Ground combat was definitely improved with the DLC.  Space combat however is its major weakness.  Both the actual battles and preparation for them, are lopsided.  It's the most frustrating aspect of the game.If you are a 4X fan, and see something in this game that makes you want give it a try, by all means do.  However, I don't think most gamers in general would enjoy StarDrive 2.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												An awesome game in the same lineage as Master of Orion 2!The game looks fantastic, both the 3D and 2D assets. It's fun to just sit back and look at the pretty map, or watch the space battles.Except if you just sit back you may well lose. How you approach combat matters, as does ship design. If you like to get hands-on with your ships, expect to spend a fair amount of time designing them.Sound design and music are very satisfying. Everything sounds right, which goes a long way towards selling the game.Interface is informative, understated, and polished. It avoids the overly minimalist interface of Endless Legend, but doesn't distract you either.Empire management is understandable, but hasn't been dumbed down. It's very similar to MOO2.There are some bugs, but the game continues to receive updates after its release, and nothing I've run into has made me regret buying the game. I'm very excited about the new DLC, and I intend to purchase it soon. Do bear in mind that the developer is basically a single person; this isn't the product of some big studio. One advantage to that is that the developer has responded to player requests; larger galaxies were asked for, and were delivered, first in a free patch, and then even bigger ones in the DLC.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I do heavily enjoy this game. But I find it limited. I also find that its bugs make it unplayable. Here i am, 5 hours into a game, ive just lost 3 fleets and 2 planets. No no, dont missread, i wasnt defeated in battle. The enemy flew off the map and i was faced with a choice. let the battle play out, or end the match and sacrifice the match. I gave the first match like this 15 minutes, and no conclusion came. I am currently playing out the third match like this as i edit my review. Zero, the dev, has no intention of releasing a finished game, or even a playable game. This is just a cash grab by him. Why would i claim such? well Stardrive 1 wasnt particularly improved, but was just left as he started the project for SD2. The last patch notes Ive seen was released Nov 24, 2015. The game is on sale today for 7.49 usd. It isnt worth $2.00 usd. Fix this game Zero. I am ashamed to admit I actually thought you'd countinue to support this game.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Ever since i stumbled across the original Stardrive, i've been very eagerly awaiting a sequel. That wait has finally ended :)How to best describe this game ? Its a classic 4X game, very reminicent of the "Master of Orion" series (if you are old enough to remember that). I wanted to get a number of hours under my belt before posting anything, to make it more of a review rather than a preview.If i am to have a gripe, it would probably be that its a tad too difficult for "casual" play at the moment, but patching of that is on its way.  My very first game ended with my empire in the dust as the space bears (Kulrathi) decided to walk all over me, hehe. With them having a massive advantage in both tech and ships, there was not much i could do. But i went down fighting :DWiser from that first game, in my second, i am, if not dominating, at least holding my own.Gameplay is quite addictive, and fun, and i recommend it highly to fans of the 4X genre.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Really like it, it has some issues when it comes to the AI and diplomacy in my view, the fact that a race tries to get as many techs out of you as possible and then declare war on you just because you took 2 planets in your own influence zone is weird, there is no point in dealing with diplomacy.The AI is way to aggresive, and there is no other options then waging war on eachother, hoped for more diplomacy options like alliance would be nice. If you are in the middle and gets sorrounded by enemies then you are more or less screwed.The good point is the combat, really fun. When a faction delcares war on you, there is this arms race that is a load of fun, atleast for me. Gets destroyed by rockets one battle, and then refit your new fleet with anti-missile defences, and wreck them. Small things like that really makes the game really fun. But I get the feeling that the AI don't change much, after refitting my fleet with anti missile defences, they still used them, which is kinda weird, especially after like 8 big battles.And the customization of the races is fun, but it feels lacking at some parts.I would recommend this if you are a really big fan of Sci-fi strategy games, but at the same time, I would not recommend this over games like Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion though.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Brutal AI...... Made me feel like Hearts of Iron 3 all over again BEFORE i knew how to manage my systems correctly. However, there is noway in the world of gaming the AI doesn't cheat... IDC what anyone says... their turn rate is better...they have more ships AND they ALL declared war in 1 turn after the other ....why? i refused to give them tribute .... once ?? ok ok i'll let ya have that. However for them to manage the worlds they had and the fleets AND tech AND credits AND not be at war with each other...... come on .... i still love the game, love the concepts, love everything, but this is a STEEP micromanager game. i out teched ALL 3 empires and i had maybe a ratio of 10-1 kill rate and i STILL lost cause they had 2 more sets of fleets ready also ? ok i call bullcrap on that. Also when i mean fleets... I MEAN the same if not more ships with BETTER tech that i had, the previous 5 turns. You need to ramp up home system repair rate to balance that out. You fleet doesnt immediately repair like it says when at a starbase. command points should limit how many ships you can deploy in ONE fleet not your income. Still a awesome game, i have alot to learn .

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												If there is one big flaw with this game, it is the total lack of Multiplayer. There are not even space or ground skirmishes against other players (at least as of 1.0c). This is a pure Singleplayer vs AI game. If you want Multiplayer strategy, that princess is in another castle.For the rest, it takes some of the best concepts of other (indy) games. The game plays on 3 areas: Galactic, Space Combat, Ground CombatGalactic:Is turn based on a 2D map.The colonisation and colony building closest resembles Civilisation for me. Other liken it to Master of Orion, but I have not playe that series. It focuses more on few, well developed colonies with the right buildings.It borrows planetary effects and random events/miniquests from Galactic Civilsiations.You can freely pick you fleets destiantion (no squars/hexes), but fuel greatly limits range outside of your territory.Diplomacy has two unique turns:1. The evaluation mechanic is open, with the game actually telling you leader personalities and the weighted values of diplomacy items.2. The tollerancy mechanic means you cannot simply ignore negative relation modifiers or past deeds of the AI. Your people are a factor too and just won't allow certan deals to happen.Research:You can only research one tech per "Tier" giving you some hard choices and you have to aquire the others via espionage or diplomacy.Space combat:Is realtime on a 2D map. It closest resembles space empires for me.It seems to focus more on decisive, large scale battles rather then skirmishes.Ship design is also seems heavily borrowed from SE, but simplified. Facings matter. There is few geartypes/hulls and almost no levels, but there are lots of modifiers (1-4) you can apply to nearly every item.Upgrading and retrofitting is seamless.Ground:Turn based on a isometic, square based map.Battles are fought by small elite teams or "boarding parties" rather then large armies.Troops can have up to 3 abilities (active and passive, with cooldown or without) and based on technology and events you can almost freely choose thier gear while at a planet.There is no boarding outside of events.Documentation:There a lots of tooltips and spoken/interactive toutorials.Tech descriptions for new ship modules are often quite vague wich can result in picking the wrong tech.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												This is a very good game, I must admit I only have about 6-7 hours in it, but everything I have seen so far tells me it is an excellent 4X.  I own a lot of games (too many) so I know a good game when I see one.  I think it captures what it is trying to achieve, a excellent combat model.  Yes, if you want to to win using other methods then there might be better options out there (although this is still pretty good in those areas since Sector Zero) but if you want to expand and exterminate there is  none finer.  I love the new map, reminds me of Endless Legend maps.  With Sector Zero he spiced up the galaxy map making them more interesting to explore, the rewards is finding valuable goodies to enhance your empire.Yes, there are some bugs with Sector Zero,  but to Zero's credit he  has been releasing patches like crazy.  And that is my final point, I think Zero is comitted to this title so I think the long term support will be there.  Great game, well worth the price and Sector Zero enchances the game greatly.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Let me preface this review by stating that I'm a huge 4x turn-based fan (I've already pre-ordered GalCiv 3).After making the horrible mistake of buying Worlds of Magic, I was looking for something to tide me over and I'm pleased to report that StarDrive 2 is quite satisfying.  I love the fact that one of the nearby civilizations picked a fight with me (Normal difficulty, first playtrhough) as I am tired of passive turn-based games where you can turtle, out-tech, then curbstomp the awful AI.  Reading all of the complaints that the game is too hard is what drove me to purchase StarDrive 2 as I was leery of another Indie developer releasing garbage like Worlds of Magic.Edit: Another 10 hours in, and a few more great features.  Random, interesting events much in the vein of Masters of Orion and the infantry combat (capturing planets and other stuff) is turn-based with complete manual control.  I do find myself a bit overpowered with this but I love the addition!If you are a fan of Galactic Civilizations, you will very likely enjoy StarDrive 2 -- this should last until GalCiv 3!
