content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												There are a lot of negative reviews of this game that based solely on the fact that it's 'rock solid' and 'unforgiving'.IT'S A 4X. WHAT DID YOU EXPECT?!Seriously though, this game is wicked. It's a vast improvement over its predocessor. What I love the most about this game is that the developers have taken StarDrive (1) and gone back to the drawing board with it; keeping in the awesome and cutting out the naff. My number one hope was that they would keep in the awesome races, MoO ship customisation and the battle screen. Done. What I hoped they'd take out was the Gal Civ-esque 'real-time turn-based' time progression - which was both infuriating and rubbish. Done.The new focus on diplomacy and the ad-hoc intergalactic economy that it creates is really cool. I love that making friends with the AI is not just a pointless sideshow. If you don't play nice with them, you can't trade for those sweet sweet techs that you didn't pick in the new research tree (which is great as well) and your holla dolla generation just tanks if you stay isolationist.That being said, the AI can 'play nice', but it's my experience that it comes down to what race you're trying to suck up to. If the race is hellbent on galactic domination and keep on asking you for tribute and gifts... OF COURSE THEY'RE GOING TO END UP INVADING YOU.I have had a couple of freezes on the loading screen, but honestly - it was twice in 15h of playtime, which is a damn-sight better than some games on release.I love that this game isn't an 'early access' title too. It's something that really put me off of StarDrive (1) which ended up with me only putting a few hours because of how buggy it was.I wholeheartedly look forward to where the devs take this game. I'll happily pay for any expansion they come out with.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												This is a great game, and stands well on its own, and I plunked 9 hours into it without even blinking.  That being said, this is what Master of Orion 3 should have been.  It seems to be extremely influenced by Master of Orion 2, and even the space combat, while real time, is vaugely reminiscent.  The original Master of Orion was my first foray into 4x gaming(Star Fleet and Star Fleet 2: Krellen commander being my first Scifi gaming love) and as such newcomers to the genre, or those who have not grown up with the unforgiving older 4x titles may find this game difficult on the normal difficulty settings.  This title brings back memories of gaming long since forgotten about, and does not incorporate a lot of the hand-holding of newer generation games.  Which I find refreshing.  I recommend this game whole-heartedly.

												Let me preface this review by stating that I'm a huge 4x turn-based fan (I've already pre-ordered GalCiv 3).After making the horrible mistake of buying Worlds of Magic, I was looking for something to tide me over and I'm pleased to report that StarDrive 2 is quite satisfying.  I love the fact that one of the nearby civilizations picked a fight with me (Normal difficulty, first playtrhough) as I am tired of passive turn-based games where you can turtle, out-tech, then curbstomp the awful AI.  Reading all of the complaints that the game is too hard is what drove me to purchase StarDrive 2 as I was leery of another Indie developer releasing garbage like Worlds of Magic.Edit: Another 10 hours in, and a few more great features.  Random, interesting events much in the vein of Masters of Orion and the infantry combat (capturing planets and other stuff) is turn-based with complete manual control.  I do find myself a bit overpowered with this but I love the addition!If you are a fan of Galactic Civilizations, you will very likely enjoy StarDrive 2 -- this should last until GalCiv 3!

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												This is a great game, and stands well on its own, and I plunked 9 hours into it without even blinking.  That being said, this is what Master of Orion 3 should have been.  It seems to be extremely influenced by Master of Orion 2, and even the space combat, while real time, is vaugely reminiscent.  The original Master of Orion was my first foray into 4x gaming(Star Fleet and Star Fleet 2: Krellen commander being my first Scifi gaming love) and as such newcomers to the genre, or those who have not grown up with the unforgiving older 4x titles may find this game difficult on the normal difficulty settings.  This title brings back memories of gaming long since forgotten about, and does not incorporate a lot of the hand-holding of newer generation games.  Which I find refreshing.  I recommend this game whole-heartedly.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												There are a lot of negative reviews of this game that based solely on the fact that it's 'rock solid' and 'unforgiving'.IT'S A 4X. WHAT DID YOU EXPECT?!Seriously though, this game is wicked. It's a vast improvement over its predocessor. What I love the most about this game is that the developers have taken StarDrive (1) and gone back to the drawing board with it; keeping in the awesome and cutting out the naff. My number one hope was that they would keep in the awesome races, MoO ship customisation and the battle screen. Done. What I hoped they'd take out was the Gal Civ-esque 'real-time turn-based' time progression - which was both infuriating and rubbish. Done.The new focus on diplomacy and the ad-hoc intergalactic economy that it creates is really cool. I love that making friends with the AI is not just a pointless sideshow. If you don't play nice with them, you can't trade for those sweet sweet techs that you didn't pick in the new research tree (which is great as well) and your holla dolla generation just tanks if you stay isolationist.That being said, the AI can 'play nice', but it's my experience that it comes down to what race you're trying to suck up to. If the race is hellbent on galactic domination and keep on asking you for tribute and gifts... OF COURSE THEY'RE GOING TO END UP INVADING YOU.I have had a couple of freezes on the loading screen, but honestly - it was twice in 15h of playtime, which is a damn-sight better than some games on release.I love that this game isn't an 'early access' title too. It's something that really put me off of StarDrive (1) which ended up with me only putting a few hours because of how buggy it was.I wholeheartedly look forward to where the devs take this game. I'll happily pay for any expansion they come out with.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												As a veteran of Imperium galactic series, Galactic Civ, and SD1 as well as a few others I have to say StarDrive 2 holds its head up high among its piers.the gameplay is fresh yet familiar. I have to admit I was leery of the new turn based system but in the scheme of things it makes sense and it's a welcomed addition.Currently I've restarted the campaign 3 times as I wrap my head around some of the new mechanics and because my poor human civilization was blasted to death by alien scum - which means either I'm terrible at this game or it's hard, which is awesome!.The graphics are beautiful, especially the way space combat looks, the planets are all awesome looking as well, the new hex system and fresh.The mechanics of researching and building your fleet is pretty much the same as SD1, which is a good thing.Space combat is enjoyable and satisfying, nice big explosions and a slow motion mode too! One gripe I have in space combat is that weapons don't lead targets, they aim at where the target was, not at its expected position. Missiles don't turn to intercept targets instead they make weird turns trying to catch up to it... it all feels very unnatural and I hope it's addressed in a patch.When it comes to planet colonization, the variety of planets is massive making the whole experience of picking and choosing where you want to focus the new seeds of your civilization as engaging as it is important.I like the way they've handled the freighters. Moving food and colonists around really saves us from a lot of the needless planetary micro from SD1. However freighters are not controllable, combine that with the smaller fleet caps and it makes it difficult to protect freighters when your main fleet is off attacking or exploring, they will literally fly directly at an enemy and suicide themselves. We should be able to control freighters, either directly or give us the ability to force them to dock at the nearest planet until the enemy fleet is taken care of.Fleet Caps: I really don't see the point of fleet caps. Since each ship has an upkeep cost which in itself is the fleet cap, to compound that with an additional cap to me seems redundant. I like the idea of the fleet cap but instead of having it give you a monetary penalty, it might be more interesting if it gave you a penalty to ships rearm and repair rate, maybe even a damage dealing reduction to ships. Reasoning being they just aren't receiving the maintenance they should.Ground combat. The research and upgrades aspect of it is well thought out and implemented however the actual ground combat is meek, it needs a re-tune. If it would have followed in the footsteps of Fallout 2 or X-COM it would have been amazing! But currently, weapons have a hard limit of minimum and maximum ranges,Covert Ops: Works similar to the first one, but different enough to be fresh, that being said I think it needs a re-tune. I have 5 spy's doing counter espionage which is the max and I'm still getting tech stolen from me every few turns, which is really quite frustrating. Perhaps remove the spy caps for home defense?Spatial anomalies, these are quite fun and new, really enjoying them so far and is a very welcomed addition.Interface: interface is well designed, lots of tooltips and the information is easy to understand and readily available in most circumstances. A few gripes I have, on the planetary screen, when cycling from planet to planet via the arrows - every time you click to go to a different planet, the arrows location move to a slightly different spot, making cycling planets in this way annoying, and dizzying. If a fleet is hovering over a planet, the planet under the fleet becomes un clickable, there's also a few other minor annoyances that needs that little bit extra polish.Overall, StarDrive2 is an engaging experience and I will surely play many more hours of it as I attempt to conquer the universe however as much as I like it, it's not quite there yet. everything seems 70-80%. It just needs one more good thick coat of polish to make this game really shine

												Excellent space 4x with modern graphics, good UI, and familiar mechanics for colony and fleet management. It's comfort food for those of who grew up with Master of Orion. number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												It's the best space strategy since Endless Space.Nicely customizable ships with vastly different abilities and even some interesting tactical ground combat.Game reliability has increased significantly since Stardrive 1 (I haven't even crashed once yet) and the semi-turn-based system does wonders for both late-game performance and an easier overview of your empire.There are still a couple of balancing issues where certain weaponry is more powerful than it should be and the different hull sizes give certain races an advantage, but I do believe those things can be balanced given time.All things considered, if you liked Stardrive 1 and it's potential - you'll love stardrive 2.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Just finished 20 hours straight on this game and I love it! I'm playing on easy mode since I'm new to 4x space games. I've spent hours just creating ships, which is a blast! For those complaining about the game being too hard, even on easy, customize your setup and choose "Creativity" pregame, you'll be glad you did when  your ships are always better or as good as any fleet that comes your way! I'm really impressed with this game. I spent hours reading/watching reviews prior to purchasing and am very happy with my decision. I've played most all Civ games, but this game is a lot more challenging and fun. The battles are something to look forward to, especially when you have a new weapon tech that you've added to your fleet and you want to test it out.I agree that the GNN (which can be turned off in options) and ground war text scrolling is way to slow and that it should at least go to the end of the current sentence instead of skipping to the next, but that's about the only gripe I have.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I must say that the developer has ambushed me with how much this game is better than it's infamous predecessor. I own the first Star Drive and I was mildly dissapointed (some other people were foaming at the mouth and flinging rotten fruit).Now I see that the gameplay was re-worked, getting rid of the annoying stuff from the previous game. Also, some of the better gameplay concepts from the genre were expanded in most satysfying fashion (ground combat !). Loved ship design part then, love it even more now. Space battles are very good. Research system follows MoO2 which is not a bad thing (why change perfection :) )Sure enough there are some bugs being fixed (the review is written couple of days after release mind you), some balance tweaks, but this is a good game. Unless something horrible reveals itself during the gameplay later on I wholeheartedly recommend this title to any 4X lovers.Developer (and this is one person only) seems to have learned much and started to listen to the community closely. Good work.PS. Also, owners of the first part of the game were granted 33% off,  I suspect as a form of reward for sticking with the dev and StarDrive franchise. Good move.Edit: Got 15 extra hours under the belt and with almost daily balance updates by the dev I like this game even more :)

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												This is a very good game, I must admit I only have about 6-7 hours in it, but everything I have seen so far tells me it is an excellent 4X.  I own a lot of games (too many) so I know a good game when I see one.  I think it captures what it is trying to achieve, a excellent combat model.  Yes, if you want to to win using other methods then there might be better options out there (although this is still pretty good in those areas since Sector Zero) but if you want to expand and exterminate there is  none finer.  I love the new map, reminds me of Endless Legend maps.  With Sector Zero he spiced up the galaxy map making them more interesting to explore, the rewards is finding valuable goodies to enhance your empire.Yes, there are some bugs with Sector Zero,  but to Zero's credit he  has been releasing patches like crazy.  And that is my final point, I think Zero is comitted to this title so I think the long term support will be there.  Great game, well worth the price and Sector Zero enchances the game greatly.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Review is current per ver 1.1aWith the latest patch fixing many gameplay and bug issues this is NOW a awesome game with a ton of potential down the line with easy moddability.  SD2 Combines the best parts of Moo, Moo2, Gal Civ and other 4x games. The crown jewel of Stardrive has always been the real time space combat and SD2 does not disappoint. The combat is now faster, yet with more control, more streamlined and less frustrating YET more complex with more tactical choices in battle.  Choosing the most optimal Strategic counter response to threatening enemy fleets can win or lose the game. In a recent game I designed a slow, heavily armored and shielded fleet to demolish a Vulfar massed frigate/CRV  swam only to have a another race tear my primary fleet to shreds from all the way across the battle map with long range stand off missile fleet.  SD2 has  By FAR the most engaging and fun tactical space combat in any 4x game.  -1 point for some lingering bugs/ AI issue/ things need to be fleshed out (occasional Crashes)  but with future mods an patches this game will deliver me (and any 4X fan)  years of fun.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I found myself playing StarDrive 1 again after a while playing StarDrive 2!I need atmosphere, so I expect that your star empire evolves from Earth, as it is in the real universe.This is at least true for the Humans of Sol, where Earth is. And in StarDrive 1 you get a pretty good image of Sol - just like it is. (Yes, I'm probably a Human fanboy!) :)The only problem is that in StarDrive 1 the planets circumnavigate the central sun (Sol) in the wrong direction.But it looks good to see it in real time, for they are all there: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter and so on.In StarDrive 2 you have the same situation like you had in MoO2, but the battles are in real time and there is no multiplayer!Anyway, the game feels like MoO2, regarding a lot of aspects. Your home system always consists of 1 to 5 planets in random order. You'll face up to 8 different opponents and a lot of rouges! Battles take place in space, on planets and even on ships, with your away team entering! You start with a colony ship and a recon vessel. And you have to deal with research, money and ship design. I'm loving it!

content:
Posted: March 11
												I wanted to like this game, partly because of the review by @Armazati but this is no Star Control or Master of Orion. The lore at first glance appeared intriguing, until you start playing and realize it doesn't hold true, nor does it actually have any depth. I chose the immobile telephatic slaver race for the first playthrough, and even though their lower race should adore them like gods and unquestionably carry out everything, what I see is that there's planet happiness and it's low. I get an event to walk(!!!) to a space cowboy bar and the game dialogue treats me like a human peasant.Combat sucked, and the laser turrets apparently do not cause damage with the lasers themselves, but by pushing ordnance towards hostiles. How else do you explain them flying donuts around the shots of the laser turrests?!? Furthermore, the range on all weapons is limited, like do you even space? -_-;That combined to the developer apparently abandoning this project, just avoid this.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												This is a game i really strongly recommend. Think of master of orion 2, and add all the new jazz modern pc games have to offer. What you get is this game, and if you liked the original moo2, you're gonna love this.Now i've read the reviews before buying this game, and in most of the negative ones people cried about the game being too hard, about the ai cheating, about them dying the instant they meet anyone. I played the original master of orion a lot, and i must say that i had no problems holding my own. Yes, the pc is overagressive if he has a larger fleet. But as others have said in ther reviews, it is usually just a load of junk. Having a few decent ships, it was no issue to shoot that junk down and have enemy sue for peace.There is one slightly irritating issue, although it's hardly keeping me from enjoying the game. The GNN and ground missions have text written letter by letter. I assume it's because my pc isn't top-notch anymore, but it takes ages for the text to appear, much slower than my reading speed anyway. And after a click it's gone. Now what i've seen in other games that used this letter-by-letter style is to use the first click to complete the text, and second click to move on. This avoids frustration in fast readers / slow pc owners.In any case, if you liked the master of orion series and the original star drive, this is the perfect blend. Highly recommended.EDIT:After playing all the way through a game twice, I find it really worth the money. However there *is* one issue with planet management I see in late game - there are just too many structures I want to *build on each new planet*. Right now I avoid colonizing additional planets just because it would bring low benefit for much clicking - which is a wrong choice strategically.A very nice solution I've seen in one of the fan-made old civ games is - *templates*. Imagine there are cca 4-5 templates defined (template 1, template 2, T3, T4, T5) and *the player choses what this template will build*. After that a planet can be assigned to 'build' "template 1" and will start filling it's queue with stuff that is in template 1's queue. Now the obvious advantage of this approach over ministers is that player has complete control over what his planets are building, while *saving tons of clicking*. Plus when a new building is unlocked, there's nothing easier to add it to template 1 and have all planets using it build it.Example of this template approach can be found in an old fan civ game "C-Evo"->menu->macro management->city types.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Star Drive 2. Turn based strategy, real time combat. All of the original races are back along with a new race. Very good game.  There Can Be Only One! No alliances here, but you can butter up your neighbors. If they cask to trade for a really good tech, give them something lower and avoid diplomacy penalties by getting a diplomacy bonus! Trade and Non-Agression treaties can buy you time.This is a game where you need to build colony ships for each colony you want to colonize and there are three population tasks - Food, Industry and Research. You can even move population around.Food is available across the Empire - provided you have freighters (easy to build). Everything is handled by the game for your freighters. Poor planets give the same amount of money as any other, however, production suffers. Research is great! The larger your Empire the more expensive research is. There are research fields, and you only get one item from the list of three. You can trade or maybe capture the other items.Races are neat. Each is different with different traits. Racial traits for the playable race can be adjusted. This is Way Nice!Combat is pretty neat. This game does not have as many ships as Star Ruler 2, both games are very good. There is also ground combat, so bring troops!The only negative I have is that in the late game things slow down. However, the developer has stated he is working on improvement in this area. That will be good.Star Drive 2 is a really good game, it is very similar to Master of Orion 2, and I think even better. Do not listen to the negative reviews, Star Drive 2 is a very good space 4x game.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												SummaryProsGraphics better then sd 1Better UI changesMore techs/buildsConsTurned a great RTS into a mediocre TURNED BASED GAME(go play civ 3 its a better Turned based game)No new ships except for one new teamTeching is tedious and forces you to miss out on alot of techsGround combat is hella Lame and they wasted their time on itCan't build your own space stationsConstantly annoyed by enemy spies 5-6 a turn in late gameJust all around more boring the SD 1 Graphics are slightly better some UI changes are nice and some are horrid. Compared to starydrive one things are kind of boring and really nothing new. You can no longer make your own space stations which is a huge let down. They turned this RTS into a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥turned based game G♥♥♥♥♥♥♥G. The minor factions are cool but pointless. You have all the same ships as the frist one and only one new race the worst thing about this is they ruined the TAB view of Stardrive one and they replaced it with a tab click which shows ur ships modules but only one way so u have to remember what side is what(gets very annoying considering in SD 1 it tied in with w/e way the ship is facing.) Takes forever to tech up(just like sd1) and the computer will do it 50x faster. You are constantly annoyed by spys every turn 4-5 AI's will send spys to steal ur♥♥♥♥♥♥EVERYFUKIN TURN) to the point where the notifictations will take up half your screen. They also turned this into a turn based game.... so its like playing a lesser Glatic Civ. The reasearch is also annoying you can only do one of each tech or reasearch per tier per category which makes you have to decide on missing so much♥♥♥♥♥♥ The new ground combat mechanics are completely pointless its very boring and i feel like they could of not done it and they could of added more content to space and we would of all been happier for it. Spying/negotations are the only way to get tech you missed and spying is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥stupid hard you have to get 500 spy points on an Ai which requires you to go through 15-20 spies to steal one tech(if your lucky) since they pretty much kill them off every turn. If this game was 15$ i would say worth.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13
												So our Boy Zero is a Solo Developer with a good idea. That Idea was to rip off every 4X game ever made, get people to buy a semi finished product and then buy the DLC which is basicly the fix for the broken game. Even at this (Abandoned) stage it is still pretty much a polished Beta.So why am I recommending it?Because it is fun to play. The AI is OK, the mechanics are all in place. Yes it gets a bit repeatative towards the end, but then most 4X games do.StarDrive 1 had a thing where other Empires would just look at your empires power and surrender all control to you, which speeded up the final inevitable victory which this lacks. As was the whole game working in real time and being able to control your ships directly, which was a nice alternative to other 4X Turn based games, which was a fun, but I digress.The tactical combat in this makes up for that (When it doesn't bug out), Think Imperium Galactica's space combat.The Ground Combat is still a numbers game - Space bears Roll 20, Plant people roll 10+5 pointy stick techonolgy, like Master of Orion. But the Random Special Opperations and spy missions, Master of Magic style is a nice touch, if in need of some variation and expansion.Interactions and treaties with the AI are handled nicely too. Weighting of technologies and explaintions of what you are doing that irks them.The Graphics are basic but pretty, the UI is easy to get around and nothing that hasn't been seen before in every Sid Mayer game. If Buggy in places.Yes the galaxy is paper thin but there are the occational thing to mix it up a bit, Pirate attack, Political unrest, Vengence/Life Goal/Just plain random missions from a Hero Character. If thease were expanded on this game would be truly amazing. Think along the lines of Endless Legend, but here the stories are never fully finished.I look at other games like Polaris Sector, Stelaris and the New Master of Orion.Slightly more expensive, the Tactical combat is treated OK by some and then badly by others. The glitchy AI on a complicated idea is forgivable is it isn't game breaking. But DLC to make the game playable, this is something of a♥♥♥♥♥♥take. So even some of the bigger studios are guilty of the same crimes as Zero.So if you want to kill many hours leading your race of Space bears to colonise worlds afflicted with "Sharknados", ponder the best design of Space craft, before having T-Rexs with Guns stappled to thier heads break into a secret laboratory, this is the game for you.That and you are resigned to the "Coming Soon" Features not coming at all.I would love to see Zero properly finish a game and then release it, all the ideas fleshed out, it would probably be remarkable. As opposed to "Meh, brought it for the cost of half dozen beers, an it kept me occupied."

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												This game is pretty fantastic.  I am a fan of space civ / tactical combat games.  This addresses both of those categories extremely well.  The space combat is VERY fun.  The variety of races, abilities, ship weapons and modules, and technology is IMPRESSIVE.  I have spent a lot of time on this game in the last 10 days.The only complaint I have... is the end game goals are not clearly defined. I beat the massive Master ship, and was encouraged to retire... but saw no in-game way to conclude the game.  Seeing empire stats, and numbers comparing my empire to my competitors would be a really nice thing to have.  I felt underwhelmed, and somewhat unsatisfied with just quitting.  Will I play again?  Yes.  Do I love this game? Yes.  Could it be even better? Yes.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												First game, lasted only 30 minutes due to starvation and pirate fleet attacking my underwhelming fleet.Second game, Did better as the Vulfur (wolf guys) and started to capture planets and systems but met the humans, was promply eradicated. Third game, made a tiny map to think it would be easier to expand....I was wrong.Forth game, made a medium sized galexy and set it to 4 races, they gang banged me into a corner but I proudly held them off. Was killed later by crystals.Fifth game, started to learn the basics of the game at that point and got into the groove of it. Managed to control half the map till pirates started to attack my homeworld from the edge of the map, couldn't get there in time and soon whole race died. Eventually I'll be able to win one game but even still, I'm having a blast playing it. Sure, it may be a dumbed down version of it's first title but thats good for someone like me. I feel this game appeals to both hardcore 4X gamers and those just starting out. For me, its a must buy and sure, there may be other 4x titles out there but that doesn't mean this isn't a great game either. P.S. I know I don't have a lot of time in the game. It's due to my college work but I will be spending a lot more hours in StarDrive 2.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												StarDrive 2 is an excellent tribute to the classic Master of Orion II. This review is based on patched version 1.1a.A few comments:Stability and completeness: I've played this game for 40 hours. It never crashed. All features are present and complete...I assume the "this is a beta" reviewers were playing an earlier, unpatched version, or that I simply haven't encoutered the severe bugs they have. For comparison, every Bethesda RPG I've ever played had more and worse bugs than this game, even in GotY editions, and SD 2 is a one-man-show that cost me $30 undiscounted. It's not a beta.Space combat: emphasis in ship design is on tactics, not customizing appearance. I love this...that's why it's a MOO II tribute game. The real time combat does allow you control of targeting, movement, and some special ship abilities, but it's simple enough that you can resolve a large battle expediently...unlike MOO II. Much better tactical combat than Galciv 2 or Endless Space, with or without extensions.Ground combat: it's a simplified variant of Heroes or Age of Wonders style combat on a grid. You can customize troop loadouts, deploy shields, etc. Early in the game there are some nice ground combat missions that give you a challenge and reward early on, but once I figured out some simple tactics I found planetary invasions a bit easy: the AI is weak here. Personally I prefer the combat grid to the dice roll that is common for combat in 4x space games, especially in the early game.AI: Challenging, at least in the early game. I need more playthroughs on harder difficulty to assess this properly, but so far it's better than the really stupid AI in competing games, including Civ 5, etc. I suspect big publishers know the player wants to win, even if he's rubbish! I do think the AI needs some better ship designs in the late game.I've played the following similar games: MOO II, Galactic Civilizations 2, Endless Space, Sins of a Solar Empire. I actually bought Distant Worlds: Universe at the same time as SD 2, but opted to try SD 2 first...it's a good time for 4x gamers!

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												closest game to master of orion 2 i have seen so far. Since this game is like a remake of the all time classic I will compare the two gamesOriginally written at release, edited on release of the DLCPro:-It does have a great economic system that is heavily inspired by MoO2 and even improves the former ones.-The Space fights are Top, also the Ship desgin system-Nice Graphics-Really good strategic space map and boarder simulation (Note: got even better with recent DLC)-random events with some storyNeutral:-early random pirates can really hurt and bascilly trough the game, so u HAVE to prepare before expanding-the diplomacy has the potential to shine, but it needs some more tradeobject. like force someone to declair war to someone etc.-the UI is not as compact as MoO2, and could need some more links and detail tooltipsNegative:-Like MoO2 it still has some bugs BUT the dev is stil actively working on the game (as of 2016 still active, just released an DLC)-german langunage is partly bad translated, better play in english-you feel like with some final relatively small adjustment this could be the best 4x game ever. (with the recent DLC this is even more true)-I dont like the ground battles. (its like a streamlined XCOM). I feel sorry for the dev since u can see he invested quite some time to develop this. It just doesnt works out that good in a game focused on space (THIS IS FIXED WITH THE DLC's new ground combat system!!)Total:I enjoy the game, and I am looking forward to every patch from the dev. If you liked Master of Orion than buy this. Some points Stardrive2 does better others MoO2.As of 2016 with the recent DLC, this is the true succesor of MoO2 and the very best 4X available at the moment.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												After my negative review of Stardrive 1 I thought I'd review this to set the records straight, this game improves on SD1 in every way, every little problem I have with the first one is resolved and more:+ It's stable! Not a single crash, laggy moment or instability. + The research system is vastly improved and adds a few features I've not seen in a 4x game, including a system that makes diplomacy and espionage very important. + The ship varieties are nice, the game is very pleasant to look at. + There's even a little X-com like tactical game for your ground troops+ Random events and regions of space can trigger special research projects that can help your empire+ Freighters and cargo transport has been hugely streamlined, this used to be very frustrating in SD1 having to micromanage all of your freighters.+ Good variety of planet features that give extra depth to the colonisation system including some nods to classic sci-fi.All that being said, there are some things that could have been done a little better:- The sound design suuuucks! from random 'sci-fi beeps' on the tactical map and cheesy 'pew-pew' noises in battles, the sound design could have been so much better, honestly can't remember what the music is like other than I turned it off pretty quickly.- there is a max 100 system limit. the galaxy doesn't feel particularly big, gets crowded quickly with more than 3 opponents.- A couple of balancing issues could use looking atAll in all though, this is a solid 4X game that improves greatly on it's predecessor, pleased to have bought it.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												The original Stardrive was a fun little game, and I probably spent over a hundred hours on it. But it had quite a few problems too, so I was a bit skeptical in how the sequel would be. I was however positively surprised! This game addresses nearly all my issues I had with the first title. The presentation, and game flow feels far better this time around. It does however still have a few random bugs every now and then, even if none of them game breaking it can be slightly annoying. Besides that, the game itself runs smooth, and the turn changes are near instant. The prequel had a tendency to become near unplayable at higher difficulties due to performance drops, as the enemies would clog the galaxy with endless fleet battles. I think the new instanced battle system is an improvement from the old one in that regard ( no late game lag anymore ). As for the people complaining about the AI “cheating” in some reviews – I see no proof of this, and I have no trouble personally keeping up with the AI at medium and hard difficulties ( currently halfway into a game on hard as Vulfen, with me owning 1/4th of the galaxy ) . The game however does have bit of a learning curve, and the AI is quite aggressive for some races. Expect to die a few times before you learn the ropes.  ( when to expand, what to research first, figuring out what ship designs to make etc ) I for one like the AI this time around, it feels more clever than before. Although I’d guess a “Beginner” difficulty setting wouldn’t be a bad thing though, to let new players get to learn the game at a slower pace. (I might write a beginner guide sometime ) I don’t really have a lot more to say. The gameplay is fun, the races varied, and the artwork is neat. If you like x4 games, and don’t mind a challenge. This is a solid indie buy and I would recommend it to my friends.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												So, I'm a very old gamer, but I've never written a Steam Review before.  This game needs more good reviews, so I'll make it my first.  As a veteran of every major 4x and strategy game since I played the first Civilization as a teenager, Stardrive 2 stands out as a real gem.  Major pluses:+Depth and complexity in race and game setup without endless sliders and checkboxes.  You have several meaningful choices, which can be combined in complex ways to make for a very different play experiences, but customization isn't a total swamp of minor adjustments.+The planet characteristics (Size, Type, Gravity, Mineral Abundance, Strategic Resources, Special Features) can be combined in an absolutely cool and endless number of ways to create a very unpredictable variety of planets.  This makes for great choices to make on the strategic map.+The graphics are effective and evocative, and the game text and lore have a sense of humor matching the gamestyle.  This is an unusual and really beneficial thing - too many games have beautiful art that's not so evocative, or err on the side of grim-and-serious when that is not a needed aesthetic for their other choices.+Ship design is fun, deep, and offers many ways to optimize your ships together or individually, while refit system encourages you to redesign when needed without a major gameplay penallty.+Battles are pretty, quick, and offer an appropriate level of micromanagement.  They break the turn cycle with a real-time experience, tracking individual ships with medals and such for accomplishments is also a nice touch.+Tooltips abound, meaning the complex mechanics can be explored and understood easily.+Ongoing patching seems to indicate developer involvement and dedication.+Diplomacy system uses trade, different weights for different groups and players, and a "tolerance" mechanic in an effective and interesting way - but see below for critiques of diplomacy.No game is perfect, though:- UI could use improvement and efficiency, with better keyboard commands and such.  This includes things like idle planet notifications.- More and more interesting random events are needed to keep the universe outside of the AI players more alive.- Some races feel less balanced than others, in the area of advantages and ship designs.  Same with weapon designs.- Total randomness of setup can create very unfun initial game conditions, or conditions where you don't realize how much better other player's starting areas were until you're already a ways into the game.- More diplomatic options and win conditions could make this feel more like a "complete" 4x game.  The AI's tendency to want to kill you at first sight could also be watered down a wee bit, at least for the 'not genocidal' races.This is not a complete review, just a few isolated thoughts.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Stardrive 2 have been a highly anticipated game for me personally this year so i eagerly sat down and started playing it the 10th.First of all it was completely different from SD1 and so there was alot more to learn, but if you know the basics of x4 games this wont be too difficult as you need to follow the basic "explore, expand, exploit and exterminate". Thus you will do this and the AI will do this during the whole course of the game through a wide variety of strategies with invasions and diplomacy.What i really like is that the tech tree has been improved, now i am still a little uncertain if it is for the better og worse as you only get to choose a handfull of technologies (in a normal game), but this will push you towards "roleplaying" or acting more with your races' traits, if you choose the trait "creative" however you will be able to get all the technologies except racial/experimental tech from the other races. I was a big fan of SD1 not exactly being turn based so everything happened in real time like space battles and exploration, but to compensate for that the developer gave us BATTLE ARENAS! which i for one enjoy very much and it makes for a more interesting experience though i hate that i always manage to get destroyed.What i dont like that much is mostly a few smaller problems like when i try to box-select my ships in a battle arena the mouse cursor may touch the minimap and then my view gets teleported to the other side of the arena which is annoying. I am very unsure about the ground combat, but that is my personal preference, it does however feel a little quick made in many ways; firstly it looks bad but i can always get over that fact, Secondly the player is too prone to missclick and give orders by accident, there should be some way to give the soldiers orders in a proper way (example: i tend to click and check what soldiers are equipped with so i can send my short ranged soldiers to the front, but it is too easy to give them orders so they will either shoot or walk somewhere by accident).These are tiny problems of course and i will enjoy the game to the fullest no matter, but it would be nice to see some sort of fix for this. Now i havent even touched the surface for how good this game can be, i mean the best part about it is to construct your own ships and send them into combat to see how long they survive, but it seems to me that the remnant invasion, angry crystal ships, pirates and the other empires loves to harrass the player alot. (i was so lucky to get the "Zapp Brannigan" leader on my first run and didnt understand why i was attacked so much). Maybe i am just a complete idiot and embarrasingly bad at constructing ships too, but i spent most of my time researching tech and turtling while being blokaded by remnant ships and pirates until the empires around me sandwitched me to kingdom come.So all in all if you are still reading, this game is very good! it is easy to understand and get into, the AI will destroy you on Normal and you must learn that Patience is a virtue, i recommend this highly, especially in the future when there probably will be alot of exciting mods to come from a great modding community.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												this game build on predecessors like Sins of a Solar Empire or Imperium Galactica II to create an amazing 4X strategy game that stands out all on it's own.  there are plenty of different races (9 I believe), all with pretty unique traits.  only one race doesn't seem that great.  the diplomacy is top notch, something most games is this genre struggle with.  this game also has ground combat (think old school x-com), something most of the games in this genre do not have.  Some of the random events that occur in campaigns require you to do things like attack a pirate base with mariens to stop their raids, or clear a derelict of hostile aliens to acquire alien technology.  these random events, combined wiht the fact that each races AI behaves differently depending om their racial traits make for a very replayable and divergent game.  which alien you first contact can totally change the way your game unfolds.  Last but far from least, the ship combat in this game is pretty darn good and strategic, and it hinges rather heavily on designing your own ships.  you have different ship hulls ( you start with 3 and can research more) and can outfit different variations for each hull to serve different roles.  what is really cool about this is that it creates incentive to actually buld carrier battle groups with escorts and the whole 9 yards, very cool.  If you love strategy, or space, get this game!

												OK, Bought it and have played about 30 games. In a good game, my empire doesn't get squashed 20 turns in from making first contact and it reminds me of all the good parts of Masters of Orion.But the really sucky thing, is that there is a game stopping BUG (and I do't mean an alien bug) when your fleet destroys a large enemy fleet of small ship. A list of the destroyed small ship names appears on screen and doesn't go away. Effectively Game Over! This especially sucks because it happens when your empire is kicking♥♥♥♥♥ a rare event.So, overall, excluding the BUG which must be fixed, I give it 3.5 stars out of 5. And, with practice, you can learn which weapon and armor techs work best and actually kick♥♥♥♥♥ Plus NEVER sell the good war techs your enemy doesn't have, but that is just  common sense, not a problem with the game.As far as game management is concerned, their MUST be a central ground troops load out screen for the entire empire. I can't tell you how many planets I have lost because I forgot to upgrade the troops. With some more TLC and the BUG fix, this could be close to a 5 star 4X game that runs on mAC!

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												It doesnt suck!I play alot of games, most of which suck, not this one doe.If you like 4x games and you like space themes your gonna like this game. interface is clean, research is straight forward tho geared a little more towards unlocking new weapons for your ships then say a shiny new building.Combat is where this game stands above the rest for me. your ships can be bound to a fleet and move as a single unit across the strategic map but once you encounter a enemy your brought into a real time battle where your ships are controlled individually and the battles are always exciting. and for those of you that don't like the pressure of real time combat, don't worry, you can slow the combat down to issue orders.The second best part about this game is the turn times, if you've ever played civ 5 you'll know what i mean when i say theres nothing more frustrating then finnaly building a empire just to quit the game because you don't wanna wait 20 min for the ai to take thier turns. just isn't an issue with stardrive 2. every time i hit end turn, the next turn starts right away. crazy huh?The only bad review i've seen so far are from people who are getting beat non stop by the AI.They arent lieing the ai is smart and ♥♥♥♥ing scary, when i get threatened by another race or see them approaching my borders i don't laugh at thier feeble armys. i♥♥♥♥♥♥my ♥♥♥♥ing pants!If i still havent convinced you to buy this game, think about the fact that this game was made by a smaller team then any game you've probably ever played, yet still gets fast updates and you can count on the devs to help you anytime you find a bug. hell i even saw zero helping a dude who was simply missing video card drivers.Great game by a great team. buy this♥♥♥♥♥♥ even if only to support good game devs.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Only a short review since there is a character limit and my last atempt run out of space half way through.It's a good game for the MoO2 fans. If you liked MoO2 this game will scratch that itch, however it is a bit different.Each race has different ships which means different sizes and so some races are just better for having bigger ships, in fact some races has cruisers as big as some other races battleship so there is a bit of inballance there, looking up the wiki to find which race to play is definitly advised at least for the first playthroughs.Spaceship combat is interesting, it allows for some things that MoO2 didn't since it's in real time. For example I can fit a few fast ships with cruise missile and run circles around enemy slow ships avoiding slow moving rockets and out of range of their guns. on the other hand the turn based combat of MoO2 was more strategic allowing you to chose what weapon to fire so you could make sure that point defense weapons wouldn't be wasted on enemy ships just because they got close. Differences aside, long range weapons are incredibly overpowered. Mass drivers and guass cannons are pretty much the metagame because not only they are incredibly powerful, but they are also very easy to research.There are some inbalanced in the perks, creative is too bad because it's very expensive to justify learning all tech but on the other side subterranean gives you so much population that it's nearly a crime not to take it with how overpowered it is.The diplomacy system leaves a lot to desire, it is in fact the one thing I'd say is straight up worse than MoO2. Trading depends on tolerance, you spend tolerance to do a trade and have to wait for it to refil. Tolerance limits also depends on how much the enemy likes you. This leads to trades often being impossible. Add that the hardest difficulty makes the AI want 70% gain on trades and that's that for diplomacy. Obviously because of this system nothing lasts forever. Trade agreements last 50 turns, so do pacts and there are no alliances (not that i think alliances were needed).I could keep going on but the bottom line is. The game has a MoO2 feel to it while still managing to be it's own thing. I feel however that at this point a lot of balance improvements are required and a lot of quallity of life improvements too are needed.If I had to rate this game I'd give it a 7 out of 10. Definitly a game which is above average, but with a bit of a road ahead to become really good. The good news are that the developer (which is only one guy) is still actively balancing the game and doing bug fixing (not that you'll find many, I ran into a couple bugs only and they are not really easy to reproduce).

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												As an avid fan of Stardrive 1, I had high standards coming into Stardrive 2. I was surprised to find that the game had changed from a real time strategy to a turn based format, although space combat still happens in real time. The turn based format does not hamper the game flow however, and Stardrive 2 is just as fun as it's predecessor in terms of a space 4X Game.Pros:-Diplomacy system is greatly improved from SD1-Space combat is simple, but effective. Your ships will have multiple weapons and can engage multiple targets at the same time.-Ground combat is now a turn-based system, unlike SD1's "Land troops on a planet and cross your fingers" system.-Ship Building has been simplified but still very easy to grasp.-Unique missions and events featuring neautral factions keep the game interesting.-Interesting and diverse factions with different personalities. Factions with similar personality traits get bonuses in diplomacy.Cons:-The game can be very hard for players not familiar with the genre.-The game does not tell you if a planet is sitting idle and not constructing anything. This results in lost production so it's important you keep your build queues full.-Less ability for automation compared to SD1. For example, you cannot tell your scouts to Auto-Explore, or your ships to defend an area.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												Stardrive 2 is a very deep, turn space managing game. The battles are very well done as the ship fitting system. The experience levelling of ships is also very interesting, made by levels and medals that give you bonus in battle. The game is more about managing the fleet, create good fittings, managing planets and expanding. Diplomacy is quite fine and the gameplay can be very deep. The ground battle could be improved, maybe doing it a bit quicker, or make the troups auto-fighting. The core and best aspect is to me the fleet battle where you can pause the fight and study a good strategy, according to your fleet composition / fittings. Technology tree could be a bit more clear, but is still working fine. Defenetly if you liked Galactic Civilization 2, you must play Stardrive 2. I feel is a naturale improve of GC2.Pro - Deep ship fittings system      - Nice battles to watch and manage      - Good longevity, replayable      - Very nice system of levelling of ships, with medals according to kills/assists and Xp      - Good map generator      Con - Not 100% customizable faction       -  Battles on ground are not so enjoable as space battles       - Still not enough mods

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												This game is awesome! Super fun, super difficult, and super addicting. The ground troops building is very confusing. They appear when you build an infantry base, but the number varies and the time to spawn or if they respawn is not obvious, still good though. However the space AI does odd things. 386 command point fleet (chukk) crossed open space on cluster map and snipe colonies. They have about 14 colonies. I have more colonies and I have about 33 command limit. Now you can build past your limit, but it is expensive so I really have no idea how they are not bankrupt. The only thing I can think of is that they don't take upkeep on their buildings or they don't pay penalties past their command limit. The devs have said that the AI doesn't cheat and I believe him, but I just can't believe something glitchy or buggy isn't happening. By the way, this is on easy difficulty as well.Questions I would ask are, does the AI suffer attacks from random events, remnant, crystal ***holes, and pirates and do they follow the fuel rules? Is their a cheat to toggle fog of war to see how the AI is doing this, and how do I take a break from playing this amazing game without withdraw symptoms?

By the way, this is on easy difficulty as well.Questions I would ask are, does the AI suffer attacks from random events, remnant, crystal ***holes, and pirates and do they follow the fuel rules? Is their a cheat to toggle fog of war to see how the AI is doing this, and how do I take a break from playing this amazing game without withdraw symptoms?

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Short: A clean, solid 4X game. Less short: A good mix of everything from other 4x games. It won't win out on orginality of the nth degree but what's here is workable and enjoyable. The dev has been in constant contact with the community on the steam forums and his own in adressing the issues that have been cropping up. It can be difficult but after a few tries i've finally reached a point in the game where I have a foundation to whack back. I personally found the pacing to be ideal as the starting game doesn't feel like it takes forever like Civ V or Gal Civ does. Your on toes from the get go which for some this may not appeal too. Overall as stated earlier the UI is clean and responsive. The gameplay is tough but rewarding. My main gripe is other empires colonising in my sphere of influence. I hope this gets fixed.

												Amazingly fun game.  While people complain that it is bad because it isn't like most 4X games, they are wrong because it is trying to be something else. number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												A lot of good features from the first game.Would like options to custom the design of starbases, or at least better information on what its current stats are.Several bugs encountered, however massive improvement over first game.  I have yet to actually crash or be unable to complete a game. Auto saves and Prebattle saves insured impact was minimized.Large battles could use optmization, however even though things slow down, it still works, which i call a winner so far.AI clearly is able to bypass some of the limits in the game.  Fuel, CP limits, constantly nagging you for tech in diplomancy, so you can never actually build up points to ask for large, if you decline to trade you still lose points to ask for what you want later.Late game the AI does not seem to have the ship designs needed for combat against high tech ships? Seems to spam low tech instead.  As with Stardrive 1, no real late game closer.  even on tiny galaxy, 40 systems, spreading domination across the map can take hours, though you've got death fleets moving in all directions. Just turns into an exercise in OCD.  Its like tracking down coch roaches. Leaders don't actually manage, or build ques.  More then 10 coloneys there should be profiles for building things on each world.  The bigger it gets, the slower... kind of the problem.  Some things in the game arn't really clear... Whats on your starbases, what zombies do, rugs?, Infected planets?, space highways how to, what guns do what and fire at what. How many things you can build on your planet?? The shipyard needs a SIMULATOR, so you can test your design. The big black ship on the other side of the worm hole is a beast, that was fun.  But thats it?  I was sure i would get something to help me kill everyone with.The game is either too easy, or hopeless, or just too long.  Fun is shortlived once you start wining. The fun is really in watching your ship designs work.  I honestly believe the future of gaming is in here somewhere,  When a game lets you design the content, but we are still a long way off.Look at Reassembly, its single player, yet incorporates designs from other players into the player's experience... Seems like this would be a good idea here to apply.  The posiblities of ships and designs are more then 1 developer could ever come up with... what if the AI used valid designs from other players in its war effort?  Things they have the tech for from a pool of player made items?  You'd never know what to expect?Ultimatlely I feel like this is a more finished version of Stardrive, the first game was commonly reguarded as unfinished, and as someone that put 100s of hours into the first game, I feel the game is unfinished, yet still had potential.  Stardrive 2 should be considered Stardrive 2.0 not a continuation of the game, but a more finished version of the first game.  It feels like the developer took what he learned from the first game, and improved on the game.  Discounting it for those that bought the first game, good call. Clearly Zero has put in a lot of work on this, and deserves a pat on the back, because this is far more then just an update on his first game, he's completely over hauled it.Combat optimization, maybe some PLayer AI assistance both in combat and in over all map control could be helpful.Ground combat is my only real beef with the game, its just bad in many ways... needs to be more like fleet battles, like a RTS when it goes down. and NEVER AUTO ground combat... really just dont.Conclusion...If you like 4x, pick this game up... the art work alone is great, I honestly love the aliens.  You already know what to expect from other 4x games.  Music is pretty good... bugs sure, but the developer seems to be addressing things harder for his new baby.  What else are you gona do?  Go outside?

												I will start by first saying I am allitle Biased.  I loved stardrive one, it was easilly my favorite game durring that period and I sank hours into it.  When I heard that they were making a StarDrive 2, I thought it was going to be a money grab.  I was a little dissapointed.  I am glad to say that I was pleasently wrong.  Looking at StarDrive 2 on its own merrits, I enjoy it a lot. To me the best part of the game is the customizable ships.  While some parts are more simple then Stardrive 1's but it works.  What they did with the randomish quests and story elements really reminds me of playing Masters of Orion Two with a updated UI and real time space battles.  I would recomend this game to people that are a fan of space combat games or Masters of Orion.  If you are looking for a clone of the first game this is not the game for you.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Played, or at least tried every 4x Space Genre game for many many years.  As an original founder waiting patiently for Gal Civ 3, I was anxious to give SD2 a spin for something to do while waiting.....Now this is a first impressions review and I have not logged many hours yet, but that said, first impressions are pretty important and SD2 made a good one with me.  So far I am lovin it!  I found it easy to get in to and was quite impressed with the interface and game systems.  Its clean and plays well.  I like the spin on a the tech tree where you have to choose a single tech in a given category/level and can only get the others in that category/level through diplomacy or espionage.  Decisions decisions!  I also really like the ship building.  Here again, many decisions to be made yet the construction interface is easy to use and makes sense.  More decisions when it comes to expansion and building.  I found that the normal 4x land grab rush may not work as well here due to various encounters and mechanics.  It can be pretty dangerous right out of the shoot even close to your home planet.  A more planned and thoughtful build/expansion strategy is required.  At the end of the day, I find the games mechanics to present many more meaningful decisions than some of the other 4x space genre fare out there.  Kudo's to the SD2 team!  Looks like you might have a winner!

It is a true evolution of the previous game, an improvement and new direction in almost all aspects. For the better. The dev finally got it right after the first game honestly kind of was a beta experiment.Buy it now, if you are a fan of 4x games, such as Galciv, Distant Worlds, MOO, Armada or Endless Space.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Pretty much every 4X game that has come out since the genre has started gets asked one question. How does it compare to the styles of Master of Orion 2 or Civilization. A lot of them fall short because they are missing key features or ideas from one of those two iconic games. Stardrive 2 is a game that manages to remake the classic feeling of those games while also adding to the formula. In a nutshell and remake of the legendary MOO2. You only need to glance at it to see the similarities. This is both good and bad. If you are a diehard Civilization fan, you will immediately notice the game focuses less on empire simulation and more on conflict and exploration. That may leave you a bit disappointed. On the other hand though, if you like MOO you will love this game for those exact reasons.Each game has a lot of customization options, though I wish there were a few more galaxy option types. Still there are a lot to fool around with and you can customize a lot of the details of each opponent race. Once a game is started there is a lot to explore and do. Things start out slow for your planets, but you will eventually unlock a ton of tech to build each planet or asteroid. I find myself satisfied with these options and can churn out planets exactly how I like. So for empire building it is a thumbs up.A little while into the game you will see that it is very combat focused. And the game is difficult on normal setting. The AI is aggressive and challenging. You can’t sit on your laurels waiting for things to happen. You have to be constantly building and expanding to stay competitive. To make matters worse for any fledgling Emperors, your empire will also face random scenarios from time to time that usually involve someone attacking or pillaging your empire. The AI doesn’t have to deal with this events and if you are not careful, you can find yourself surrounded by other empires as well as random event attacks. On the plus side, the scenarios usually grant your rewards for their completion.Combat and ship design are definitely SD2’s strong point there are a lot of options to make some truly unique ships that fight how you want. It is very rewarding to watch your designs bring your victory. In actual combat, the game looks and plays great. Tactics are key and the right or wrong moves can turn a lopsided battle into a victory or defeat. The AI employs some solid designs and tactics, however he should be a little quicker to adapt to my designs. Ground combat is okay. It is nice to see something attempted and I am having fun with it, but it could definitely be more fleshed out. This maybe because the maps feel a little empty.SD2’s biggest weakness right now is diplomacy. It has the standard options, but uses a system called Tolerance to represent a race’s familiarity to limit the amount of options you can conduct in a session to keep you from just spamming options. The system is great on paper and was super cool early in the game, however the AI’s aggressiveness will soon override your options. Too many things can effect a races opinion of you negatively. If the AI wants to trade for a tech even when he has nothing worthwhile if I turn him down our relationship suffers. If I say yes our tolerance gets used up so I can’t ask for things I want later. If I don’t pay them money for their threats they get angry. If I expand too much they get angry. It is hard to keep them happy without simply giving into all their requests. Conversely, they seem to not care at all about my happiness. Worse I have no option to complain about their spying or attempts to colonize planets in my systems. The concept is sound, but the balance needs to be reworked. Right now it is a little more frustrating than rewarding.Overall, the game really is a great accomplishment. It just does so many things I have always wanted in a 4X right. There are plenty of nitpicks here and there, but the amount of fun I am having with it far outweighs those issues. The game only retails for 30 USD. As of this review I have 16 hours logged in so for me it was well worth the price. There are a lot of options and plenty of ways to get in all 4 of the Xs. And it certainly has the “Just one more turn feel”

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												One of the best Space 4x games yet. The ship/hull outfitting and customization is 2nd to none and is my top pick in that category on a 4x no holds barred wishlist.Stardrive 2 is Master of Orion 2 remade with Stardrive integrated into it. And its all done extremely well. His politics and bargaining system is quite ingenious in preventing the typical barter everything at once exploit that no one else (of whose games I've played at least) has manged to do.Combat is pausable real-time and what you outfit your ships with and  how you use them makes a difference. Same goes for ground combat which in most other 4x is largely ignored or marginalized.Modding support looks to be great (I'm not a modder but already upon release theres a good playable Star Trek mod in progress)The only area where some other 4x games have over this is victory scenarios other than all out total conquest. Thats it. Graphics, depth, ship/hull customization, ground combat, thought out diplomacy. This game has a lot! It may not score perfect 10s in ALL categories, but it does is some and high 8s or 9s in others. I highly, highly recommend this space 4x!

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												TL;DR - Overall the game was worth it for me, I think they got the pricing right on this one. Hopefully they patch some of the problem areas listed below.The game is fun, interesting, and quite challenging at times. I enjoyed it, until I beat it.Pros:-I liked the diplomacy in this one with the 'tolerance' limiting your trades-Ship design was a lot of fun-It was fun to micro the ships in combat-the tech tree was cool.Neutral:-The number of high-quality planets (i.e. planets that grow food) are quite low. So the game does sort of stove pipe you into some tech decisions. Cons:-Very large battles take FOREVER to process even with a decent computer.-The end game needs some work-no technological victory. If you are playing on a large universe you have to hunt down every single occupied planet. Quite a big turn off for me after being in such a dominating position.-The above point really drags down the replayability for me.-Canopy shields OP.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												If you love 4x games (like me), you can't really go wrong here. Stardrive 2 steals features unapologetically from games like Master of Orion, Endless Space and of course Stardrive 1. It also tries to add some new depth to the XCOM style ground combat and the event-driven campaign.All that being said, it's not very polished. There are (slight) bugs as well as balancing issues and the "random encounters" aren't random at all, but always appear in the same order. I actually found the relatively small amount of ship modules refreshing, since your choices are more meaningful if there aren't thousands of options. What I'm missing are more planetary modules, more diplomacy options and a better end-game.

												Pretty much every 4X game that has come out since the genre has started gets asked one question. How does it compare to the styles of Master of Orion 2 or Civilization. A lot of them fall short because they are missing key features or ideas from one of those two iconic games. Stardrive 2 is a game that manages to remake the classic feeling of those games while also adding to the formula. In a nutshell and remake of the legendary MOO2. You only need to glance at it to see the similarities. This is both good and bad. If you are a diehard Civilization fan, you will immediately notice the game focuses less on empire simulation and more on conflict and exploration. That may leave you a bit disappointed. On the other hand though, if you like MOO you will love this game for those exact reasons.Each game has a lot of customization options, though I wish there were a few more galaxy option types. Still there are a lot to fool around with and you can customize a lot of the details of each opponent race. Once a game is started there is a lot to explore and do. Things start out slow for your planets, but you will eventually unlock a ton of tech to build each planet or asteroid. I find myself satisfied with these options and can churn out planets exactly how I like. So for empire building it is a thumbs up.A little while into the game you will see that it is very combat focused. And the game is difficult on normal setting. The AI is aggressive and challenging. You can’t sit on your laurels waiting for things to happen. You have to be constantly building and expanding to stay competitive. To make matters worse for any fledgling Emperors, your empire will also face random scenarios from time to time that usually involve someone attacking or pillaging your empire. The AI doesn’t have to deal with this events and if you are not careful, you can find yourself surrounded by other empires as well as random event attacks. On the plus side, the scenarios usually grant your rewards for their completion.Combat and ship design are definitely SD2’s strong point there are a lot of options to make some truly unique ships that fight how you want. It is very rewarding to watch your designs bring your victory. In actual combat, the game looks and plays great. Tactics are key and the right or wrong moves can turn a lopsided battle into a victory or defeat. The AI employs some solid designs and tactics, however he should be a little quicker to adapt to my designs. Ground combat is okay. It is nice to see something attempted and I am having fun with it, but it could definitely be more fleshed out. This maybe because the maps feel a little empty.SD2’s biggest weakness right now is diplomacy. It has the standard options, but uses a system called Tolerance to represent a race’s familiarity to limit the amount of options you can conduct in a session to keep you from just spamming options. The system is great on paper and was super cool early in the game, however the AI’s aggressiveness will soon override your options. Too many things can effect a races opinion of you negatively. If the AI wants to trade for a tech even when he has nothing worthwhile if I turn him down our relationship suffers. If I say yes our tolerance gets used up so I can’t ask for things I want later. If I don’t pay them money for their threats they get angry. If I expand too much they get angry. It is hard to keep them happy without simply giving into all their requests. Conversely, they seem to not care at all about my happiness. Worse I have no option to complain about their spying or attempts to colonize planets in my systems. The concept is sound, but the balance needs to be reworked. Right now it is a little more frustrating than rewarding.Overall, the game really is a great accomplishment. It just does so many things I have always wanted in a 4X right. There are plenty of nitpicks here and there, but the amount of fun I am having with it far outweighs those issues. The game only retails for 30 USD. As of this review I have 16 hours logged in so for me it was well worth the price. There are a lot of options and plenty of ways to get in all 4 of the Xs. And it certainly has the “Just one more turn feel”

Posted: May 17, 2015
												Brilliant.Played Galactic Civilizations III for 30 minutes, having been a fan of the previous games.Bought StarDrive 2.Far more love, care, passion and attention to little details went into this sequel. It is a true evolution of the previous game, an improvement and new direction in almost all aspects. For the better. Something which a previously mentioned high profile 4x title did not deliver.StarDrive 2 is not a reskin of the same game with merely .ini mod-level changes.It is a completely fresh redesigned game, and a bloody brilliant one at that.This is the Master of Orion of the modern day. The dev finally got it right after the first game honestly kind of was a beta experiment.Buy it now, if you are a fan of 4x games, such as Galciv, Distant Worlds, MOO, Armada or Endless Space.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												One of the best Space 4x games yet. The ship/hull outfitting and customization is 2nd to none and is my top pick in that category on a 4x no holds barred wishlist.Stardrive 2 is Master of Orion 2 remade with Stardrive integrated into it. And its all done extremely well. His politics and bargaining system is quite ingenious in preventing the typical barter everything at once exploit that no one else (of whose games I've played at least) has manged to do.Combat is pausable real-time and what you outfit your ships with and  how you use them makes a difference. Same goes for ground combat which in most other 4x is largely ignored or marginalized.Modding support looks to be great (I'm not a modder but already upon release theres a good playable Star Trek mod in progress)The only area where some other 4x games have over this is victory scenarios other than all out total conquest. Thats it. Graphics, depth, ship/hull customization, ground combat, thought out diplomacy. This game has a lot! It may not score perfect 10s in ALL categories, but it does is some and high 8s or 9s in others. I highly, highly recommend this space 4x!

												TL;DR - Overall the game was worth it for me, I think they got the pricing right on this one. Hopefully they patch some of the problem areas listed below.The game is fun, interesting, and quite challenging at times. I enjoyed it, until I beat it.Pros:-I liked the diplomacy in this one with the 'tolerance' limiting your trades-Ship design was a lot of fun-It was fun to micro the ships in combat-the tech tree was cool.Neutral:-The number of high-quality planets (i.e. planets that grow food) are quite low. So the game does sort of stove pipe you into some tech decisions. Cons:-Very large battles take FOREVER to process even with a decent computer.-The end game needs some work-no technological victory. If you are playing on a large universe you have to hunt down every single occupied planet. Quite a big turn off for me after being in such a dominating position.-The above point really drags down the replayability for me.-Canopy shields OP.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												If you love 4x games (like me), you can't really go wrong here. Stardrive 2 steals features unapologetically from games like Master of Orion, Endless Space and of course Stardrive 1. It also tries to add some new depth to the XCOM style ground combat and the event-driven campaign.All that being said, it's not very polished. There are (slight) bugs as well as balancing issues and the "random encounters" aren't random at all, but always appear in the same order. I actually found the relatively small amount of ship modules refreshing, since your choices are more meaningful if there aren't thousands of options. What I'm missing are more planetary modules, more diplomacy options and a better end-game.
