content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Review for those who have played Masters of Orion 2 on the hardest settings and won without taking "Creative":It's MOO2.  Spend the money, cuz MOO2 is back again, but now with space wolves!  Beware the purple spies.Review for those who are hardcore 4x gamers who play for the challenge:Stardrive 2 is a phenominal game that will test your endurance, wits, and resource management skills from TURN 1.  There are a LOT of things you need to know to play this game, but if you have ever played Masters of Orion 2, you're ready to tackle this game on Normal.Pros:1.  Ship design - While some games allow you a fair deal of customization, Stardrive 2 allows you nearly 98% customization of your fleet.  The only thing you can't customize is which ship 'hulls' you use, as that is determined by the race you play as.  For those of you out there who played Stardrive 1, there have even been some hulls that were removed, but the selection is more than adequate and what you can do with your ships is peerless.2.  Difficulty - This game is HARD.  VERY VERY hard.  I have beat Masters of Orion 2 (the game this game is effectively emmulating) countless times on the hardest difficulty.  The first playthrough I attempted in Stardrive 2, I tapped out as I had pirates, 3 races, space crystals, and the Remanent (The Antarans, if you're a MOO2er) all coming after my homeworld of Earth.  If you enjoy a TRULY dauntless and unforgiving game - this is IT.  That's not to say this game isn't beatable, but you can seriously lose this game on turn 1 if you don't know what you're doing.3.  Graphics - Beautiful starship battles framed in slow-mo bullet-time-esque speeds await you.  Expertly drawn and animated unique races bring you into the rich universe.4.  Gameplay - Everything you do is it's own task in this game - managing an intergalactic empire takes the form of many screens feeding you the information you need to make the correct decisions, star ship battles are done in a real-time strategy where you can control your AI's engagement ranges and behaviors, ground combat is done on a hex grid.This game is definitely a must buy for you.Review for the Casual gamer:This game has far too many things that aren't explained or are intuitive enough for the casual gamer.  If you're looking for a game where you just build up ships and watch them clash - this is not the game for you.  If you see the pretty starship battles and think that is the majority of the game, I'm just going to say that isn't the case.  The game will be ludacrisly difficult for you, and you will rapidly become frustrated with this title.Unless you are serious about entering the 4x genre, this title is definitely not for you.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Excellent game concept and friendly user interface. This is the new MOO2, imho. The game is VERY fun to play and some subsistems are excellent (ship design, random events, heroes, space battles). After 100 hours in, however, I can say that the game is still very buggy and has some design issues that sorely need fixing. There is a steady stream of patches coming from the designer, so I hope this game will eventually shine as it deserves to do. Right now, Espionage and Diplomacy seem to be the two sub systems more in need of an overhaul. There is a tendency for AI to build HUGE fleets that will smash right through anything you can send against them, and I suspect the command control mechanism in place to keep in check huge fleet building for the human player does not work properly for the AI. Overall, the game is more fun at the beginning, where exploration ad special events count more, than during late game where usually it becomes simply a matter of amassing production points to build a huge fleet or research points to win a tech victory.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												StarDrive 2 has gone a slightly different direction than it's predecessor, which has split it's fan/player base somewhat.  To understand why some people don't enjoy this game, one needs to look at an overview of the first StarDrive game.StarDrive 1 was a Real Time with Pause 4X space game.  It had a well crafted ship builder (one of my favorite aspects of the series), a streamlined planet management system, and entertaining combat.  It's biggest flaw was its bugs and engine issues late game, and the developer team discontinuing updates due to difficulties with the Unity engine.  That said, it was still an above average game in it's genre.Along comes StarDrive 2, offering a more traditional Turn Based approach (though it's made to progress turns rapidly until something interesting happens).  Changing some of the aspects of the first StarDrive (though keeping the excellent races, lore, ship building, and real time combat), StarDrive 2 aims to mime Master of Orion 2.  This to me, is a good thing, as MoO2 is a classic for a reason, that hasn't been remade.  If any 4X game is deserving of a modern revamp, it's MoO2.  StarDrive 2 gets a lot of things right in it's tribute, and a few wrong, but is a very solid game overall, and aims to better itself over time.StarDrive 2 does have it's share of bugs (currently), but it's developer is releasing patches on a regular basis to try and fix these, as well as rebalance passes to curb the difficulty spike (or easiness spike, depending on who you talk to) that many have experienced while playing.  So long as the team keeps at it's current rate, this will be an overall better game than the prior version.Pros---+ Great ship building system+ Real Time Instanced Combat looks clean and is uncomplicated+ Follows the Master of Orion 2 template almost tick for tick+ Events and Quests add spice/lore+ Thematic, enjoyable music fitting a space empire+ A new addition to diplomacy that limits player abuse while keeping it interestering+ Unique races that each lend their own personalities (and in some cases, unique playstyles) to the game+ Samurai Space Bears...Cons---- UI could use a few more tooltips and usability changes (ship management for example isn't overly informative)- Space Combat could be spiced up with more things to do / active abilities- Ground Combat gets tedious fairly quickly and could be spiced up as well- Auto-Resolve is currently terrible for both Space and Ground Combat- Only one victory condition (extermination)... would be nice to have some more common 4X conditions like tech, diplomacy, etc... other ways to win the game other than wiping out all your enemies (though that is fun)* Note: This is strictly a single player game, and while this has been a note of contention for some, shouldn't bias the game negatively.  That said, multiplayer would be a nice addition if another StarDrive game is made, as that is becoming fairly staple for the modern 4X genre.In conclusion, StarDrive 2 is not without it's faults, but Zero Sum have seemed to have learned from their mistakes of the first game and have crafted a better product as a result.  While not for everyone, StarDrive 2 delivers an enjoyable experience to 4X fans that can easily keep you playing just one more turn.TLDR: Different than the previous game carrying the StarDrive name, but better in just about every way (unless you really liked the original being Real Time).  Modern remake of Master of Orion 2.  Real Time Space Combat, Turn Based Ground Combat, Turn Based Empire Management.  Though it still has some growing to do, it's definitely a Recommend.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												A pretty solid 4X. Takes the Master of Orion formula and adds a modern spin.Pros: - Pretty good racial diversity- Ship designing is amazingly fun- Plenty of planet variety- Random events are cool- Modding community is decent (Check out the official forums)- Loads of options for customizing your race- Capturing resources feels importantNeutral:- Research tree is... fine. It's okay where it is, but it's nothing special.- Very stable. Haven't run into any crashes. I put this under neutral because this should be expected, not surprising.Cons: - Space combat is fun to watch your first time, but gets bland quickly. Ships move so slowly and so inaccurately, it's like playing with paper boats in a rain gutter. During a hurricane. While on morphine.- Ground combat is mind-numbingly boring. Imagine playing chess, but with only pawns (and as many queens as you can build, as soon as you get mechs). When it shows up, cover is useless. Micromanaging 15 guys, one after another, on a square grid isn't fun. Would be much more enjoyable if you could disable movement/attack animations and just show the damage markers.- DO NOT USE THE AUTO-BATTLE. I've lost massive fleets to lone frigates that were using early-game tech, while I had max-tier shields and weapons. Add this to the problems with combat, and you'll be finding more fun in smashing your keyboard through your screen.- Usually too difficult early on and far too easy in the late game. Even on hard, I was able to completely curbstomp a species that owned 75% of the galaxy because they refused to use their massive tech advantage, and kept building the same ships they'd been building since mid-game. This was AFTER the AI ship overhaul.- Trade with other factions feels pretty pointless. You can get (or start with) a tech that lets you capture enemy tech when you take their planets. It's usually cheaper to conquer an enemy's planets and steal their industry alongside their tech.- No satisfaction from beating the snot out of the AI. They barely try to defend themselves or barter for their own lives. Even if you've kicked their asses back to their homeworld, they'll still try to short you on the peace deals, then get uppity when you tell them where to shove their pitiful Tier-1 offerings.Despite its problems, I still got several hours of entertainment out of it. I'd only recommend if you buy it on sale. $33 is way too steep for what you get. If you want a similar experience, and can tolerate older graphics and UI, try Master of Orion 2.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I was able to pick up this little gem for $10 on a steam sale.  I played for about 100 hours and enjoyed the game thoroughly.  It may not be as grand as some 4x's but it is well made and worth what I paid.  As of today the developer is still active and fixing some of bugs in sporadic patches.  He apparently is working on new DLC or version.  I didn't seem to encounter or notice any bugs in my gameplay hours.  I had no crashes, just the program slowing some as I conquired every planet in the galaxy.I played the humans during my play, other alien races are available and will be encountered and negotated and fought with.  The gameplay is not complex but has similiar depth to the old master of orion series.  Space combat is real-time that can be paused.  Ground combat is representative and turn based.  Difficulty can be selected from easy on up.  There is minor races to conquer and you can, if you wish, enslave other alien races to speed population growth and production.The game captured enough complexity and depth of gameplay to hold my interest (not the easiest task since I own hundreds of steam games)....researching that next beam weapon or device to bombard the enemy planets with.  Perhaps, building new ships variants which are more powerful and faster.  Something always kept me engaged.  Ignore the board trolls, for some reason this particular steam board was inundated with them? Most have had nonsensical arguments or some wacky agenda now that I've actually played and seen the product for myself.  I would recommend giving this title a try for anything under $20 US dollars.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												This game has good fundamentals and is fairly fuin to play, but it lacks polish.  The minimum requirements for a 4X game are there, and what's there is well done.  But there are several eyebrow-raising things, such as the inclusion of a tactical ground combat minigame.  It's not a terrible minigame, but it isn't very fun.  It's pretty boring.  You just move your guys and click "fire".  The interface is pretty poor and even a fairly simple encounter is very tedious and long.  It feels like a projhect they gave the junior programmer, or like a senior project for someone in game school.  It oculd have easily been left out, and shoudl have been in favor of more polish on the main game.  There are just.... oddities.  Missing stuff.  There seems to be no way, for example, to see how you're doing in relation to other empires.  The AI is fairly weak.  There are basically zero options beyond screen resolution and audio.  It could genertally use a really indepth round of interface enhancement.  But overall, a pretty good effort.  They should have let it cook for another six months.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												StarDrive 2 has the same vices as StarDrive, though to a lesser extent. There are peripheral areas of the game which feel rushed or unpolished, not for lack of effort as I understand it, but lack of manpower. Unlike SD, the mechanics and overall gameplay is SOLID. I liked SD but there are segements of that game which were flawed.Diplomacy is much more responsive and worthwhile in SD 2. The different factions in StarDrive have a lot of character and its something you actually want to engage in.Not feeling the need to slow down time to a crawl in order to micromanage every detail of a star-spanning empire, is great. While I miss combat actually happening on the stategy map, turn-based allowed the rather spartan and unwieldy management aspects of the game to flower.It can almost go without saying that StarDrive's defining aspect; ship design and combat have been developed, honed and polished to outshine any other 4X. It moved ahead in leaps and bounds, and it is fun, fun, fun. The are more options and everything is really slick. On top of that, there are special technologies and components you acquire outside of the actual scientific tree through various means. Some are stellar, others feel gimicky - which isn't a bad thing. The only addition I don't like is the proto-molecule device which is underwhelming - not because it underperforms, but because it is pretty superflous and there is a sizable build-up to actually getting it. Also because the mechanics which underpin it are perhaps the one weak point in SD2's fleet combatIt highlights the one real complaint I have with shipboard weaponry in the game. Ships can carry massive Subspace Artillery and Mass Drivers which by any yardstick should be able to get the job of bombarding a planet done. Instead ships have to carry a seperate arsenal of otherwise useless weapons, which take up precious space, in order pummel planets into submission. It is extremely arbitrary, especially one one considers that tactical and strategic nukes are available form the very start of the game - long before any sort of ground-based counter is available. A doom fleet in orbit, armed to the teeth with kinetic weaponry and only able to 'blockade' is a sorry spectacle. Maintaining planetary defenses on more than a few planets seems prohibitively expensive, even of it wasn't useless because most of the AI strategy is based around landing troops anyway.At times playing on defensive boils down to playing wack-a-mole with invasions fleets amongst your holdings. That will probably be alleviated somewhat by wormhole junction forts and other defensive options in the 'Sector Zero' DLC. Planetery invasions were unwieldly (in capital letters) in SD1, and while massive focus has obviously been put into tactical ground combat in StarDrive 2, it feels tacted on and doesn't really add much to the experience at this point in time. Overall though, the game is fun which is to say that what it does well, it does really well. The feature set it touts is there and it is solid. It is the little things where this game looses ground. I dwell on the little things a lot, but that is nitpicking. This game deserves a much better rating then it has.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Game is great!!!It's back!I don't believe it. It's back....MOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO 2 is back.!!!Back with a vengeance! Mixed in with XCOM and Stardrive. Awesome!Finally somebody, has been able to fill Steve Barcia shoes. Cudos to "Daniel DiCicco".This is a thinking person's game.Don't change anything with the AI. It's great. It's tough at first but that forces you to analyze what you're doing wrong.This... THIS kicks your brain around and forces you to analyze your strategic thinking.There's no cheating by the game that I can tell going on here. Everything is out there in the open and logical.You must study.  You must observe.You must remember.You can study your opponents equipment on their ships before you go into battle.The man has written and entire holographic simulator to test and evaluate how all the equipment you're researching works.  And most importantly how that equipment works with other techs added on.I get the same old lost in the game feeling here as I did with MOO2.And the same: "Just one more turn" syndrome as well.It's like I've just met an old friend!Live long and prosper mates, Ciao!

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												The games basically MOO2 (Master of Orion 2) under a different company and with updated graphics. It's pretty decent as far as 4x games go, and there really hasn't been a good one since MOO2, *and no Galactic Civ is terrible*.What i have played I have enjoyed, it has everything you could want in your typical 4x game and the game is still in development.What I will point out is what I feel is missing or dislike.* Story frame of reference - So many of these games are just > load game > load race > start. What would be nice would be some more depth to the history of the races and the galaxy itself, add to the immersion of the game.* Not a fan of the ship design UI, feels very clunky and doesn't really match the feel of the rest of the game, some people might like tediously placing 1 tile at a time when making their ship designs but its basically lego on an established blueprint. The whole system could be completely redone in my opinion. *hint hint, MOO2's design screen worked well*. Also with regards to upgrading/refitting/redesigning ships if they stick to the clunky model, have a way to sort weapons and equipment by technology level and stats.* More depth for your *not Antaran* incursion race, and fix the dimensional portal. It's bugged three times now in my games and cannot access it even though it says "go explore it".* More race traits and customisation options.* More anomalies and galactic events, as well as more unique planetary anamolies.The game is really good, and it has a huge amount of potential. I would recommend it to players.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												I enjoy the game, but it's almost a copy of Masters of Orion! seems the  name and faces of oppenents are changed , the skills are somewhat the same with different meanings, although building of ships is different. You get heros, and allowed only 4... and seems the AI is bias towards you, because no matter how fast you build, you are always outnumbered. Your enemies seem to always attack your weekness even not knowing what in your territory. It seems as they always have your armada outnumber as well. Not saying i want it to be easy, but would like to have it as equal to get a honest fighting chance.Traiding seems to be boring, it seems if your opponent don't get the upper hand in the deal, there no trade. So what good is that! Even if you trade with them, a few turns later they are asking for tribute, if you deny , then war! Useless!For the price, the graphics could have been better, i paid for the digital deluxe, and i was able to put color on my ships, however there only 4-5 selection you may choose from. Sound track is ok, after playing it for awhile, you need to turn off because it becomes overbearing.The game runs smoothly, i played without any crashing, so I give that a thumbs up. Just wish there was more to it, explorating is a joke, your ship can only go so far, and its a small universe too! If your playing the biggest map, unless you find wornholes then build a gas station to go futher, there no need, the AI has taken up the stars for your rivals. It seems that thier plot of space is always larger than yours!Recommend for thoes who never played Masters of Orion, but for thoes whom played that gave, no!

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												At first, I was a little confused because other than the races, techs and graphics SD2 doesn't have much in common with SD1 - it's a completely different kind of game. Sure, there are features you'll miss if you played SD1, but SD2 offers so many other gems instead! I got completely hooked, the "just one more turn" addiciton is right there. I have to admit: I started the game on easy after having read some reviews regarding the hellish degree of difficulty. On easy, it's fine. For a first play through, it's still challenging, but certainly not unfair. Overall, I really enjoy this game and highly recommend it, if you are into not overly complicated 4x games. If you like Sword of the Stars, you'll also like Stardrive II.Oh, and if you like certain books by James S.A. Corey: this game even features the vomit zombies. You ever wanted to let loose the protomolecule? Feel free to do so :)

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Very good game that has already provided me with many hours of enjoyment.  Everything is not perfect but what it delivers is addictive and very fun.   Replay value is much higher than many other games so that alone makes it a worthwhile get.  I was also glad to see the Star Trek mod becoming avialable so quickly.   Stability has not been a problem for me at all.  There are some bugs and balance things but those have been relatively minor and the developer appears to be making an honest effort at avoiding the mistakes made on the first stardrive.  When I've ran into something I've found the answers I needed quickly in the forum.   So if you are looking for a 4x game don't be afraid to take a chance on Stardrive 2.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												this will be short but I want tog ive my two cents in.I know people were clamoring for a multiplayer aspect to be added but in all honesty I don't know how it would work, especially with waiting for real time battles to finish up, unless all real time battles happen at the end of a turn which can seriously derail someone's strategy even moreso if other players are allowed to do things while a real time battle is going on.Stardrive 1 was fun but it had issues, primarily with the bland proceduraly generated race descirptions and while a fully real time setup was a novel idea it presented too many issues to work around vs the traditional 4X turn based game. AS it stands, making Stardrive 2 into an equivalent of "Total War in Space" was probably the best idea, yest you can't reinforce fleets in battle anymore but at least the game kept it's staple of real time combat scenarios to help it stand out.My only major compaints with the game are as follows: the lack of victory conditions and no sandbox ship editor. There's no turn limit (at least not that I've found) and no other way to win excepyt total military conquest. I'd like to see a return of the "ascendence" victory from the first Stardrive as well as diplomatic or science based victory options. As for the second, I want to be able to experiment with ship designs freely outside the game and, most importantly, figure out wxactly what layouts each of ships for each race have, I want to say I love that each races' ship has a unique style and design to it that is more than just aesthetics but even with that I can't help but wonder how it will affect my ship designing when I can't figure out ahead of time which ship layout I prefer.Only get this game if you understand what you're walking into, it plays Total War in Space and I love total war, this isn't quite it but it's the best attempt I've yet seen. Is this the best game since "master of orion 2" in the 4X sapce genre... well I can't say. The overall space based gameplay is msotly the same between each series but I will say I much prefer the real time space combat over the turn based space combat I've seen in every other Master of Orion successor. And kudos to finding a way to make "creative" both overpowered but hideously difficult to use, it's still the best trait in the game though and it almsot triples your research speed, I just with the penalty and bonus limits were higher or adjustable iun single player

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												The game is totally awesome! SD2 is likely to become my favorite 4x game. I enjoyed playing SD1, but this is a whole new level.My impressions:- Turn-based strategic mode is far better than "real-time" SD1. Everyhting is kinda easier to manage.- Art is beautiful.- Random stuff that you can explore if you don't feel like exterminating the galaxy ATM.- Ground combat: well, frankly specking I didn't like the way it was implemented. It seems to be another game of singificantly lower quality unfortunately. But the game has an option to autoresolve, so that's not a major issue.- Difficulty. Don't take me wrong, I like when the game is a challenge, but the difficulty here is nearly absurd. I started on easy level to learn game mechanics (though already being familiar with the game thorught videos) and the enemies kicked my♥♥♥♥♥almost immediately. I did almost okay in the second game, but still this is a bit ridiculous: easy should not be hardcore. Things here go significantly more difficult than in playthroughs of beta (with quite reasonable balance).- Space combat and ship design is awesome. Just nothing more to say here, great job. Just a small issue with selection (sometimes selector doesn't respond to mouse) and inability to set the engagement range for several ships at once.- Diplomacy is transparent, as promised. But I hate the moment when some guys want some of your techs, want to trade, but their tolerance to you isn't enough to take anything of the same value from them. And after I dismiss the deal they become angry that I refused to trade with them. What a nuisance... Hope that will be fixed, because it really spoils your diplomacy.- Game runs smooth. I remember late-game lag of SD1 and I was afraid to find the same problem here. But no, everything is fine.I encountered some bugs in the first release, but Zero fixed them in a couple of hours after the report. Some minor issues exist, but they are rare. Had to reload the game once because build queue went crazy and also found the remnants stuck because their wormhole dissapeared. Nothing serious so far.So, 9/10 from me.

												Best 4X stuff since Master of Orion 2!Great 2D art, huge space battles, fun races to play or fight.Some strange bugs but the dev is at work to fix them.The parts that are modable at the moment are very easy to mod, waiting for more to come on that end.Made my first ever mod of anything for this and it is dead easy. number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Massive improvement on Star Drive, if designing ships and testing them combat appeals to you its a must have.  it has the opposite approach of endless space, it has complex ship design and tactical combat, while the empire managment has a bit less shine. In all i would say its enjoyable in its current state, but it still needs a fair bit of polish, it just dosent feel finished to me. In fairness It has extremly small development team which to its credit is still working very passionatly on the game. In particuar the empire managment part dosent feel quite right, it misses something that makes expanding past the mid game a bit bland for me.  The ground combat is quiet tedious in its current form, though it shows alot of potenital. The AI still needs some serious attention. but watching your brand new battleship firing a rolling broad sides at hostile invaders while despratly trying to shoot down incoming missels, and that sinking feeling you should have forgone some of those cannons for extra flak, and armour makes the game. im happy to support the micro team which is zero sum games.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												The learning curve is what threw me off so many 4x games in the past but this game has such a great tutorial (voiced over too!) that I felt like I picked it up in 15 minutes. Anything else I couldn't figure out what easily learned from the help menu which covers extra details like food and transports etc, maybe 10+ minor topics.Building your own ships is super intimidating at first because you have no idea what counters what, but once you get the hang of it (make a save a few turns before a battle and experiment!) it's super fun to see what you can cook up! TIP: You eat the infinite missile stream of death a few times before you figure out ~3 or so tiny laser turrets can pick them off before they hit your ship.Custom races traits are also REALLY great. Want to make a cybernetic race of bears that lives underground? It's possible. And it's fun!Most addicting game I've played in space in a long time.The one CON I can list for this game is that their are Command Points limiting your # of ships, but each race's ship layouts are unique, and some races get significantly more tiles to build on per ship type than others. This could be turned into a plus if you decide you want to play the easiest race (cybernetic guys) first then move on to the hardest (bugs/wolves, etc)...

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												StarDrive 2 has the same vices as StarDrive, though to a lesser extent. There are peripheral areas of the game which feel rushed or unpolished, not for lack of effort as I understand it, but lack of manpower. Unlike SD, the mechanics and overall gameplay is SOLID. I liked SD but there are segements of that game which were flawed.Diplomacy is much more responsive and worthwhile in SD 2. The different factions in StarDrive have a lot of character and its something you actually want to engage in.Not feeling the need to slow down time to a crawl in order to micromanage every detail of a star-spanning empire, is great. While I miss combat actually happening on the stategy map, turn-based allowed the rather spartan and unwieldy management aspects of the game to flower.It can almost go without saying that StarDrive's defining aspect; ship design and combat have been developed, honed and polished to outshine any other 4X. It moved ahead in leaps and bounds, and it is fun, fun, fun. The are more options and everything is really slick. On top of that, there are special technologies and components you acquire outside of the actual scientific tree through various means. Some are stellar, others feel gimicky - which isn't a bad thing. The only addition I don't like is the proto-molecule device which is underwhelming - not because it underperforms, but because it is pretty superflous and there is a sizable build-up to actually getting it. Also because the mechanics which underpin it are perhaps the one weak point in SD2's fleet combatIt highlights the one real complaint I have with shipboard weaponry in the game. Ships can carry massive Subspace Artillery and Mass Drivers which by any yardstick should be able to get the job of bombarding a planet done. Instead ships have to carry a seperate arsenal of otherwise useless weapons, which take up precious space, in order pummel planets into submission. It is extremely arbitrary, especially one one considers that tactical and strategic nukes are available form the very start of the game - long before any sort of ground-based counter is available. A doom fleet in orbit, armed to the teeth with kinetic weaponry and only able to 'blockade' is a sorry spectacle. Maintaining planetary defenses on more than a few planets seems prohibitively expensive, even of it wasn't useless because most of the AI strategy is based around landing troops anyway.At times playing on defensive boils down to playing wack-a-mole with invasions fleets amongst your holdings. That will probably be alleviated somewhat by wormhole junction forts and other defensive options in the 'Sector Zero' DLC. Planetery invasions were unwieldly (in capital letters) in SD1, and while massive focus has obviously been put into tactical ground combat in StarDrive 2, it feels tacted on and doesn't really add much to the experience at this point in time. Overall though, the game is fun which is to say that what it does well, it does really well. The feature set it touts is there and it is solid. It is the little things where this game looses ground. I dwell on the little things a lot, but that is nitpicking. This game deserves a much better rating then it has.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												Ill start with $30 is a little pricey for all the faults this game has.. HOWEVER it does have sever good things going that should make this game be on your pick up list. -Ship Customization is amazing. Many different weapons and upgrades. At times almost too much! I found myself designing ships and thinking "OH! I want that on here too!" lol-You dont have a real restriction on how many ships can be in combat at one time. One play through I found myself sending what I thought was a large fleet with several Titan size (Largest ship available) ships into a star system to encounter an enemy fleet. When we got into combat I found I was out numbered like 6 to 1. This DOES cause problems performance wise. I have a very good PC and still had bad issues. It wouldnt start till all the ships began firing. Some weapons like the cluster cannon shoots a projectile that bursts into several peices before impact. When 40 ships are all firing different projectiels performance just plumets. I realize this sounds pretty negative, thats my only real issue with the game. Past that you have several interesting side type quests that spin things and keep you wanting to just run "one more turn. The modding community for this game isnt large but I have seen several on their forums that make this game even deeper as far as features go. Which is crazy!With steam allowing refunds now for games played under 2 hours I highly suggest you check it out. Its work it

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												StarDrive 2 is so much fun - it feels like a much newer version of Master of Orion and totally worth it. After 127 hours I definitely haven't explored the entire game, but I do feel like I've exhausted most of the appeal. Hopefully they'll fix a few of the things below and then it will be even more awesome.***Things I've liked about it***You can customize your ships by placing individual components onto the hull at different locations, and you have to consider the cost, power, weight, size, and hitpoints of different systems. Not all the components are the same size/shape, either, so designing a ship is a lot of fun.In battle, ships acceleration matters - you can't accelerate to maximum speed instantaneously and can't turn immediately either.There are many styles of weapon - beam weapons with essentially infinite speed (but still limited range), artillery with long range but no guidance after they're launched, and rockets with good range that home on enemits, plus many, many other weapons and/or variants.Ground combat is interesting and doesn't feel contrived - there are lots of different weapons, and the units have actual coordinates during ground combat, allowing for more strategy.You can customize your race at the beginning based on whether you want to boost research, production, combat, and lots of other things. Each race also has a few race-specific technologies and/or abilities that can't be customized and add a little more flavor.The tech tree is interesting because there are several branches that are independent. Also, each branch has tiers of three technologies where you can only research one of those three technologies before moving on to the next tier. This leaves you to get it from another race (by trade, extortion, spying, or assimilation), or to live without it.***Things I don't like about it***The battle arena prepares you for a much harder game than this actually is. Once you design a sufficiently good ship to win the battle arena, that ship is probably roughly 12 times as powerful as another AI ship of similar cost, and then the normal game gets pretty easy (you can build no military, wait for them to declare war on you, and then quickly build a ship to wipe out their entire fleet by the time they arrive). The way that I'd like this to be fixed would be for the AI to more clearly pay attention to the kinds of ships that it knows/expects that you have, and to build ships designed to beat those ships. I'd also like for it to design slightly better ships in the first place.StarDrive 2 has the same problem as lots of empire-building games where as your empire grows, it takes more time to micromanage all of it if you feel that urge. Unfortunately, if you don't assign a planet to build anything then it doesn't build anything, and the game doesn't remind you that some planets aren't building anything. There are notifications when a planet finishes building its latest building, but sometimes those notifications dissapear if other things are happening in that turn too. The way I'd like this to be fixed is first for the turn to not allow ending if planets are idle, and second to allow the user to set a default build order that planets follow if they have no planet-specific orders.The AI doesn't know how to evaluate the ships that I build. When I try to autoresolve a battle, the AI is much more likely to favor the opponent than if I were to actually fight the battle. That's understantable, but it's unfortunate when combined with a bug where in some battles (perhaps 2%), if you click to fight the battle then there never appears the button to actually start the battle, and the game is then stuck. Usually this can be fixed if I reload the game from a save, but not always.When forming a team for ground combat (which is a lot of fun (unlike what I expected); good job guys!), sometimes characters will be designated as starting the battle with fewer than their maximum hitpoints. This can be reproduced if you have two preset loadouts, one having the Bone Weave attribute and one without it. The steps are 1. Restore the character's equipment from one preset loadout. 2. Restore the character's equipment from the next preset loadout. 3. Toggle the presence of the Bone Weave attribute by clicking manually. Note that now the character's starting hitpoints has adjusted by 20 (positive or negative depending on which way around the loop you went). It looks like someone else noticed this at 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



 and was even able to make a unit whose starting hitpoints was negative (presumably by going around the loop three times)The zooming could be a bit smoother - I wish that the zoom would spend less time animating and instead would adjust more quickly.Sometimes colony ships will get stuck on the strategy map and won't respect orders to colonize the planet that they are at, but if you tell them to move away from the planet and move back to that planet then they are willing to colonize it.The AI's don't have as good of an alignment between their diplomatic goals and strategic goals as I'd like them to have. Mostly it feels weird that they tell you upfront how much they value each technology, but they don't adjust their valuations based on circumstances. I've been able to give some unimportant economic technology to an enemy who was about to take one or two of my four planets in exchange for a peace treaty that bought me more than enough time to build up a much bigger army. The AI diplomacy doesn't really bother me that much since it's a very hard problem, but it's still another opportunity for improvement.In some special-mission ground combat battles (but none of the important planet-taking or planet-defending ones - don't worry) , the zoom prevents the leftmost column of squares from being visible, so I can't select my units and therefore can't fight :(

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												This is an amazing space strategy game with an unfortunate amount of bugs. I enjoyed it enough to give a thumbs up, even with all the issues.Bugs I’ve run into:When you use fighter squadrons, the post battle process can take 10-15 to finish loading.The post battle process can sometimes crash the game after large fights.The fleet ownerships were once switched between myself and the NPC during a battle. This was actually kind of funny at the time (I mad their ships turn around so they couldn’t shoot), but it’s a bug none the less.NPC ships will sometimes fly outside of the battle screen (out of your view) if they are being defeated. If your ships aren’t fast enough to catch them, the battle never ends unless you forfeit. Good things:The game has one of the best ship designers in my opinion. It’s simple to understand but difficult to master. Ships must be constantly redesigned/improved as the technology in the universe gets better, or risk being left in the dust. I generally ignore diplomacy managment in space games, but it’s actually very useful here.  As you progress through the various technology trees, you will leave some research behind. For example, you may opt for a new type of ship armor instead of advanced fighter technology.  Diplomacy with other cultures allows you to trade for this technology, which would be lost to your civilization otherwise.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Great game.   Wonderful ship designer. You'll have tons of fun researching new techs, incorperating them into your designs, and then deploying them in battle.The problem is that the game is really buggy.  Sometimes I have fleets clone and attack themselves.   Sometimes I have space anomolies that spawn hostile ships and cannot be destroyed because there is no "start battle" button.  Which means the ONLY way to exit the screen is to forfeit the battle and have your entire fleet self destruct.Oh yeah, don't even bother with trying to get your contructer ships build an effective space highway to move your ships faster.   That entire mechanic does not work making constucter ships pointless except as recon stations.Finally, no end game.   You kill everybody and the game just keeps running forever.This game should still be in alpha but it's tons of fun as is.   I recommend this game because of that.   I would love to see something more polished but if the fate of Stardrive 1 is any indication of what the future holds for Stardrive 2 then my guess is I'll be dissapointed.  I hope for this game to be complete someday because when it is it will be better than any other space 4x I have ever played.  THe bugs don't make it unplayable in most cases.   But they will sure♥♥♥♥♥♥you off enough to make you put the game down when you would have otherwise kept playing.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												Overall I give a positive review of the game. Is it perfect?  Well no, but it still gave me several dozen hours of fun (and the developer intends to support the game further).The game's biggest flaw is that as it stands (and this is intended to change eventually) there are only two victory conditions (one official, one secret that says you won when you beat a final boss encounter).  Diplomacy as it stands cannot be used to form long lasting alliances and the end goal is always conquest.  The player can mentally set their own goals, such as controlling and containing all threats, or getting friendly with as many other civilizations as possible, but there are no built-in alternate victory conditions yet, and the ability to win by forming an alliance would add another facet to the game.The ground combat has a very mixed reaction.  Personally I like it, but I can see why some do not.  The developer does want to improve this eventually.Just like the first game, ship building is a huge aspect of the game's fun.  To summarize, I think it's a really good game but focuses a bit too much on the aggressive side of 4x play, but as I said the developer is accepting feedback and does want to fix that.  I do not feel an imperfect situation is enough for me to give a negative review.As far as how the game looks and feels, for the most part I think it feels quite well done.  Perhaps my play time speaks for itself.  My stance is if I put this much time into the game, how could I at least not recommend it?

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												This wonderful strategy game is the all the product of a development team of 1. Just 1 incredibly dedicated man. He has not abandoned the game, he's constantly working to improve and fix it.The other reviews really don't give it justice, and claim that this guy has abandoned it, and he hasn't (see: @zer0sumGames on twitter, he's still updating this thing), and nitpick it for its bugs while completely ignoring the many things that StarDrive 2 does right. Its writing is witty and awesome, the gameplay is very in depth, and the game just generally has that indie charm that some of the games in this genre fail to bring forward for me. I'm a big fan of Endless Space, and I have to say, this game impressed me and none of the bugs I encountered were enough to warrant a negative review. The modders also have contributed a lot to this game, which is another reason to play it. I reccomend this game to anybody who appreciates 4x space strategy. I appreciate the fact that this game is really really close to feeling like the ideal game that I dreamed about when I was a kid.Also, he talks to people on twitter when they have a question about a bug or just developing games in general. Cool indie dude making a nerdy indie game, can't get much better than that.

												I really like it so far. Its not a perfect game but I have not had any serious glitches. I am running this on windows 10 also. i saw a post saying that it did not run under windows 10 right after I bought while it was downloading and was thinking I was going to have to request a refund but its worked perfectly. content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												This game is an interesting sort, in which it makes it look like the game has a lot more in it, than it actually does. This game is just outrageous in so many ways it's hard to pick one that I dislike the most, but I'll try anyway.Pros:+ Looks nice+/- Factions look different+ Interesting to create new ship designs, even if it is just like trying to pack as much useful stuff into a suitcase that's two sizes too small+ Allows for a bit of customization to the game.Cons:- Every faction plays exactly the same. If you removed the faction picture and name, you couldn't tell the difference.- Everything takes a ridiculous amount of time to do. Building ships, researching new technology, even moving a fleet from point A to point B. It takes 30 turns just to build the most simple building, and trying to erect a fleet quickly to stop enemy ships that just suddenly decided they hate you? 13 turns a piece. The smallest ships available are around 8 turns. Seriously?- The ground "battles" are little more than a game of chess... Unless they bring more advanced tech than you. Then you lose. - The AI is practically unhindered and when you go to trade technology, they have 4 for every 1 you have. - The tech tree is extremely limited, instead of a web, you have to pick one out of three and if you decided you needed something else down the line, too bad. Maybe try getting it from those stingy AI. Good luck with that.- The "galaxy" is extremely small. A real galaxy has billions of stars but this one only has 100 maximum. Trying to expand your empire? Too bad, AI got there first. Seriously, you can't sneeze without hitting another race and they'll declare war on you for the most trivial things.- The game is lag-infested, crawling with bugs, and just feels plain unfinished. The character models on ground battles are poorly done and everything just feels very choppy.-Confusing UI that just seems to get in the way most of the time.I'd have to give this game a 4 out of 10, the game isn't abysmal by any standards, but it's certainly not good enough for long time enjoyment. If you have time to kill and money to waste, then try it out. If I had to describe Stardrive 2 in a sentence, it would have to be a "Pretty looking waiting simulator where pretty much nothing happens. Also the skip turn button will be your best friend. Just waiting for those crazy turn costs to tick down... Really really slowly."

Posted: August 30, 2015
												I really like it so far. Its not a perfect game but I have not had any serious glitches. I am running this on windows 10 also. i saw a post saying that it did not run under windows 10 right after I bought while it was downloading and was thinking I was going to have to request a refund but its worked perfectly. The ground combat can be a little clunky and not everything is explained but I like the questing system and the tech tree where you have to make choices on what tech you want rather than having a static tree where you get everything and you always know the best path. The combat system is pretty good also. I have played some 4x games where you have run every action and some that are just viewers while this one takes the best of both. You design your ships to do a function and then in combat you can pick targets in real time and pause it but do not have to micro manage each action each ship is going to take so you can have large fleets.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I find this to be a great game, but there are some issues. For one, there's no voice acting. This game could heavily benefit from voice acting in that it's very quiet, other than the amazing soundtrack. Secondly, the video options menu is painfully limited. You have the option to swap between preset video qualities ranging from "Fastest" to "Best," but they have no description of what changes what. You have your average AA options, 0-8 evens. You can set V-Sync and Fullscreen. Lastly you can change resolution. That's it, except for the option to turn off GNN, which it provides no explanation of. The only audio options you get are sliders for FX and Music, but no more. Not even a keybind menu.Unfortunately, you are also left in the dark when it comes to information on ships, at least from what I can see. When lookign at the ships I can construct, I am not given any explanation of what they are or what they can do. The best I can do is guess based on the name.The positives include great combat. It's easy to learn and very fluid. You can even go so far as to change the engage distance on individual ships, something that I haven't found before. Granted, I've never really played 4x games too often.Another positive is the interface. The interface is neat and well designed, and allows for quick access to many things, with preset shortcuts to certain menus. I also found the art style for most things to be very beautiful, and even animations for the characters are present.Overall, I would give this game a 7/10, and I recommend it to any who like the 4x genre.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												This game is the closest to the feel of MOO2 of any other space 4x I've played.Graphics, sound and interface are all first class in my opinion, especially the screens when interacting with alien races.Lots of atmosphere and flavour to the game, the random events (such as one of your arctic planets founding a ski resort), are nice little touches that help give the game it's own personality.The space combat is fun, it's good to see your latest weapon making mincemeat of an enemy fleet, plus as it's real time the battles are over fairly quickly so you don't get bogged down.The land battles have potential, but they aren't up to the same standard as the space battles.Bear in mind this is entirely a war focused game; the alien races are very aggressive and at the moment there is no option to form alliances with a race. You can make a non aggression pact but at best this just buys you some time before you will need to fight that empire.If treated as a "Total War in space" type game it's really good. To stand up better against other 4x's I think an expansion may be needed to expand on the non-combat aspects of the game, such as wider diplomancy options and perhaps improved espionage.

content:
Posted: January 29
												The closest thing to the Master of Orion series, including humor. Strategy side is good except for AI opponents going to zero tolerance when you get too big - makes diplomacy more or less impossible unless you are losing. Well, maybe realistic but not fun. I enjoy the strategy and ship design, don't much care for the race-specific hulls or RTS combat. I find the overall strategy pretty engrossing and can kill a day at it pretty quickly. This game does NOT feel like CIV to me - the tech tree makes you give up good stuff to get stuff (real decisions), and NO STARLANES! Hooray. If you want a civ-type game, get the new Master of Orion or GALCIV III.All it is missing is Turn Based Combat and multiplayer.On the hulls, you "can" make the Ralyehans good, just skip to the cruiser and use generic corvette and frigate hulls. When you get BB, there is plenty of room in the hull for a stand-off mass driver, missile, or anti-matter torpedo attack. You just have to make nice in the beginning and wait for the decent hulls. Mid-game stacked disruptors and cluster cannon on a well-shielded and armored BB makes some fun explosions too.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												tl;dr - Stardrive 2 is overall a good game with a number of polish issues.  It is hard to recommend at $30 given the number of great 4x space titles available, but I can easily say it is worth playing in the $10 to $15 range.  Despite borrowing HEAVILY from Master of Orion 2, it brings enough new to the table to be worth playing.Stardrive 1 was a fully realtime 4x game with pausing, sort of a cross between Master of Orion 2 (MOO2) and Sins of a Solar Empire.  Stardrive 2 (SD2) doubles down on the MOO2 side of the equation, switching to turn based and cloning many aspects of that old school classic - to the point that it feels like a straight remake of MOO2 with some elements tweaked.  Not to say that is entirely a bad thing.  I love MOO2 , and the chance to play it with a new coat of paint is fun.  Unfortunately, SD2 falls into some of the same pits as MOO2, as well as bringing its own to the table. Mid and late game building queueing isn't as bad as it was in MOO2, but it still really causes things to get bogged down, which is a double shame for a game that seems so focused on combat.  Ground combat can get tedius, and auto-resolve is actively bad (I had a 5:1 numeric advantage and the tech edge, and lost more troops than the computer had in the fight?) effectively forcing me to manually resolve almost all ground combat.  Even more criminally, new troops insist on being automatically created using outdated tech and a partial kit - why can I not designate a particular setup as default for all new troops?  Ending the game is awful, my choice is between total annhilation - extending the game long past the point that it is clear that I won - and score victory - which seems broken and ALSO lasts long past the point that it is clear I won or lost.  The one game I took to a score victory, the next turn button simply disappeared.  No fanfare that the game was over, no notification of where I placed, no popup of the victory tracking screen showing listing the score and showing that there are zero turns remaining; the only change was that the ability to advance the turn disappeared.  Where is the domination victory option that ends the game when I control X% of planets?Don't forget the bugs - they aren't so bad as to kill my enjoyment of the game, but they definitely detract.  Twice when an enemy fleet has attacked one of my freighters, the game got confused, lost the UI, and I had to alt-f4 the game and reload the latest save - fortunately, in both cases the latest save was at the start of the combat, and things resolved correctly the second try.  Bafflingly, on one ground combat, instead of controlling my side, I controlled the enemy side - I intentionally lost the combat, and kept the colony.  Multiple times, I traded technologies with an opposing empire, and then didn't have access to the technology, despite it showing up as available in the tech log.  These bugs aren't constant, but you are pretty much guaranteed to run into a few during a typical playthrough.If I have so many complaints about this game, why do I recommend it?  Because the brilliance the game brings is too great to ignore.  Space combat is where the greatest difference between MOO2 and SD2 lies.  Functionally, the ship construction and combat of SD1 returns, with an appreciated simplification of construction (no more power conduits) and combat resolved off the galaxy map.  Occasional Antaran Remnant attacks combined with a war on one or more fronts combined with fleet travel times forces a spreading of military forces, more than I've typically experienced in the genre.  I'm not normally a fan of real time combat resolution inside my turn based strategy, but here it works.Diplomacy has some issues, but it is still among the best in class.  Implementation of personality attributes and writing and annimation bring a clear sense of character to the races.  The tolerance mechanic is great, clear way of limiting the number of deals made with the computer in a way that (more or less) makes sense.It's a small thing, but being able to hold down the spacebar to continuously advance the turn just feels good.  Reading other reviews, it is clear a lot of the community has gotten bogged down in the meta narrative of this game.  Concerns that SD1 wasn't supported for long enough after launch, the proliferation of bugs, charging for DLC that should be part of the game.  If you "buy into the hype" and those things get under your skin, give the game a pass.  However, if like me, what you really care about is: "Is this game worth picking up and playing right now?"  I would say $30 might be a bit too much given the polish issues, but it is definitely worth picking up on sale.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												In my opinion this game is completed by the DLC. Although a bit of a questionable move, I can understand why the developer has chosen to go this route. The DLC makes the game much more fun, the addition of the hex tiles means sensor range is more sensible now and the construction ships offer an additional gameplay mechanic with more resources to control. The new ground combat is much better and more suitable for 4X games. Please don't be put off by the learning curve, even on normal it will take a few games of getting your♥♥♥♥♥wiped on the floor by the AI before you learn how to take them on. What's great is that everyone will develop their own strategy naturally.My one gripe is the AI. Now I like diplomacy in 4X games but you HAVE to keep in mind that the AI is also trying to win and there can only be one winner. As soon as the AI thinks you're weak, they will take advantage. My advice is to avoid AI until you can defend yourself but be warned, from mid-game onwards the AI will produce fleets that will literrally take up the whole screen before the battle starts, so build a fleet you think will be of adequate size, then make it tenfold.Also, try not to use the default ships as they're a bit lacklustre, make sure you take the time to experiment in building your own ships.Enjoy!

												Before everyone takes a steaming dump on this game and complains about zero being some kind of fraudster you might like to compare this game to paradox's newest release and see that they borrow from this game in many ways.This game will kick you♥♥♥♥♥ and make you wonder why. Then, after a few tries you will get the hang of it. Try to keep pace with the 1 big and donminating AI and you should be in with a chance.As for the galactic map, works well.-Tech tree is very interesting and options would be more restrictive if you didnt just trade it all back with AI.-Ship design rocks balls end off story.-Unique heros are quirky and fun.-Economy is hit and miss. sometimes i have loads of cradits and in other games i have f-all - and that before i build my fleet up.I watch quill18 play STELLARIS and thought, thats almost identical to stardrive2, with a paradox twist (which is to over complicate things). If you are into the same kind of experience and less paradox skull ramming then you wont be dissapointed with this game. Once you know how to build your ships that is.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												I finally can give my recommended for Star Drive 2. With the relase of "Sector Zero" and patches that followed this game is now very much enjoyable and fun to play.  There is room for more improvements and I hope the devs continue the path currently taken and further expand on what I consider now a 4x space game ahead of most others. Distant Universe is deeper and complexer, but not always in a good way. When you have to handle spreadsheets in your games and deal with only the most basic in terms of visuals, it is not appealing to many gamers. I prefer a good mix of both: Depth but not too heavy on the spread sheet side and good to look at. I want to see my home made ship designs in all their beauty and in action, and this is where Star Drive shines. Though it could use a bit more depth and complexity.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												I really wanted to enjoy this game, but even on easy it all boils down to combat, combat, combat.Pros:- ABSOLUTELY LOVE the ship editor.  By far, I think it's the most robust unit customization mechanism I have ever seen.- Intuitive and streamlined planet/resource managementCons:- Even on easy, end game ends up one big ship slug fest with limited diplomacy options- Diplomacy overall is limited, although I can appreciate some of the unique elements in it (racial tolerance for deals)- Some missing quality of life featuresSo if you want to just design the cheapest, most effective ships and go conquer other people, this game is for you.  If you want to run a peaceful federation with ships that explore, do science, and occasional light combat, maybe wait for a patch or some mods.  Until then, I am not recommending this game in the current state.

												do not listen to everyone writing a review. Yes AI is hard, you just have to switch up your play style you normaly play with as the creator knows how the average person plays. The creators of this game seem to be doing their best to help everyone. I found it hard like crazy the first 4 goes at it. Then it became simple. You just have to understand the game, how it works how it makes money. Do not listen to everyone writing this, this game will keep you on your toes and it makes you want to finish the game and wipe out the other races as they made you mad and sacrifice them all. I use to just play and play and play with other games like I am god or something with other games, this one you are just one of the races out for a fight. The game is fun, the battles are fun, you just have to understand it. You think you are ahead in this game and you are a god again and everything is easy then BAM.....very engaging. Been a while sense I had some fun, not  becuase I can lose, but a I can win, just have to do things differently and you can not seem to keep to one play style. I am now going to play on normal. Just make sure you create good ships. This game is great so far no bugs nothing, which is more then I can say for the first one they made. People like to just sit back and relax and play, and I understand being a God of a game is fun to, also can be boring eventually. I will go back to easy if I want to play a God way.after playing this game it became easy and there is no love in it, no diplomnacy. I played allot of hours on this game and ya I will play it as it is fun to some point. I want to give this game a 5 out of a 10. There  is no love. Everyone is rabit dogs and everyone wants to kill you. The first one you cound get them to join you and your empire and be friends with someone, gain access to their stuff and build with their ships. This one wipe everyone out and kill everything and eveveryone is rabit mad dogs. It si fun to a point as everyone hates you and it is a challenge. But there is no allies no, diplomacy, just kill everyone. That is why I changed it. If you like to just kill everything and this is a empire game and love it there is no allies or anything. Then this game is a great game if you like the loner stuff. The first one was great in the area you could ally and get them to join. This game is great do not get me wrong great graphics, game plays somewhat good had some glitchs nothing bad bad....but the war war war war war war war, just gets so boring. The game is by the way easy once you get to understand it. I would go to hard mode as it is to easy for me, but there si no love in this game and it bores me.They seem to keep changing it to make it better so I am now going to give it a better update. The AI is not as crazy with somethings anymore. They are still nuts and will hate you, but the game can be really fun. I do enjoy the battles. So I will now give it a 7 out of 10. I still wish there was Allys in this game it would make it a perfect game for me anyway. The thing is in order to make this game easy, you have to get a ultra rich astroid as your 3rd capture or collony and make sure you max it out quick with people.  If you have that with 2 planets the game is easy. Astroid can dish out a army quick. The comptuer is a moron with land battles(thank God) so they can never defeat you just make sure you have troops there. Store up a army and then fight. From the get go I had 2 people declair war, I had really no army. They came and tried to take over my place, If found my astroid, built a army quick and then kicked their butt. The game is easy so far, has some moments that it is hard. But follow that adivse and of course learn to make a good ship and always pick the subtarian trait, so you can have that 3 person in the astroid, production powerhouse, but that is up to you. I find missle ships are the best in the biginning with some decent counter measures for missles.  You will rule the space if you have all crusiers for a time  Do not listen to the people the game easy I have only played on normal so, I am not sure about the other lvls. the AI is crazy though, they just hate you...kinda do not like that but it is fun.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Stardrive 2 requires holding down the "Control" key when clicking the "Play" button in steam when using a 4 K resolution TV or monitor.  This brings up a menu allowing the user to select custom resolution, and  choose full screen or windowed mode.  Failing to do this the user will get a blank screen with a mouse cursor and music playing in the background.  Nothing to click on.  Hopefully the developer will address this in a future patch.The game looks visually stunning on a 4 K resolution Ultra HD TV.  The sound loops are pleasant and unobtrusive.Stardrive 2 is a generic 4x turn based game with research, exploration, expansion and extermination or assimilation.  The implementation is good, the game is fun, and there is a lot of customization possible.This game is well worth a look, especially if it is on special discount.  It may not be the "Best" in the genre, but it is pretty ok and is worth investing some time to play.6 / 10

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												What MoO3 should have been.StarDrive 2 seems to take the best elements of many of the 4x games to come out in the past decade:Smooth and intuitive interface (Endless Space)Easy to learn, hard to master economy (MoO 2)Fantastic real time space battles (Armada 2526)Deep and choice-intensive tech tree (MoO 2, and better! - love the experimental and special projects branches)Ship customization! (Space Empires IV/V, and better!)Good galaxy lore and interesting races (Galactic Civilizations)And, ground combat! Sure, it's not the best or most polished part of the game, but NO other 4x to my knowledge has anything at all. It's almost always badly abstracted - so this is a step in the right direction.Out the box, with the TLC it has received from Zero, being careful to have a polished product out of the gate, as a 4X fan I'd give it an 8/10, and with some DLC and more polish, I think this could solidly, finally, dethrone MoO2. No more nights of waxing nostolgia playing MoO2 to scratch the 4X itch. The replacement is here.  (Galciv 3 is coming along pretty sexy though to!)

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I played a lot of original stardrive and while it had it's flaws I enjoyed the game a lot.StarDrive 2 however, I can't enjoy at all. No matter how hard I try. Game has numerous problems that really hurt the experience and generally it is quite unpolished.Thing that ticks me off most are the ridiculous "random" event raids and attacks. Yeah, they aren't random at all and if you were planning to try pacifist playthrough I got some bad news for you. Every time you encounter your first race you soon get these warhawks with 2 options, either declare war on newfound race or get attacked by a considerably large fleet. So you either build war fleet or build war fleet, great and diverse options. Then there are these crystal things coming after your butt constantly, as well as remnant wormholes popping left and right. Wanna guess how well your diplomatic approach works on these buggers? Not very well. You can either have no random raids at all, ever. Or you can have them every single time in same order forcing you to have large fleets ready no matter what playstyle you would want to use. Would be nice to have some options to the mandatory fights.Diplomacy is quite literally worthless for anything else than getting more tech, many of the races are hyper aggressive and will just demand tributes and send their fleets after you anyway. Tolerance is unpolished feature and will simply hinder any attempts to do meaningful trades. You can't ask other races for example to freaking bugger off from your space as they fly all the way over your area and colonise a planet right in the middle of your solar system when you have 5 battleships orbiting the damn thing waiting your own colony ship 1 turn away to get there.So, what we have at this point is pretty much a turn based space combat game. Now you might wonder if that at least is amazing... well no, not at all. Battles are boring to play and watch, and auto battle doesn't know anything about how the battles would actually turn out making you lose about 4 times as much fleet. Modules are horribly balanced too, fighter bays seem to be the be-all-end-all module and bunch of carriers will just wreck the AI every single time (also wrecks your performance and freezes the game for a while after every battle). Ground combat isn't any better, it's just slow and boring and auto battle again will just lose you troops for no reason.Tech tree is just plain bad and some of the choices make no sense at all to exclude another. Got fusion shields? Great. Now you might want fusion engines? Too bad.UI is bad with many features needing unnecessary clicking and scrolling around with relevant information not being where it needs to be. Like the empire overview, why can't it have X/X population numbers?Turns are annoyingly short and you will find yourself mashing spacebar more than your keyboard can handle.I guess the ship building is cool though... that's about only nice thing I can think of, although UI makes even this much worse experience than what it needs to be.I hope this game gets some serious patching, that might well be what makes this game worth your time.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												This was really hard to recommend, and if it wasn't so fun, I wouldn't.  But be warned...there are some bugs to be aware of.  I only encountered 2 bugs, but they were rather game breaking, and I hope I'm the only one who is encountering them, though I doubt it.  Read the rest of this review and other reviews before you buy, and you'll probably want to buy this on sale, like I did, though if you have the original SD you already have a 33% discount(I waited for an even better deal).Pros- In depth ship customizationgood diplomacyfun battlesgreat empire buildingcustomize your own raceCons-The game will crash if you don't auto-resolve battles with too many ships, as it will crash upon trying to load casualty listsIf you auto-resolve even larger battles, the casualty list will cover your screen, causing you to be unable to do anything.  AT ALLThe auto-resolve is bad...though it is also pretty much the same in other games.  I played out a battle, won without losing more than half a dozen small ships, crashed trying to load casualty list, auto-resolved, lost my whole fleet, and the casualty list from THAT covered the center of my screen and made it so that I couldn't click on anything and I could only use hotkeys and had to alt+tab and close out the gameConclusion-Fun overall, but it has some game breaking bugs, and is poorly optimized.  Judging from past experience, I'm not sure whether or not Zero will even optimize the game or finish bugfixing...he abandoned the original Stardrive long before it was done, and moved onto this project.  Let's hope he doesn't do it again.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Oh. My god. I'm not saying it's a difficult game. I'm just saying that Dark Souls is like Kirby's Epic Yarn in comparison to this game. That said - once you realise that you need to play it smart and stop thinking in terms of this being a 4X game - the game becomes really interesting. The only way to win is to take an intimate interest in your empire's stats. Like some kind of super micro managing mother. Use all the tools you are given to carve out a bloody path for your empire to success, because otherwise someone else will carve a bloody and desperate path right through your face.Pros:The UI is buttload better than most of the other space strategy games out there. It's not great. It's just better than most, which I call a pro.The management of the planets and ships makes sense. I've yet to go "Oh. I wish I could do that." Customising the loadout of your ships both works great and is absolutely vital to victory. Because only you know what kind of ship you need for what kind of scenario. Need a pure tank to absorb the initial attack and then a bunch of fighters slam into the enemy dealing the real damage? You gotta make it happen yourself. And you can. And it's awesome.Cons:The tutorial. I sort of didn't want to put it as a con, because it's not bad compared to other space strategy games. But it's still narration. "Do this, this happens." That said - it's short, to the point and gives you the important stuff. As someone who never pays attention to tutorials, this one worked well enough to get me into it. The difficulty is a bit odd. On the lowest difficulty I got my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me. This was until I started customising my ships, but even so. The lowest difficult is supposed to be a "try this button and see what it does." kind of affair, not "you want easy? You can't handle easy. Here, have some insanity."Overall - if you want a challenge, and a good space empire game, I say grab this one.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I bought and quite enjoyed SD1. I do seriously lament the lack of multiplayer, which is not yet present here either, but to be honest, for now I'm quite happy to play SD2 by itself, which is weird for me because I'm very MP oriented. I really thought I would miss the contunous play aspect of SD1, but to my surprise the instanced fleet action gives a bigger sense of scale than was present in SD1, which for me, at least for now, makes up for the smaller map sizes. This is much more a spirtual successor to MoO2, with proper characters, events, and buffs/penalties. The graphics are excellent and it runs quite smoothly on my, admitedly powerful, laptop. There are some minor bugs that i've come across, but no deal  breaks and I've no doubt that Zer0 is working hard to fix whatever crops up. I was fortunate to get the SD1 discount, so this worked out to be slightly more expensive than a trip to the movies, and there is no doubt in my mind I will get more than 2 hours of solid enjoyment out of it. I strongly reccomend playing without creative selected, as this makes your research choices much more important and leads to much more replayability.
