content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												It's a great 4x strategy game. If you like things like empire management, designing ships, tech trees(not quite a tech tree but something better imo), and some good old real time tactical spaceship combat then this game might be for you. There's just one thing you might want to consider before buying it. Do you like a challenging game that has a lot of depth that is hard to learn and hard to master?At first I found the game very frustrating. The first half a dozen games I played ended in utter failure. In my first couple of games the AI got a huge lead and dominated me. I did better in the next two and managed to compete with  and beat some of the AI empires but one still got a lead in the end and beat me. The last two I was doing well and it looked like I was going to come out on top but I ended up making a huge mistake and it ended up setting me back enough that I lost. I'm on my seventh try right now and I think I might actualy win this one though I'm not certain as I suffered a fairly big set back before I decided to turn in for the night.A lot of peopel would be upset by this kind of experience and I can understand why. It's very frustrating to be beaten so badly and wonder how things could have gone so wrong. It can feel down right oppressive and if you don't enjoy a challenge then it is certianly overwhelming, but the thing that has made it all worth it to me and the reason I am recommending this game is because I'm getting better each time I play and I'm enjoying more each time I play too. The game has a lot of depth and I've only scratched the surface so far but each time I play I understand more about how the game works. I'm not confused as to why I lost so badly in my first couple play throughs now. I now understand the mistakes I made and I won't be making them again. The game is not easy to learn and that is going to scare a lot of people away but it's very rewarding for the persistent. If you play this game you are probably going to lose pretty badly on your first games and that's a tough sell for most people. However, if you stick with it and keep playing you will find enjoyment in this game and won't regret the purchase.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												You'll be seeing a lot of "negative" reviews that say this game is too hard.  Ignore them.  These people are terrible at strategy games.  I won my first game on easy, which, while challenging at the beginning when I had no idea what to do, quickly lived up to its name.  As I write this, I'm currently blazing through my first normal game as a cybernetic civilization where I basically wasted my first 60 turns doing jack squat.  If this game is too hard for you, go play baby's first tbs, the garbage known as Civilization V.That being said, I was originally wary of this game.  StarDrive 1 was a bundle of broken promises and not a very good game, and made me wary of anything with an 'early access' label on it.  To this day I'm still annoyed at just what 'could have been' if the game had ever actually been finished.  I was never going to buy this game, but I saw that it had gone from real time to turn based and talked to a few people with decent amounts of played time, and decided to try it out.  I was not disappointed.  It is a good game.  Not a spiritual successor to MOO2, but it comes bloody close.  With a little more work and polish (or even a single, well made expansion pack) this could be the game moo fans have been waiting for.Just remember this -  mass drivers.  Mass drivers everywhere.Pros:The space variant of 'roaming barbarians' are actually more than a minor irritant early game, and can wipe out entire fleets if you don't pay attention.AI is much better than it was in 1.Techs are much more fleshed out than in 1.Mass Drivers.The diplomacy menu and tech trading is way better, ala galactic civilizations 2.  You can see what they'll accept and how much more you can push it.Cons:Still too few techs, doesn't feel involved.AI could be better.  They'll declare war on you for over expansion when you have an empire and a fleet twice as big and nasty as their own.  It's also far too easy to get them to leave you alone.  Throw them a few techs and they'll back off even if they have a clear advantage.Aside from a few standard lines, the AI chatter quickly becomes dull.  The 'humor' seems forced at a few points.The GNN.Not as many ship types, weapons are either worthless or overpowered, with no inbetween.The "traits" for various species need more work.  There needs to be more variety that and more traits that actually mean something.Tolerance is a bit hard to figure out, keep in mind I've only played for over a dozen hours though, so this is a mechanic I might just not have grasped fully yet.

												Daniel pretty much fixed everything that was bothering me in the first game, but I do hope he keeps fixing and updating the game post-release. The only thing that REALLY bothers me at the moment is the lack of proper long term peace treaties and alliances in the otherwise vastly improved diplomacy screen. It gets a bit samey if my only option to win the game is to wipe out everyone else, and having to constantly renew the numerous short term non-aggression pacts and trade treaties gets a bit annoying after a while. So, please add more long term diplomacy options (only available with good very good diplomatic relations of course) and I will be extremely satisfied with the game.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												first of all,keep in mind  this is my second 4X game i have played, so im not an expert on them.since I played the first game and really enjoyed it, the second I saw this game came out (and the discount it had from having the first one) i bought it. the tutorials make it clear that stardrive 2 is very complicated, and right they are. I've been playing as the opteris( cybernetic bugs, passion to expand and destroy everything in their way) and I've restarted probably about 8 times now.the first mistake I made was ship design, trying to cram good weapons into frigates and make as many of them as possible. its simply not practical since the AI somehow created a fleet of 400( yes, FOUR HUNDRED) frigates and were about to wipe me off the face of the galaxy.at first i thought this game really did cheat the AI into being a ship building superpower, raining death on everything like others say. I ws going to shelf this game for good,  but then i started playing in the battle arena, and realised its all down to how you design your ships! now after many attempts at starting an empire and failing, I am on my way to completely eradicating the squid people, all thanks to about 5 ships designed by me, tearing through these masses of enemy fleets!so if you are thinking of buying this game, I would get the idea of amassing a huge force out of your head and binning it. stardrive 2 runs on brilliant  ship design, trial and error, and understanding how to create as few fleet killing ships as possible, rather than a massive armada to do your bidding. so if you enjoy a challenge, love an in depth design system full of a hundred different weapons/ systems to choose from, and won't cry when the odds are against you, buy this game. I've had great fun playing the game so far and will be playing around in the shipyard a lot more!

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												And there goes my last ship......If your not a fan of really great space strategy games then you wont like this but if you do then man will you enjoy this game.  Firstly this game does what other space strategy games get wrong.  It has real time space battles that are fully controled by the player with really awesome spaceships to fight with.  The artwork in the game is great fun to look at and even though i like a more serious tone to my games the design of the races are fun and badass at the same time.  The game has a sort of humour intermixed with some serious lore.  The idea of cycles of destuction with the races of the galaxy destroying each other each cycle.  Theres also fun side quests that pop up every so often with crystal ships, ancient black cruisers appearing from insects, space worms and of course space pirates.  However there are some problems,  like the races are a little overly psychotic and are not interested in deplomacy like other games.  It can go from a promising start to instant war just from discovering your existence.  Some races also have way too much power and shoud be nerfed slightly.  Theres a couple of bugs and battles can run a little slowly if alot is happening.  But for all of the problems their is still alot of patching and tweaking here and there so im sure itll get better.  In my opinion if you want to wait it out fine but id recommend picking it up cus man you will not regret it.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Thumbs up for a game that surprised me unexpectedly in a positive way.In the first place I was very cautious to buy it while reviews were very contradictory and controversial. However I did get it and... surprise! Had so far some great time with fun and lots of adrenaline. A mixture of ingredients from other similar games that even reminded MOO but with original components as well.But honestly for some reason I find it difficult to make a sort of “traditional” review because there are many issues and aspects to put down on the ground. So I will choose a rather unconventional method of approach...Stardrive 2 is definitely not like an expensive gourmet restaurant ala card menu. Neither is ma's or granny's good old dish. It is like a neighborhood canteen junk Food! But a very tasty one, addictive, full of fat, crunchy and juicy, spicy with lots of exotic stuff inside it. Now if you are the kind of person that likes variety in food styles then go for it. But if you are the “snub” kind of a character that likes healthy food and especially sensual delicate pleasures in taste, than i should tell you to stay away from it. But I won't. And yet for this to happen the devs must in the fist place prove that the game will soon get to it's promising potentials making some improvements, developments even changes as well. Just really hope to see this things happening in future updates because this game can really become a hit. Bon appetite!P.S And one thing to start with improvements, among others, is just changing the ridiculous ground battle mode where it doesn't fit the general grand strategy idea(!) where in some level the game flirts with.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												SD2 is a difficult 4x strategy game with homicidal AI and some very good game mechanics. Overall the game is very solid but in its current state if falls just short of a classic. A must have for space strategy fan boys, not a good buy for a casual gamer or those new to the genre.The Good:* Customizable options for the factions and starships lends to great immersion. I have made plenty of flagship battle heavy titans that get smashed because I didn't place armor in the right places or had too many spinal mounts that could hit anything far away but the big ship couldn't turn fast enough to handle flank attacks. * Graphics are awesome. Clicking on planets and watching the cities light up on the dark side increase with population is a nice touch. Ships blow up into several smaller pieces and actually come apart instead of an explosion cloud animation.* Space battles tend to devolve into choatic melees despite the most careful planning and ship design ( I consider this a realistic plus some micromangers may get frustrated with the lack of form in battle) A formation button would be a plus.The Bad:* Homicadal AI that will attack at immediately when weakness is shown* AI sends massive doom fleets that are kinda of fun to destroy with some well built smaller fleets, but it is easy to be get overwhelmed* Some characters cause some serious headaches. Watch your♥♥♥♥♥if you hire Zapp Groening, because the AI will go ape♥♥♥♥♥♥ (-20 diplo for a 30% firepower bump)* Ground combat seems a bit underwhelming. Troops are determined by population so 6 soldiers defending a world of 6 billion doesn't seem right in scale.* Tech tree are based on difficult choices. Each category has one of three options. If you just start playing and researching blind you will find that you have a broken economy and a disfunctional empire mid game.Summary:* Active community with a developer who reads the damn forums and reacts with frequent patches* Hard but satisfying when you develop a winning reciepe * A beautiful game with great FPS for the graphics (34 hours in no CTD)* A lot of bang for 30 bucks* Samurai Space Bears

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Star Drive 1 was better. This one doesn't feel very unique. It's like Galactic Civilisations 2 lite. It tries to do a bit of everything in GC2, but doesn't excel in anything.Prepare to go to war from the start of the game. There is no diplomacy in this game. AI will come knocking as soon as they meet you.The space combat is average. Not like the first game where you can have hundreds of ships duking it out. Ship design is like the first game. But your choices are simpler because you're not faced with as many units as the first game. You just have to kill whatever is in front of you before they close the distance to your ship, so mounting an array of long range rail guns and flak cannons (for point defense) = like shooting fish in a barrel.The ground assault is meh. It's like XCOM but there isn't much variety in units, gear or abilities even with full tech research. The limited amount of troops (only 4 units) permitted in ground assault is a let down. I ended up bombing from orbit rather than deal with the frustrating ground assaults.Planetary invasions are buggy. You clear out the sector of enemy ships, but then you can't invade or bombard. The only way is to leave the system and come back and try again. Annoying.For $20... its ok. Not great but ok.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Boo.  I played SD1 and it had some interesting ideas but also had some big flaws that made it hard to enjoy playing for very long.  There seemed to be some changes in this version so I tried it out.  Long story short, while it has some nice bits the pieces do not fit together well at all.  Some UI elements that you have to use every truen are tedious to access.  Many turns, nothing happens.  The AI is poor and only excells at massively cheating up units.  I experienced multiple crashes and lock-ups in the later game and late game fights were slooooooooow.  And this is a super minor thing but the background 'spaceship' sound effect is not controlled by the audio sliders in game, so I had to turn off all sound from the game to keep it from making my head hurt after a while.The wrost part is some aspects are less good than the first one.  Such as the ship combat and ship design, both of which I think are more simplified to the point that they are just busy work.  The ground combat got an upgrade but it is still tedious.  I doubt I will play any more games of this.  It was not expensive, but still not worth the time invested for a game that feels half baked.

content:

												Stick to professioanly developed games for this one.  The creator Zero is literally a zero when it comes to doing anything but making you play the way he wants you to.  There are entire scripts that all make it so you HAVE to play it a certain way or a wormhole opens up in your home system connecting you to the enemies home system.  You can look it up if you don't believe me.The creator is amateur at best when it comes to handling anything bug related and all the races play the same.  They all have the same upgrade and the same effects for their weapons. With all this though the true reason to not get this is becuase of what the creator did to everyone who got the first one.  Completely walked away from it to make the second and it is the same game.  Charged people twice while promising the world.  Just buy a game from EA. Even they aren't as corrupt or immature as the zero who made this.

												Just buy the first one.The combat in this one is stale. The Ai just spams smaller ships that use rockets, so equip 20 ships with long range weaponry and just retreat to win. Battles also take so long and don't feel like they have a big impact on the game. The ground combat in the first one felt epic, throwing hundreds of soldiers at a planet and watching this huge battle. The second one is turn based with special abilities and feels dry as ♥♥♥♥. Only thing the second one does better is graphics, diplomacy, and empire borders. For real, if this game interes you just buy Stardrive 1, you'll enjoy it way more.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I absolutely love a ton of features in this game. But there are some things that make this game beyond broken and not worth the money. Firstly, the AI is stupid, it buys every upgrade, masses little ships, has no strategy, and on higher difficulties all it does is cheat more, no extra strategy, just gets extra stuff for free. It has complete map awareness at all times, knows where your fleets are on any difficulty, and a plethera of other aweful things. Secondly there is a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of ♥♥♥♥ing bugs that makes me question, how on earth this game even is released as a compelte game. Crashes all the damn time, during space fights enemies will run off the map where you can't see them, so the fight never ends and the only option is to forfiet destroying all of your ships... Seriously that is the only thing you can do, and hope you saved before the battle. The end game is bad, just plain bad. There are 70 solar systems in a normal game, and the information displayed to you makes it nearly impossible to navigate your enourmous empire. Allocating resources, troops, knowing populations, will take you about 40 minutes a turn once you start to get a lot of stuff. It's not am enjoyable 40 minutes either, it's trying to remember how much population planets have, which planets are where, what type of abundance are they, etc etc. and you generally have to navigate 3 to 4 different screens just to try and gather all this information... It is beyond frustrating. There are some wonderful features in this game,random encounters, ship design, good humor in the stories of heros and missions, andship battles(if there was a bit more strategy, but it's still fun blasting 100 enemy ships into dust with long rauge gauss cannons before they reach you). But these features will not satisfy you. Avoid blowing your money on this game and support a game that actually designs quality games.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												StarDrive 2 is a game where core mechanics are mostly superb, but it lacks features required to make a truly good 4X game.Quite frankly, this game focuses way too much on "exterminate"-part of the 4X, which makes it seem shallow compared to it's peers.  This is not a game where you try to win with a peaceful empire by intrigue, colonization, science and diplomacy.  While these parts are certainly a part of the game, they have habit of getting into one another's way.  Given that, the game's focus tends to be in ship design, logistics and space battles.  But most of all, this game lacks diverse content that is usually a requirement for any 4X game.  The game's pacing also feels like it's not been thought out, with research, exploration, and conquest all working on their own pace, instead of supporting each other.The good parts of the MOO2 are there, no doubt, and they will suck you into the game for a good 10 hours or so, before the flaws start to shine through the gaps in the awesome.  The alien species that seemed varied at the first sight, start to all feel more same-y with only a slight twist after a while, the short tech tree is past future-tech at the point around third of the galaxy is explored -- I haven't even met all species before the tech tree is done, and I am quite certain this problem will just seem all the more clear if you like to play research-centric species, which I do not.On the other hand, the random-ish events and whatnot give some background into the galaxy, and fill some gaps nicely.  The worlds slowly turning into core-worlds, ski resorts built into tundra worlds and beaches of the ocean worlds all give nice flavor to your empire's worlds.  Designing ships is also fun, and quite likely the best part of the game.  Only thing I would love to have in the design is more options later on, but in the early-game, there were more than enough.  The problem there comes only later on, when you can just cram some full of long-distance weaponry and near-impenetrable shields, at which point any opposition just gets obliterated.The diplomacy mechanics of the game are also good, which is a pity, since every alien you meet will want to murder you, however peaceful they claim they are (they usually don't).  The only empire I have ever managed to hold peace with, was the one trying to constantly steal my technology, to the point where I wanted to murder them instead.  And this is the problem with the alien species.  While they seem like really cool ideas with built-in shout-outs, you will soon see a certain pattern there.  There are Cthulhu-esque theocrats that want to murder you for not worshipping their gods, wolf-like evil warriors who want to murder you for the evulz, space-bears that want to murder you for honor, mind-controlling molluscs that want to enslave you out of boredom, robot hive-mind that want to murder you for lebensraum and plant-like "peaceful creatures" that quite likely just wanted to enjoy the gentle optics of my laser beam arrays on my ships.  The tendency of everyone trying to murder you, combined with AI's suicidal optimism and overconfidence about their odds about winning a war tend to lead them declaring war on you just to get horribly murdered instead.  And while this was fun the first time, it grew old fast.  There simply aren't any aliens that like to win the game, instead of giving you excuse to fight to showcase the game's combat mechanics.The space combat itself seems OK, and ship designs seem to really matter.  The AI seems to just move towards you guns blazing though, regardless of its ship designs.  The UI is good enough, if sometimes a bit annoying, especially if you like to use fighters, since selecting ships is sometimes not as straightforward as it should be.The absolute worst part of the game is ground combat.  It seems like an afterthought and the UI makes it constant misclickfest at it.  It is skippable, but the automagic resolution doesn't do as good job as you would with some equipment, so it becomes just a chore to be done before you can continue on the fun parts of the game. In the end, the focus on the extermination and conquest strip the game of many of the strategic elements it should be capable of.  The space and ground combat lack good enough AI to actually showcase the best parts of the game -- the ship design.  The replayability also suffers when every game ends up in a war with only slightly varied opponents.  That being said, the game's strategic mechanics are excellent, and most of the bigger problems COULD be fixed with patches.  Even with all its flaws, this is probably one of the best space 4X games after Master of Orion 2.  The problem is, I still rather play MOO2, which currently costs quarter of this game's prize.  If this game would cost 10€, I would recommend it, but for this cost, it just doesn't offer enough.tldl: If you can look past some flaws and/or have infinite money to spend, this is a good grab.  Not worth 20€, probably not even worth 15€ at 1.1 patch.  If you can get it sub-10€, get it.

Posted: October 18, 2015
												This 4x space game has several excellent differentiators. The ship-building has more depth than many other games in the genre; where you place your systems really matters. You get more tactical control of battles than some others, also. From the strategic side, supply lines are widely distributed and cannot be defended on all points; just like reality.  Have not encountered the glitches that others reported; maybe because my gaming machine has plenty of RAM? Don't know. Works pretty smoothly IMO.Final word is that this game is fun to play. Recommend.

												Alright so I've played this game qutie a bit, and through multiple updates.Not gonna lie when I frst played I swept the map off all enemies relatively fast due to the AI building super terrible ships. The DLC that turns the map into hexes is awesome. suddenly tactics in space becomes a thing besides throwing my brave (Or not so brave) space men to their deaths. Pro-tip for those that buy and play this regularly, SPAM BUILDING SPIES. ALWAYS. Otherwise well... You didn't really need that lead in tech did you?

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												4x space empire building game which uses mechanics which are similar to those found in Master of Orion 2. Looks nice, works well under Linux and can be challenging to play. One of the nicest features is being able to design your own ships based on 5 types of hulls, where each race has their own hull configuration. Meaning that each race has to think about which configuration of weapons, armor and systems is best suited for their ships. Knowing what your opponent is using and how to counter their ship designs is important. Downside of the current game is that there is basically only one way to win the game, by conquering the other races. However in the coming DLC different victory types will be added, alongside a sectors mechanic and a revamped ground combat mechanic.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												4x space empire building game which uses mechanics which are similar to those found in Master of Orion 2. Looks nice, works well under Linux and can be challenging to play. One of the nicest features is being able to design your own ships based on 5 types of hulls, where each race has their own hull configuration. Meaning that each race has to think about which configuration of weapons, armor and systems is best suited for their ships. Knowing what your opponent is using and how to counter their ship designs is important. Downside of the current game is that there is basically only one way to win the game, by conquering the other races. However in the coming DLC different victory types will be added, alongside a sectors mechanic and a revamped ground combat mechanic.

content:

												Having played the first StarDrive, I am a little disappointed with the second so far. I feel like I have less direct control when its comes to research and commerce, and that the AI even on easy is vastly ahead in terms of expansion.  But this is only a little under two hours into the game, so things could change. It's not a bad game in and of itself, but it feels more hands off (except on the damn space bar) than the first.I have to add that the developer is a one man army, so take the following with a grain of salt. The first game was left with some issues that were never addressed, which is unfortunate because as I mentioned above, StarDrive was more fun to play than its successor. I can only hope the developer will stay with the second game, and make the steam workshop an option. Mods could benefit the game quite a bit. I can't recommend the game, not yet. Wait until the summer sale, check on its price and its update status, and maybe take a chance then.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												So with all of the 4x clones coming out recently (MoO, Stellaris, etc.) it is hard to know what is truly good and what is failing. SD2 is turning out to be very much like the MoO2 from back in the day with one noteable difference, ship design is much more sophisticated. It seems that none of the current 4x games offer much in terms of tactical battles, but at least this one does cut away from the game so you can fight the fight and send out some fodder or advance screen ships while your big guns start hammering.StarDrive 2 started out a bit shakey with a alot of bugs, but has come a long way. The DLC had added significately to the game but came with its own problems. Most of those seem to be sorted out and for the most part, the game now seems stable.As for the balance and end game pacing, the game like so many seems to be more about your early choices, some placement and experience. This game seems to be more engaging than Stellaris from my point of view due to my personal taste in designing ships. Stellaris is more of a plug and play style, lacking in creativity. MoO is more along the lines of the old school MoO, ship wieght capacity vs weapon wieght. SD2 copies from ship design of Galactic Empires. If you can put up with the 10 year old graphics, then GE is superior.Overall, this game has something the other newer games don't, a more intriguing ship design, with Stellaris lacking tactical battles as well. Other than that, all three are very similar. As of right now, I rate SD2 > MoO > Stellaris. Until the others implement more features, this one gets my positive review.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												There's a lot to like about this game.The ship design is in depth and works pretty great. It's great fun to design ships with specific roles since every decision were you put which parts matters. But there are also a lot of issues and some of them show that this is an indie developer and not someone very adept at game design.1. The combat is just boring. It has a lot of good things about it. The graphics are pretty, the ships move in cool ways and it's pretty tactical. But it just moves soooo slow. There is no option to speed of the passage of time which kills the pacing in these battles. First you position your troops, then you wait half a minute were they crawl across the map until their actually in firing range and then you wait till the ships slowly widdle down each others help until you're done. It's just too damn slow. I once had to wait two minutes being bored because my big ships turned too slowly and always missed a fast small ship of the enemy. The last one. The ship was way too weak to even get through my ships shields, but i still had to wait two whole minutes until my ships finally hit that little bugger.2. The ground combat is even worse. It's designed in an Xcom sort of way were you move your units around a grid to attack and finally kill the enemies. But it's just not fun. It takes way too long to finish any mission, because the enemies always have about 10 times your numbers and all you can do is crawl through the level.Rule number one of game design: If you can't implement a feature properly don't implement it. These ground battles, which you can't auto resolve by the way, only add tedium to the game and are not fun to play.3. This all would not have been terrible if the strategy part of the game would have been great, but it's not. The game crawls very slowly. Often you are just forced to end turn after turn without doing anything, because the pollution mechanics means your production is pretty much always♥♥♥♥♥♥and takes forever to finish anything. The research isn't all that interesting and worst of all it locks you out of technologies unless you make a creative race or use the horrible diplomacy to trade for the tech.  4. I heard from quite a few people that the AI cheats massively and stomps you with unkillable armies in the later game, but i didn't even get that far without growing bored.Don't buy. It's not good.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												I'm not even sure to recomend it or not,There is soooooo many bug and even more when you get late game! My ship simply cannot use wormhole because they keep ''overshooting'' the thing! I even sometime see the AI having trouble with the bug.The auto combat is stupid! Got 5 of my titan coming out with all of their armor destroyed against a few cruiser and corvette when i can easily take out a fleet of 10+ battleship with a single titan. Same thing with ground combat! My mech get almost destroyed and reduced to 5-20 hp when they are maxed at 220! It would be fine if i could heal them outside combat but nooo. They can regenerate 5hp/turn but can't regenerate 50 hp in 10 years. even with a hospital built. Not enough time i guess.... And one funny bug that i found but not able to recreate is when i switch fleet with the AI, i control his ship and he control mine so i just suicide his long-range ship and send one by one his close range ship...And there are many more bug that i wont list since i dont have all day to do that and this is not the place to put them but still, the game look like it should be in early access not fully release.The space combat mechanic are annoying and long for no reason if you cant simply click and forget and hope for the best for your ship, you need to set the range of your ship every single time you do a battle you need to set the formation of your ship every single time you need to order your supply ship or support ship to retreat at the start of the battle every single time. Cant you save you setting so you dont have to do this every single time??? And when you try to select your ship to give them order you almost always select another one if they are too close.The ground combat could use improvement too, if you are colorblind you will have a hard time to see the range of your weapon and then you when you try to select one of your troop you better not have forgotten that you have your rocket launcher selected on the last dude you tried to shoot because boom you just lost 3 of your men because of thatThe diplomacy is almost optional, if you have slightly less ship than the AI does (and you will since the AI can produce them faster than you can with all of your planet focusing production) the AI will ask for tribute at best and then war if you dont agree. After the war the AI will be mad at you because you defended yourself and will ask for tribute after the peace ended and if you dont agree he will declare war again. If you can, try to have trade route with him before he get angry so you can at least get some money before the war. You cant even have an aliance there is no research to do so and the AI would problably just say no anywayBut i still have fun when the AI does not send 137 ship agaisnt me when my supply limit is 30 (not kidding) and when he bomb my planet without any bomb on his ship (i checked every single one of his ship and no bomb on his design!) I wil play more game where i will rage when near the end because my ship just doesnt do what i tell them to do like attack or intercept the enemy fleet or use the wormhole because they keep ''overshooting''I like the game but there is so much that can be done to improve the gameplay its great and it have a good potential but dont buy the game unless you realy want to play it, there is many other game where you can have more fun.There is a lot of bad thing i have to say about the game but its only because i want it to be better!

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												While StarDrive 2 is a hard and entertaining game, but it's biggest problem seems to be performance. I can not in good conscience recommend this game as it becomes unplayable the more time you invest in a game.Around the time when you can make the biggest ships in the game the "titans" the game is becoming increasingly more laggy. The fps takes a dive the more ships you have in your fleet attacking any other, and while that is to be expected. You must have a large fleet to combat the enemy's equally large fleet.Another issue is the transition from combat to world map. Once you finish a battle between two larger fleets it can take in my personal experience several minutes (3-5 min) before all the damage taken, damage given and any earned medals that are given to the ships are done calculating and the statistics of the battle are shown. So unless there would be a limit to sizes of fleets or increased performance of the game, I won't be playing it again nor will I be recommending it

Posted: June 24, 2016
												This is a very good space strategy game, easy to pick up and challenging to master.  Built on—but by far an improvement over—a similar design philosophy to games like MoO, the depth added to gameplay far surpasses current offerings like the newest Master of Orion.  This game is arguably up there with Star Ruler 2, Stellaris, and Galactic Civilizations III in terms of both addictiveness and replayability.  The developer is responsive to the community and works continually to improve upon an already strong game.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Very interesting game. Stardrive No1 kept me occupied for years. I kept restarting again and again so i can try out the different races. Overall i must have finished the game around 10 times. I will not say the same for No2I spent around 20 hours on it before i get bored. And i can't find something to unbore me with it..-Identical AI with First game. which was one of the game's major flaws.You can never beat this AI. You might win one race and by the time you are done with them your allies start stealing planets of them trying to annoy you into starting a war with them but ... If you do they will destroy you because by the time you finish opponent No1 opponent No2 is building a fleet against YOUR fleet ship by ship.I warn you before you find yourself frustrated.This hasn't changed from Stardrive 1.I took my first ship and run early to AI planets to see how fast they move. Their exploration ship has never moved from their planet within the first 50 rounds.But when you meet them they have a full empire stronger than yours no matter how fast you make your moves.the only thing artificial about this intelligence is the CHEATING part! More.. : -Identical Shipyard with S1-Identical ships with S1-Identical technologies with S1. ATI 6990 (3GB RAM) with 24 GB of Physical RAM and the game stutters to infinity when ships are more than 10 and they all fire rockets. When one fleet is more than 100 ships the whole map stutters if you select that fleet.keeps stuttering until you deselect it. As long as you stick to 5 ships max it should be ok...I have absolutely no reason to speak bad about this game other than the fact that i strongly believe i wasted 30 euros!If you have a very strong fleet the AI will create an INFINITE fleet to attack you and when it happens your PC freezes all the way until all your ships are broken to pieces. This is Stardrive 1 remastered to be turn based and with some serious flaws removed and a lot of others added.Some stuff are improved but a lot of stuff have deteriorated from Stardrive 1 to a point where i don't feel like playing any more. This game is what every 4x game should be about. I just consider it to be a beta, and not yet ready.It's a great game if it ever improves. but not yet. I loved S1 and hoped and waited for S2 so some flaws could be corrected.Now after seeing the end result... i have to admit Stardrive 2 was a waste of my money!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Since Master of Orion II I have experienced a few notable contenders that have tried to recapture the same magic. Sword of The Stars, Endless Space, and now StarDrive 2. StarDrive 2 is the closest direct copy with (semi) modern visuals with the majority of its gameplay lifted strait from MOO2. Corn/Hammers/Beakers with Civ style buildings make up the majority of colony management. This is an exact replica only slightly tweaked by the maintenance cost of buildings forcing actual choices (that the AI is unprepared to make). Design wise this comes off as a fan patch that makes sense in the context of MOO2 but has no life of its own.The stolen content is the best part of the game.Anything that was not mathematically or superficially lifted from the original is incredibly unpolished. The entire experience is like a house built with only a photograph as a reference. The AI does not know how to design ships or manage its empire, The new ground combat is a tedious slog of looped animations, and the "real time" space battles (though nice looking)  are not decided by player commands just the ships you carefully designed. It is reminiscent of gratuitous space battles except because you designed decent ships you can take on 5x the chaff that the AI is stuck with.I can not recommend this game to anyone who has never played Master of Orion II and even then not at full price. On the outside it looks and feels exactly like the MOO2 you may fondly remember while running on modern hardware. It scratches the itch in a way that irritates as much as it satisfies. At the time I write this the developer is making severe content and balance changes and this game may become a late blooming gem like Sword of The Stars one was. However, the developer ditched fixing StarDrive to make StarDrive2 and the problems above may just get dropped for StarDrive3.*Breaking news*$10 DLC to address gameplay shortfalls of an unfinished early access game. Buy now! Buy later!  Buy until StarDrive1 is finished in StarDrive4

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Не ожидал и был приятно удивлен увидеть в нераскрученном проекте интересный геймлей и глубину проработки идей. Подинный наследник идей Мастера Ориона, также есть реализация идей других проектов. Бои динамичные с возможностью ручного контроля. Основная фишка - крафт кораблей и их проверка боем. Квесты на глобальной карте дают неожиданные технологии. Наземные бои грешат яркими тонами в отображении сетки ходов, но терпимо. Наземные юниты также настраиваются в экипировке. Космический флот получает опыт и ранги, наземные - нет, но 4 грамотно настроенных юнита побеждают все бои с ИИ. В дополнение есть отдельный боевой режим. Очень интересный проект. Рекомендую, особенно тем, кто играл в Master of Orion 2.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Maybe I have the game setup wrong, but every single time I try and play the game, I get forced to go into a battle long before I ever am able. Diplomacy works, you make a peace treaty with the aggressive AI, only to get hit with a message next turn that 'your people believe that the enemy is trying to take over your space and should be dealt with.' If you agree with them, you get 500 gc, and subsequently annihilated because even 1 turn after negotiating peace you still arent freaking ready. Or, you can tell them to screw off, and well what do you know? There is an uprising that whipes out your fledgling fleet entirely.So, this game franchise goes from being really cool, to the second iteration which is impossible to play through.tl;dr Your enemy can build things 10x faster than you, and either you attack them and lose, or your own people will attack you and you still lose the game.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Not sure what all the hate is about, this is one of the best 4x games out there currently.  Beats the hell out of Stellaris -- and this is coming from a longtime Paradox fan (hoi2, eu2, eu3, ck2, hoi3, hoi4, eu4).It's not perfect, but I'm hard pressed to name a recently released 4x space game that's better.  The new MOO is casual trash.  Stellaris is hollow and in desperate need of about 5 DLCs to flesh it out.Distant Worlds was promising, but is seriously hobbled by needless overcomplication married to the worst UI I've seen in 20 years (hope you don't want to read any of the text because the fonts are blurry and microscopic).  Endless Space is way too simple and lacks any significant depth.  I grew up on Space Empires (2, 3, & 4) and 5 is playable, especially with mods, but looks, and plays, like it was made 15 years ago an desperately needs some quality of life improvements.  Galciv 3 is inferior to Galciv 2 in most every way, and suffers from bad AI, bad ship building, bad combat, and mostly, is boring.  Sword of the Stars 2 is a bad joke.Star Ruler 2 is good but lacks a lot of the standard space 4x mechanics, particularly the empire management which feels very abstracted and more like a board game.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												"I guess the bottom line is that I would've rather had a remake than this version of the game. "For the purposes of this review, I'm going to ignore the fiasco that happened with the first game. From here on out, let's continue with the assumption that had the first game been finished as it was intended, it would have gone on to become a great game - if you don't already consider it to be one. Why am I bringing this up? Stardrive 2 is a sequel. It is NOT a remake of the first game. And as a sequel, I"m going to compare it to the first one just like I would any other sequel.So first things first:Stardrive 2 is turn based - not real time. While some people might like this change, I for one HATE it. I personally feel that a sequel should try to be somewhat similar to its predecessors and this change is a bit overwhelming for me. I mean we went from RTS to Turn Based, and while I do genuinely like some turn based games (Civilization comes to mind), it felt very awkward for this game because I just wasn't expecting it I suppose. The planetary menu/information screen has changed quite a bit. All the planets have hexes (instead of tiles) you can build on now and all hexes are unlocked where before Biospheres were important for unlocking all tiles on any given planet. I actually like this change quite a bit. Tiles that were disabled seemed too arbitrary before and this hex system seems much more balanced. Furthermore I LOVE the citizen/workers. You can now quite easily reassign any citizen(s) to a different role (Farmer, Scientist, etc.) and I think overall this change was extremely well done. It is far less tedious trying to get a new planet established than the original Stardrive which had major issues when you got "Bad Starting Territory."Of course the space battles and ship design have always been the major attraction to the Stardrive series and this game does not fall short in that department. I feel like the ship design has been tweaked slightly from the first game and I also consider this to be an improvement. Since the game is now turn based, you get encounters when engaging in space combat. There is first a deployment stage where you can move your ships around and decide what positions/formation you want them to be in, followed by the actual battle. You may NOT give attack orders during the initial phase. I find this to be quite frustrating for someone who likes to micromanage the entire fight but overall combat is still done very well.Now on to a few matters that really drive me nuts!CP stands for command points. Ships cost command points to maintain every turn and if you go over your CP limit, you now have to pay a heavy BC fee (BC stands for Billions of Credits IIRC). This forces one of two things: you either maintain an ENORMOUS empire, or you are forced to have a small fleet. Small as in compared to the first game. Hell I remember the nerf from the original Stardrive. I never actually looked up the patch notes, I just remember loading up one of my files where a had a huge fleet and looking at my massively negative income. I don't know if credit income was nerfed or ship maintenance fees were increased but I truly loved the massive fleet sizes you could attain in the original Stardrive before that patch. Even after it you could still field a somewhat large fleet. But that's the problem. I played the Original first and I know how much fun it is to watch that many ships having a chaotic space battle. In Stardrive 2 a LARGE battle is something like 20 vs 20. CP is a soft cap due to BC paying for ships but.... your economy probably can't handle even tens of ships past the limit.The best way to increase your CP is to build new starbases (or their upgrade/Battlestations) on all your planets. So what this comes down to is not how much money you make, but is much more about how many planets you control. Therein lies another problem.I feel like the interface isn't very good for managing a large empire. After playing a few games I quickly learned I was having more fun on cluster settings with the minimum number of systems - 20.  Even at 5 systems you typically control somewhere around 10-15 planets. I can't stand just using the galaxy map at that point. Maybe I'm missing something or maybe the layout of the Empire Overview just isn't what I"m looking for. But ultimately in the original game I wanted a HUGE, MASSIVE EMPIRE! ...But in this game I just want to be small civilization :(Last but not least due to the fact that the number of ships for each race is so small, the initial fight seems to decide the outcome of the entire war. You kill their fleet, you go on to take over all their planets with little difficulty (Neuro Toxic Bombs quite easily wipe out the local ground oppostion). The last thing I want in a 4x game during combat is to have only ONE definitive space battle against any one race. Ships are hard to spam fast enough to recover from a loss that quickly, even with a Gaia world. Overall I feel the original game was much better, though there were obvious problems completing the game due to what happened. I guess the bottom line is that I would've rather had a remake than this version of the game. Note that I didn't quite go over EVERYTHING (like leaders) but this review is already long enough and I want anyone who takes the time to read it to make up their own mind.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Edit: After the release of the DLC I would recommend the game with the DLC or without. Most of the bugs are fixed (though some appeared for the DLC vrsion but it was to be expected. Actually it's not really a DLC but an expansion which adds deep and interesting mechanics to the game and improve it a lot. Ground combat has been fixed for the most part (as it has been revamped), balance is still not optimum but we're getting there. Zero is still not the best communicator with detractors but he actually personally helped me and fixed a bug I had (and that some other people had to) in mere minutes. I can't yet judge the change to the AI but it seems that it is more involved diplomatically which hopefully will give it an edge. Overall I would recommend now.Pros:- Great Visuals for a 4X game.- One of the best ship designs there is in a 4X games.- Good tactical combats.- Interesting lore reminiscent of MoO.- Interesting 4X game with a gameplay similar to MoO. - Mod friendly. It's very easy to tweak some Xml files to tweak some stuff out.- DLC is coming and it looks very interesting and improving many areas of the game.Cons:- DLC is coming and yet the game doesn't feel like finished.- Modding community is very small and seem to have deserted the game. There are actually very few functional mods left.- Ground combat is not very interesting.- Balance is lacking in tactical fights. It's too easy to have one type of ship designed and stick with that, obliterating the poorly designed AI ships. - Unbalanced races. Some races have much smaller hulls than others for the same ship categories. They then must rely in more ships to have a chance to win but the more ships you have the harder it will be on your economy.- AI is poor. It's just plain dumb and only manages to keep you on your toes at higher difficulty levels because it cheats (I think). - The game feels like rushed. Lots of bugs still exist after almost a year of release. - The updates are few and far between with amost if any changes to the game and the existing bugs. After almost a year of being released the game saw less than 5 updates (if my memory serves me right).- The developer. Zero seems to lack communication and as such he appears as lazy and not caring about his community. I couldn't say that it is true as I do not know him but it appears to be. In conclusion I cannot recommend the game in its state. I hope that the next DLC will fix and improve many things that are wrong with the game. I do believe that the game is interesting to play and has interesting mechanics for any 4X games fan  but shouldn't be considered a complete game. Definetly not worth 30 bucks, would buy for less than 10.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Stardrive 2 is the sequel to Stardrive 1, by the same developer. To understand why this review is negative, you need to understand Stardrive 1. This was a game with high hopes and moddability, with support from an up-and-coming indie developer who interacted with the community.For...awhile. And then support dropped off, and contact became sparse, and despite the game not being in a decently-finished state, it was abandoned, and Stardrive 2 was announced. Stardrive 2 is a space RTS like its predecessor, like Master of Orion, you outfit ships, you manage planets, you enact ground invasions, you manage your empire, etc. The races are decently-mixed and have varied ship appearances, the story and characters are mostly light-hearted, the art style is appealing...the game play is unfinished, and buggy, despite patches meant to improve it. Some of these bugs are quite game-breaking, immersion-breaking, and some features are incomplete or end up rough around the edges. What is there is much like Stardrive 1: Full of potential, ready to be built upon, ready to be expanded...ready to be finished.Well, the game is finished. If you buy the $9.99 Sector Zero DLC, which essentially finishes up the content and fixes a fair amount of bugs, and changes some mechanics in the game. Unfortunately, it's paid DLC. Paid DLC to fix and finish the game. As someone who went the extra mile and bought the "deluxe" edition, I cannot justify spending yet another $10 just to have the complete game. I bought a game I assumed would be completed. Paid DLC is not complete. Fallout 4, for all its bugginess, is feature-complete, pre-DLC. XCom 2, is feature-complete, pre-DLC. Buggy GTA V is feature-complete, and their DLC is free. I could pick a whole mess of games who are feature-complete through dedicated developer support, and the DLC simply adds on to the game, instead of simply containing bug-fixes and completed aspects of the game left-unfinished pre-DLC.What other games are feature-complete before DLC and what is "feature-complete". Kay, feature-complete entails that a game is decently playable and fulfills the goals stated by the dev, their store page, and the assumption when you're buying such a game, based on its history and your past experiences. What is a reasonable amount of developer support? Until the game reaches said feature-complete state, or a decent amalgam of such as defined by you, the person shovelling out the money for it. Just because DLC exists and can be shady or bad like this example, does not mean we sit here and joyfully accept it. Find your own list of what proof of decent pre-DLC, feature-complete games are out there, that's not the point of my review.The game is good, but because I must pay to get the good aspects ontop of the regular retail price, I cannot justify giving the game a good review.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												A good game. A very "american" game (the human starships are a really inspired by american Navy, the Wulfar have german U-boot), but really pleasant. The diplomacy is quite funny, not very developped, but fun. The starships customisation is also quite fun and easy to learn : it can take hours to find the good balance between energy and weapons.The battles, without being extraodinary spectacular, are well made : we quickly see the effects of the customization of starships.One regret : the extra galactic scenario is of no interest. I would have liked to disable it and win only by conquest.I recommand this game.in French :Un bon jeu. Un jeu très "américain" (les humains ont des vaisseaux qui ressemblent à ceux de l'US Navy et les Wulfars ont des vaisseaux en forme de sous marins allemands), mais un jeu très plaisant. La diplomatie est assez amusante, pas très développée mais avec du second degré sympa. La personnalisation des vaisseaux est simple et agréable : on peut passer des heures à trouver le bon compromis entre énergie et armement.Les batailles, sans casser des briques, sont bien faites et spectaculaires : on y voit assez vite les effets de la personnalisation des vaisseaux.Un regret : je trouve que le scénario avec les extragalactiques ne sert à rien. On voudrait pouvoir le désactiver entièrement pour simplement conquérir la galaxie, mais on ne peut pas.Je recommande ce jeu.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF YOU VALUE MONEYBuy StarDrive 1, it's a far more playable game and is actually enjoyableI realize I'm going to be bashed in the comments by a bunch of fan boys and that's fine because personally after painfully trying to play this game for as long as I did and that I struggled to attempt to enjoy it I don't mind people insulting me, at least I didn't waste perfectly good drinking money on them.Let me start off with saying I loved StarDrive, it still remains one of my favorite games I've played. The dev had quite the gem with it and because of StarDrive, I had no hesitation whatsoever to purchase StarDrive 2, especially after the wonderful discovery of ground combat being added, even bought the digital deluxe one just to show support. I also tried so very hard to enjoy this game, I really did.This game is a sham and a huge letdown, I haven't been this disappointed in a game since Unity came out after Black Flag, and CA tried to pass off Rome 2 as a playable game on launch.Pros -Customizable ships (Although was far superior in StarDrive 1 as well) -Ground combat (Or well, the idea of it anyways.) -4x space game worth playing (When talking about StarDrive 1)Cons -Ground combat (As it's far too easy and seems to be more of an aesthetic feature than anything serious) -Space Combat (StarDrive 1 was far superior to this drivel of a combat simulator, again this is far too easy. Also to mention that in StarDrive 1 you were able to move your ships into systems and they would automatically battle to the death with aliens, not some little battle screen that takes away the fun of the old combat system) -Tech Tree (Now I understand the thrill of being able to only choose one tech from a branch at a time and having to plan it out ahead of time but it gets way too old, far too fast. Being able to build onto previous techs is far more realistic than saying "Oh hey, should we focus on a rover bay or xeno mine?" Then you choose one, then suddenly "Well that's that, why should we bother with the other?" Now I didn't get too far in detail in the tech tree and if you are capable of going back to research the ones you didn't pick please leave an insulting comment down below although according to the tutorial you had to pick the other ones up through espionage or diplomacy which is fine if you want to get them that way but let us build on as in the first StarDrive) -Turn based (Now the beauty of StarDrive 1 was that it was automatic turns that happened every 4 seconds if I recall correctly (Please leave an insulting comment down below if I'm wrong) having to manually click to the next turn gets irritating because it allows you to ensure everything is done before you want to move on. In my opinion this makes the game far too easy because you never get caught out of sync and have to deal with a random invasion out of the blue, and holding the space button is just demented, they should have added a feature in the menu that lets you select continuous play or turn based. That feature actually set StarDrive 1 apart from Gal Civ for me and pushed it to my favorite.) -Customizable Ships (It feels like the ship design has been modified to make it "Easier" but far less creative and worthwhile) -Feels like a dummed down version of the original StarDrive with some aesthetic looks to make it smell less foul.I really am disappointed in Zero and sad to say he's been added to the list of terrible devs. If you have any soul or self respect left, please refund my money. I realize you won't, but you can't blame a guy for trying although I just want the money back for the principal. You may try and pretend that this is "an exciting and evolutionary step forward for the StarDrive franchise." But, in actuality it's a sad step backwards. Let's not try to take crap and call it gold, let's just call it for what it is. Even if you won't refund my money, please take this atrocity down from steam and give us an actual enjoyable experience that I came to expect from you. And as stated above, if any fan boys want to insult me, I welcome your comments. Make sure they're extra spicy as well please.Devs behaving like this is why I'm slowly turning more and more to tabletop gaming than video games in my spare time.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												I went into Stardrive 2 with high hopes that it would improve upon the old game that was basically abandoned and had missing features. What did I get? a game that tried so desperately to be different from the first that the smooth science tree is replaced with a clunky pick 1 thing lose out on the other two options. Ship designing that was nothing like the trailers, it offered limited choices and felt bizarre and all around poorly done. Which was a shame  because I loved ship designing in the first game, it was my favorite aspect. Then we get to freighters and population growth, apparently I can't send my freighters on trade missions, a planet needs to be starving for food to be sent to them automatically, taking even more control away from the player. Next is the turns, in the first Stardrive time passed and ever 5 seconds was a turn, you had the option of speeding up or slowing time, and even stopping it all together to make choices. Now time is paused from the get go and you have to hold down the space bar, wait a matter of seconds, and then it moved to the next turn as things jump ahead. Yet the game advertises as real time, to em this is a blatant lie as it is clearly a next turn button. This is all I could stomach of the game before closing it to play the original, as I don't want to be miserable on my birthday.  In summary, a soul crushing level of underwhelming game play and sheer disappointment, with the only perk being that the game wooks pwettyer than the first.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Before you purchase read the reviews. Be mindful when reading both positive and negative and look at the paterns, praises and complaints in both. Pros:Visuals are okSpace and ground combat can be challenging but fun for a time if you design your ships/troops correctly.Ground combat is way better and more visually appealing than SD1Several aspects add immersion and more challenge to the game, ie pirates, crystals entities, wormholes so on.Ship desing is more simple with less modules and less options than SD1. This can be both good and bad.You can disable GNN!!!!Cons:Interface is awkward and confusing. Devs should have stuck to what they had in SD1 bcs this attempt to change things up made the interface awkward and not user friendly. This is not a game breaking feature but it is definitely frustrating and disapointing. Sometimes the interface sounds will make you think you are playing FF7 all over again.Economy is punitive, confusing and awkward. Good luck trying to figure out what to build in order to make a profit and not plunging you planets into a Chernobyl like state. The money making builings are scarce and you are also limited by the tech tree as to which buildings can be built. Which brings me to the next point.Diplomacy is mediocre. Your military, financial or technological might or lack thereof does not seem to influence or sway the AI one way or the other. Basically what it comes down to is dont colonize too many planets or you will never be able to negotiate anything with anyone. All the while they will keep asking you to give them stuff for free but God forbid you ask them for the equivalent of a slab of bread in return to  make the deal fair somewhat... They will not have it.Tech tree is very restrictive and confusing (at first). The Tech tree is divided into 6 main categories each with 10 sub categories. Each sub category has 2 to 3 techs in it and you only get to pick one. Once researched you move to the next and cannot research anything else in the prior category. VERY limiting especially since some sub categories have your Titan, the best starbase and the best armor in game. Guess what, you only get to pick one. There are several other categories like these that limit you significantly although with very good planning this can be overcome.The Command point structure is extremely punitive and borderline game breaking. Why is this? Because this is what limits how big your fleet can be. Go over it and the game will be over for you in no time. This is a borderline moronic feature that was poorly implemented ESPECIALLY since the AI does not abide by it. To put it into perspective lets say you have a decent size empire with several planets, you can probably squeeze out 13 to 15 ships. Sometimes maybe a bit more if you reduce the amount of battleships and titans to 1 or 2. Not bad not bad right? This means absolutely nothing when not even the most powerful AI comes at you with 2 full fleets of 40 plus ships. Keep in mind your empires are similar in size and you are relatively equal in tech lvl. No.. im sorry.. NoAI does not seem abide by any of the restrictions and/or  limitations you will be put through. They are not attacked by the other forces (ie pirates and such) and they do not seems to have a fleet or ship cap (aka comand points). Their only limitation is tech, which they will steal from you no matter how many counter spies you have. AI will violate your territorial integrity regardless of treaties (which is expected) but will immediately declare war the minute you go an inch into their space.Wormholes will pop randomly all over your territory (usually right by your planets). This would not be a problem if they would connect to other wormholes across or near your turf. Sadly they lead right into the gates of oblivion at the heart of the enemy empire. They will use this repetadly to move their superfleets through you territory regardless of any treaty in effect. They also use this to teleport their main fleets right next to your main planets. This pretty much renders borders useless.... Maybe tone down the amount of wormholes a bit.There is no "bounce back" or "come back" in this game. Once you are brought to your knees you might as well quit. You can have better ships than the enemy and you may be able to repell their attacks but they will continue to send those endless waves of superfleets at you with no detrimental economic impact to them or no replenishment time of their fleets. Even if you beat them every time single time you will go bankrupt = game over. Summary:Game is not bad but its just not good either. I feel it is a stepdown from SD1. In its current state it is good to play in the long term if you are a masochist. Otherwise wait till they patch it and purchase only at a reduced price. Like when its 40-50% off.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Patch H has really messed this game up. The AI does not respect Core Space. I've started several games and the narrative is always the same. Opteris colonizes beside me, sends a colony ship to Sol system. If I try to block it, its war and it sends wave after wave of fleets 7 and 8 ships strong.  Even if I manage to build a fleet of ten ships it always has more. If I allow it to build the colony then soon after I get a message telling me that I am in its space and need to vacate.  In which case its war and I have fight wave after wave of superior ships.The AI seems to muster resources quicker that I can ever manage.  In all, these are 15 to 45 minute games with the outcome always the same.  It does not seem to suffer the same penalties for building ships as players do. The only weapon that was somewhat effective, the mass driver, now is useless because of the newly introduced aiming penalty. One of the missions right off the bat is to colonize three systems for which you get 500 bc. However it seems that colonizing three systems really pisses the AI off and so it makes a bee line to my cololnies to take care of business. Doing this takes away valuable resources that could be used to build fighters.  However not  colonizing only postpones the inevitable.It is obvious that there is no fog of war for the AI as it always goes for the weakest colonies and when it knows it has the advantage it swoops in and destroys everything.  I like a challenge, but so far have not been able to find a way to stay alive against an enemy that knows all, builds faster and gets all the tech before me. Yes I've traded for tech. Other players have mentionted how the Ai does not attack with updated ship designs.  I have not found this. For me it is always a case of fighting outgunned and in the end completely outnumbered.I like where the game is going but hope some of the AI related issues get worked out. I feel that backing things off to give players time to figure things out a little more would make the game that much more enjoyable.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Reviev for version with all DLCs.For MOO2 fans:Buy it- You will enjoy it just like MMO2. Sure game has bugs, some of them are serious (like negative creds, ctd) but they happen rarely enough to enjoy the game, others have workarounds.For non-MOO2 fans:This is 4x wargame in space. Even the lowest difficulty level is hard until You know what is important and what isn't.AI is extremally aggresive, especially at higher difficulty setting... and definitely not dumb. Peacefull expansion is nearly impossible (but still doable).If You grow too fast AI will be offended if You grow too slow u will get plundered, bombed, thieved, raided etc by the AI.In short:+Graphics+AI+Space combat+Custom ship designs+Ship/Colony leaders+Diplomacy-Micromanagement (lack of custom construcion queue, no repeat order)-Bugs (I hope they will get fixed soon, some are capable of destroying present game).-Performance in larger battles-Spying (You will get thieved no matter what You do and how hard You work on spying defences)+/- AI Agressivenes (depends what You like).Becouse of the bugs I'm giving game 8 out of 10 points. If they weren't present in game I would give 10/10.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												6.8/10It's like space Total War, but with less features, less UI information, less things to adjust in Options menu. Main map graphic is great but most of the time you will have to zoom out until everything are represented in UI icons, so you can see things going on in your territories clearly.Ship in zoom-out level are shown as a boring arrow icon, and you will spend most of your game time to look at it.Pros- It has all major concepts of space Total War game in the contents, but only for "major" aspect.- Universe in normal-zoom level looks nice- AI try to communicate with player frequently, not lifeless as AI in Endless Legend- nice musicCons- Lack of every small contents that make a game great, UI details, minor features, Options menu. Playing SD2, you will begin to appreciate every small features/UI that other developer put in their game for you- no ship automation, you will have to micromanage a lot - ship icons in zoom-out level looks meh(green arrow icons), why can't I just have the same ship icons as normal-zoom?- no keys rebinding (I want <Spacebar> as empire management shortcut instead of <F2> key)Nonetheless, it's a good game if you don't mind that all development in this game is focus on main features(Space Total War concepts), balancing, and bug fixing.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Stardrive 2 is what Master of Orion 3 should have been. The space combat engine is probably the best ever created, the space battles are spectaculars, and once you know what you are doing with the ship designer, the tactical part is really present. It's a pure jewel. The economy and research system are an improved and modernised copy/paste from Master of Orion 2, so it's very good and also very solid. This part of the game is also quite well balanced for release, that's worth mentionning.However, as all 4x release, it's not perfect, the game has also some flaws due to its youth. The different ship modules are not as well balanced as the economy, some work is still needed here. The ground combat system is not as bad as it could look, but still, it need some work also (espescially the ground combat IA). The diplomacy lack some obvious options, like the 'Alliance' and 'Declare war to' ones. There is also some small bugs here or there (quite rare, no crash), and some optimisation to do for big battles.On the overall, despite its youth's flaws, Stardrive 2 is wonderfull. Since release I have put nearly +70hrs in it, and enjoy it like crazy. It reminds me of the MoO2 birth in the old days : the game had lot of bugs (far more than SD2), and still I couldnt stop playing during nearly a month, it was a so good time.. as it is now with SD2 actually! To end this review, and to be fair with you, readers, I would not say that it is the best space 4x ever created yet, as for me Distant Worlds, which is in real time and quite different on many aspects, has still the title. But trust me, considering all the passion Zero (the lone dev) put in SD2, it's only a matter of time before Stardrive 2 take the title. Six months? One year? I dont know, but for sure, it will happen! ;)Thank for reading.Gut/Gorko/Kruos

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												A giant step back from StarDrive 1 - the development of which was abandoned before I and many others felt it was actually finished.My gripes:The interface has regressed in almost every way - this feels like it was designed for consolesShips now have sections, so if you enjoyed setting up your own firing arcs you'll find that the customization available from the first iteration of the game is goneGround combat is completely uninteresting and feels like a solution in search of a problemThe tutorial isn't great - it suggested I colonize a planet in my home system where I couldn't produce any foodThe 'Battle Arena' scenarios are often an exercise in frustrationNo difficulty adjustment for the Battle ArenaWeapons and Armor/Shields aren't very well balanced yetI'm currently almost 20 hours in, and every time after I quit a session I just feel underwhelmed.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												Before I bought this game, I checked the reviews and was dismayed by the negative reviews. However, the game was on sale and I gave it a chance. I'm glad I did.The game captures a lot of the features of Master Of Orion 2, which I am very fond of. It is intriguing, challenging, surprising, exercising the intellectual glands and has this "one more turn" appeal.Yes, there are 2 bugs that I found so far in 16 hours of play. They haven't spoiled my enjoyment too much yet. They may be in the future, but until then, I see myself clocking several tens of hours in this game.Pros:* Master Of Orion II feel* Selective research. You can't research all technologies, so you need to trade with the opponents.* Ship design is detailed and appealing. One of the best I've seen.* Rich strategic features like colonies management, planetary bonus resources, construction ships.* Turn based tactical troops combat and ships combat.Cons:Nothing.
