content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												I really wanted to recomend this game, and I really hope in not too long a time as the game is polished I will be able too. At the moment it just feals like it could have done with a while longer being tested and the bugs and balances worked out. It's got a really nice narrative, the races and interactions with the AI seem to have had alot of effort put into them which is lovely. The ship system and tech works really well overall other than needing a little balancing and work. Unfortunatly there are many little bugs that make it difficult to play, especially late game ships seem to constantly over shoot their target, anomalys appear that can't be ineracted with, admirals become practically useless as their ships can't be upgraded, multiple occasions have had my own fleets engage themselves (litterally end up fighting a replica fleet), severe lag with massive fleets that the AI will envitably create in a long game. As I said though I hope in afew weeks I will be telling all my friends to give it a go.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												[On the DLC]Here we go a year later and the same problems. Original release originally stabilized a bit to get rid of some of the game breaking bugs, not all or most but some, but along comes a DLC to reintroduce problems that were solved right along side a whole slew of new issues. Diplomacy is still nonexistant, the shipyard still bugs out randomly though you can usually correct them by scrapping and remaking the designs until it decides to validate them properly. Combat is about the same as before, mash your ships into their ships and hope your ships are tougher.  AI is still super aggressive to almost unreasonable lengths, and the nonfaction AI recieved some inflated numbers to add to the fun. Would not recommend, and be warned if you bought the DLC you won't be able to refund it if you had time in the base game as the refund system does not count the DLC as a separate purchase. [On the Original Release]  I really wanted to like this game, I bought the first one and was excited for the sequel but much like the original the sequel was released too soon.  The game is still fairly buggy, which isn't necessarily a deal breaker most of the time but it has a terrible tendency to freeze on loading screens or the GNN videos that pop up occasionally.   The shipyard interface also tends to bug out occasionally and mark your ships as invalid due to not having met criteria that you clearly have i.e. Requiring you to add ammo cannisters to pure energy ships.Outside of the bugs, some of which are game breaking (freezing on load screens) but mostly just annoying (shipyard bugs) you also need to deal with artificially inflated difficulty.  The AI opponents clearly cheat, it doesn't even attempt to hide the fact that they do it, which again is not normally a deal breaker, but the AI is also incredibly aggressive and the diplomacy setup is almost impossible out in front of due to it restricting what deals you can accept using the same mechanics it uses for the AI.   You will frequently find yourself staring down multiple full fleets of enemy units that are generally 2-3 tech tiers up on you before you expand much past your initial system.  If you invest in expanding you're just going to end up losing the expansions to random occurance since pirates and rebels will also randomly pop up with large fleets to take them over. Over all it has potential but it's really more frustrating than it's worth to fight your way past the bugs just to have to try to game the inflated advantages that the AI gets.

Developer didn't finish first game due to engine not being good enough, didn't learn from his mistakes.  The bigger you get in this game, the more bugs get produced.  Screw this garbage.Nice concept, fun game, small house style with out small house cheese pushed on you.   TERRIBLE QA.   I've been robbed, same bugs show up over and over, nothing that was 'missed' on the way out the developer door.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												I recommend the game to any people who enjoy strategy 4x space. That said I share the disapointments among the community.There are bugs, interface bugs are the ones that I have noticed the most. I feel like the game hasnt had enough testing before release. It is still playable at least for me.My biggest complaint about he game:There are tons of different research options and weapons in the game. Most of the time you speed through research before even needing to use the things you have unlocked. I guess what happens is that you move along this research path too fast. By the time you get to fighting you never used those missiles, or that powerplant because now you have way better ones. Almost as if the research to those things served no purpose. It is like you can skip from tier 1 weapons to tier 10 weapons before you actually need to fight anything. Also the pirates and the aliens that attack you are pretty ridiculous... They dont attack the ai as far as I can tell only you. The ground combat is poorly coded from what I can tell. The longer you are on the ground view the more memory gets leaked or whatever it is that is happening. The defensive base cannon does nothing.I mean the list goes on and on. Shady development is what it looks like. Cutting corners here and there to rush something out.Either way it is still a 4X game and it has a lot of cool things about it. The exploration of new systems is good. The ship module builder is great. The combat is eye candy. Lots of great stuff but the overall balance and feel of the game needs work and the bugs need to be sorted out. If it is just one developer then perhaps the developer would consider spending some of the fortune on some help.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												It's like Master of Orion 2, almost verbatim, I was kind of stumped at how the ai was able to send 10 large ships after me with lots of advanced tech on them by the time I was able to colonize my third planet then I read other peoples reviews claiming the ai cheats in typical more "resources per turn than you fashion" and I remembered, oh yea, just like Master of Orion 2. If you liked the first Star Drive game, stick with the first game, this game is more of a Master of Orion 2 update than a sequal to Star Drive. RIP my 20 bucksThere's still lots of bugs and the dev seems to be pumping out patches but there's just lots of strange behavior in the game, an enemy caught me spying and I have -675% diplomatic approval, but I'm always under constant assault by the ai's legion of spys which apparently cost the ai nothing to produce or upkeep despite having huge costs for the player to upkeep. The AI likes to request trades but you don't have good enough relations with the ai to request something in return so obviously you decline, which incurs a penalty. There are lots of descriptions that are filled out for some weapons that seem like they could benefit from someone re-reading them now that the game has been published so they could be clearer, lots of weapons that have slightly different terminology to describe them. My most recent game loaded up and my tooltips weren't displaying all my racial bonuses and I couldn't save ship designs after I spent 10 minutes customizing them so thats fun. Bugs I'm sure will be patched some day. Also, the AI seems to have unlimited fuel range and your ships can barely get to the neighboring system, but when I inspec the enemy ships... they have no extended fuel cells. Also, if you auto resolve combat, you lose about 20 troops even if you went up against 4 guys despite the enemy not being that much better at ground combat, so you have to play through each ground combat which is basically waiting for 3 turns then firing missiles from your mechs you bought on the black market, but if you autoresolve you somehow lose half of your 20 infantry, makes sense. Canopy shields are also totally broken, put one on each big ship until you have about 6 in a fleet, fill up on flak cannons and regular energy cannons and you can just walk away when the enemy sends a megafleet at you. Combat is so laggy during these mega combats that you can't tell whats going on, but if you auto resolve then you lose, if you circle the canopy shield wagons then you win but you have to watch combat for half an hour.The game is fun when things work within reason, but I just spent a day playing through and all the enemy races declared war on me simultaneously after I killed the vulfars which is a race that declares war on you for the sake of declaring war. I managed to kill their bigger fleets which occupy the entire deployment area (which should also bankrupt the ai due to how fleet sizes should work) but then I have to play whack a mole with every other AI's mega fleet while they cherry pick my star systems with a mix of omniscience and unlimited fuel range and poorly designed ships and for every mega fleet I send my entire fleet after I lose 3 planets to bombing or invasion. Buy it if it goes on sale for 5 bucks.

												This is like the old masters of orion before it went to hell.  The game is great or appears to be.  Unfortunately I don't believe it is very well balanced. Then 10 rounds later my titan goes up against their new fleet with three titans.  5 rounds after I captured their main homeworld. I have to spend 150 rounds of my homework to build a titan, they just pop 3 out of their butts, needless to say I can't compete with those odds and loose everything.Even so, and even though I have yet to succeed at surviving the game, it reminds me of my all time favorite game.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												This game is NOT recommended for one reason, and one reason only, but I feel it is a very important one.  The game is the first I have encountered that abandons support for 1024 x 768 and lower resolution.  This may sound trivial, but I believe it may be the start of an ominous trend.  Because of this withdrawal of support gamers using still good gas plasma displays will not be able to play the game.If the game succeeds in getting away with this move it could be the beginning of the end for all players using gas plasma displays.  Other developers will quickly follow suit, and soon GPD users will find that their computer rigs are useless for any and all new games.   This progression will soon follow to higher and higher resolutions, finally leaving players in a frantic and never ending quest to own systems with the highest possible resolution.  What Microsoft has done to operating systems, games like this will do to monitors.  Each new game out will see a new set of resolutions and monitor types rendered obsolete.This movement needs to be squashed before it has a chance to take root.  I urge all prospective buyers to refuse to purchase the game until it extends support to all currently used resolutions.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Amazing game for a One Man Dev team.  Could things be better yes, more victory conditions than combat, better AI for those who might want it.  Less hardcoded stuff for modders to fiddle with.  but the positives IMO-huge amount of different modules to play around with in ship design-nice variety of weapons- Turn based instead of RTS (this is a personal preference obviously ) - Nice variety of positive and negative race modifications to select from- nice forced choices with research (a large costs racial option to get rid of the "choice part")-nice variety of alien species each with their own distinct personality (you can turn that off and make them random)- on the last point each species has unique ships and the size and shape of those ships vary species to species- acceptable diplomacy options would like more options here but serviceable atmmy vote try it out if you get it soon you can get the game for only 21$ way less than any normal 4x game

												a well thought out 4X game. excellent mid-game late game fun. In comparison to Master of Orion re- release this game scores better marks in ALL aspects, from the GUI, to the gameplay emchanics, to endgame challenge, to interesting story elements. content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Well, after one day and nearly 5 hrs on record I feel comfortable giving this game a review. Since others have described their own problems with the game, which generally reflect my own, I want instead to use an analogy. StarDrive 2 is that really hot girl at the bar that everyone tries to hit on, but give up after about 10 minutes. Sure, she's gorgeous, but she's kind of a c*nt, only drinks martinis, and to be frank, she has no soul. See that's the thing, StarDrive 1 was the slightly nerdy girl you found in the back of the library that could kick your♥♥♥♥♥in chess. O.K. maybe her teeth weren't perfectly straight, but she knows who Arthur Schopenhauer is, can have some seriously deep conversations with you over a beer, and speaking of beer; did I mention she crafts her own ale's in the basement of her house? And in bed, she does this thing with her .... anyway I digress. In short, the kind of person you are will determine whether or not I recommend this game to you. Its superficial and as a result, lacks the depth of its predecessor. Some people like beautiful things, some people prefer the profound. As for me, give me StarDrive 1.

content:
Posted: February 20
												Dear Haters of this gameMy experience with this game were awesome, You cant even imagine what kind of things you can do with this if you put your mind to it, Most of you arent actively planning out what your going to do, But when you do, It is entirely awesome when your plan comes together like a giant sandwich, You haters havent put your mind into this game, Thats why you lost, I suggest that you actually put your mind to this game, Maybe you will win, Technology and Logistics are key in this game, You want to know the way into a enemy base before you send a large fleet in, Sure the enemy may have around 50 or several times larger CP, But you might have the technological advantage, You could devestate your enemy from orbit with nukes after your Titans have successfully destroyed a Starfortress, Or you could conquer them on the ground, Trust me, I have lost many more times then i can count, But i kept going, You should too, I know many strategies that work out in many ways, Against a enemy with High Technology and low numbers? Overwhelm them with High Technology and Overwhelming numbers. Against a swarm of enemies with limited tech? Lure them to a distant sector of where you can battle them with support from a Starfortress. Against a enemy with High Technology and Numbers? Outwit them, This game is awesome, If anything, You should be learning how to play this properly, Lazy snakes.BoundCNapalm Lucharias signing out, Goodbye for now.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Where to start.....I'll say this. I re-installed SD1. I played enough to say that although the graphics are a step in the right direction, everything else is not. The artwork is recycled, the UI is clunky and limited, the functionality is limited and almost rectricted. Why can't I hit "E" on my explorer frigates and have them run all over the galaxy???? So I'll break it down like this: I'll base my grades off of two criteria. The first criteria is "was this a step in the right direction from the original SD" The second criteria is based off of other games in this genre, I'll give a letter grade for this. Let's begin:GRAPHICS: SD1<SD2 This was a step in the right direction. Overall grade compared to other 4X Space games: B-ARTWORK: SD1=SD2. The art is recycled. Overall grade compared to other 4X Space games: C-FUNCTIONALITY: SD1>SD2. Definately a step back. Overall grade: D+UI: SD1<SD2. This is almost a push..just needs to be patched. Overall Grade: C+AI: SD1<SD2. So far the other factions haven't banned together to form one giant super federation.(My biggest complaint from SD1) Overall Grade: ATactics: SD1>SD2. The turn based system does not work, unless you're GalCiv or MoO.I'm actually fed up from writing this review....$30 not worth spending. If you don't own it already buy SD1 instead. Wait for this to get patched or scrapped all together.***EDIT***Okay so I'm not going to delete my previous post, but I will say this. There have been at least 5 patches since my review and becasue of that I give this game overall a passing grade. I'll play and support this game just for the fact that the owner/developer wasted no time in getting back to work and polishing up/fixing/updating a lot of issues. Just for the fact alone I'll say buy this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												A tough call to NOT recommend this game. At least until some more patches resolving critical issues on a otherwise very fun and solid game.So after reaching 16 hours into this game I've decided to give some solid feedback. In it's current state, I do not recommend the game. I throughouly enjoyed my 16 hours and I like SD2's particular style of a space 4X game.The ship design system actually means something. When you research shields further along you can then make a new design for researched and unlocked hulls (corvette up to titan) that include that technology. You can also look to retrofit now obsolete ships you've already built at a cost of production and recalling the ships or Fleets back to a planet with the facilities built to do so. It's very practical, has costs to consider at different levels. It gives you full control over what you want to do for your Fleets and tactics for combat. A huge focus on this game.Unfortunately, despite the vast amount of different weapon technologies you can research most aren't effective enough to warrant their research or use. Mass drivers and gauss cannons blow any other weapon type out of the water. I would just mass build cruisers with 6 mass drivers each and I'd destroy anything before they even got into weapons range. This is just the most popular and easy example to give of the overall balance issue in combat. With soooo many different technolgy choices it makes things very complicated. For another example the AI likes to build hundreds of missile frigates and you will literally have hundreds of missiles imbound on your half a dozen ships or so. No level of flak cannons, vulcan cannons or ECMs will save you. So much for the mass drivers. The combat is really circumstantial when it comes to imbalances and you will always have that in a technological race for superiority but it becomes a serious playability issue when the AI cheats and/or doesn't seem to follow a strategy at all when it just builds 50+ missile frigates.The diplomacy system is nice. I like it. It isn't as intricate as another games but it works with SD2. Different racial factors, perks and handicaps will influence your ability to negotiate. Previous interactions of all sorts will build a reputation with each Empire. So, you can literally develop a trust between others over time -- even with aggressive traited species. However, despite the solid diplomacy system it's all for naught when you consider how psyopathic the AI is. The AIs are hyper aggressive. Perhaps that's due to the fact SD2 has a focus on combat and military conquest. SD2 is NOT for you if you're the kind of person that would rather spend most of their 4X play time on the empire management side or would rather win through research and diplomacy. Nope. SD2's focus is combat.I'm forcing myself to uninstall this game until several more patches have come out improving the AI, combat/technology balances and maybe some more features to really solidify a unique, fun game that is SD2. I also must mention the Developer(s) have been giving constant feedback in the forums and has been pumping out patches since the release based on player feedback. That's great. However, I feel this should've been a thing done during a Beta -- I didn't pay to play an incomplete, untested game. I look forward to seeing where this game will be in 3-6 months!TLDR - A fun, solid Space 4X game with a focus on combat whose favorable traits are undone by horrible AI, serious combat imbalances, large battle lag and did I mention the horrible, cheating and psycopathic AI?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												If you liked StarDrive but found that there were flaws in the game, you'll highly enjoy SD2.The combat and ship building system is made much clearer and honestly, this is the game that SD1 should have been - while there are some new things in this game that makes it interesting (new races, ship systems, research system), there does seem similar to the previous game and diplomacy with different races are similiary unfair due to racial traits.That's not to say that there isn't problems with the game - diplomacy is actually pretty weak in that it's mainly trading, and anything the AI does with you takes up part of the guage the system uses to limit broken diplomacy. However, it also does not allow stronger diplomatic actions like asking the AI to help you in wars, or declare war with others, etc.The ground combat UI can also use a lot of work. It uses a rather clunky "click on this weapon to use, click again to cancel" system, and there's a hero that joins on a pretty high chance that will wreck any ground force simply because airdrops deals a lot on a large area.Overall, I say if you're looking at Stardrive, get this instead. If you're looking for a casual space 4x, this is a good choice. There are better ones, but this is one that you can play without worrying too much about winning or losing simply because it'll absorb your attention for quite some time. But I do recommend that you get this on a sale, and not the $30+ price.Edit April 13 2015Having played till the end, I can no longer recommend this game.One of the weakest points of the Stardrive has always been its endgame. Now in Stardrive 2, there's a rather interesting research system that... actually penalizes players for expanding. That means, if you want to make it to late game you must limit your expansion because otherwise the AI will out-research you.So, what does this mean? This means that if you play on a large map, you'll be forced to invade every planet that you let go and that could get boring fast because there still isn't any alternate end conditions.Oh, and if you're wondering how big of difference having a small emprie vs a large one makes? On average, I'm one ship size higher than the AI which focused on expanding and killing neighbours. Which also means that my ships, at minimum, kill 5 of theirs due to advantages from weapon, shields, and other military advantages.

												A tough call to NOT recommend this game. At least until some more patches resolving critical issues on a otherwise very fun and solid game.So after reaching 16 hours into this game I've decided to give some solid feedback. In it's current state, I do not recommend the game. I throughouly enjoyed my 16 hours and I like SD2's particular style of a space 4X game.The ship design system actually means something. When you research shields further along you can then make a new design for researched and unlocked hulls (corvette up to titan) that include that technology. You can also look to retrofit now obsolete ships you've already built at a cost of production and recalling the ships or Fleets back to a planet with the facilities built to do so. It's very practical, has costs to consider at different levels. It gives you full control over what you want to do for your Fleets and tactics for combat. A huge focus on this game.Unfortunately, despite the vast amount of different weapon technologies you can research most aren't effective enough to warrant their research or use. Mass drivers and gauss cannons blow any other weapon type out of the water. I would just mass build cruisers with 6 mass drivers each and I'd destroy anything before they even got into weapons range. This is just the most popular and easy example to give of the overall balance issue in combat. With soooo many different technolgy choices it makes things very complicated. For another example the AI likes to build hundreds of missile frigates and you will literally have hundreds of missiles imbound on your half a dozen ships or so. No level of flak cannons, vulcan cannons or ECMs will save you. So much for the mass drivers. The combat is really circumstantial when it comes to imbalances and you will always have that in a technological race for superiority but it becomes a serious playability issue when the AI cheats and/or doesn't seem to follow a strategy at all when it just builds 50+ missile frigates.The diplomacy system is nice. I like it. It isn't as intricate as another games but it works with SD2. Different racial factors, perks and handicaps will influence your ability to negotiate. Previous interactions of all sorts will build a reputation with each Empire. So, you can literally develop a trust between others over time -- even with aggressive traited species. However, despite the solid diplomacy system it's all for naught when you consider how psyopathic the AI is. The AIs are hyper aggressive. Perhaps that's due to the fact SD2 has a focus on combat and military conquest. SD2 is NOT for you if you're the kind of person that would rather spend most of their 4X play time on the empire management side or would rather win through research and diplomacy. Nope. SD2's focus is combat.I'm forcing myself to uninstall this game until several more patches have come out improving the AI, combat/technology balances and maybe some more features to really solidify a unique, fun game that is SD2. I also must mention the Developer(s) have been giving constant feedback in the forums and has been pumping out patches since the release based on player feedback. That's great. However, I feel this should've been a thing done during a Beta -- I didn't pay to play an incomplete, untested game. I look forward to seeing where this game will be in 3-6 months!TLDR - A fun, solid Space 4X game with a focus on combat whose favorable traits are undone by horrible AI, serious combat imbalances, large battle lag and did I mention the horrible, cheating and psycopathic AI?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												New Edit. 22.06.2016It's worth it now with all the changes they have done. They fixed most of the stuff below, especially the ground combat which was the biggest detriment :)New Edit 22.05.2015Happy that the devs did not listen to the fanboys. The game is now harder, many of the problems below are fixed. This game is still not one of the best 4x game but I would give it a 6/10 in it's current state.Ground Combat is still boring as hell, feels out of place, takes a hell of a long time (and you can't save during the battle) and makes planetary invasion very tedious and boring. I really miss the old Stardrive planet battles, but even more I wish they could have gone for the MOO model instead. Stardrive 2 is basically just planetary bombardment=automatic win without any real consequences (you get some insignificant pollution). Planetary bombardment of your own planets is still just a pop up message.At least now the game offers a challenge, although it is usually a predictable one, the only interesting factor is seeing what tech the enemy have gone for. But usually its just standard configurations.The space battles are great, colonization is cool, empire management is okay. As stated above it is a 6/10 now.Old Review:Edit: Many fanboys are thumb downing my review, they have obviously never played any of the great old 4x games and I wish them well on their journey into the 4x space genre. The developer is working hard to rectify many of the detriments below so I may be changing this into recommended. Want to add like many other of the no fanboy reviews that long range cannons make the game very easy to exploit. Hope to see this change as well like the dev was hinting in the last update.This is the best Strategy Starship customizer and battle simulator to date, sadly though I can't recommend the game as a full 4x product because of it detriments.Here is a summation of the Detriments:Ground Combat:Awkward out of place RPG grid turn based board game that is slow, boring and does not belong in a 4x game ever. The customization of the soldiers is tedious, the limited amount of soldiers is stupid as it makes planetary defence which was a very cool aspect of the original Star Drive impossible. No more massing an armada on nearby planets planning your military invasion in steps in a grand strategy. Now its just 12 ground troops=automatic Win. If you need some inspiration then check out a old glory game called Imperium Galactica or it's prequel Reunion by one Hungarian team, or even better use the MASTER OF ORION II system with two armies basically just slugging it out on a battlefield referencing Empire Strikes Back battle on Hoth. Not a RPG slow grind that take ages for a simple comat which is in truth a wierd minigame within the game.Note: The Diplomacy has been greatly improved in the last update, so this criticism is no longer valid.Diplomacy: Went from exploitable in Stardrive the original into plain stupid in Stardrive 2. In the original stardrive you could get any treaty if you just sprinkled it with enough techs or capital, which made it very easy to get a cease fire even when the Opteris or Rayleh had just destroyed your armada and they stand ready to commit genocide. Now even throwing everything at a normal trade treaty the AI just says "wow you are giving me too much, this would tip the balance of power too much in our favor and we are so for equality and fairness we can't accept this"...Planetary Bombardment:So I guess the developers wanted to go back to Master of Orion II, which would be great. But don't half♥♥♥♥♥it! The Planetery bombardment in MOOII was great visually and strategically with planetary shields, planetary hangars, orbital gun batteries etc. But no, none of the Master of Orion goodness instead it's just a text that appears "Your planet was bombarded *YAWN*". This is just plain boring, especially visually.Races and the lack of Factions:Instead of learning from other great 4x Games such as Distant Worlds where a limited number of races equal an almost endless number of factions, we are now stuck with the same 8 opponents forever, same personality, same lack of diversity and same predictable diplomacy in every game. Please add some randomness to the factions with different personality traits equaling different approaches to expansion, military and diplomatic behavior.Limitation on fleet size:The new system based on command points or whatever is not a bad system, it's just a step in the wrong direction from the first game. There is no rational or logical explenation given for why i.e 7 cruisers wrecks the economy whereas 6 cruisers is just fine, just fine. Why even have this system? Why not let each component have it's maintainance cost with ability to dock your ship at planets for lower maintainance? That would make sense.Poor Camera in battle control:This really bugs me, for a space battle simulator with excellent graphics you can't tilt the camera 360 degrees or even 180 degrees. Why? Even in old games such as IG2 or Homeworld you have this option, granted these games also let you change altitude of your spaceships but compare it to another game with same gameplay as Stardrive 2 which is Empire at War, where is the awesome battle cam? Unit control:In general the unit control is simple and good enough with the ability to give orders like target enemy with broadside or the bow depending on what type or role or guns the ship has, and if it should keep moving in order to avoid missiles, torpedos or artillery shots or stay stationary if it's a artillery gun in space ship design. But there is no attack move function and there is no attack everything or target enemy fighters option for your own fighters which leaves you micromanaging the fighters which is tedious at best and very very frustrating at worst.Lack of Multiplayer:Still no multiplayer for a game that in 2015 when everyone have high speed internet connection connected to steam 24/7 and would be perfect for multiplayer. With all this being said this is still a great game, but I can't recommend it as a full fledged 4x product which it promises to be in the desciption. The humour is great, the space battles are awesome, especially the ship customizer and the general campaign is an okay game the fact that the campaign is more static than the first Stardrive and have horrible ground combat which is such an important aspect of the game leads me to the conclusion that this is not a recommended game.  It does space battles very well even with the bad camera and unit control but it is a step in wrong direction and is not an improvement over the original.

So only positive is allowed so that he can sell more games. He is just after the money and only want to hear good things.I changed my recommendation from yes to no because my first review was first impressions of playing game, but after playing a while and getting late game lots and lots of issues came up which the developer does not want to hear about, he does not like negative feedback and as of now it seems this game is also abandoned just like Stardrive 1 but he speaks about DLCs etc and core game still having issues. I will not support this guy again because he only wants the guys commenting when its good, its like a little gang he has and as soon as you say something negative then his gang on top of you and you get banned from his forums.Do not buy this game, there is way better 4x games out there and by the way a new Master Of Orion is on the way. I cannot wait for this.END EDIT: I was really upset when Stardrive 1 was abandoned and never finished and i sweared i will never buy a game from Dan (Zero) again.....ever!!!!BUT.....I took advantage of my 33% discount and did what i said i would never do again.....I bought the game.....yes, yes, i gave my money to Dan again.and.....WOW, all i can say is WOW, this game is amazing, i am stunned by the graphics, the combat, how ships die, the universe, the story, the design of ships etc etc etc. I am glad i took my 33% discount and bought the game.The only thing i do not like is the way research works, because i would like to research everything....maybe i would get used to it because the game has so much to offer.Now i have not played much but WOW Dan, amazingly done, i am really amazed by your talent and this game is so well done.Please please Dan....do not abandon this game as well.I would definitely recommend this game to 4x gamers and i am stunned. Take it from someone who was very angry at Dan abandoning the first game but i think he made up for this BIG TIME with Stardrive 2.I will play this game more but i think i am going to eat my words and i already love this game. Cannot wait to see what happens the next turn, it keeps on surprizing me.WELL DONE DAN!!! Amazing job. If Stardrive 2 turns out to work and not full of bugs big time then you will see me again buying Stardrive 3, LOL!!!Well done on this game, amazing for one man show. You have surely changed my mind so far with this game. You are really showing other BIG companies making 4x games on how it should be done. I love it.I know i gave you hard time with Stardrive 1 because of bugs and abandoned game but so far you have made it up with this game.Again WELL DONE!!!Edit: After playing some more i am a bit irritated by the AI coming with big fleets when your still trying to build up, its as if the AI is cheating and they attack you so quickly in the game.\Not even mentioning the damn pirates and other creatures attacking you so quickly like 20 turns into the game, i have like 4 small fighters and lose everything, they come to quickly in game.Also the easy setting does not work, AI so strong and kill you so quickly.The setting to make pirates less does not work as well, they just keep coming and coming, lots of them and so often.The map is small as well, even with 100 systems it is still too small, the AI so quickly on you and then just overrun you.I hope this gets patched soon or fixed, and bigger maps would be great.

												Actually a cool game but still filled with room for improvement.Still lots of room for improvement:- The creation of acceptable starting planets really takes the fun out of it regardless of the level of difficulty and the adjustment of planetary richness.- Depending on the adjustment of hostile threats (pirates and other neutral groups) one is likely to get busted very hard very early in the game.- The campaign doesn't seem to be an actual campaign. The map setup is different every time, which was acceptable if the creation of the universe got some improvement, and for some reason you don't have a real agenda to fullfill. There is no genereal campaign-mission but occasionally small events that can be done. Still a nice game that, depending on the very randomly setup of the galaxy and individual adjustments of the galaxy and its inhibitants, has the potential to take you in other worlds and lets you explore the depth of the universe.___Edit___Whatever got changed ♥♥♥♥ed up the gameplay massively.Random Hostile Threads kind of  make you feel like Anne Frank while her hosts' home got raided by SS-Officers on a regular basis and you have to pray to some higher power not to get killed.It became impossible to enjoy the game with these ♥♥♥♥ed up adjustments, plus what I've complained about in the first review has not been fixed yet.If you feel like nothing will make you rage you can play the game, but i strongly doubt that you will enjoy it since there is much of balance missing. If you think about giving this game a shot, don't do it!!!You should wait for the release of STELLARIS ( also available on Steam - check out some gameplay here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=shoiYDp7EEA ). It seems that the developers of this game intend to keep its promise to create a beautiful game and therefore will outstand Stardrive II by far.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												I bought Stardrive 1 shortly after it came out and despite all the bugs and issues, enjoyed itI was hoping Stardrive 2 would be a much better version than Stardrive 1 with improvements, in some respects, it is better, but in a lot of ways, it's no where near as good as Stardrive 1.Unlike SD1, there's no governors, so you have to manage each colony individually, when you have a lot of planets, that's a LOT of clicking to queue items up and move workers around.You can't build troops, like you could in SD1 (I guess there's no such thing as recruitment in this universe), you have to wait for troops to "spawn" and unlike SD1, you can only spawn 2 mechs (which are the equivalent of Tanks in SD1) PER planet.Another annoyance is when you colonise a planet, you confirm colonization, which takes you to the planet view, but then other popups, like battles or other events, popup right after, so you can't start building on the colony until you've dealt with the other items first.The ship customization seems a fair bit more limited, although graphically the UI is better and there's options for overload/extend arc etc, the ships seem? smaller, even the titan classes, which would often take 10 minutes or more in customizing SD1 because they were so big, take a lot less time in SD2, because everything seems to be scaled back.The battles are....ok, graphics and detail are great, but they can sometimes take an age to finish, with no option to speed them up (which wouldn't be advisable right now, due to massive FPS issues)Speaking of FPS issues, I have a powerful machine, but I had 25ish ships and the enemy had about 25, the frame rate was in the single figures, often dropping to 1FPS while the rockets were being fired by my ships, it's awful, such a let down.In SD1 you could customize starbases/ship yards, not so in SD2, so they end up being destroyed quite easily by medium sized fleets.The ground battles are the worst part of the game for me, I did try using Auto resolve, but often found my troops which had superior technology and regen, lost to the weaker forces on most auto resolvesDoing ground battles manually is incredibly tedious, having to click for each shot of a weapon and it just takes an age to finish a ground battle sometimes, especially if both sides have high hit points.The ground battles feel unfinished and rather alpha/beta in quality.A lot of what made SD1 great (albeit, buggy) have been removed or stripped down in SD2, I Can't understand the rationale behind that, surely it's best to work on what was great about the previous game and include and improve apon it for the sequel?Ah well, such a shame.Update - 02/04/2016I decided to change my review to a positive one.The main reasons are a new/renewed interest and bug fixing rampage by Zero, which has been ongoing for a couple of months nowThe game has also been improved quite a bit with the addition of a basic governor system, although it isn't perfect, it takes away a  lot of the tedium of queueing up tons of buildings.

												After further time I have change my review. It's been months since this game had a release. Despite the huge potential , there are still very significant bugs in the game (e.g. If you happen to open any planet's details at the exact moment a ground combat event happens your screwed. Can't acknowledge/proceed with the combat and can't exit the planet details screen... I've lost hours of game time having to go back to an older save game. The game is also severely unbalanced.  One game mechanic is random threats (e.g. Pirates and other more sinister beings) , they may warp into the middle of another enemy's territory but they always make a beeline straight to your planets :( even crossing paths of enemy ships and colonized planets.  I love the ship builder in this game, you get complete customization on weapon and hardware locations - I would love to see this part of the game improved on further. Maybe even adding fighters into the designer. Also needs better player feedback on the design. I've had some ships that looked equal in the designer but on the battlefield one design was supreme and the other plain sucked. Perhaps a test battle arena where the player gets 1 of each ship design currently included in their roster and they can skirmish against a drone pirate ship. The spying aspect of the game is irritating - if I spy on others and get caught my reputation tanks. If they spy on me and I catch them ... there seems there are no repercussions whatsoever.(Possible spoiler) I have managed to beat the masters once, but to my surprise that only qualifies as a "cool , at least we won't have to worry about them anymore. " Meanwhile all the rest of the ai opponents  haven't had to worry or expend any resources fighting the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and are consequently way further ahead on everything (tech, expansion, army size) Planet sizes and which can be populated always feels so few at the start of a game , but again this never seems to affect or slow down the ai players. In summary, really hoping this game gets a major release soon that addresses all theses problems.  Right now I would recommend other games in this genre instead of this one

Posted: December 25, 2015
												Like most people, when this game first came out, it was fun; it had a couple bugs here and there but it was no huge issue. Then the dev. came out with a new dlc and changed the game drastically; but on top of the new play style we had to learn, we had bugs that break the game. When the dev. made the dlc he also switched the game engine, making the current mods for ship models all white and annoying to play with. We begged as a community for him to release the mod tools and stop making game breaking dlcs. But the dev. is self centered and only in it for the money, he made a second dlc that is in my opinion, 100% worthless. This new dlc adds in new ship types, which we all thought would be cool. but then we discovered that it was the same damn ships for every sinngle race. "lets add in ships to a galaxy of fledgeling civilizations and make them all have the same type of ship design." This breaks the game for me as it makes all the races no longer unique with their own ships.If the dev. smartened up and listened to what's left of his community, he might actually make a good game. But currently this game has become terrible, and virtually unplayable.

Posted: April 18
												I'm very conflicted if I should recomend this game or not. The concept of the game is great the design is good and overall it is a fun game. The big problem is you do not get the feeling the game is completed. The space battles gets boring and you feel limited. The ships seem compared to the first one and the modules are limited.On the otherhand you do have freedom in designing your ships works within your empire, Its easy to learn how it works simplefied.In the end I did play 44h and that's something you cant say about most single player games. Even tho I think the first one was better.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												*edited feb 2017*I cannot recommend this game anymore as looks It has been abandoned by Zero. Its shameful, as with some patching could be easily the best 4x out there. Its damn so close....*First: I own Stardrive. But this is about Stardrive 2. This game is very good. Period. As an old 4x gamer I can say this for sure. Haters gonna hate.Now the review:I've tried almost every 4x game published during the time between MOO2 and Stardrive2. I've been waiting for too many years for this. Almost every game I tried had some things attractive and were lacking in other areas. Never found one 4x space game that fullfilled my expectatives. There was always something.I admit, for me the canon is MOO2 and I must say Stardrive 2 is the closest game to it that I found during years. You can notice in everything around the game. The races, the research, the design, freighters... etc etc. One special mention for the ability to move the colonists around. I was showing the game to a friend and he almost cried when he saw it ;)But Stardrive 2 has its own potentialities: RTS Ship Combat, complex ship design, TBS Land combat, the humour, surprises... you have to play it to feel. And of course and not less important a polished and beautiful UI and solid and very good graphics. If you like 4x space genre, you must own this game. Its the best by far in years. When I think that this game its basically the work of one man, as a coder myself I only can think wow! Thanks Zero.

												Thus far a nice moo2 clone and generally fun, it's also including lots of bugs, unfortunately.The bugs are frustrating and are leading to lots of unfinished rounds. Even if the bugs are known for months or years, no changes thus far.Game just crashes sometimes, or from on round to another, you are unable to build on your planets, any planet.Restarting and loading the unfinished game doesn't help. And there are a lot of other minor bugs.
